DOC.HEAD: Mayor Faces Recall _ Anti-Drinking Effort an Issue
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 8th graf, `Recall organizers ...,' to ADD further comment from Ms. Tiley; minor editing throughout to tighten.
DOC.TEXT: Residents voted Monday to keep Gallup's feisty mayor, who once threatened to erect billboards proclaiming his city the nation's drunken-driving capital, in office for the remaining 11 months of his term. The vote to recall Mayor Ed Munoz was 1,995 to 2,135. Opponents needed 2,246 ballots to oust the 62-year-old Democrat. ``This tells me that the people of Gallup want me to continue to address the city's alcohol problem,'' said the longtime mayor of this city on the edge of a huge Indian reservation. The 50 percent voter turnout was about 15 percent higher than expected, said City Clerk Rosa-Lena Chavez. Gallup has 7,218 registered voters. Munoz said he was not upset that 1,995 voters wanted him out of office. ``It tells me that people associated with the liquor industry carry a lot of clout and that other people want to continue to live in denial,'' he said. ``People that have drinking problems want to continue drinking and continue to live in denial.'' Munoz contends the liquor industry was behind the effort to drive him from office because of his campaigns against alcohol problems in Gallup. Recall organizer Linda Tiley said she hoped the vote sends a message to Munoz. ``I hope he sees by the number of votes against him that there are a lot of people who disagree with his views,'' Ms. Tiley said. ``I don't feel that the recall was a total failure just because we didn't win,'' she said. ``Maybe now, people will start to pay more attention to city government.'' Recall organizers had said they were fed up with Munoz' confrontational style, and accused him of using his position to help friends. They noted that he has three times offered to step outside to settle differences during City Council meetings. ``If I had been charged with malfeasance or something like that, then I wouldn't feel good,'' Munoz said earlier. ``But I feel good about this.'' Ms. Tiley said the mayor's proposal in February for billboards depicting a car on a road paved with skulls was just the last straw. The billboards, 20 miles west of Gallup on the Arizona state line, would have told visitors that lifelong New Mexico residents have an 86 percent chance of being involved in an alcohol-related traffic accident. ``The rest of the country now thinks this is nothing but a town of drunks,'' said Ms. Tiley, a skin-care consultant and part-time waitress and bartender. Munoz retracted the billboard proposal, saying it was intended to get the attention of state legislators after they failed to act on liquor-law reforms the mayor supported. He has proposed closing all drive-up liquor windows and halting sales before 11 a.m., and persuaded voters to impose a liquor tax to pay for alcohol treatment. Munoz was mayor from 1958 through 1969 and is in the middle of his second consecutive two-year term. He is challenging state Rep. Dominic Ferrari in the June Democratic primary election, and has said he won't seek another term as mayor no matter what happened Monday. Ms. Tiley rejected the mayor's accusation that the recall was backed by the liquor industry. She said the campaign, organized with the help of a mail carrier and three of her co-workers at the Powder Puff beauty salon, hasn't taken any money from alcohol-related businesses. ``Alcohol has nothing to do with it at all,'' Ms. Tiley said. ``It's his tactics. We don't like the way he runs things.'' Examples, she said, included Munoz interceding on behalf on an acquaintance in a zoning matter and three times offering to step outside a council meeting to settle a dispute. The mayor doesn't deny challenging people to fights. ``When they make personal slanders against me, I'll threaten them,'' he said. Of allegations he helped his friends, Munoz said: ``I'm responsive to people in the community, as a mayor should be. When someone needs help, I try to help them.'' Ms. Tiley contends that Gallup's liquor problems are no worse than any other city's, but says Munoz, by drawing attention to drinking, has hurt tourism. Gallup, population 24,600, is on the edge of the West Virginia-size Navajo reservation, which sprawls across three states and is home to 165,000 people. Alcohol is banned on the reservation, so Navajos who wish to drink legally must go to nearby cities like Gallup. The National Institute on Alcoholism and Alcohol Abuse found in a one-time study that the Gallup area's rate of alcohol-related deaths per 100,000 people was nearly six times the U.S. average from 1975 to 1979. In 1987, the National Safety Council reported that New Mexico was the nation's per capita leader in traffic deaths, and that year McKinley County, which includes Gallup, was worst among New Mexico counties for severe alcohol-related crashes. In 1988, city police threw 26,222 people in ``drunk tanks'' to sober up, many of them multiple offenders.

DOC.HEAD: Winemaker Cuts Himself on Bottle, Bleeds to Death
DOC.TEXT: A man who stocked his home with more than 6,000 pints of homemade wine accidentally cut himself on a bottle and bled to death, authorities say. Junius Huggins, 67, cut a four-inch gash across his left wrist and severed an artery as he apparently tried to tighten or remove the top of one of the wine bottles April 10, said county coroner Jimmy Gregg. He left a trail of blood to his neighbor's home, where he sought help, and died behind the house, Gregg said. Police confiscated 6,100 pints of wine in bottles, kegs and jugs. ``We have no proof he had intentions of selling it. For all I know it could have been a hobby of his making wine,'' sheriff's Capt. Wayne Jeffords said Monday. The shed at his home where the wine was stored was covered with spray-painted biblical verses, and biblical quotations were displayed around the property, but Jeffords said he didn't know who put them there.

DOC.HEAD: Sponsor of SAT Asks Court for Exemption From Truth-in-Testing
DOC.TEXT: The sponsor of the SAT is asking a federal court to exempt the test from a state law requiring disclosure of questions and answers. The College Board said Monday that the exemption, if granted, would allow it to administer the Scholastic Aptitude Test more often in New York state by holding down the cost of complying with the decade-old truth-in-testing law. The law requires testmakers to make public test questions, answers and related research reports. Such disclosures enable students to check their answers or challenge questions they believe are flawed or biased. New York and California are the only two states with truth-in-testing laws. But since New York's law was passed, test makers have voluntarily extended its provisions to test-takers in all 50 states. The board's request for an injunction was filed Monday in Syracuse. Joining with the board was the Educational Testing Service, of Princeton, N.J., which administers the Scholastic Aptitude Test and numerous other standardized tests. If the injunction is granted, disclosures of test questions and answers will no longer be mandatory. But board spokesman Fred Moreno said the testmaker would continue to voluntarily disclose tests administered on the four existing New York test dates. The board would then add two new opportunities in December and January each year for New Yorkers to take the SAT. There would also be additional dates for New Yorkers to take the Graduate Record Examination and the Test of English as a Foreign Language. But tests taken on new dates would not be disclosed afterwards. In effect, the College Board said, that would mean New Yorkers would have the same number of opportunities to take the tests as students in most other states. The board reduced the number of test dates in New York shortly after truth-in-testing was enacted, claiming that it had to do so in order to keep the cost of the exam down. Blair Horner, a spokesman for the New York Public Interest Research Group, which successfully lobbied for truth-in-testing, said the College Board-ETS suit ``reveals their true character _ to gouge students in order to maximize their profits.'' But test publishers insisted they were not trying to subvert truth-in-testing. ``We do not want to turn the clock back on test disclosure,'' said Greg Anrig, president of ETS in a telephone interview. He added that he had gone on record on numerous occasions in support of truth-in-testing. Consumer advocate Ralph Nader called the lawsuit ``a big mistake. This lawsuit will make the standardized testing industry fraud a nationally visible issue for public discussion.'' Cinthia Schuman, executive director of FairTest, a Cambridge, Mass., group critical of standardized tests, called the action by the College Board and ETS ``hypocrisy.'' ``Why should your right to disclosure of a test depend on the date that you take it?'' she said. The SAT is taken by about 1.6 million college-bound high school students each year, and approximately 200,000 New York students. The way was paved for Monday's action when a federal court in January ruled that disclosure provisions of New York's truth-in-testing law conflicted with federal copyright law. That case involved the MCAT, a medical school entrance exam.

DOC.HEAD: `Ninja Turtles' Banks Another $14.1 Million
DOC.TEXT: ``Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles'' was No. 1 at the box office for the third straight week, becoming the highest-grossing independent film in U.S. history. ``Ninja Turtles,'' released by New Line Cinema, took in $73 million in its first three weeks, including $14.11 million last week, according to figures Monday from Exhibitor Relations Co. Disney's ``Pretty Woman,'' a Pygmalion tale starring Richard Gere as a powerful businessman and Julia Roberts as a streetwalker, was second with $10.1 million. ``Ninja Turtles'' overtook Vestron's 1987 ``Dirty Dancing,'' which held the record for biggest North American box-office take by an independently produced movie at $63 million. Otherwise, box-office business over the weekend was just fair. ``The Easter egg hunts cut into the kids a little bit,'' said John Krier of Exhibitor Relations. In third place was the Tom Clancy techno-thriller ``The Hunt for Red October,'' with ticket sales of $4.26 million. ``Ernest Goes to Jail,'' the latest installment in the adventures of an obnoxious bumpkin, was fourth with $4.25 million. Here are the top movie ticket sales for Friday through Sunday as tallied by Exhibitor Relations, with distributor, weekend gross, number of theater screens, average per screen, total gross and number of weeks in release. Figures are based on a combination of actual box-office receipts and studio projections where actual figures are not immediately available. 1. ``Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles,'' New Line, $14.1 million, 2,377 screens, $5,917 per screen, $72.9 million, three weeks. 2. ``Pretty Woman,'' Disney, $10.1 million, 1,707 screens, $5,927 per screen, $59.3 million, four weeks. 3. ``The Hunt for Red October,'' Paramount, $4.26 million, 1,702 screens, $2,503 per screen, $89.8 million, seven weeks. 4. ``Ernest Goes to Jail,'' Disney, $4.25 million, 1,956 screens, $2,172 per screen, $12.6 million, two weeks. 5. ``The First Power,'' Orion, $3.8 million, 1,336 screens, $2,858 per screen, $11.7 million, two weeks. 6. ``Crazy People,'' Paramount, $3.4 million, 1,389 screens, $2,417 per screen, $4.2 million, one week. 7. ``I Love You to Death,'' Tri-Star, $2.7 million, 1,095 screens, $2,425 per screen, $8 million, two week. 8. ``Driving Miss Daisy,'' Warner Bros., $2.2 million, 1,387 screens, $1,617 per screen, $90.4 million, 18 weeks. 9. ``Cry Baby,'' Universal, $1.6 million, 1,236 screens, $1,255 per screen, $5.5 million, two weeks. 10. ``The Gods Must Be Crazy II,'' Weintraub, $1.2 million, 321 screens, $3,676 per screen, $1.2 million, one week.

DOC.HEAD: First Black President Of School's Law Review Uninterested In A Cushy Job
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: His boyhood friends in Indonesia were street peddlers, and his grandmother still lives in a mud-walled house in Kenya. But Barack Obama is another world away, presiding over the Harvard Law Review as the first black president in the prestigious journal's 103-year history. The charismatic 28-year-old, ensconced in the halls where tradition reigns, is taking aim at another custom: Obama's sights are set on the South Side of Chicago, not on a U.S. Supreme Court clerkship or a fast-track career with a cushy firm. ``I'm not interested in the suburbs. The suburbs bore me. And I'm not interested in isolating myself,'' Obama said in a recent interview. ``I feel good when I'm engaged in what I think are the core issues of the society, and those core issues to me are what's happening to poor folks in this society.'' His passion is rooted in his background. He was born in Hawaii, his father an Oxford- and Harvard-educated economist from the African nation of Kenya, his mother a white anthropologist from Kansas. Obama moved to Southeast Asia at age 2 when his parents divorced and his mother married an Indonesian. Until the fifth grade, Obama attended Indonesian schools, where most of his friends were the sons of servants, street peddlers and farmers. Concern for Obama's education led his mother to return him to Hawaii, where he attended public schools through high school. In 1983, he graduated from Columbia University with a degree in political science. At a recent meeting in a Harvard cafeteria, his affinity with the underdog was readily apparent. ``I lived in a country where I saw extreme poverty at a very early age,'' Obama said. ``Parts of my family in Kenya remain very poor. My grandmother still lives in a mud-walled house with no running water or electricity. ``That's who I am, that's where I come from, not always literally, but at least emotionally.'' Obama entered Harvard Law School in 1988, and through a combination of grades and a writing competition, was elected to head the law review this February. He succeeded Peter Yu, a first-generation Chinese-American. Obama cautions against reading too much into his election. ``It's crucial that people don't see my election as somehow a symbol of progress in the broader sense, that we don't sort of point to a Barack Obama any more than you point to a Bill Cosby or a Michael Jordan and say `Well, things are hunky dory,''' Obama said. ``There's certainly racism here. There are certain burdens that are placed, more emotionally at this point than concretely,'' Obama said. ``Professors may treat black students differently, sometimes by being, sort of, more dismissive, sometimes by being more, sort of, careful because they think, you know, they think that somehow we can't cope in the classroom,'' he said. Obama sees the inner cities as the front lines of racism. ``It's critical at this stage for people who want to see genuine change to focus locally. And it is crucial that we figure out how to rebuild the core of leadership and institutions in these communities,'' he said. For five years before law school, Obama took on that task in Chicago. As the director of a program that tried to bring South Side churches, unions and block associations together on projects, Obama was not trying to solve local problems, he said. Instead he sought to construct something more lasting _ a forum for the community to speak with one voice. ``I'm interested in organizations, not movements, because movements dissipate and organizations don't,'' Obama said. America suffered when the movements of the 1960s dissipated, Obama said. Those movements succeeded in raising doubts about harmful traditions of sexism and racism, but failed to offer a viable alternative. ``Hopefully, more and more people will begin to feel their story is somehow part of this larger story of how we're going to reshape America in a way that is less mean-spirited and more generous,'' Obama said. ``I mean, I really hope to be part of a transformation of this country.'' And the future of black people and of America generally? ``It depends on how good I do my job,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Asian Elephant Birth Important Event For Zoo, Species Survival
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The amorous escapades of a 10,000-pound Asian elephant named Indy have captured the attention of the zoo world. The 18-year-old pachyderm has impregnated two females at the Burnet Park Zoo. Babe is expected to deliver her baby around the last week of April and Romani is due in July 1991. That's earth-shaking news for the continent's zoos, where just 62 calves have ever been born in captivity. It's also a sign of promise for the 35,000 to 45,000 Asian elephants that remain in the wild as an endangered species. ``North American zoos are getting serious about reproducing elephants. The two pregnancies at Syracuse is evidence we are making progress,'' said Tom Foose, conservation director for the American Association of Zoological Parks and Aquariums. To highlight the importance of the twin pregnancies, Jacksonville Zoological Park Director Dale Tuttle said there are only six other zoos with pregnant Asian elephants. An elephant's pregnancy lasts 22 months. Only 14 of the AAZPA's approximately 150-member zoos have the facilities to breed Asian elephants, said Tuttle, coordinator of the AAZPA's Species Survival Plan for Asian elephants. ``There are only 11 proven male breeders in captivity and just 12 females that have reproduced,'' said Foose. ``What's going on in Syracuse is very impressive _ and very significant.'' ``The survival of the species is dependent, in part, upon the establishment and maintenance of viable breeding of captive populations in North America. And that's where we come in,'' said Burnet Park Zoo Director Dave Raboy. Like the decision to have a child, starting an elephant family is not a commitment entered into lightly. The zoo decided in 1979 that it wanted to breed elephants, said curator Don Moore. It began by transforming the 350-square-foot indoor pen that housed its one elephant, Siri, into a spacious 3,200-square-foot indoor-outdoor living area with a breeding barn. Romani was purchased in 1984 from a circus, which bought her from an elephant orphanage in Sri Lanka. Indy, also an ex-circus performer from Thailand, and Babe, a one-time gift to the U.S. ambassador to Pakistan, came to Burnet Park in June 1985. With dual pregnancies and a virile male to make it worthwhile, Burnet Park this year is spending $500,000 to thrust itself fully into elephant breeding. The money will be used to further enlarge and modify the zoo's elephant habitat. A single elephant can cost more than $50,000 and a suitable habitat, hundreds of thousands more. ``There's no secret,'' said Roger Henneous, the senior elephant keeper at the Washington Park Zoo in Portland, Ore., the nation's premier Asian elephant breeder. ``In order to have babies you have to accommodate adult males. You're talking a tremendous financial, physical commitment to accommodate a mature male. Most places can't or won't. It's that simple.'' Washington Park Zoo, which has had 24 births in the past 28 years, has accommodations for three males among its 12-animal herd. Chuck Doyle, the senior elephant handler at Burnet Park, says there are other important factors in elephant breeding, one of which is luck. ``Copulation is a learned behavior among elephants. A female has to see another couple mating, otherwise she won't allow the male to breed her,'' said Doyle, who broke some ribs in attempts to get Babe matched up with a mate. ``For three years, we watched Indy push the females around without success. Finally, he pushed Babe the right way. Romani needed less time because she witnessed Indy and Babe.'' Babe's calf, which will likely weigh about 200 pounds, will be the first one born at Burnet Park. So it's understandable the zoo _ like a first-time parent _ has been excited about the pregnancy. ``I feel like I felt having our first child,'' said Moore. It's also a first for Babe, who at 36 may be the oldest first-time Asian elephant mother in captivity. Trainers worry she may not know what to do when she delivers. Babe has gained more than 1,150 pounds since she became pregnant in June 1988. She tipped 7,450 when she was weighed by state police on a truck scale Jan. 24. ``She's a very, very nervous animal, and she's not real thrilled about people,'' Doyle said at one point, although he said she has become more sociable during her pregnancy. Romani and Siri, who has resisted Indy's advances, will be allowed to watch the birth, zoo officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: A good song is hard to find is the new tune being sung by Randy Travis. ``It's more competitive,'' the country music star said in a recent interview. ``They're out there, but you really have to search for them.'' Travis, whose current hit is ``Hard Rock Bottom of Your Heart,'' said that when he began recording five years ago, George Jones, Merle Haggard and George Strait were his only rivals for traditional country songs. ``Now you've got all those and you got Ricky Van Shelton and Patty Loveless and The Judds doing some kinds of that music ... just all kinds of people,'' he said.

A painting by Frank Sinatra sold for $17,000 at a celebrity art auction to benefit a treatment center founded by the singer's wife for sexually abused children. The abstract floral painting was bought Saturday by Bob Rossi, an executive with Toys R Us, said Susan Reynolds, a spokeswoman for Sinatra. More than $140,000 was raised for the Barbara Sinatra Children's Center at Eisenhower Medical Center. Mrs. Sinatra founded the children's center four years ago. Celebrities attending the event at the Ritz Carlton hotel included the Sinatras, Gregory Peck, Roger Moore, Don Rickles and Betty Ford.

Donald and Ivana Trump patched things up long enough to greet guests at a fund-raiser for AIDS victims. The Trumps later held hands as they ascended the stairway from The Plaza hotel's grand ballroom to a suite where they shared an Easter Sunday lunch with their children and in-laws, said a hotel employee, speaking on condition of anonymity. The appearance came amid an escalating legal battle over the Trumps' split, which has been the subject of front-page stories in New York tabloids since February. Mrs. Trump filed a lawsuit last month challenging Trump's claim that she waived her right to half his fortune _ estimated at as much as $5 billion _ in a series of postnuptial agreements, the last signed in 1987. Trump's attorneys said the agreement, which gives Mrs. Trump $10 million and their $12 million mansion in Greenwich, Conn., is ironclad.

Students at Wellesley College are protesting the selection of Barbara Bush as their commencement speaker, saying the first lady hasn't earned the honor on her own. ``To honor Barbara Bush as a commencement speaker is to honor a woman who has gained recognition through the achievements of her husband, which contradicts what we have been taught over our years at Wellesley,'' said a petition signed by 150 students and presented to college President Nanerl Keohane. Anna Perez, a spokeswoman for Mrs. Bush in Washington, said Sunday the first lady had no comment on the petition. Mrs. Bush accepted an invitation to speak at commencement June 1 at the 2,200-student women's college. Laura Stavis, a Wellesley spokeswoman, defended the invitation. Mrs. Bush is ``involved in crucial issues, literacy, volunteer programs for the needy and the homeless. I feel she speaks with her own voice,'' Stavis said.

DOC.HEAD: French Knack For Freeing Hostages Raises Questions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: France has had 11 citizens held hostage in the Middle East, and it has managed to free them all. Commentators are asking whether it is a Gallic flair for diplomacy or cynical deals with terrorists and their sponsors that account for France's success. Is there, as one commentator here asked, a special French method that can ``maneuver around the obstacle that others run into?'' France makes an important distinction, said Bassma Kodmoni-Darwish, an expert on French-Middle East relations: ``It doesn't bargain with terrorist groups. It negotiates with states.'' Each time hostages come home, top government officials find themselves denying that France panders to terrorists. ``And it's true. It cannot be criticized'' on that count, said Ms. Darwish, who works for the French Institute for International Relations. ``But it is also a hypocritical nation.'' France came under fire from many prominent Western newspapers for lauding Col. Moammar Gadhafi of Libya for his role in securing the release Tuesday of Frenchwoman Jacqueline Valente, her Belgian companion and their child. The three were held for more than two years by the Libyan-controlled Fatah-Revolutionary Council, headed by terrorist Abu Nidal. Detractors draw little distinction between Abu Nidal's group and Gadhafi. France did. Foreign Minister Roland Dumas, who praised Gadhafi's ``noble and humanitarian gesture'' in seeking the trio's freedom and promised improved relations, said France did not talk with the abductors. He denied that France traded three jetfighters _ returned to Libya several weeks ago _ for the hostages. France negotiated the freedom of 10 of its 11 hostages in 1986-88, when conservative Premier Jacques Chirac was in power. Eighteen hostages of other nationalities remain in captivity in Lebanon, including eight Americans. The longest-held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, who was kidnapped March 16, 1985. The U.S. government has publicly refused to negotiate for the release of its hostages. But three Americans were freed in 1985-86 while U.S. arms were secretly delivered to Iran, which backs groups holding hostages in Lebanon. Reports of the deliveries led to the disclosure that some of profits were funneled to the Contra rebels fighting the leftist Sandinistas in Nicaragua. French thank-yous that followed the release of its hostages were never so effusive as those proffered to Gadhafi. But France has also made concessions to Iran for earlier releases. All but one item on Iran's shopping list was met by the French, who expelled top Iranian dissident Massoud Rajavi, normalized relations with Iran and repaid part of a billion dollar debt dating to the days of the Shah. The only outstanding demand is freeing Anis Naccache, serving a life sentence in France for the attempted 1980 assassination of the exiled former Iranian Premier Shahpour Bakhtiar. Gadhafi called for freedom for Middle Eastern ``political prisoners'' in Europe, and it remains to be seen whether Naccache will go free. ``The true French art is hypocrisy,'' columnist Richard Cohen wrote this week in The Washington Post. ``The French prattle on like a womanizer, saying whatever seems effective at the moment. At this particular moment ... Gadhafi seems in line for the Legion of Honor: He freed three hostages.'' Hypocrisy was a word often used abroad each time France obtained the release of hostages. But the French view themselves differently. ``There is here a certain resigned tolerance for half-truths or half-lies for reasons of state, perhaps more so than elsewhere,'' the leftist daily Liberation said in an editorial. ``La raison d'etat'' is a famous phrase in France, used by governments as an excuse to remain silent. The 1985 sinking of the Greenpeace flagship, the Rainbow Warrior, in New Zealand, in which one person was killed, proved one of France's biggest debacles in decades. International pressure eventually overcame ``reasons of state,'' and the truth came out. But polls at the time revealed a public far more outraged by the bungling of French spies than by their murderous task. France has shown concerned nations it was prepared to negotiate to release hostages, said Ms. Darwish, but she added that each time French hostages have been freed the political context was favorable. Public pressure was a determining factor in freeing French hostages held by Iranian-backed groups, Ms. Darwish said. The last three hostages held by Iranian-backed groups were released May 4, 1988, days before the presidential election. The gambit did not work for Chirac, who lost to the incumbent Francois Mitterrand. Chirac's government denied charges it made payments or promised to free Naccache, as Iran claimed. The current Socialist government says it can find no written record of any deals. In the latest release of hostages, the return of the three Mirages held in France under an embargo was but a signal for change in French-Libyan relations, she said. A more moderate stance by Gadhafi over the past six months, including his willingness to renew ties with Egypt, ripened the political climate. ``It is that evolution which is more important than the hostages,'' she said. ``It's not just a deal. Libya has evolved.'' ``We did not exchange three hostages for three Mirages, but for two epithets,'' said one French official, referring to the words ``noble'' and ``humanitarian'' used to describe Gadhafi. In any event, it ``had to be done,'' said a Foreign Ministry spokesman. ``It is the custom.''

DOC.HEAD: Lebanese Hang On After 15 Years Of War, But Peace Seems Distant
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: After 15 years of fratricidal carnage, living in Beirut has been reduced to survival. Real life, as other people know it, is on hold. ``Peace has become more important than life, electricity more important than the future and butane gas more important than completing the school year,'' says Talal Salman, owner of the leftist daily As-Safir. The Lebanese, whose disparate factions are sponsored by such as Iran, Israel, Libya, Syria and Iraq, appear to have an insatiable appetite for killing each other. No one knows for sure how many people have been killed or maimed since the sectarian civil war began on April 13, 1975. Estimates of the number killed range up to 150,000. Doctors at the American University Hospital say a total of 200,000 killed or wounded probably is close. In the latest war-within-a-war, Christians are fighting Christians. Rebel Gen. Michel Aoun's soldiers and Samir Geagea's militiamen are battling for control of the 310-square-mile Christian enclave north and east of Beirut, where two-thirds of the 1.5 million Lebanese Christians live. Even the remarkable resilience of the Lebanese has been tested to its limits by the long war, factional feuding, two Israeli invasions and countless air strikes. For most of the last year, Beirut has had little or no water and electricity. Civilian life has been conducted largely underground, in basements and subterranean parking lots used as shelters from artillery fire. ``What future is there any more?'' asked Antoine Mousa, a Christian civilian. ``One works only to make enough money to cover the expenses of repairing damage.'' Fadi Koukou, who at 14 is one year younger than the war, has had only three months of schooling since March 1989. Most of his time has been spent in shelters. ``I don't think I'll be able to concentrate on my studies if classes resume,'' he said. ``I haven't held a book for a long, long time.'' Koukou, who lives in the devastated Ashrafiyeh district of Christian east Beirut, said he envied youngsters in Europe and the United States because ``at least they don't have to spend hours filling canisters with water and lug them up five flights of stairs because the elevator's out.'' Flashes remain of prewar Lebanon, when Beirut bustled with vitality and a Phoenician gaudiness that made it the last of the great Levantine cities, the playground of the Middle East. Lady Cochrane, who was Yvonne Sursock when she married an Irish baronet, still holds elegant dinner parties in her colonnaded home in east Beirut, as she did when she was the queen of Beirut society before the war. It is her way of showing contempt for the danger and insanity around her. Even so, Lady Cochrane, whose Greek Orthodox family has produced generations of Lebanese notables, has stored her art works for safekeeping. A Briton invited for dinner a few weeks ago, while an artillery duel raged, said she ``sat at the head of the table as family retainers brought in the family plate. She brushed aside all talk of alarm or conflict. She had house guests ... and they were going to have an enjoyable visit.'' Regular water and power supplies to Beirut were cut off when the Dbaye pumping station and the Zouk generating station, both in the Christian enclave north the city, were hit in the early days of war between Aoun and Geagea. ``Even if the fighting stopped today, it would take at least a month to make enough repairs to the power plants to supply the city with three hours of electricity a day,'' a municipal official said. The Syrians, who have 40,000 soldiers in Lebanon, provide 80 tank trucks to carry water from the south. The bloodletting between Aoun and Geagea is seen by many as the ultimate madness in a country thought to have seen it all. Nearly 900 people have been killed and 2,500 wounded since Jan. 30, most of them civilians. Brother is pitted against brother. Sometimes, Aoun's soldiers refuse to fire at other Christians or on streets where relatives live. A Christian security source said an Aoun artillery battery was ordered to fire 60 howitzer shells around Geagea's headquarters near Beirut harbor. ``They did as they were ordered, but they defused nearly all the shells before they fired them,'' he said. ``Only eight exploded. Most of the rest landed in the sea. They simply found it unbearable to fire on fellow Christians.'' A Christian woman expressed the civilian viewpoint: ``We've taken everything they've thrown at us for the last 15 years, but we never thought we'd have Christian fighting Christian like this. It's insane. We're killing ourselves. It has to stop.'' But it never does.

DOC.HEAD: Revolutionary Euphoria Has Faded in Czechoslovakia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The euphoria surrounding Vaclav Havel's fairy-tale journey from prison to the presidency is gone and Czechoslovaks are back in the real world, arguing about the economy, politics and the country's name. In January and February, intellectuals still exulted over the end of censorship. The playwright president in Prague Castle and his entourage of former dissidents and underground artists introduced a new morality to politics at home and abroad. They were praised from Washington to Moscow. Then domestic worries began to take over. Czechs and Slovaks, whose winter revolution was so smooth, split on the question of whether ``socialist'' should be removed from their republic's formal name. The matter still is not resolved. Government economists, facing a deadline in late April for an agreement on drastic reforms, fell out over how quickly to adopt a free market. Political rivals of the movements that led the revolution began campaigning for the June 8 elections, the first free vote in four decades. Havel, recovering from a hernia operation, acknowledged in a national radio address April 1 that ``the time of elation and happiness, stemming from the fact that everyone can say what they want, has come to an end. ``The time has come when we will really have to do something with the freedom,'' he declared. Transition from communism to democracy in Czechoslovakia and elsewhere in Eastern Europe as been sudden and makeshift, marked by ethnic problems, sharp decreases in worker output and a political shift to the right. Czechoslovakia is better off than most. Disputes between Czechs and Slovaks have not become violent, as ethnic strife has in Romania. The economy, while lagging behind countries Czechoslovakia outstripped 50 years ago, is not burdened by heavy debt but hundreds of potential Western investors flocking to Prague still await laws liberalizing capital movement. Unlike Hungary, Czechoslovakia has not even begun establishing such fundamental elements of capitalism as new banks and a stock market. A senior economist with close ties to the government said reform is hindered by a split between Finance Minister Vaclav Klaus, who wants to go all-out for capitalism, and others, including Havel, who fear the social consequences. Havel's Civic Forum and its Slovak partner Public Against Violence lead opinion polls for the elections, with about 20 percent. The Communists, who still claim 1 million party members in a nation of 15.5 million, are second at about 11 percent. Conservative Christian Democrats won free elections in East Germany and Hungary, however, and a similar coalition in Czechoslovakia can count on strong support in heavily Roman Catholic Slovakia. The visit of Pope John Paul II on April 21-22 also could provide a boost. The strong Communist showing has shaken Civic Forum into a vigorous campaign against the Communist Party's right to keep buildings and other assets seized during 41 years in power. Tens of thousands of people massed in Wenceslas Square this week, for the first time since December, to support Civic Forum demands that the party return the property. Otherwise, the ability to draw a crowd seems to be gone. Only 28 people showed up when Mayor Jaroslav Koran of Prague, appointed by Havel, called for volunteers to clean up the city April 7. Most Czechoslovaks still are affected by old habits. In the past, the Communists threatened those who did not take part in their parades and other rituals with loss of jobs or other misfortunes. Four decades of that created a lack of civic awareness yet to be overcome. Old habits also remain with former dissidents. Kveta Dienstbier, whose husband, Jiri, now is foreign minister, was alarmed one February night by two mysterious men outside their home. Dienstbier arrived, driving his official Mercedes. The two men got out of their car. Scarred by years of surveillance and sudden arrest, Mrs. Dienstbier screamed to her husband. The men were ministry drivers, waiting to collect the Mercedes.

DOC.HEAD: South Carolina Psyche Battered by Hurricane Hugo
DOC.TEXT: The physical wounds left by Hurricane Hugo are slowly healing, but domestic strife and other signs of stress are on the rise among South Carolina survivors of the killer storm. Counselors and psychologists say some of the deepest emotional wounds are only now emerging and may plague survivors for years in areas of the state hardest hit by the Sept. 21 hurricane. Hugo claimed 29 lives and caused $5.9 billion damage in South Carolina. Police, court and mental health officials also found a toll on the psyche: _ During the first three months of 1990, 70 rapes were reported in the Charleston area, an increase of 112 percent from a year ago. _ The number of domestic abuse and divorce cases filed in Charleston County is up 17 percent so far this year, an unusually large increase, court officials say. _ An estimated 20,000 South Carolinians suffering post-traumatic stress syndrome are expected to develop long-term psychological problems, mental health officials say. _ The number of people seeking help at the Charleston office of the state Department of Alcohol and Drug Abuse was up 25 percent in March compared with a year earlier. _ Studies show young children from the sea islands and Mount Pleasant, which bore the brunt of the storm's 135 mph winds and 15-foot tidal surge, suffered a variety of emotional symptoms, ranging from flashbacks to fear of storms. Officials note that not all of those statistical increases are a direct result of the storm, but they say Hugo's emotional effects are real and probably will grow worse in coming months as the start of another hurricane season, on June 1, approaches. ``We'll see a continuing rise in the need for counseling,'' said Dr. Sydney Jordan, an associate professor of psychology at the Medical University of South Carolina. He said post-traumatic stress usually takes about six months to set in. ``It doesn't take a rocket scientist to figure out that if everybody in the family is under stress, it takes a lot less of a stimulus to set people off,'' said Dean Kilpatrick, director of the university's Crime Victims Research and Treatment Center. ``There's nothing about Hugo that made people feel kinder or gentler toward their fellow man or spouse.'' The state Mental Health Department's Hugo Outreach Team, operated with a $1.5 million federal grant and 50 counselors, counseled 2,300 people in the first three months of the year. Officials suspect thousands more need help and don't know it. Support groups have found that many people don't recognize the link between their problems and the storm, said Cathy Joyner of the Hugo Outreach Team. ``They don't connect that they're unable to relate to their spouse, or that their children are incorrigible, to the fact they have had a significant life change,'' she said. The increase in reported rapes is probably associated with storm stress, said Jane Wiggins of a victim support group called People Against Rape. ``Anytime you have such a disruption of normal life _ the loss of a home, loss of material goods, loss of jobs and the influx of people _ it creates stress on the community and those prone to violence are more easily triggered,'' she said. Divorce attorneys in Charleston are busy these days. ``People are certainly calling more,'' attorney Sandra Jones said. She said she has had to book appointments two or three weeks in advance, something that was not necessary before the storm. ``I'd venture to say it is people who were feeling some sort of emotional problem in their marriage already,'' she said. ``They were already on a thin line and just can't cope with the additional frustration and pressure.''

DOC.HEAD: What the Halite is Wollastonite? Talc to a Mineralogist
DOC.TEXT: The next time New York is looking for a new nickname or something catchy to put on its license plates, how about this: Tops in Wollastonite. That's right, folks, the Empire State _ which likes to think itself unique in many ways _ is the wollastonite capital of the United States, if not the world. In fact, New York was the only state that mined the stuff last year. And the reason we know this is the U.S. Bureau of Mines says so in its annual ``State Minerals Summaries 1990.'' Now maybe you're wondering what the heck wollastonite is. The Bureau of Mines report doesn't say, so let's try Webster's Dictionary. Ah, yes, wollastonite: ``a white, monoclinic mineral, CaSiO3, a native calcium silicate.'' It was named for William H. Wollaston, an English physicist. The Bureau of Mines report does offer tantalizing tidbits about New York's wollastonite industry. ``In late 1988,'' it tells us, ``NYCO, a division of Processed Minerals Inc., announced that they made a significant discovery of wollastonite at Oak Hill, a few miles from NYCO's existing mine at Lewis. Drilling at the site, which was initiated in 1986, indicated that the new deposit would double the company's current reserves.'' The federal report continues, albeit ungrammatically: ``During the year, NYCO also introduced wollastokups, a chemically modified for use in wollastonite product engineering thermoplastics for fascia and body panels.'' Fascia? Body panels? Wollastokups?? Now, wait a minute. A fascia (plural fasciae), according to the dictionary, is ``a flat strip,'' or ``an instrument panel or dashboard.'' And anyone who has ever had a car accident knows what body panels are _ so we may be getting warm. Todd Hutchins, a machine operator at NYCO's Lewis mine in the Adirondacks, confirmed that the company sells wollastonite to car manufacturers. In addition to being used in dashboards and body panels, wollastonite reinforces car bumpers and is a component of brake discs and pads, he said. Asked for a definition of wollastokups, Hutchins said, ``It's the same stuff but it's chemically treated to make it stronger.'' While Hutchins knew he was working at the only wollastonite mine in the United States, he was modest. ``We're something,'' he laughed. ``We're big-time in a town of about 2,000.'' Wollastonite has been found in California, Norway, Romania, Mexico and Hungary _ but it's only mined in New York's Essex County, according to the Encyclopedia Americana. Wollastonite is also used as a paint filler and in ceramic products such as electrical insulators, tiles and porcelain, the encyclopedia says. The mineral's namesake, William Hyde Wollaston, was quite a guy. Born in 1766 in East Dereham, Norfolk, England, he earned a medical degree from Cambridge University, according to the encyclopedia entry written by L. Pearce Williams, a history professor from Cornell University. ``Although possessed of the attributes of an excellent doctor _ intelligence, extraordinarily keen senses and superb manipulative ability _ he was unhappy as a practicing physician and in 1800 turned to chemistry and physics,'' Williams says. Between 1803 and 1805, Wollaston focused on procuring platinum soft enough to be shaped. ``His efforts were successful and his fortune assured,'' Williams writes. ``From 1802 until his death, a whole host of discoveries flowed from his laboratory.'' For example, Williams tells us, Wollaston discovered two new metals _ palladium in 1803 and rhodium in 1804. But Williams does not say Wollaston discovered wollastonite, nor does he tell us who decided to name the stuff after him. The mystery continues.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Breaks Out On 16th Day Of Strangeways Revolt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with inmates setting fire. Picks up 3rd pvs, `In response ...'
DOC.TEXT: Rebellious inmates at Strangeways Prison started a serious fire early Monday, the 16th day of their revolt, after accusing authorities of beating prisoners who had surrendered. Prison officers entered the prison and had extinguished the blaze an hour after it was set, a spokesman for the Home Office, the department in charge of prisons. There was no indication that any of the estimated dozen prisoners still on the loose had been injured. ``There was a danger to life _ both to the prison officers who went in to fight the fire and to the inmates on the roof,'' said the spokesman. The fire started around 2:20 a.m., when heavy smoke was seen billowing from the building. The prisoners said Sunday they would carry on their siege another week, alleging that fellow rebels who had surrendered ``got broken arms and legs.'' They communicated their plans on a large board to friends, relatives and sightseers in the streets below. In chalk was written: ``We was coming down today but because some of the boys departing last week got broken arms and legs we are staying one more week.'' In response, prison spokesman Ian Lockwood told a news conference outside the prison: ``We categorically deny that there has been any action against prisoners who have come down. We can't speculate where they have heard these reports. ``We want to emphasize that with all prisoners coming down there is a standard routine. Prisoners coming down are observed by independent witnesses. ... The prisoners are then fed and showered.'' Lockwood, governor of Haverigg Prison in northwest England, pressed into service at Strangeways, said negotiations that ended Sunday morning had not resumed. ``The past 48 hours inside the prison have passed quietly with only sporadic activity by prisoners and no direct confrontation,'' he said. Hundreds of prisoners rioted on April 1 in the overcrowded prison, which was heavily damaged when inmates set fires and hurled roof tiles at guards and firefighters. Most surrendered in the first few days. On Friday, officials said two more prisoners had surrendered, leaving fewer than 13 inside the prison. Government officials said Strangeways disturbance sparked unrest at eight other prisons in England and Wales April 8, ranging from a sit-in at Leeds Jail to rioting at Dartmoor prison.

DOC.HEAD: Guide Says President Has Right Stuff _ for Bonefishing
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: Mounted on a wall in George Hommell's tackle shop in this sportfishing haven is a plastic replica of a 13-pound bonefish President Bush caught a week before his inauguration in 1989. It's the kind of monster some anglers wait a lifetime to catch. But the self-proclaimed environment president threw the fish back after measuring it. ``That fish is swimming around yet, probably 13{ pounds by now,'' said Hommell, who is taking Bush to his best bonefish haunts on Saturday and Sunday. Hommell, who has worked the sand flats and coral reefs around the Florida Keys for 45 of his 65 years, pointed with pride last week to the sparkling blue-green water under Backlash, the 17-foot bonefishing boat he uses on fishing trips with the president. ``Everything he wants to do is conservation-minded. The first time I fished with him he looked down at the water, nice and clear, and said, `We have to make sure the next generations are able to enjoy this,''' Hommell said. Hommell said Bush has become an expert at catching the muscular, silvery fish during five outings with him since Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady, a fellow angler, introduced them in 1980. A former Navy gunner, Hommell came to Florida after World War II and got hooked on the Keys, where more than 400 species of fish meant steady business for good fishing guides. He ran charters until he could open his own shop, World Wide Sportsman, in 1968. Golfer Jack Nicklaus is one old customer, and baseball legend Ted Williams hauled in a few prizes on Hommell's boat. But his tackle business has expanded and now Bush is the only angler he finds time to guide. ``Bush is a darn good fisherman,'' said Hommell. ``He'll listen to you. He's very attentive. ... And he's patient. You might go three, four hours without seeing a bonefish, and he's got the patience for that.'' Bush, talking to reporters the day after he caught the 13-pounder, said of the bonefish, ``These are, pound for pound, I'd say, as fighting a fish as there is in the world. It really is amazing what they do.'' ``Then you take them in, weigh them and hold them in the water and stroke them so that they can escape without some shark getting them. It really is very wonderful,'' he said. Other resorts claim to have good bonefishing. But only in the Keys do bonefish grow over 10 pounds, according to Sportfishing magazine. At that size, only the most skillful anglers can haul in the fish known as ``the ghost of the flats.'' ``You've got to fish them like you're hunting deer. They're very spooky,'' Hommell said. Bush has ordered his small army of Secret Service agents and other federal officials to keep their boats and helicopters at a distance, and other trappings of power are left at the dock, Hommell said. ``He's just a regular fisherman, and he acts that way,'' he said. Hommell said he hasn't told Bush how he feels about allowing oil drilling off southern Florida, a move locals say could destroy the fragile Keys environment and shatter the state's tourism-based economy. Bush has promised that drilling won't be allowed in ``highly sensitive areas,'' but he has stopped short of calling for the ban Florida's entire congressional delegation wants. ``He's basically down here to fish and I don't ask him about it because I realize he only has a few days each year to do it,'' Hommell said. ``I try to make sure we talk fishing and look at the clean surroundings, and he'll realize how important it is that it stays that way.''

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Shopping for Foreign Aid on Capitol Hill
DOC.TEXT: The president is a little like the shopper who consistently underestimates his shopping list and has to go to the automatic teller machine to replenish his wallet. In the waning months of each fiscal year, he always finds himself short of cash and has to ask Congress for more. Unexpected expenses have arisen, or things cost more than anticipated. But unlike the teller machine, Congress has a mind of its own. You can have the money, lawmakers tell the president, but only if you'll also take all this extra cash and use it for a list of projects we would like. The scenario has been much the same since the birth of the republic. The first supplemental appropriations bill, as the money measures are called, was proposed in 1790. Deficit pressures have led to an actual decline in their use in recent years. This year, President Bush asked Congress for a relatively modest $870 million: $500 million to support Panama's fledgling new democratic government, $300 million to do the same for Nicaragua, and $70 million to pay for resettlement of a higher-than-planned number of Soviet Jews emigrating to the United States. Because of budget rules, any new spending must be balanced by cuts in some other part of the budget so the net package won't add to the deficit. Bush proposed to pay for the new aid by trimming the Pentagon budget. But the House wants the Pentagon to finance a good deal more than Bush's package. House members added $510 million for food stamps, $111 million for disaster assistance, $390 million for veterans' assistance, $432 million for fire fighting, and a list of other items, pushing the bill's total to $2.4 billion. The money bill is among the first items facing the Senate when it returns this week from a two-week Easter recess. The Senate Appropriations Committee is likely to take up the measure late in the week. When that happens, the bill probably will grow some more. Already, Sen. Joseph Biden, D-Del., has indicated he wants to add $125 million in U.S. economic aid to help wean Andean farmers from producing coca, the leaf used in making cocaine. Others likely will seek additional spending on various domestic programs. ``It's seen as the only train leaving the station,'' said one senior Senate aide. That is because of the urgency with which the White House sees the funding bill. It is a ``must sign'' measure because of the aid to Panama and Nicaragua, which Bush believes is crucial to the survival of two nascent Western Hemisphere democracies. In Panama, the administration is anxious to repair the physical damage from its invasion last December and the longer-term economic damage from U.S. trade sanctions imposed as pressure on former dictator Manuel Noriega. The situation is even more desperate in Nicaragua, which voted the leftist government of Daniel Ortega out of office in February and replaced him with a coalition led by President-elect Violeta Chamorro. ``She's got the Contras (the U.S.-backed rebels) to dismantle, a wrecked economy, she can't make agricultural plans,'' said a senior administration official. Chamorro is to be sworn in April 25. ``Even before she raises her hand to take the oath of office she's got more problems than the average president accumulates in a year,'' the official said. Nicaraguan inauguration day, just nine days from now, has become the administration's new target date for winning approval of the aid package. Bush's earlier goal, April 5, slipped by without congressional action. There is little controversy over the items Bush requested. The House trimmed his $500 million for Panama to $420 million, devoting the rest of the money to other foreign aid causes, but gave him the full amounts for Nicaragua and the refugees. But the bill may be further delayed by unrelated disputes. Its must-pass nature makes the measure the ideal target for those with sharp policy disputes with the White House, such as a band of congressional liberals who want Bush to take a tougher line toward the government of El Salvador and its alleged tolerance of human rights abuses. Nobody ever said shopping on Capitol Hill was easy.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Jim Drinkard covers foreign affairs in Congress for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Musical Tribute Lincoln Never Heard Set for Performance
DOC.TEXT: Fate kept Abraham Lincoln from hearing the march ``Honor to Our Soldiers,'' composed as a tribute to him, but its strains will resound tonight at a concert marking the 125th anniversary of his assassination. It was to have been played in Ford's Theater following the play ``Our American Cousin'' on April 14, 1865. But actor John Wilkes Booth shot Lincoln during the third act, mortally wounding him. The rest of the program was canceled. Composer William Withers Jr. originally wrote the march for piano. In tonight's performance sponsored by the National Park Service, however, the 13-piece Federal City Silver Cornet Band will play an arrangement scored for saxhorns _ large, deep-toned, brass instruments. ``This may be the first time it has ever been performed,'' said Mark Elrod of Gaithersburg, Md., founder of the ensemble. According to Lincoln assassination buff Richard Sloan of Long Island, N.Y., however, the march was played at another theater following the shooting. But he would not give details, saying he wanted to use them himself in a magazine article. Sloan plans to be on hand for the concert of Civil War songs, ending with ``Honor to Our Soldiers,'' after which the stage will go dark.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
King Dissolves Parliament, Bowing To Demands Of Pro-Democracy Movement
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs to UPDATE with king dissolving Parliament, prime minister resigning. Picks up 12th pvs, `Demonstrators chanted ...' ^LaserPhoto KAT3
DOC.TEXT: The prime minister resigned Monday and King Birendra dissolved the national assembly he had dominated, satisfying the two major conditions pro-democracy protesters had set for joining an interim government. The announcement, broadcast by state radio, ended a week of political deadlock in which the two parties leading the campaign for democracy refused to join an interim government unless the Rashtriya Panchayat, or national assembly, was dissolved and their own nominee named prime minister. ``In view of the events that have taken place in certain parts of the country, the people's aspirations and the ideals of democracy, we have been making political changes,'' Birendra said. ``There should be a congenial atmosphere where every citizen can enjoy democracy and nobody should be be forced to do anything which can run counter to the expression of freedom.'' The proclamation was the second major victory for pro-democracy forces. On April 8, Birendra caved in to their demand to lift a 29-year-old ban on political parties. He also freed several hundred political prisoners and permitted several previously banned newspapers to reopen. The prime minister who resigned, Lokendra Bahadur Chand, had been named to the post on April 6 in one of the king's last moves to try to contain the pro-democracy movement. On that day, police unleashed the bloodiest crackdown in Nepal's modern history. Witnesses said as many as 200 protesters were killed, though the government put the death toll at 10. Birendra's proclamation followed the collapse earlier Monday of marathon negotiations between Chand and leaders of the pro-democracy movement, from which hundreds of protesters refused to let the politicians leave. After learning of the breakdown, demonstrators destroyed a Mercedes Benz belonging to the prime minister as well as the car of Foreign Minister Pashupaiti Rana. By then, a crowd of about 15,000 had dwindled to a few hundred angry students who refused to let negotiators leave. Police were deployed on three sides of the government-run Royal Nepal Academy of Arts and Literature, site of the talks. But officers said they were under strict orders not to use force. Government officials and opposition leaders said they would sleep in the academy, where the talks began Sunday. The king had invited the leaders of the pro-democracy movement, the previously outlawed Nepali Congress Party and the United Left Front, to join an interim government until the next general elections. But they refused, saying they wanted their own nominee as prime minister and the national assembly dissolved immediately. Frustrated protesters burst through the gates of the academy three times during the Sunday's talks and demanded that the government give in to the opposition demands. Demonstrators also stoned and slightly damaged Chand's car as he attempted at one point to leave the building. Chand scurried back to the meeting. Minutes later, they also forced opposition leader Yog Prasad Upadhyaya back to the talks. Demonstrators chanted slogans including ``Hang Chand'' and ``Chand resign now,'' clapped and danced on car rooftops during the 12-hour meeting. At least two people were slightly injured during fighting between members of opposition factions, police said. Also Sunday, hundreds of Christians held an Easter march, chanting ``We want religious freedom!'' as they tested the promises of new democracy in this Himalayan nation. The march was the first in recent memory in the world's only Hindu kingdom, which bans Christian missionary work. On King's Way, the broad street leading to the tall walls surrounding King Birendra's palace, 300 Nepalese Christians marched shouting: ``We want religious freedom!'' Nepalese law bans Hindus from converting to Christianity. Anyone convicted of proselytizing is subject to prison terms ranging up to six years. The authorities did not interfere in the Christian procession. Although King Birendra's government has described itself as a democracy, the Nepalese Constitution gave the monarch supreme executive, judicial and legislative powers. Ninety percent of Nepal's 17 million people are Hindus, while 5 percent are Moslems and 3 percent are Buddhists. Nepalese Christians estimate their number at 25,000.

DOC.HEAD: Yeutter Predicts Japan Will Allow Imports of US Rice
DOC.TEXT: Few developments would make American rice farmers happier than to see Japan open its door to imports. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter predicts it will happen this year. For decades, the United States has been badgering Japan to open its import door to more agricultural products. There has been significant success with beef, citrus and some other products. But rice, no way. Rice has almost mystical status as a food staple in Japan, and government policies for many years were aimed at guaranteeing self-sufficiency, regardless of high subsidy costs and rising surpluses. Now, Japan is one of the most important trading nations engaged in the Uruguay Round of negotiations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The goal is to liberalize global trade by the time the talks are scheduled to conclude at the end of this year. Yeutter, who is optimistic about a favorable conclusion to the GATT talks, speaks with more certainty about Japan opening its rice door. ``I believe that the Japanese market for rice will be opened up prior to the end of the Uruguay Round, and should be open,'' Yeutter said. Allowing rice imports not only would be good for the Japanese consumers but will help those countries that want to sell rice to Japan, he said. And Tokyo cannot stand up for world trade liberalization without looking at its own policies. ``Or, putting it in a more specific way,'' he said, ``Japan simply cannot continue to exclude imports of rice from its own marketplace while it insists in the Uruguay Round that other nations liberalize trade in their industrial products and in services such as the financial marketplace.'' Yeutter's comments were made last week in a televised satellite interview with European reporters, part of the U.S. Information Agency's WorldNet operation. If Japan wishes to continue expanding its own exports, it must open itself to others, he said. ``And my judgment is that the political leadership in Japan will come to that same conclusion between now and December, and, therefore, Japan will open its rice market,'' Yeutter said. ``There will be a great debate, of course, as to how far it will open,'' he added. ``No one is suggesting that Japan must open its rice market totally; that's unrealistic.'' Meanwhile, these are uncertain times for U.S. rice producers. It's not just the political maneuvering over the 1990 farm bill. World supplies and prices are huge factors in the U.S. market. Rice is an important crop in half a dozen states, with Arkansas the biggest producer, followed by California, Louisiana, Texas, Mississippi and Missouri. Globally, most rice is consumed in the countries that produce it. Total output in calendar 1990 is projected by USDA at 503.6 million metric tons. One ton is equal to about 22 hundredweight. The hundredweight, or 100 pounds, is the standard U.S. measure. Of the world total output, China is expected to account for 179 million tons of rice and India, 105 million tons. Neither is a major exporter in 1990. But Thailand, which is forecast to produce 21 million tons of rice this year, will be the world's largest exporter at 4.7 million tons. Japan's 1990 rice crop is forecast at 12.9 million tons. Exports are zero, along with imports. The United States, which may produce around 7 million tons of rice this year, according to USDA projections, is expected to export about 2.6 million tons, second only to Thailand. According to the department's Foreign Agricultural Service, China and Indonesia imported some rice in calendar 1989 but have dropped out of the market this year. Now, the agency reported, the major rice exporters are having to scramble harder in 1990. Meanwhile, in another report, analysts said U.S. rice stockpiles could drop to 19 million hundredweight _ less than 1 million tons _ by Aug. 1, the beginning of the 1990-90 rice marketing year. That would be down from 26.7 million hundredweight last Aug. 1 and 31.4 million on Aug. 1, 1988. It also would be the lowest U.S. rice stockpile at the beginning of a marketing year since 1981. Market prices paid to farmers have improved because of the tighter supply and are currently expected to average $7.25 to $7.75 per hundredweight over the 1989-90 marketing year, up from $6.83 in 1988-89.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Ibuprofen Can Cause Kidney Failure in Over-the-Counter Doses
DOC.TEXT: Patients suffering from kidney disease so mild they don't know they have it run a serious risk of kidney failure from the widely used pain reliever ibuprofen, a study warns. Ibuprofen is sold over the counter under such brand names as Advil, Medipren, Motrin and Nuprin. The three-year study, appearing in Sunday's edition of the Annals of Internal Medicine, was accompanied by an editorial that proposed the Food and Drug Administration strengthen warning labels to urge consumers ``with any serious condition'' to consult their doctors before using the drug. Ibuprofen, approved for sale in non-prescription form since 1985, accounts for about 20 percent of the nation's $2.5 billion annual over-the-counter sales of pain relievers. The study examined the short-term effects of ibuprofen on 12 women with mild kidney disease who also had arthritis and high blood pressure, two illnesses that often prompt the use of ibuprofen. Researchers at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore, led by Dr. Andrew Whelton, gave participants 800 milligrams of ibuprofen three times a day _ the equivalent of 12 ibuprofen tablets _ for up to 11 days. The maximum recommended non-prescription dose is 1,200 milligrams a day. After eight days, three women developed kidney failure, which reversed when ibuprofen was discontinued. The three were then given 400 milligrams of ibuprofen three times a day, the maximum recommended dose. Two of the three again developed kidney failure but recovered when ibuprofen was stopped. The remaining nine women, who received ibuprofen for 11 days, showed changes in kidney function but did not develop kidney failure. Ibuprofen relieves pain by interfering with the body's production of prostaglandin, a substance involved in inflammation. But at the same time, the drug constricts blood flow. Normally, the change poses little risk if used for a short period. But for those whose blood flow to the kidneys is already reduced by kidney, heart or liver damage, the flu or aging, ibuprofen could trigger acute kidney failure, the study says. Over-the-counter use of ibuprofen was of ``special concern'' because without careful monitoring people may not know their kidneys are failing, the researchers said. ``Patients with previously undiagnosed mild renal impairment may consume therapeutic doses of ibuprofen without supervision'' and could suffer severe kidney damage, they wrote. The editorial's authors, pharmacologist Michael Murray of Purdue University and Dr. D. Craig Brater of Indiana University, said the study's results do not warrant the removal of ibuprofen from drug store shelves. Instead, they agreed with the National Kidney Foundation that warnings for the drug should be more explicit. Current labeling on ibuprofen products warn only those people who are allergic to aspirin not to take the medication. FDA spokeswoman Eva Kemper said an agency advisory panel met in February to consider ibuprofen warnings but had not yet made any recommendations. Brater and Murray urged that further studies be conducted to determine the risk to the general population of developing kidney damage from ibuprofen.

DOC.HEAD: Administration to Argue for Further Study on Global Warming
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will ask a 17-nation conference this week to examine the economic impact of global warming, but the administration plans to argue it's too early to propose specific measures to deal with the problem, officials say. The White House's cautious approach in developing responses to global warming is expected to unleash renewed criticism from some European countries that the United States is failing to provide leadership in dealing with the so-called ``greenhouse'' effect. The Bush administration has maintained that while there is widespread agreement that man-made pollutants are causing the earth to become warmer, there remain too many unanswered questions to warrant pollution controls that could have widespread economic implications. The president is hosting a White House conference on the greenhouse effect on Tuesday, just days before next Sunday's Earth Day observance. During his 1988 campaign, Bush said such a conference was a top priority and would be held in his first year as president. Senior advisers on economics, science and the environment from 17 nations plan to attend, making it the first gathering on the subject with government officials representing such a broad spectrum of interest. Senior Bush advisers said they hoped the conference would for the first time give equal weight to economic as well as environmental issues related to global warming. ``We hope it will raise the level of debate ... on the science and economics of global change,'' said Michael Boskin, chairman of the president's Council of Economic Advisers, who will be one of the three conference co-chairmen. Administration officials cautioned in briefings with reporters that the gathering is not intended to produce any blueprint for dealing with global warming. Instead, the officials said the administration will emphasize the need for further scientific studies and incorporating the economic issues involved. Last week, the president's chief science adviser, Allen Bromley, criticized those who advocate ``slam-dunk solutions'' to global warming. He said too many scientific and economic uncertainties remain to map out specific measures. ``We cannot sail blindly into the future,'' he declared. Bromley will serve as a conferenceco-chairman along with Boskin and Michael Deland, chairman of the president's Council on Environmental Quality. But even before many conference delegates arrived, officials from several European countries complained about the Bush administration's emphasis on further research and its refusal to discuss specific action plans to deal with the greenhouse issue. ``Some delegates will advocate more than just research,'' said an official from one European country, asking that he not be identified further. ``We want to stress that research should not be a substitute for action.'' Some of the Europeans plan ``to push the Americans pretty hard,'' said another European, also speaking anonymously. A number of European countries, including The Netherlands and West Germany, have called for the industrial nations to commit themselves to a stabilization of carbon dioxide emissions by the year 2000. Carbon dioxide, primarily from the burning of fossil fuels, accounts for more than half the ``greenhouse'' pollutants. Such curbs would require significant increases in energy efficiency or cuts in energy use. William Reilly, head of the Environmental Protection Agency, said Sunday the president is committed to an international treaty on global warming, but he too cautioned that more scientific evidence is needed. ``We have to be cautious, careful and take out something of an insurance policy,'' he said on ABC's ``This Week With David Brinkley.'' While most scientists agree that man-made pollutants are enveloping the earth and causing it to warm, they are unsure about the eventual severity of the warming. Some computer models have suggested a 4-degree to 9-degree Fahrenheit increase in global temperatures, but some scientists said those projections are uncertain and may not adequately take into account the effects of clouds or other factors that might have a counteracting effect. ``What we do not know is the timing, the magnitude or the rate of the (temperature) increase,'' said Bromley.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0431, changing form of editor's note, which is publishable.
White Marks His 28th High Court Anniversary
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court's nine members are among the most private of public officials. They wield enormous power, but rarely hold news conferences or give interviews. Recent polls indicate only one in three Americans can name any of the nine. This, the sixth in an occasional series, offers an up-to-date look at one member of the nation's highest court.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: It is not as if Byron R. White's resume needs enhancement, but for two decades the capital city's rumor mill has had him leaving the Supreme Court for some new challenge. Will he run for president or vice president? Has he been asked to become FBI director? Will he become commissioner of major league baseball or the National Football League? White has denied or ignored each of those rumors, and has remained an independently minded, intellectual force on the court. Marking his 28th anniversary as a justice today, White, 72, is considered an influential, consistent member of the court's conservative majority. He has more seniority than anyone except Justice William J. Brennan, 83, who joined the court in 1956. One rumor persists, seemingly finding its way into print every year or so, that he is about to retire. After such a report was published in 1988, White dispatched court spokeswoman Toni House to tell reporters, ``He has not told friends any such thing. He is not considering retirement.'' White, who refused to be interviewed for this article, continues to scoff at any suggestion his retirement is imminent. His resume, by any standard, is impressive: athletic and academic star in the tiny town of Wellington, Colo.; University of Colorado valedictorian, class of '38; best-known college football player of his time and star in basketball and baseball as well; member of professional football's Hall of Fame; Rhodes scholar; decorated war veteran; high-honors graduate of Yale law school; law clerk to Chief Justice Fred Vinson; Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy's chief aide; appointed to the Supreme Court by President John F. Kennedy at age 44. It is an All-American story. In a breezy dispatch written just months after White joined the court in 1962, an Associated Press reporter predicted, ``He is going to be no flaming liberal, no social reformer type. Nor a right-winger.'' At the same time Life magazine said, ``Although he has had no experience on the judicial bench, White is a man of depth and intensity with a capacity for dispassionate analysis.'' Some liberal critics say White, indeed, has become a right-winger after spending most of his tenure at the court's center. ``His voting record ... manifests a judicial philosophy that is very close to Ronald Reagan's ideal,'' Washington lawyer Nathan Lewin has said. White would let states outlaw most abortions, opposes broad use of affirmative action to remedy past bias in employment, and favors greater governmental accommodation of religion in ways some consider violations of church-state separation. In cases pitting societal protection against individual rights, White generally votes on the ``law and order'' side. He wrote for the court when in 1987 it ruled that the privacy rights of homosexuals do not protect them from state laws making sodomy a crime. ``I'm not a fan of his,'' said Stephen Barnett, a law professor at the University of California-Berkeley. ``He has had no coherent judicial philosophy and little distinction of any kind. His service on the court is distinguished only by its length.'' Barnett called White's opinion in the homosexual privacy case ``a low point in its sneering tone and lack of reasoning.'' But Harvard law professor Lance Liebman, a former White clerk, says that throughout his career the justice has tried to decide most cases narrowly and without sweeping statements. ``He thus plays the role of the careful lawyer, applying his powerful intelligence to the case before him, in the context of the precedents as he finds them,'' Liebman said. White's written opinions, most often employing unadorned prose rather than rhetorical flashes, reflect his personality. Friends say that in his personal life, White exposes no more of his thoughts and feelings than necessary. He can be gruff and impatient, as lawyers who appear before the court have learned to their discomfort. Bad lawyering is almost as sure to make White grimace as being reminded of the football nickname he has grown to hate _ ``Whizzer.'' Despite starring as the National Football League's best running back for three years after signing in 1938 for a record-high $15,800 annual salary, White says the sport was merely a means to an end _ to earn the money needed for law school. Nevertheless, he played with a tenacity later displayed in his legal career. ``That guy was tougher than hell. If we needed a yard or two, we didn't call on our fullback, we called on him,'' former Detroit Lions teammate Howard Weiss once told The Washington Post. ``I should know, I was the fullback. He was a tough monkey.''

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Impose Heavy Security on Democracy Movement Anniversary
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of police, some in riot gear, took to the streets of China's capital to prevent unrest on the anniversary of the start of last spring's pro-democracy movement. They succeeded: a lone protester was arrested Sunday. Other expressions of dissent were discouraged by the heavy police presence. A year ago Sunday, former Communist Party chief Hu Yaobang died. Hu was ousted from power in 1987 for failing to stop student demonstrations and students mourning his death used the occassion to criticize the leadership and push for democratic reform and an end to official corruption. For seven weeks, Beijing streets were filled with crowds of up to 1 million people demanding the resignation of unpopular leaders and more say in how they live their lives. It all ended when troops invaded the city on June 3-4, killing hundreds of pro-democracy demonstrators with automatic weapons fire and driving students from Tiananmen Square, the country's symbolic seat of power.
