This spring, Beijing is a different city. Students say protests are unlikely because of heavy police surveillance and the certainty that anyone who tries to organize a demonstration will be arrested. In addition, thousands of people who took part in last year's demonstrations are thought to still be in jail without charges, and some protest leaders have fled the country. In anticipation of Sunday's anniversary, police set up checkpoints at several intersections near the university area in northwestern Beijing, and officers carrying rifles with bayonets drawn patrolled the square. The square was open to the public Sunday, unlike on April 1 and 5 when police sealed it to block feared protests. Overseas dissidents had urged people to silently stroll through the square on those days in honor of those killed last June. Sunday's only incident occurred when a man in his 30s began to pin on his sleeve white paper flowers, a traditional sign of mourning. Streamers from the flowers read ``To mourn Hu Yaobang'' and ``Heroes who die for democracy and liberty.'' Police quickly arrested the man, who told onlookers he was a scientist from the southern province of Guizhou and had come to Beijing ``to mourn our great general secretary (Hu).'' He carried suitcases and said he had come to Beijing with everything he owned in anticipation of being arrested. About 20 police stood guard around a Monument to Revolutionary Heroes in the middle of the square throughout the day, forbidding entry. The monument, usually open, was covered with wreaths last year brought by students and others to mourn Hu. It was also the headquarters for student leaders during their occupation of the 100-acre square last May and June. Buses and vans loaded with police were parked around the monument, and dozens of uniformed and plainclothes police patrolled the square. As usual, almost all the people on the square were from outside Beijing: workers in blue Mao jackets and rubber-soled slippers, sunburned farmers in ill-fitting suits and honeymooners posing for pictures. Students and young workers have been warned by authorities to stay away from Tiananmen this spring and told they face expulsion or banishment to a countryside job if they are involved in protests. Hundreds of riot police, some with shields and hard helmets, were stationed along main streets of the capital on Sunday, ostensibly to control crowds for a marathon race through the city. Surprisingly, security was only marginally increased at the university campuses in northwestern Beijing that were hotbeds of dissent last spring. At Beijing Normal University, crowds gathered around recently posted notices announcing the expulsions of movement leaders Wu'er Kaixi and Chai Ling, both of whom escaped to the West. Students appeared more concerned with making the most of Sunday's sunshine and warm temperatures _ reading outdoors or playing basketball _ than with attempting to mark the anniversary. The Communist Party's official People's Daily did not mention the anniversary in its Sunday edition. There have been no reported official events to commemorate the death of Hu.

DOC.HEAD: Washington Post Racing Columnist Shares Bounty at Horse Race
DOC.TEXT: The Washington Post's racing columnist has won a share in the second-largest jackpot in Maryland horse racing history, a double-triple pool of more than $1.3 million. Andrew Beyer and nine other bettors grossed $134,161.80 apiece Saturday at Baltimore's Pimlico racetrack from a pool that had been steadily growing for 23 days. The other winners were not identified. Beyer gambled $4,578 after determining that ``at least half the horses in the field were so totally devoid of talent that they couldn't possibly finish in the money'' and then plotting out possible strategies for the remaining contenders, he said in his column Sunday. The ten winners had to pick the correct order of finish for first, second and third in both the third and fifth races. ``I never even had to root,'' Beyer wrote. ``My horses controlled the race from start to finish.'' The state record for double-triple payoffs is $314,366, which went to a syndicate of local professionals in February 1987. ``I have spent many, many years and a ridiculous amount of effort trying to win a six-digit payoff at a racetrack, and I had finally done it,'' Beyer said in his column. ``I'll save seven digits for a future goal.''

DOC.HEAD: Independent Counsel in HUD Case Had Long, Varied Legal Career
DOC.TEXT: Retired judge Arlin Adams, a longtime stalwart of the federal bench, is taking on what may be his toughest case _ the HUD scandal. His staff isn't complete and remains in temporary offices, but Adams said it has been making progress anyway in its investigation of alleged fraud by top officials in the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development. Adams, who travels back and forth to Washington as needed, said his staff has received FBI files and other documents and met with two congressional committees. He expects to have his staff completed by this week, and interviews in the investigation should start ``almost any day,'' he said Thursday. Adams, 68, spent 18 years on the bench of the 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Philadelphia. He retired and went back to his old law firm three years ago. He also is finishing two books, due out this year, on religion and law. Never quite out of the legal limelight, Adams last month was named independent counsel to investigate allegations that former Housing Secretary Samuel Pierce Jr. and other HUD officials conspired to defraud a government program by steering rent subsidies to politically connected developers. There has been testimony before congressional committees that hundreds of millions of dollars were improperly handled, possibly stolen. The soft-spoken Adams has a reputation for being sensitive but firm with those who stand before him. If the evidence is there for him to seek indictments, Adams said, he will hire other lawyers to do the courtroom work. His expertise at the trial level is in civil work, mainly in antitrust, securities and mergers. Yet he said his most interesting case was a murder. Early in his career, he was appointed to defend a man charged with killing a policeman. He won reversal of the conviction when he was able to prove his client hadn't fired the bullet. As a judge, Adams heard the appeal of two Soviet spies convicted of obtaining secrets of the Strategic Air Command. Adams said he persuaded his colleagues on the court that the president, as head of foreign affairs, did not need court authorization to order the wiretaps used to convict the spies. ``The interesting windup of the case is that the Russians demanded the United States return the two spies in exchange for Gary Powers, who was shot down by the Russians during the Eisenhower Administration in the U-2 incident. I think that was a good result,'' Adams said. Adams, a lifelong Republican, staunchly believes all lawyers should be involved in public service _ even when it costs them money. ``If the lawyers won't do it, who will?'' he said. ``For reasons I don't quite understand, lawyers today are not taking on as much public work as they did 10 or 20 years ago. Like so much in society the legal profession has gotten very materialistic. But I am hopeful that is going to change.'' His first taste of politics came in 1949 when the head of his law firm, William Schnader, was chairman of a commission writing a new charter for the city of Philadelphia and got Adams involved. Then Adams worked in several campaigns of Rep. Hugh Scott, who later became a U.S. senator and minority leader. When another congressman, William Scranton, ran for governor, Adams became a key supporter. ``When he won he urged me to become a member of his cabinet and first I said, `No, I couldn't afford it,' but when he asked me to be secretary of public welfare, Mr. Schnader and I decided that was a request I couldn't turn down because that was public service,'' Adams said. Later, Scranton and Scott unsuccessfully urged Adams to run for governor. In 1968, Adams became one of the key people in Richard Nixon's successful presidential bid. That led to his appeals court appointment. Adams said high points in his career came when Nixon and President Ford considered him for the U.S. Supreme Court. ``I don't think I was entitled to it,'' Adams said. ``There were many other lawyers and judges more qualified, I thought, and just being considered was honor enough.'' ``President Jimmy Carter, while I was a judge, offered me a very high government position which I cannot discuss because I declined to accept it,'' Adams added. ``I thought that was a very satisfying thing because he did that strictly on my record. I did not know Jimmy Carter.''

DOC.HEAD: Project Aimed at Reducing Frailty Among Elderly
DOC.TEXT: The government will sponsor a three-year, $2.9 million research project aimed at reducing or preventing the elderly from becoming physically frail, two federal agencies say. The National Institute on Aging and the National Center for Nursing Research said sites in eight states will be used for the ``FICSIT'' project _ which stands for Frailty and Injuries: Cooperative Studies of Intervention Techniques. More than 1,500 volunteers are expected to participate. The program will feature exercise, ranging from the Oriental practice of tai chi to aerobic dance; education, to make older people aware of accident risks; and rehabilitation, to improve physical conditioning. Millions of older people lack strength, mobility, balance and endurance, and are therefore susceptible to serious falls, nursing home admissions and a loss of independence, according to the NIA. ``The new trials highlight the fact that frailty and injuries are not the inevitable outcome of aging,'' said NIA Director Dr. T. Franklin Williams. ``Instead they are problems for which we have now found some very viable solutions.'' More than 32 percent of people over age 75 cannot climb stairs, 40 percent are unable to walk two blocks, 7 percent cannot walk across a small room and 22 percent cannot lift 10 pounds, the NIA said. Forty-two percent of nursing home residents cannot get out of a chair without help.
DOC.HEAD: Senator Leaders Say U.S.-Soviet Trade Improvements Could Be
DOC.TEXT: Threatened

A hoped-for trade agreement between the United States and Moscow could be derailed if Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev carries out his threatened economic blockade against Lithuania, warn Senate leaders in both parties. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, and Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., said Sunday that retaliation by Moscow to Lithuania's March 11 declaration of independence would jeopardize a trade agreement President Bush and Gorbachev hoped to sign at a summit in June. The Bush administration was taking what Secretary of State James A. Baker III called a ``wait and see'' attitude as the Kremlin-imposed deadline for Lithuania to rescind its declaration of independence passed Sunday night. Mitchell, who on Saturday condemned Gorbachev's ultimatum as ``precisely the wrong approach,'' said Sunday he was waiting for Bush to do the same. But in an interview on CBS-TV's ``Face the Nation,'' Mitchell also supported the administration's reluctance to issue specific counter threats. ``We ought not to be announcing in advance what we're going to do when we don't know for sure that they are going to do,'' he said. However, Mitchell said ``a wide range'' of possible reactions could include canceling the summit, slowing down the trade negotiations and ``in between those ... a whole lot of things that can be done.'' Dole, interviewed on NBC's ``Meet the Press'' from Jerusalem, questioned the wisdom of canceling the summit if the Soviets carry out their threat to cut off supplies to Lithuania. Any U.S. retaliation, Dole said, should be limited to measures that are more to Moscow's benefit than to the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Urges Dialogue To End Lithuanian Crisis, Salutes Quest For Freedom
DOC.TEXT: In his Easter message, Pope John Paul II paid tribute to the thirst for freedom that toppled dictatorships last year and said he hoped Lithuania can achieve independence through dialogue. Celebrating the holiday elsewhere, East Germans and Romanians sang hymns of joy for the freedom won by their pro-democracy revolutions. In the Soviet Ukraine, Roman Catholics in Kiev were allowed to legally perform Easter services on Sunday for the first time in 44 years. In Sunday's message, the pope declared that man's ``true dimensions of the spirit have been discovered anew'' after two bloody world wars and ``years of dictatorships which have deprived men and women of their basic freedoms.'' After the noontime message from a balcony overlooking St. Peter's Square, the Roman Catholic leader spoke in Lithuanian, saying, ``In the name of Jesus dead and risen for all men, we ask for peace for our children in the dear Lithuania nation, while we hope that their aspirations find confirmation in a respectful and comprehensive dialogue.'' Cheers went up from a crowd of 100,000 faithful and tourists in the square, where the pope earlier celebrated Easter Mass in front of St. Peter's Basilica. His message on Lithuania was the latest attempt by the Vatican to help ease tensions between Moscow and the tiny Baltic republic, which declared itself independent on March 11. Tass, the official Soviet news agency, reported that a Soviet envoy received by the pope on Saturday had delivered a message from President Mikhail S. Gorbachev about the crisis in Lithuania, where four out of five people are Catholic. The contents of the message were not disclosed. The Vatican in March opened diplomatic relations with Moscow. Earlier this month, the Vatican's newly appointed envoy to the Soviet Union said the Holy See would be willing to mediate the Lithuanian dispute. In his speech, John Paul gave holiday wishes in 55 languages. The longest greetings went to Lithuania and his homeland, Poland. In Romania on Sunday, tens of thousands of worshipers sang ancient hymns in packed churches across the nation in an emotional celebration of their freest Easter in more than four decades. In Timisoara, where Romania's December revolution began and where some of the worst fighting occurred, Archbishop Nicolae eulogized the martyrs of the revolution in a sermon to 2,000 people. ``After 45 years during which (Communists) tried to enslave our soul and history ... we now celebrate in freedom Holy Easter,'' he said. Similar services were held in the two Germanys. East and West Germans poured through their border in both directions and packed churches. Last month, East Germany's citizens held their first free elections ever and elected a goverment that favors speedy reunification. Thousands of Germans took to the streets for traditional Easter peace marches. For the first time ever, peace activists from both West and East Germany joined together for the anti-war rallies and demonstrations. Nearly 3,000 leftist demonstrators carrying East German, Soviet and Palestinian flags took part in a noisy march from East Berlin to West Berlin. ``Berlin without a Wall _ Germany without weapons _ Europe without blocs,'' read the lead banner. ``We want an East Germany and a West Germany completely without the military,'' a demonstration leader yelled through a microphone to the cheers of the crowd. In Lebanon, church bells vied with bursts of gunfire from warring Christian groups in east Beirut as thousands of Christians wondered whether full-scale fighting would break out again in the battle for control of their enclave. ``The roar of the guns today is sharpening fears of renewed warfare,'' said Patriarch Nasrallah Sfeir of the Maronite Catholic community, the largest Christian sect in Lebanon, in an Easter sermon at the chapel of his seat in Bkirki, north of Beirut. He warned that a new round of full-scale fighting would finish off the Christians, saying that more than one half have already fled Lebanon's Christian enclave. In Israel, the Roman Catholic patriarch of Jerusalem used his Easter message to call for equality between peoples. In a sermon before hundreds of pilgrims and tourists at the Church of the Holy Sepulchre in Jerusalem, the traditional site of Christ's crucifixion and burial, Patriarch Michel Sabbah said: ``Individuals and peoples are equal in all rights. A people must not oppress another people, nor must a people be dominated by another people.'' As Ukrainian Catholics held Easter services in Kiev, a controversial cathedral in the western Ukrainian city of Lvov that was given back last week to Ukrainian Catholics was closed for Easter to avoid conflict. An announcement by the Ukrainian nationalist movement Rukh said St. George's Cathedral, which had been under Russian Orthodox control, was closed ``to prevent provocations and ease tension during the holiday.'' The Ukrainian Catholic faith, outlawed in 1946 as Stalin moved to quash expressions of nationalism, has been practiced openly under Gorbachev's reforms.

DOC.HEAD: Chinatown Shutdown Called to Protest Mayor's Freeway Plan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Shutdown scheduled for 4:30 p.m. EDT. Lead prospects uncertain.
DOC.TEXT: Chinatown merchants desperate for speedy repair of an earthquake-damaged freeway that once led tourists their way organized a shutdown of the district today to protest a plan to build a new highway. Mayor Art Agnos doesn't want the elevated Embarcadero Freeway rebuilt. He wants it replaced with a highway at street level or underground. But neighborhood activists say a new highway would be more expensive and take longer than repairing the 1.7-mile road damaged in the Oct. 17 earthquake. Hundreds of merchants in Chinatown were to close their doors today and head for an afternoon meeting of the Board of Supervisors, which has the mayor's proposal on its agenda. Agnos argues the elevated freeway is ugly, blocks a panoramic view of San Francisco Bay and is too expensive to repair, although state Transportation Department estimates put the cost of reopening the road at $32 million. Agnos wants to spend $120 million to replace it, acknowledging that the project could take five or six years. The Transportation Department said repairs could be completed by Oct. 1 if the work started in June. Rose Pak of the Chinese Chamber of Commerce and others said time is critical for Chinatown merchants who have been doing without their key link to tourists who usually keep their shops and restaurants bustling. She called today's shutdown a ``very basic, grassroots, humble gesture.'' It follows the submission of 10,000 signatures in favor of repairing the freeway. ``It's a political statement that we're not a silent minority,'' Pak said. The freeway has long been controversial. In 1986, voters rejected a proposal to spend $10 million to tear it down. Many groups opposed it even before it opened in 1959, saying it would sacrifice city streets and alter the character of neighborhoods. Supervisor Tom Hsieh was outraged by the mayor's proposal, which he said was explained to the board of supervisors in a two-page statement that lacked details about where the $120 million would come from and what Chinatown is supposed to do while the expressway is built. ``Some leaders have no idea of the hardship and the trauma people in that community are facing,'' Hsieh said. ``They lost not just business, they lost employment.'' Last week, a San Francisco Chamber of Commerce business panel voted in favor of rebuilding the road. Although business leaders vow that Agnos' position will hurt him politically, the mayor contends that the long-term interests of the city must come first. ``Nobody wants to sacrifice short-term discomfort for long-term progress, but that's what a great city has to do, or it will become stagnant,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 28,463.18, down 750.74 points, or 2.57 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Fuel Tanks of Religious Group's Fallout Shelter Leak Near Yellowstone
LaserGraphic NY9
DOC.TEXT: Up to 19,000 gallons of fuel are believed to have leaked near Yellowstone National Park from a fallout shelter built by a religious group girding for nuclear Armageddon. Workers on Sunday began pumping out 540,000 gallons of gasoline and diesel from the underground tanks, while furious local residents said their fears of an environmental disaster were borne out by the leaks. ``I'd say we're mad as hell,'' said Richard Parks, who owns an outdoor equipment shop in nearby Gardiner. ``I hope they can get (the fuel) out of there. I hope to God people have got the sense not to let them put it back in.'' The 35 tanks, with a capacity of 634,500 gallons, were installed last winter in the Church Universal and Triumphant's underground complex. The shelters are on a ranch purchased in 1981 from publisher Malcolm Forbes to prepare for a nuclear catastrophe. Church officials reported last week that one tank containing diesel fuel had leaked 4,000 gallons into the ground. Two others were reported leaking over the weekend. Steve Pilcher, chief of Montana's Water Quality Bureau, said 15,000 gallons were unaccounted for Sunday and most likely were in the soil near the complex. The tanks and the 750-person shelter complex are five miles north of Yellowstone National Park and within several hundred yards of Mol Heron Creek, a cutthroat trout spawning stream that runs into the Yellowstone River. Small amounts of fuel had reached the creek, but no major damage had occurred, officials said. Pilcher said less than 1,000 gallons of spilled fuel had been recovered, but trenches were dug to capture most of the fuel before it reached the creek. ``It's not a one-day, quick-fix cleanup. ... They're looking at a long-term recovery and cleanup effort. There's still a big threat there,'' Pilcher said. By Saturday night, church officials had decided all 35 tanks must be pumped out, excavated and inspected, said Murray Steinman, a sect spokesman. ``After the second and third leaks, we said, `That's it, we're going to get all this out of here,''' Steinman said. The cleanup is under the direction of Envirocon, a Missoula-based engineering firm retained by the church. Steinman said tanker trucks hauled out 110,000 gallons of gasoline on Sunday, and crews will work all week to remove the remaining fuel. The leaks occurred within weeks after state officials reopened their environmental review of church developments near Corwin Springs. They said the church concealed construction of the complex during the original review, completed a year ago. The local population of church members mushroomed this year after spiritual leader Elizabeth Clare Prophet, who claims she receives and passes on to church members messages from a group of souls known as the Ascended Masters, warned that March and April are dangerous times. She told members to come to Montana for a prayer vigil and to prepare for a possible nuclear war or accident. Local officials estimate 2,000 to 3,000 church members live in the scenic mountain valley, where the church owns about 30,000 acres and has sponsored housing developments. The church said nobody is living in the fallout shelters. Steinman said the tanks might have been defective. But Pilcher said the tanks might have ruptured because they were installed in frozen soil that shifted when it began to thaw.

DOC.HEAD: Tokyo Stocks Down, Dollar Up
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing Nikkei, dollar, bond prices
DOC.TEXT: Share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange tumbled in thin trading Monday, while the dollar ended higher against the Japanese yen. The Nikkei Stock Average, the market's main barometer, fell 750.74 points, or 2.57 percent, to 28,463.18. A thin 230 million issues changed hands on the exchange's first section, which includes the country's largest and most profitable firms. The dollar closed at 159.42 yen, up one yen from its close Friday at 158.42. The currency moved in a narrow range between 159.00 yen and 159.45 yen after opening at 159.15 yen. In the bond market, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year government bond was quoted at 85.79 points at 3:00 p.m., down from its close Friday at 85.90. The bond yield rose to 7.405 percent from 7.380 percent. Kazuhiro Nomura, an analyst for New Japan Securities Co., said arbitrage selling of spot issues accounted for the deep losses in the Nikkei index, which were further exaggerated by the unusually light trading. In arbitrage trading, dealers exchange spot issues for stock futures, or vice versa, in an attempt to profit from the difference in prices between the two markets. Japanese market participants have frequently pointed to the recent introduction of arbitrage techniques as a reason for the continuing instability of the Tokyo market. Nomura said market dealers were largely waiting on the sidelines ahead of an announcement Wednesday by the U.S. Commerce Department of the country's trade figures for February. They were also waiting to see the Bank of Japan's moves to regulate the country's money supply and the trend in exchange rates. On the currency market, dealers also pointed to the U.S. trade figure announcement and speculation about future Bank of Japan policy regarding interest rates as affecting the yen-dollar rate. Norio Takeda, a dealer with the Bank of Tokyo, said the dollar's early strength was attributable to the view that the upcoming U.S. monthly trade imbalance will show an improvement. A dealer with Fuji Bank, speaking on condition of anonymity, added the dollar was also propped up by a large demand for the currency by banks on occasion of the first day of the monthly reserve-accounting period Monday. Early in the reserve period, banks try to obtain a lot of cash to fufill their reserve requirements. The surge in demand often kicks up demand for the dollar as well as various short term interest rates.

DOC.HEAD: Glance at Independence Movements in Soviet Republics
With PM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A look at drives for independence or greater autonomy in some of the 15 republics of the Soviet Union:
Parliament declared independence on March 11. Communist Party has split into two factions, with the majority favoring independence and smaller, conservative faction remaining loyal to Moscow.
Parliament has declared Soviet rule to be tantamount to occupation of an independent country, and has voted to re-establish independence at the end of a still-undefined transition period.

Legislators working on draft on independence, which could be voted on May 3. Communist Party has split in two, with group of independent members, mostly ethnic Latvians, forming their own independent party after pro-Moscow Communists refused to support a pro-independence platform.

Nationalists are demanding independence and the republic's parliament has condemned its forcible annexation to the Soviet Union in 1921. Georgians vote for a new Supreme Soviet legislature on June 17, and independence will be a key campaign issue. The opposition groups remain badly splintered, however.

The Moldavian People's Front, an independent political movement, is the main challenger to the Communist Party. The front initially wants political sovereignty, followed eventually by full independence. Moldavia was once part of Romania, and the overthrow of Nicolae Ceausescu has increased the passion for independence or a return to Romania.

A nascent nationalist movement is emerging in the Soviet Union's second-largest republic. Rukh, the organization of progressive nationalists, is the most vocal of several movements demanding an independent Ukraine.

Some Azerbaijanis, a Turkic and predominantly Shiite Moslem people, want to be united with their brethren across the border with Iran. Some tore down border fences with Iran in January. Azerbaijan is engaged in a bitter dispute with neighboring Armenia over control of the Nagorno-Karabakh territory that has sapped the authority of Moscow in both republics.

DOC.HEAD: Text of Pope's Easter Sunday Message
With PM-World Easter
DOC.TEXT:
Following are excerpts from the Vatican translation of Pope John Paul II's Easter Sunday message, which was delivered in Italian.
I have overcome the world! (Jn 16:33). The stone before the tomb at the foot of Golgotha' rolled away. The tomb itself empty... He is not here. He has risen, he is not here. (Mk 16:6). Go, tell his disciples and Peter... (Mk 16:7). Simon, Peter and John discover in the tomb everything just as the women had said. They do not find him. Were they perhaps, already then, capable of recalling those words: I have overcome the world? In the world you have tribulation, but be of good cheer, I have overcome the world. (Jn 16:33). Yes. Those last days had been a time of terrible tribulation. They had been dismayed by the arrest in Gethsemane, by the condemnation to the cross, by the death on Calvary. They had experienced a terrible tribulation. Before the empty tomb did they wonder: Has he conquered the world? ... This world in which man lives, where man has dominion, this world in the end seems to overcome man. It overcomes him through death. But Christ, who has conquered death, has overcome the world... By his own death he has put to death that death whose beginning was sin. Man's sin and the sin of the world. The world, as the original lie was whispered, became in man's heart God's foe. The world, which should have opened man's heart to God, began instead to drive God out of the human heart. And even though the tempter has repeated from the beginning: You will be like God (cf. Gen 3:5), this world is never able to offer man, in the end, anything more, anything other than death.... In the world you have tribulation; but be of good cheer. That world which is the theatre of man's history...carries the marks of his energies, his tragedies and his triumphs. (Gaudium et Spes, 2). The world...the scene of man's many tribulations has fallen into the bondage of sin (ibid) and so often calls this very bondage its freedom! The world, called into existence out of love and kept in existence by its creator, by Christ on the cross, freed by the power of his death and revealed anew, through his resurrection, as the divine Cosmos (cf. ibid.). Man of our time! Man living immersed in the world, thinking that you have mastered it, whereas you may well be its victim, Christ frees you from every form of bondage to set you upon the way to victory over self, to love that is constructive and aims for the good, a love that is demanding, that makes you build up and not destroy your tomorrow, your family, your environment, and all of society. Man of our time! Only the Risen Christ can fully satisfy your irrepressible yearning for freedom! After the horrors of two World Wars and all the wars which in these last fifty years, often in the name of godless ideologies, have reaped a harvest of victims and sown hatred in so many nations, after the years of dictatorships which have deprived men and women of their basic freedoms, the true dimensions of the spirit have been discovered anew, those dimensions which the Church has always promoted by revealing, in Christ, man's true stature. Today as well the reawakening of many democracies is leading to dialogue and trust between peoples; and the world is coming to understand once again that man cannot live without God, without the truth that, in him, makes him free (cf. Jn 8:32) Man of our time! Christ sets you free from selfishness to call you to a spirit of sharing and to a ready and joyful commitment to others. I have been in Africa, in the Sahel, and I have seen the sand burying villages, drying up wells, burning the eyes, turning children into skeletons, paralyzing the strength of the young, as it brings desperation, starvation, sickness and death. Death from hunger and thirst. Man of today! Wealthy nations of the civilisation of opulence! Do not be indifferent to this great tragedy, be ever more urgently resolved to help those peoples who struggle each day for survival. Let yourselves be convinced that there can be no freedom, where misery continues to exist. Let human and Christian solidarity be the challenge that provokes your conscience to make that sand slowly give way to the advancement of human dignity, an abundance of bread, and the return of laughter, employment, hope and progress. Yet I thank God that I have also seen volunteers, individuals, associations and institutions, priests, religious, laity of various professions committing themselves and making sacrifices for the good of their brothers and sisters, who are most lonely and most sorely tried. I thank them in the name of the Crucified and Risen Lord! Man of our time! Christ frees you because he loves you, because he has given himself for you (cf. Gal 2:20), because he has won victory for you and for all people....

DOC.HEAD: Miss Norway Snares Miss Universe Crown
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf pvs, `The green-eyed ...' to CORRECT to 5-foot-6. Grudt is cq. The winner's name is pronounced Moo'-nah Groot.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LA4
DOC.TEXT: Miss Norway Mona Grudt has been crowned Miss Universe 1990 and wins an audition for a major Hollywood movie. The auburn-haired 19-year-old, affectionately nicknamed the ``beauty queen from Hell'' after the name of her hometown, took the top spot over 70 other contestants in the pageant Sunday night at the Shubert Theater in Century City. Miss USA was first runner-up and Miss Colombia second runner-up. Miss Grudt said she wants to work as a pediatric nurse and ``help the poor children in Africa.'' ``Now I can be ambassadoress, not just for Norway, but for the whole world,'' she said. ``I will try to make girls believe this is more than a beauty contest, and that you have to be something more than empty inside to win this.'' She said that when she called her parents in Norway with the news, ``My mother was screaming. You couldn't make sense of what she said.'' The global glamour parade featured a first-ever entry from the Soviet Union and a prize package to the winner worth $220,000. It includes an audition for a major studio film and a $40,000 personal appearance contract. The green-eyed, 5-foot-6 winner turned 19 on April 6 while preparing for the pageant. She said she is a fan of Bruce Springsteen and actress Meryl Streep. Carole Gist, a 20-year-old student from Detroit, represented the United States and was the first black American to compete in the Miss Universe pageant. She took her runner-up status with grace. ``I still get to be Miss USA for the year, and I hope to make it the best year possible,'' Miss Gist said. The second runner-up, 18-year-old Liseth Mahecha of Colombia, said through a translator, ``I'm very happy with the result _ especially because I put Colombia's name in a prominent place.'' The 39th Miss Universe pageant was televised live in the United States by CBS. An estimated 500 million viewers worldwide were expected to have tuned in. The contestants, wearing traditional garb of their homelands, opened the pageant by parading in front of a replica of the ``Hollywood'' sign in a production number done to the strains of ``Dancing in the Streets.'' Other first-place prizes included $66,000 in cash, a luxury Los Angeles apartment for the year-long reign, a convertible, a mink coat and jacket, a gold and diamond watch, and a selection of evening gowns. The winner also gets a 100-inch TV set, a portable video package, cosmetics, clothing and a camera.

DOC.HEAD: Rain Falls in Plains
DOC.TEXT: Rain dampened the northern Plains early today, hours after a tornado touched down in Texas. While much of the nation enjoyed fair weather, showers fell early today in Montana and North Dakota, and thunderstorms continued to sweep through western, central and northern Texas. Flash floods were reported in Dallas and Kaufman counties. On Sunday, a tornado touched down in west Texas near Sweetwater. No one was injured, but several homes and businesses were damaged. Baseball-size hail fell at Capps Corner, Texas, and northwest of Durant, Okla. Thunderstorms produced golf ball-size hail at Clarita and Wister in Oklahoma and Mansfield, Ark. Elsewhere Sunday, showers and thunderstorms developed over Tennessee, Kentucky and east-central Florida. Showers and thunderstorms were scattered over Colorado, Utah and Oregon. Rain dampened northwestern New York state and eastern New England. Snow fell over upper Michigan and Wisconsin. Temperatures were unseasonably high in the Northwest Sunday. The mercury rose to 85 degrees in Boise, Idaho, and 82 in Portland, Ore., both records for the date. The high for the nation Sunday was 100 at Laughlin, Nev., and Phoenix. A cold surge was expected to dip into the central Plains today. Brisk northerly winds and light rain were forecast for Wyoming. Cold rain across Nebraska could change to wet snow from late today through Tuesday morning. Today's forecast also called for rain for most of California and parts of Oregon, Illinois, Iowa and Michigan. Thunderstorms were expected to develop over Arkansas and Oklahoma. DOC.HEAD: Stocks Fall In Tokyo, Dollar Surges
DOC.TEXT: Prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange dropped sharply in thin trading today, as the dollar surged against the Japanese yen. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average, the Tokyo exchange's main index, fell 750.74 points, or 2.57 percent, to 28,463.18. Only 230 million shares changed hands on the exchange's first section, down from 320 million shares on Friday. Masahiro Umemori, an analyst for Nomura Securities, said a sprinkling of sell orders during the day over thin trading forced down the Nikkei index. He said many participants stayed on the sidelines awaiting the release of U.S. economic indicators, including the consumer price index due out on Tuesday and February trade statistics on Wednesday. As a result, he said, ``No one wants to do any buying.'' Traders said the weakening yen also discouraged market participants. Dealers and news reports earlier in the day said the Nikkei's fall was related to arbitrage selling of spot issues, but Umemori said arbitrage had only a slight impact on the market. In arbitrage trading, which has been frequently blamed for recent drops in the Tokyo Stock Exchange, traders attempt to profit from price differences between the spot and futures markets. In currency dealings, the dollar closed at 159.42 yen, up 1.00 yen from Friday's close of 158.42 yen. The U.S. currency stayed in a narrow range between 159.00 yen and 159.45 yen after opening at 159.15 yen. An analyst with New Japan Securities, speaking on condition of anonymity, said many currency traders also were awaiting U.S. trade statistics. ``There is particularly strong sentiment on the market that the trade results will be good, so dealers are trying to attain long (or strong) positions'' in the dollar, the dealer added. A trade report saying the United States had further decreased its trade deficit is likely to strengthen the dollar on currency markets. In the bond market, benchmark No. 119 10-year government bonds closed at 85.74 points, down from 85.90 at Friday's close. Their yield rose to 7.415 percent from 7.380 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Gunman Argued With Hospital Staff Before Shooting Spree
DOC.TEXT: A man who flew into a rage at a surgeon after learning his father had died on the operating table returned with a gun and opened fire in an emergency room, killing two people and wounding two, police and witnesses say. Bradford Warren Powers Jr., 46, was being held today for investigation of murder and attempted murder in the rampage Saturday at Mission Bay Memorial Hospital. He surrendered to police shortly after the shooting spree, in which a nurse and a medical trainee were killed and a doctor and a patient's father were wounded. The elder Powers had suffered an abdominal aneurysm and required emergency surgery, but his son had told doctors not to operate, saying the 75-year-old wouldn't survive the surgery because of his age and condition, said Dr. Harry Henderson, hospital chief of staff-elect. But Henderson said the man would have died without the operation. He said the surgery was successful but the elder Powers, who suffered from heart and lung ailments, died on the operating table of cardiac arrest. People who were in the emergency room when Powers was told by a surgeon that his father had died said the son became enraged. ``The surgeon came out to talk to him and he got irate. He was stomping around,'' said P.J. Ginsburg, who was being treated for burns. ``He started to yell, `What the hell's wrong with you, why didn't you treat him the first time?''' The elder Powers had been taken to the emergency room the night before for an unrelated ailment and released, Henderson said. Powers apparently left the hospital, then returned and opened fire with a handgun, police said. Deborah Burke, a nurse at the hospital for about 10 years, died after being shot once in the chest, authorities said. Edward Thomas Rooney, 30, who was studying to become an emergency medical technician and was in the emergency room as an observer, died of multiple gunshot wounds, officials said. Dr. Michael Hughes, an emergency room physician, suffered minor wounds to his abdomen and hip and was reported in good condition at Scripps Memorial Hospital, officials said. Frederick Mowrer, 38, was treated for a superficial gunshot wound to the buttocks. Mowrer, a lawyer from Albuquerque, N.M., and his wife had taken their 2-year-old daughter to the emergency room with flu symptoms. Mowrer said he tried to help the wounded before he realized the gunman was aiming at him. ``He didn't look like a crazy man,'' said Mowrer, who was wounded when he tried to run. ``I was looking at him and I saw the gun coming up. I turned to avoid him. I guess I thought I was giving him a smaller target. I didn't even know I was shot. I fell to the ground.''

DOC.HEAD: Fifth Cabbie Killed in Bronx
DOC.TEXT: Police said the fifth slaying in five weeks of a cabbie in the Bronx is not the work of a serial killer suspected in three of the shootings, but that did little to calm drivers' fears. ``I want to stop driving this month,'' said Aleou Gueyes, a driver for four years who manages Uptown Car Service in the Bronx. ``I can drive a truck.'' The latest victim, Rafael Montes De Oca, 38, was found slain Saturday night, the fifth time since March 7 that a cab driver had been fatally shot in the head at close range in the Bronx. All five had been robbed of cash. Police have said one man using a .22-caliber handgun was responsible for the first three shootings. That person phoned three Bronx car services and requested cabs, then shot and robbed the drivers. In the fourth shooting, last Tuesday, a driver who picked up a fare on the street was shot and died the next day. Witnesses saw two teen-agers flee that car. Police said that case was unrelated to the first three. Police also said the killing of Montes De Orca appeared unrelated to the first three. ``There are certain consistencies in the other cases which are not present in this one,'' said Lt. James Malvey, precinct commander. ``We became convinced there is no connection.'' Mayor David Dinkins offered a $10,000 reward on Thursday for information leading to the killers. The Guardian Angels announced that a member of the group would begin riding with drivers for two car services on their overnight runs Sunday night. ``We look upon these car services as the lifeline in these communities,'' said Lisa Sliwa, a leader of the crime-fighting group known for its red berets. ``Without them, there's no way for people like nurses who work late to get around.'' Cabbies said they are being choosier about their passengers, and companies are having trouble keeping drivers as they quit or refuse to work nights. Ten to 15 percent of Seaman Car Services' 350 drivers no longer work late hours, said Luz Rivera, a dispatcher at the company where the latest victim worked. Gueyes said he sizes up his fares and refuses to take more than one person for fear of being outnumbered. ``Sometimes when I see the people, if they don't look right, I keep on going,'' he said. ``I try not to think about it, but it's always on your mind,'' said Miguel Reyes of Amigo Car Service, a cab driver for 11 years. On Saturday, a customer who gave his name as ``George'' called Seaman Car Services and asked for Car 215, Montes De Oca's car, Rivera said. ``I told Rafael and he said, `Tell him I'll be there in 10 minutes.''' More than an hour later, a caller reported the driver appeared either unconscious or dead, Seaman president Rafael Peralta said. Montes De Oca had a pregnant wife and four children, police said.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Installs New Power Unit, Begins Charging Space Telescope Batteries
DOC.TEXT: NASA says it has completed the trickiest part of preparations for the second attempt to launch space shuttle Discovery with the Hubble Space Telescope. The space agency on Saturday removed a faulty auxiliary power unit that forced a scrub of Discovery's launch last Tuesday. A new unit was installed Sunday, the first time the procedure has been performed at the launch pad. Also on Saturday, Discovery's payload bay doors were opened and Hubble's six nickel-hydrogen batteries were removed for recharging at a laboratory. The 130-hour recharging began around noon Sunday. NASA took the batteries to the lab because they can be recharged at a cooler temperature there than at the launch pad, and thus retain more power. NASA spokesman George Diller said the weekend operations were the trickiest part of preparation for the second launch attempt. Discovery is scheduled to lift off with the $1.5 billion telescope, the space agency's most expensive payload, on April 25. ``Right now everything seems to be in the bag for a week from Wednesday,'' Diller said. The shuttle's three auxiliary power units, which weigh 88 pounds each, pressurize the hydraulic system used for braking and steering. All power units must be operating properly for a safe launch. Once in orbit, the telescope will enable astronomers to study stars and galaxies so distant that their light has been traveling toward Earth for 14 billion years.

DOC.HEAD: Swedes Remember Greta Garbo With Pride
With PM-Obit-Garbo, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: In her native country, Greta Garbo was remembered with pride today as an actress whose charisma made her ``the world's best known Swedish emigrant.'' ``I do not know what it was that made everybody turn around and keep looking at her when we entered a restaurant,'' Garbo's longtime friend Mimi Pollack said on Swedish national radio. Ms. Pollack and Garbo were fellow students at Stockholm's Royal Theater School in the early 1920s. Ms. Pollack said they had not been in touch since Garbo fell ill this winter. Swedish film professor Leif Furhammar said he remembered her as a someone ``who walks down the stairs in such a way that you cannot take your eyes off her.'' Torsten Jungstedt, a Swedish film critic, told the Swedish national news agency TT that Garbo's ``face was perfect for film. It was a close shot face with an enormous amount of life in it.'' ``Photographers said it had a light of its own,'' he said. Garbo died Sunday in a New York hospital. She was 84. She grew up in Soder, a workers' district in southern Stockholm. Director Mauritz Stiller discovered her at the Royal Theater School. Stiller and Pollack persuaded her to change her name from Greta Gustafsson to Greta Garbo. Garbo was the first of several Swedes who made international film careers, including director Ingmar Bergman, and actors Ingrid Bergman, Max von Sydow, Bibi Andersson, Anita Ekberg, and most recently Lena Olin. Stiller had gone with Garbo to Hollywood in 1925 and tried to bring her back to Sweden when he returned two years later. But she stayed on and later became an American citizen, returning to Sweden to visit only occasionally.

DOC.HEAD: Small Aftershocks Hit Upland Area
DOC.TEXT: A pair of small aftershocks to a Feb. 28 earthquake that did $10.4 million in damage jolted residents awake early today, but no injuries or damage were reported. The first aftershock struck at 1:21 a.m. and measured 3.4 on the Richter scale, said Hall Daily, spokesman for the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena. It was centered five miles northwest of Upland, he said. The second tremor struck at 1:24 a.m. and measured 2.4 on the Richter scale, Daily said. It had the same epicenter, he said. Police in Upland received several telephone calls from concerned residents who felt the first tremor, but no damage or injuries were reported, said Sgt. John Cannon. ``It was a rolling one that lasted a few seconds,'' Cannon said. ``It shook our nerves a little bit. I don't need any more of these.'' The Feb. 28 earthquake was centered in the same area as the aftershocks near Upland, which is 40 miles east of downtown Los Angeles. The quake measured 5.5 on the Richter scale and caused an estimated $10.4 million in damage, according to the state Office of Emergency Services. Today's activity could be felt in nearby Fontana, but police there also had no reports of damage or injury. ``One of the dispatchers who was awake did feel it,'' said Fontana police Lt. Terry Boess. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded by a seismograph. An earthquake of magnitude 3 can cause slight damage. A quake of magnitude 5 can cause considerable damage.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Rebuffs Soviet Complaint on Arms Proposal
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney brushed aside Soviet complaints that a new Bush administration strategic arms proposal focuses exclusively on land-based missiles, a newspaper reported today. In an interview, Cheney rebuffed a Soviet suggestion that the administration's proposal be expanded to constrain sea-based missiles, The New York Times reported in today's editions. Looking forward to new arms reductions that would follow a treaty to be signed later this year, the Bush administration has proposed a ban on all land-based missiles that carry multiple warheads. The United States has the advantage in sea- and bomber-based nuclear weapons, while the Soviet Union has more land-based missiles. Some Senate Democrats have argued that the United States should tell the Soviets it will consider cutting submarine- and bomber-based weapons after a strategic treaty is completed this year. Cheney suggested the Soviets, despite their complaints, might agree to the proposal without any guarantees on sea-based missiles or bomber weapons, the newspaper said. Many officials in the Bush administration argue there is no need to restrict sea- or air-based multiple warheads because of their comparative invulnerability to pre-emptive attack. Multiple warheads also are known as MIRVs, for multiple independently targetable re-entry vehicles. ``The argument for de-MIRVing is that land-based missiles make attractive targets. With MIRVs deployed at sea that piece of the argument goes away,'' the newspaper quoted Cheney as saying in the interview conducted last week.

DOC.HEAD: Saudis Taking New Crack at Stopping Oil Overproducers
DOC.TEXT: The Saudi oil minister today announced new efforts to bring back into line OPEC partners violating the cartel's oil production quotas and driving down prices, an official report said. It was the first official Saudi reaction to last week's wild swings in oil prices as a result of overproduction by some OPEC members. The current situation not only harms ``all producers, but ... weakens the chances of the anticipated improvement in oil prices during the second half of the current year,'' Oil Minister Hisham Nazer was quoted as saying today by the Saudi Press Agency. The official agency said Nazer will meet Kuwait's oil minister, Sheik Ali Khalifa al-Sabah, and his United Arab Emirates counterpart, Mana Saeed Otaiba, in the Red Sea port city of Jiddah on Tuesday. He said consultations with other OPEC states were aimed at restoring ``their production to the allocated ceiling,'' the agency reported. ``The kingdom hopes that these contacts will achieve their aim of restoring stability to the market.'' The U.A.E. and Kuwait, which along with Saudi Arabia are members of the 13-nation Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, are considered the two main violators of production quotas fixed by the cartel. Saudi Arabia is the cartel's leading producer. In November, OPEC set an overall production ceiling of 22 million barrels a day for the first half of this year. But OPEC countries produced about 24 million barrels a day last month, the Nicosia-based Middle East Economic Survey has reported. That was the highest monthly output since 1981, the respected oil industry newsletter said. The U.A.E. has rejected its quota of 1.1 million barrels a day and has been producing double that. Kuwait has been overshooting its quota of 1.5 million barrels a day by about 300,000 barrels. Their overproduction has been a major factor in flooding the oil market and thus forcing prices down for the first time in a year. OPEC's benchmark price is $18 a barrel, based on a basket of seven OPEC crudes. During the winter, prices shot up as high as $22 a barrel at times. However, in the recent slide, the widely-traded North Sea Brent oil, to which many OPEC crudes are linked, fell below $15 a barrel.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper: Gonzalez Says Humiliation, Not Jealousy, Prompted Fire
DOC.TEXT: Julio Gonzalez, charged with torching an illegal social club and killing 87 revelers, says he wasn't jealous of a former girlfriend but humiliated by a bouncer who had earlier kicked him out, a newspaper reported today. Gonzalez spoke from the psychiatric unit at Bellevue Hospital to New York Newsday. A friend of the Cuban emigre's was present, the newspaper said. Gonzalez, who does not speak English, was quoted by the newspaper as saying he was not angry over rejection by Lydia Feliciano, his former girlfriend, but was humiliated by the bouncer who kicked him out of the Happy Land Social Club at Feliciano's request. Gonzalez said he didn't threaten Feliciano, the newspaper said. Police have said he told his former girlfriend that night, ``You won't be here tomorrow.'' ``I never said that,'' Gonzalez told Newsday. ``I told her, `You have a lot of boyfriends now,' and she ordered them to throw me out.'' The March 25 fire at the Bronx club left 87 patrons dead. Gonzalez allegedly started the blaze with a dollar's worth of gasoline. He has pleaded innocent to 174 counts of murder, two counts of arson and other charges.

DOC.HEAD: Protesters Storm KGB Office In Armenia
DOC.TEXT: Protesters attacked a secret police office in Armenia's capital with stones and torches over the weekend, and one demonstrator was killed, the official news agency reported. In the incident, a crowd of people broke off from an environmental rally in Yerevan on Saturday night and headed for the KGB office in the southern republic, Tass reported Sunday. Tass said the crowd apparently was angered by the arrest of four Armenians on charges of stealing weapons from a military unit. The attack lasted about two hours, but the crowd was unable to get inside the building and eventually dispersed, Tass said, adding that KGB officials inside did not open fire. One person was killed when a homemade grenade he was carrying exploded, Tass said. One resident said tanks and armored personnel carriers later were deployed on the outskirts of Yerevan, but not inside the city. Eduard Shakhnazaryan of the Armenian news agency Armenpress said in a telephone interview today that authorities ``had every right to sanction opening fire and the attackers could have been shot like sitting ducks from the rooftop of KGB headquarters, but no such measure was resorted to.'' He said residents believe the attack was provoked by forces ``interested in creating chaos in the city with long-reaching consequences.'' But he did not elaborate. Shakhnazaryan said none of the attackers was arrested. Alexander Arzumanyan, a spokesman for the Armenian National Movement, said his group believed the attackers were actually plainclothes KGB agents circulating at the environmental rally to instigate the crowd of ``hot heads.'' The rally began as a protest of the Narit chemical complex, where an explosion occurred earlier in the day and spewed noxious fumes into the air, Arzumanyan said. Vladimir A. Kryuchkov, national head of the KGB, on Sunday called the attack ``an onslaught by bandits.'' In a message to the agency's Armenian branch, he praised the men inside the building for their restraint. However, the Postfactum News Agency, quoting a leader of the Armenian National Movement, reported that movement members had rushed to the scene and persuaded the protesters to leave. Since Armenia's strained relations with neighboring Azerbaijan worsened this winter and armed ethnic clashes grew common, militants have staged dozens of raids on Armenia's arms depots to obtain weapons to battle Azerbaijanis. Attacks against KGB, government and party buildings have generally increased around the southern Soviet Union in the past year. Some are aimed at taking arms from police and KGB stocks, and others have been intended to force political change.

DOC.HEAD: NAACP Trying to Change Racially Offensive Texas Names
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf, `Some of...', to CORRECT name of medal to Medal of Honor, deleting `Congressional.'
DOC.TEXT: `Negros' is cq in 5th graf, `There are ...'

``Nigger Creek'' and ``Dead Negro Draw'' should be wiped off the Texas map, says an NAACP official working to replace those and other racially offensive place names with expressions of black pride. Gary Bledsoe, NAACP Austin chapter president, said he resolved to eliminate slurs from the map during an outing two years ago, when he ran across ``Nigger Creek'' and ``Niggerhead Hill'' within an hour's drive of the Capitol. ``I couldn't believe what I saw and how totally offensive that was,'' he said recently. Many Texas locations were tagged with such names because blacks lived there at some point. Bledsoe is looking to rename 33 places. There are six ``Negro Creeks'' in Texas, a ``Negro Crossing'' near San Angelo and ``Negros Liberty Settlement,'' ``Negro Bend'' and ``Negro Gully,'' all in Liberty County east of Houston. ``Negro'' was substituted for ``nigger'' in a comprehensive 1962 name switch by the Board of Geographic Names in Reston, Va. The board is responsible for deciding which names are used on all maps produced in the United States. But Bledsoe said old maps still are in use, and official name changes don't always alter what places are called. ``It's horrible, the psychological damage that is done by naming something like that,'' Bledsoe said. ``And these were official actions.'' He consulted the librarian of the George Washington Carver branch of the Austin public library and proposed new names for the 33 sites identified in a computer search. Some of the suggested names include ``ebony'' and ``freedom.'' Others honor individuals: John Jefferson, a black-Seminole Indian scout with the U.S. Cavalry; pianist-composer Scott Joplin; Ada Smith, an Austin historian who died recently; and Milton Holland, the first black Texan to win the Medal of Honor. Bledsoe said he has the support of other Texas chapters of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. The Travis County Commissioner's Court has worked for months to change ``Nigger Creek'' and ``Niggerhead Hill'' to ``Warbler Creek'' and ``Warbler Hill.'' The proposed names are awaiting a nod from the Board of Geographic Names, which relies on community approval in deciding such requests. Mike Igau, a white man who owns the two sites, said he would like to see an end to the names that came with the ranch his family bought in 1910. ``Frankly, we never did like the designation anyway, but we never had anything to do with the naming of it,'' Igau said. ``I think we need to rename these landmarks if they're offensive to any group or person.'' He said the county's proposed names celebrate the rare golden-cheeked warbler that lives in the region. But Bledsoe wants names that promote black pride. ``There are so few state and national treasures that are named in a way that would be suggestive of black accomplishments,'' he said. The Board of Geographic Names usually approves any name with overwhelming community support, said Ernie Berringer, chief of staff for the domestic names committee. He said the panel tries to avoid common names, those of living people and names not somehow related to the area. Only two racially offensive geographic names outside of Texas have been changed in recent years, Berringer said. In Yellowstone National Park, ``Chinaman Spring'' is being changed to ``Chinese Spring.''

DOC.HEAD: Jerusalem Mayor Clarifies Position on U.S. Senate Resolution
DOC.TEXT: Jerusalem Mayor Teddy Kollek said today he fully backs the U.S. Senate resolution affirming Jerusalem as Israel's capital, contradicting remarks attributed to him by visiting Senate Republican leader Robert Dole. Dole also told a Sunday news conference at the end of an eight-day Middle East tour that he would tell the Senate he now opposes the non-binding resolution, which he originally supported when it was approved March 22. ``I conclude (the resolution) was ill-timed,'' Dole said. He said it was distracting attention in the Arab world from the peace process. Dole said Sunday that Kollek agreed the timing was bad and that it served no useful purpose. But Kollek said today that the resolution had come up during talks with Dole in the context of an earlier congressional resolution recommending that the U.S. Embassy be moved to Jerusalem. Despite the earlier resolution, the United States, like most other Western nations, still maintains its embassy in Tel Aviv. Kollek said he told Dole ``my concern was that the present resolution ... would not be acted upon by the administration.'' He added: ``But this in no way detracts from the importance which I attach to this decision of the majority of the Senate. Rescinding the resolution now would only encourage Arab extremism and harm the peace process.'' The Senate resolution said: ``Jerusalem is and should remain the capital of the state of Israel.'' It was enacted shortly after President Bush said he objected to settling Soviet immigrant Jews in Arab east Jerusalem, which was annexed by Israel after it was captured from Jordan in the 1967 Middle East war. The United States has repeatedly said that the status of Jerusalem should be negotiated with Palestinians, who have demanded that it be the capital of their would-be independent state. Dole also told reporters Sunday that the United States has to take care of its own homeless before granting Israel's request for loan guarantees to house Soviet Jewish immigrants. ``Charity starts at home and that means America,'' the Kansas Republican told the news conference. ``We are going to give $400 million to Israel for housing guarantees when we have 3 million homeless in America and no program for them?'' Others in the Senate delegation were James McClure, R-Idaho; Alan Simpson, R-Wyo.; Frank Murkowski, R-Alaska; and Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio. The group visited Egypt, Syria, Jordan, Iraq and Israel before leaving for Washington on Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanians Meet on Gorbachev Ultimatum
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 12 grafs to UPDATE with Lithuanian meeting, capital reported quiet. Pickup 11th graf `Lithuania declared...'
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania's leadership today discussed what to do about a Kremlin threat to cut off crucial supplies to the Baltic republic for ignoring a deadline to repeal laws that break with Moscow. As the 48-hour deadline set by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev expired Sunday night, the republic's deputy prime minister, Romualdas Ozolas, went on Lithuanian television to urge its 3.8 million people to brace for a ``hectic'' week. Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis, Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene and members of the Cabinet and parliamentary leadership discussed ``a plan of economic measures'' in the face of an embargo by the Kremlin, Vilnius Radio said. Such an embargo would include cutting off the supply of oil and natural gas that the republic buys only from Moscow at subsidized prices. The capital of Vilnius was quiet today as the predominantly Roman Catholic republic celebrated the final day of a three-day Easter weekend. Most factories and businesses were closed, according to a worker in the information office of the Supreme Council, Lithuania's parliament. The full parliament is to meet Tuesday. Ozolas also said that Lithuania and Estonia planned to exchange ambassadors today, according to Aidas Palubinskas of the Lithuanian Parliament's information office. Landsbergis repeatedly has said Lithuania would not abandon its drive to restore the independence lost when, with fellow Baltic states Latvia and Estonia, it was forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940. Gorbachev demanded Friday that Lithuania's leaders rescind ``anti-constitutional'' actions promoting independence or face an economic embargo. That includes canceling conscription into the Soviet army and seizing Communist Party property. The Soviet president threatened to cut off products the Soviet Union sells abroad for hard currency if the republic's leaders failed to act by Sunday. He did not specify the materials, but they include oil and gas. There was no immediate word from the Kremlin today on the threatened embargo. In Washington on Sunday, Senate leaders of both parties warned Gorbachev that carrying out his threat could hurt efforts to improve trade relations between the United States and Moscow. Lithuania declared its independence from the Soviet Union on March 11 and has been locked in tense confrontation with the Kremlin, which has alternated between making threats and conciliatory statements. Soviet troops have occupied some buildings in the capital of Vilnius and conscripts who deserted the Red Army have been seized and beaten. Gorbachev also demanded that Lithuanians turn in their firearms, and the Soviet military asserted itself by sending armored personnel carriers through Vilnius. Palubinskas said Lithuania's factories would be able to function for only about two weeks if Moscow imposed an embargo. He said Ozolas advised his compatriots to rest up, ``because this week doesn't promise to be any less hectic _ but by next weekend we'll be happy by what we've accomplished.'' The spokesman said the Lithuanians consider Gorbachev to have softened his stance, appearing to back away from an earlier demand that Lithuania rescind its declaration of independence. Earlier in the day, the leader of Lithuania's Roman Catholics told worshipers in Vilnius to keep a ``cool head'' but stand tough, a resident said. Speaking at an Easter Mass with Landsbergis sitting in the front pew, Cardinal Vincentas Skadkevicius urged the population of the Baltic republic to stay calm, said Eduard Potashinskas of Lithuanian TV. In Washington, Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, and Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., said retaliation by Moscow against Lithuania would jeopardize a trade agreement President Bush and Gorbachev hoped to sign at a summit in June. Lithuanian officials have acknowledged that an embargo of materials such as oil and gas could cause mass layoffs in the republic of 3.8 million people but said they hoped sympathetic Soviet republics would not cut off crucial supplies. Lines at gas stations in Vilnius were a little longer than usual on Sunday as people reacted to the threat, Palubinskas said. Besides oil and gas, the Baltic republic also depends on the Soviet Union for metal, machinery, chemicals, cotton and automobiles. At least four other Soviet republics are now controlled by progressives who have indicated support for Lithuania's bid for independence, and some Lithuanians said they were hoping for holes in Gorbachev's embargo. ``We don't think individual republics will go along with this, especially republics like Azerbaijan and Georgia, which want independence,'' said Palubinskas. Prunskiene said the republic had stepped up efforts to establish economic ties with the West and was negotiating with West Germany and Switzerland to print Lithuanian money in case of an embargo, the official Soviet news agency Tass reported Saturday. Latvia and Estonia are also pressing for independence, though more cautiously than Lithuania. On Friday, they signed an economic cooperation agreement with Lithuania that promises mutual aid in emergencies. Palubinskas voiced confidence that the Kremlin would not be able to starve Lithuania into submission, because the republic produces more meat and milk than it consumes.

DOC.HEAD: Hawaii Sen. Spark Matsunaga Dead of Cancer at Age 73
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to add further background on Senate career, other detail, CLARIFY that payments to camp internees have not begun yet. Picks up 10th graf pvs, `Gov. John...'.
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Spark Matsunaga, who engineered passage of legislation paying $1.25 billion in compensation to Japanese-Americans interned in U.S. prison camps during World War II, has died at age 73. The Democrat died Sunday at a hospital in Toronto after a fight against cancer. The son of immigrants from Japan, Matsunaga was a U.S. Army veteran of World War II. He was first elected to the House in 1962 and the Senate in 1976. In 1988, he won passage of a law that pays $20,000 to each surviving Japanese-American interned during the war. Matsunaga had to overcome opposition from some veterans and from those who objected to the cost of the bill. During debate, the senator was forced to halt his comments in midsentence while telling of an elderly internee killed by a guard as he went to pick up a softball. ``I myself become overly emotional when I think about it even to this day,'' he said after regaining his composure. The first payments under the program are set to begin late this year. Matsunaga was a highly decorated veteran of the war. He was a member of the 100th Infantry Battalion, which became part of the ``Go for Broke'' 442nd Regimental Combat Team, the most decorated regiment in U.S. history. He was a graduate of the University of Hawaii and had a law degree from Harvard. Before entering Congress, Matsunaga was a member of Hawaii's territorial House from 1954 to 1959, the year Hawaii became a state. In the Senate, he also served as the second-ranking Democrat on the Finance Committee and chairman of its subcommittee on taxation and debt management. He used those assignments to protect tax advantages to industries important to the Hawaiian economy, including tourism, pineapples and alternative energy sources. He also served on the Labor and Human Resources and Veterans' Affairs committees. Matsunaga lobbied for 22 years before persuading Congress in 1984 to establish a U.S. Peace Institute. ``Peacemaking is as much an art to be learned as war'' was his persistent argument. Perhaps no other member of the Senate in recent years had been so attentive to visiting constituents. Almost daily, Matsunaga could be seen entertaining Hawaiians at lunch in a Senate dining room. Gov. John Waihee, a Democrat, will name a successor to Matsunaga to serve until a special election in November. Matsunaga's term runs through 1994. Rep. Daniel K. Akaka, a Democrat elected to the House in 1976, is considered the leading choice to succeed Matsunaga. Matsunaga's body was to be taken to the state Capitol atrium for viewing. Services were set for Wednesday and a private burial was scheduled for Thursday. Matsunaga had been plagued by medical ailments, including a heart attack in 1984, a stomach ulcer in 1987, a serious bout with the flu and back problems in 1988. He announced in January he had prostate cancer that had spread to the bone. He is survived by his wife, Helene, and five children.

DOC.HEAD: The Party's Over: Weary Youths Head Home From Spring Break In Palm Springs
DOC.TEXT: Weary spring break revelers headed home Sunday after more than a week of partying that landed some in the hospital, hundreds in jail and included more than a thousand arrests. ``Everybody's checked out in the first few hours or so. They had three or four days of partying and they're pretty bushed,'' said Erich Langmann, owner of the Travelodge hotel. ``The place looks like a ghost town.'' Police made 1,348 arrests since the festivities began April 6, said police Lt. Lee Weigle. He said 719 people were booked into jail, including 457 accused of being drunk in public. More than 6,100 citations also were issued charging violations ranging from having open alcohol containers in public to breaking noise limits. Hundreds of visitors were treated at Desert Hospital of Palm Springs for injuries ranging from cuts and bruises to broken limbs, nursing supervisor Jan Taylor said. One man, Paul Williams, 20, of Thousand Oaks, was in serious condition today at the hospital. He was one of two men who were struck by a Jeep early Saturday as they crossed a street, Weigle said. The other man was treated for minor injuries and released. The driver, James Dalton, 34, of Rowland Heights, was arrested for investigation of felony drunk driving, Weigle said. During the week-long invasion, the town swelled with an estimated 60,000 visitors. They cruised the main strip of Palm Canyon Drive and left it littered with soda cans, beer bottles and other trash. As the revelry subsided, police ended 12-hour shifts that cost the city $350,000 in overtime, Weigle said. Police began stepping up security measures after a spring-break riot in 1986, when some students went on a rampage, harassing motorists, pulling clothing off women and hurling bottles and rocks at police.

DOC.HEAD: Clashes On Anniversary of PLO Leader's Death
DOC.TEXT: Israeli soldiers today fired plastic bullets or used tear gas to break up protests in at least three towns on the occupied West Bank, as Palestinians marked the second anniversary of the slaying of a PLO leader. Three Palestinians were wounded in the clashes, according to Arab reports, and the army said one soldier was slightly injured. Memorial parades and protests were reported in a half dozen towns and refugee camps in the occupied West Bank on the anniversary of the 1988 slaying of Khalil Wazir, the Palestine Liberation Organization's military commander. Wazir, better known as Abu Jihad, Arabic for ``father of war,'' was killed in a commando raid in Tunis. The death was blamed on Israel, but the government has never acknowledged responsibility. To head off violence today, the army imposed a curfew and ordered the 700,000 Palestinian residents of the occupied Gaza Strip confined to their homes. In one clash in the West Bank city of Nablus, soldiers opened fire with plastic bullets, wounding two Palestinians, Arab reports said. A 23-year-old Palestinian also was reported shot in clashes with soldiers in the West Bank village of Beita. Also in Nablus, an Israeli soldier was slightly injured in the right leg when a concrete block was dropped from a rooftop as he patrolled the crowded central market, the army spokesman's office and Arab reports said. In the West Bank city of Hebron, police used tear gas and rubber bullets to break up a demonstration by Palestinian youths, who blocked roads with rocks and burning tires. At least 10 youths were arrested, Arab reporters said. Meanwhile, in Arab east Jerusalem, a half-dozen Palestinian youths, their faces covered with masks and checkered Arab scarves, ran along the main shopping street and smashed the windows of at least five cars. One of the masked men jumped on the hood of a car and kicked in its windshield. Several tires were set ablaze, and at least two police vans were stoned, Arab witnesses said. After the incident, police closed the Arab-owned shops along the street. Witnesses said two youths were arrested. Tension has been heightened in Jerusalem since the settlement last week of 150 Jews in the center of the Arab Christian Quarter of the Old City. There have been at least four demonstrations by Palestinians and liberal Jews since a 72-room complex was taken over by the Jewish settlers last Wednesday. The Greek Orthodox Church, which owns the building, has gotten a court order to have the settlers evicted, but they appealed. Elsewhere, residents of the West Bank town of Tulkarem observed 10 minutes of silence at mid-morning today in Abu Jihad's memory, local reporters said. In the Balata refugee camp outside Nablus, about 500 Palestinian students marched in memory of the slain PLO leader. Israeli troops ordered merchants to close their shops in the market town of Ramallah north of Jerusalem after slogans were painted on walls saying ``We are all Abu Jihads.'' The highest death toll for one day in the 28-month-old Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation came immediately after the 1988 slaying of Wazir. His death set off riots that left 17 Palestinians dead. Since the start of the uprising, 673 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians. An additional 207 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaboration with Israel. Forty-three Israelis have died in the violence.

DOC.HEAD: Subway Gunman Still Missing; Police Seek Wallet
DOC.TEXT: Police scrabbled through subway-stop garbage cans looking for the wallet of a gray-haired man who they say shot and killed his alleged mugger on a train. The search continued today for clues that would help identify the victim who pulled a gun and fired after he was beaten and robbed by a group of four men on a train in Brooklyn. Melvin Kirkland, 17, of Brooklyn, who police say was one of the attackers, was charged with robbery and assault in the Thursday incident. No one else had been charged, police said today. Witnesses told police the gray-haired man fired three times, hitting and killing Ricky Pickett, a 25-year-old Brooklyn man with six robbery convictions on his record. The victim left the train at the next stop and disappeared. He has ignored police pleas to surface. Officers continued searching garbage cans and subway stations Sunday for the gunman's wallet, although they were not certain it had been stolen, said Officer Hugh Barry, a police spokesman. Kirkland handed over a silver handgun allegedly used by the attackers, police said. The attackers were also armed with a retractable razor, police said. They were among a group of more than a dozen men who were smoking marijuana and drinking brandy inside the subway before the assault. The shooter is not the only man still at large after killing a mugger on a train. The ``Subway Samaritan'' disappeared after fatally stabbing a man who was robbing another subway rider Dec. 9. The Samaritan has never been identified. Bernhard Goetz received national attention after shooting four youths on a subway train on Dec. 22, 1984. Police said the incidents differed because Goetz was not attacked before he fired; Goetz said he believed he was being threatened.

DOC.HEAD: New Mexico Mayor Targeted for Recall Over Liquor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf `Munoz, who..,', to restore dropped word, `was.'
DOC.TEXT: Voters were asked to recall Mayor Ed Munoz today for waging a campaign against alcohol abuse that his chief critic says has the rest of the country convinced Gallup is ``nothing but a town of drunks.'' Munoz, 62, earlier this year threatened to put up billboards warning motorists at the Arizona line that they were entering the nation's drunken driving capital.
