The billboard had a car traveling on a road paved with skulls. ``The rest of the country now thinks this is nothing but a town of drunks,'' said Linda Tilley, leader of the recall effort and a part-time waitress and bartender at several nightspots. ``We have a Skid Row just like every other city, but our problem isn't any worse.'' Munoz, who was mayor from 1958 through 1969 and is in the middle of his second consecutive two-year term, blamed the recall effort on the liquor industry. ``They have their backs up against the wall and this is their last attempt to stop what's happening in McKinley County from spreading to the rest of the state,'' he said. The National Institute on Alcoholism and Alcohol Abuse said the area's rate of alcohol-related deaths per 100,000 people was nearly six times the U.S. average from 1975 to 1979. In 1987, New Mexico was the per-capita leader in traffic deaths. Gallup adjoins the nation's largest Indian tribe, the Navajos. Since alcohol is prohibited on the reservation, any drinking is done in Gallup or other border cities, and Gallup's population can double or even triple during the day. Gallup, population 22,000, in 1988 reported 26,222 instances of people thrown into the police ``drunk tank'' to sober up, a significant share of them Indians. Munoz and other officials want to start an alcoholism treatment center. He made his billboard threat after legislation to reform liquor laws stalled in the Legislature. He later withdrew his plan, saying he merely wanted to get legislators' attention. Ms. Tilley said she began the recall drive on other issues, such as Munoz's alleged efforts to use his position to help friends. The billboard threat was the clincher, she said. Supporters of the recall effort say the city also has lost its tourist appeal because Munoz brought national attention to Gallup's alcohol problem. ``If you're having a problem with your wife, you're not going to go down and buy a front page ad,'' said Tilley. ``You try to resolve it.'' About 165,000 of the Navajo tribe's 200,000 members live on the 125,000-square-mile reservation that covers parts of Utah, Arizona and New Mexico. The smaller Zuni Pueblo, also near Gallup, has about 9,000 members.

DOC.HEAD: Court Leaves Intact Ban on School Dances in Missouri Town
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today left intact a ban on school dances in a Missouri town inhabited largely by Christian fundamentalists. The court, without comment, rejected arguments that the ban imposed by public school officials is religiously motivated and therefore violates the constitutionally required separation of church and state. The longtime no-dance rule in rural Purdy, Mo., was upheld by a three-judge panel of the 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals last September. In November, the full appeals court voted 5-4 not to review the panel's decision. But dissenting judges called the ban ``religious tyranny'' that violates the rights of students wishing to hold school-sponsored dances. Officials are not sure when the ban on school dances was adopted, but fundamentalist ministers in the town long have preached against social dancing, calling it ``satanic'' and ``sinful.'' When the ban was challenged in 1986, ministers from five fundamentalist churches led the opposition to its repeal. More than 250 people attended a school board meeting in March 1986 and most stood in unison to signify their opposition to relaxing the rule. Parents and students who want to change the rule sued, and a federal judge declared the regulation unconstitutional. But the ruling was overturned by the three-judge 8th Circuit court panel. The panel, in an opinion written by Judge George G. Fagg, said, ``Any arguably religious effect of the rule is indirect, remote and incidental.'' It added: ``The mere fact a governmental body takes action that coincides with the principles or desires of a particular religious group ... does not transform the action into an impermissible establishment of religion.'' The ruling was criticized sharply by four 8th Circuit judges who later tried unsuccessfully to overturn the panel's decision. Judge John R. Gibson, writing for the four, said, ``The school board was motivated by religious purposes. This is a case about religious tyranny.'' He said, ``In the overall scheme of things, a dance at Purdy High School, with an enrollment of 519, may not be of earth-shattering signficance. Yet, our Constitution protects all citizens ... from religious ... oppression by a majority.'' Gibson also said the three-judge panel missed the point in describing dancing as a secular, non-religious activity. ``The true issue in the case is whether the no-dance rule has a secular purpose,'' he said. Another dissenter, Chief Judge Donald R. Lay, said the panel ruling could be ``a devious springboard for further destruction of the wall separating church and state.'' The Missouri School Boards Association and the Missouri Association of School Administrators urged the justices to leave the ban intact. The groups said local school boards should be allowed to regulate ``the extracurricular use of facilities that is neutral toward religion and which is consistent with the shared values of the communities.'' The case is Clayton vs. Place, 89-1348.

DOC.HEAD: Blaze Blackens 600 Acres of Los Padres National Forest in California
DOC.TEXT: Light rain helped firefighters battling a 600-acre blaze today in the Los Padres National Forest that apparently was started by an abandoned campfire, authorities said. Firefighters had contained 85 percent of the blaze, said Earl Clayton of the U.S. Forest Service. They expected to have it fully surrounded by this evening and controlled by Tuesday evening, he said. No buildings were damaged. Investigators concluded that an abandoned campfire sparked the fire Friday afternoon in Hungry Valley State Park, which abuts the forest, he said. They were trying to determine who may have been at the site, he said. About 280 firefighters were on the line today in the area 25 miles northeast of Ventura. One firefighter suffered a minor leg injury, another was overcome by heat exhaustion and a third was treated for a bee sting, Clayton said. The blaze broke out in 4,000-foot terrain so steep that bulldozers and engines couldn't be used. Crews were ferried in by helicopter, and some hiked in three miles on Saturday. Stands of pinon and juniper in the area were tinder-dry from the state's fourth year of drought. Authorities have said the fire danger is the worst it has been in decades. Firefighters from the U.S. Forest Service, Los Angeles and Ventura county fire departments, U.S. Bureau of Land Management, California Department of Forestry and the Los Angeles Fire Department were on the scene.

DOC.HEAD: Court Refuses to Make New York Compensate Former Nursing Home Owners
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to make New York compensate the former owners of a Buffalo nursing home forced by the state to remain open even though it was losing money. The court, without comment, let stand a ruling that the state's ordering the home's owners to keep it open when they wanted to shut it down did not amount to a ``taking'' of private property. The Constitution allows government, through eminent domain, to take private property for public use but requires that ``just compensation'' be paid. At issue in the Buffalo case was whether a temporary taking occurred when Abbott Manor Nursing Home's owners were forced by state officials to absorb about $30,000 in monthly operating losses for three years. The New York Court of Appeals, the state's highest court, ruled last June 8 that no taking occurred. The June ruling overturned lower court decisions that there had been a taking, and that the state owed Abbott Manor's owners $542,000. Before his death in early 1976, Bernard P. Birnbaum owned and operated Abbott Manor, which had some 80 residents. At the time of his death, the home was losing between $20,000 and $30,000 each month. As co-executor of his brother's estate, Saul Birnbaum notified state officials about Bernard's death. The state position was that the home could not be closed because no alternate facilities were available. After failed negotiations with state officials, the estate announced that all Abbott Manor residents would be removed by Sept. 7, 1976. State officials, however, obtained a court order blocking the home's closing and the removal of its residents. Two of the home's employees were appointed as receivers in charge of operations, but the Birnbaum estate was forced to pay all costs. The receivership was not ended until Sept. 14, 1979, after all Abbott Manor residents had been placed in other facilities. In the appeal acted on today, lawyers for the Birnbaum family argued that ``requiring a private business to remain in operation and to bear substantial operating losses, without providing just compensation ... is precisely the kind of harm'' the Constitution prohibits. The case is Birnbaum vs. New York, 89-1108.

DOC.HEAD: Court Blocks Sales of Hare Krishna Temples in California Case
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today blocked temporarily the sales of five Hare Krishna temples to satisfy a $5 million judgment against the religious sect. The justices, granting an emergency request by the Krishnas, ordered the sales postponed until they consider a formal appeal in the case. The Krishnas had filed the request with Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, saying emergency help was needed ``to save (their) religion from destruction.'' O'Connor referred the request to the full court. The International Society of Krishna Consciousness and two Krishna officials were sued successfully by a mother and daughter, Marcia and Robin George of Cypress, Calif. Their lawsuit alleged that Robin had been brainwashed by the Krishnas when she was 14 and that Krishna leaders conspired to keep her away from her parents. A California jury in 1983 awarded the Georges $32.5 million in damages against the Krishnas, but the award was reduced on appeal to $2.9 million. With interest, the judgment today is estimated to be in excess of $5 million. A state judge last month ordered that five Krishna temples already placed under court supervision, including the religion's headquarters in Los Angeles, be sold and the proceeds be paid to the Georges. Four California courts, including the state Supreme Court, refused to block that order. The state Supreme Court refused last Novebmer to review the award, and the Krishnas filed an appeal with the nation's highest court Feb. 28. The sales presumably would be unnecessary if the judgment is paid before they occur. Lawyers for the Georges, urging the justices to reject the emergency request, said no immediate court action is required because ``it will be almost months before the sale of any assets ... can occur.'' They added, ``There is no reliable evidence in the record to support (the Krishnas') allegation concerning the financial hardships which will befall them if the stay is not granted.'' Miss George and a friend, 16-year-old Caron Dempsey, visited a Hare Krishna temple in Laguna Beach, Calif., for the first time in 1974 at Miss Dempsey's suggestion. Miss Dempsey later decided to join the religious sect, and persuaded Miss George to attend meetings at the temple. By the fall of 1974, Miss George was wearing a sari while attending school and chanting and praying at a Hindu-style altar in her bedroom. According to court documents, a Krishna official told Miss George to leave her home and live at a temple. She did, spending time at Hare Krishna temples in Laguna Beach, San Diego, New Orleans and Ottawa, Canada. The Georges' lawsuit alleged that Krishna officials conspired to keep Miss George from her parents, who learned of her whereabouts in late 1975 only after Miss Dempsey left the religion and told them. In the still-pending appeal filed with the justices in February, lawyers for the Krishnas said the award won by the Georges amounts to religious bigotry. ``For the first time in this country since the anti-Mormon frenzy of the 19th Century, an entire religion stands subject to destruction and the confiscation of its property at the hands of the state,'' the appeal says. It adds: ``The proceeding below turned into a trial of what (the Georges') counsel called the `pernicious evil' of the Krishna Consciousness religion, and ... the jury awarded damages ... calculated to bring the religion in this country to an end.'' The case is International Society for Krishna Consciousness vs. Robin and Marcia George, A-682.

DOC.HEAD: Court Says American Jewel Thieves Must Stay in British Prison
DOC.TEXT: Two men convicted of a famous London jewel robbery who want to be moved from a British prison to one in this country lost a Supreme Court appeal today. The court, without comment, let stand a ruling that spared the U.S. attorney general from adopting rules that could have led to the prison transfers. Jerome Scalise and Arthur Rachel are U.S. citizens convicted in the $3.6 million holdup of a London jewelry store in 1980. Their haul included the famous Marlborough diamond. Authorities said the jewels have not been recovered. Scalise and Rachel began serving 15-year prison terms Aug. 6, 1984. They are eligible for release in July 1993. The United States and Great Britain ratified a treaty in 1985 that permits prisoners in each nation to be transferred to their homeland. Scalise and Rachel sued in federal court in the United States, seeking to compel former Attorney General Edwin Meese III to transfer them home and to adopt guidelines governing prisoner transfers between Great Britain and the United States. Meese and his successor, Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, refused to adopt such rules or grant the wish of the two men to return home. A federal judge ordered the adoption of the guidelines, but that ruling was overturned last December by the 7th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. The appeals court acknowledged that the treaty is intended to help rehabilitate prisoners by letting them return to their homeland and be closer to family and friends. But it ruled that such decisions should be left to the attorney general without judicial second-guessing. The case is Scalise vs. Thornburgh, 89-1478.

DOC.HEAD: Court Says Government Doesn't Have to Reveal Information on Retirees
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to order the government to reveal the names and addresses of retired or disabled federal workers. The court, without comment, rejected an appeal by an organization seeking to use the information to recruit new members in its campaign for increased benefits for retirees. The National Association of Retired Federal Employees used to have an agreement with the federal Office of Personnel Management that helped the association's drive for new members. The agency from 1979 to 1981 permitted the association to send information packets to newly retired federal workers through an independent mailing service. The association was not given the names or addresses until recipients of the packets expressed an interest in joining. After the Office of Personnel Management ended the arrangement, the association sought to obtain the names and addresses under the Freedom of Information Act. A federal judge ruled in favor of the association, but the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals here overturned that ruling last July. The appeals court said revealing the names and addresses of retired and disabled workers would violate their privacy. The appeals court said that if the association is allowed to have the names, there would be no basis under the Freedom of Information Act to withhold the names from others who seek them. ``Any business or fund-raising organization for which such individuals might be an attractive market could get from the government, at nominal cost, a list of prime sales prospects to solicit,'' the appeals court said. ``Business people will not overlook an opportunity to get cheaply from the government what otherwise comes dearly.'' By contrast, the appeals court said the retirees association failed to show there is a public interest in revealing the names and addresses. ``Even a modest privacy interest outweighs nothing every time,'' the appeals court said. The association said the appeals court misinterpreted the Freedom of Information Act, a 1966 law aimed at curtailing government secrecy. The association said Congress intended that such lists be provided ``unless release would constitute a clearly unwarranted invasion of privacy.'' Justice Department lawyers urged the high court to reject the association's appeal. The case is National Association of Retired Federal Employees vs. Newman, 89-1098.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Will Attempt Shuttle Launch Next Week
DOC.TEXT: The ailing hydraulic power plant that stopped the liftoff of space shuttle Discovery last week was replaced over the weekend and preparations are on schedule for another launch attempt April 25, NASA said today. As the exchange was being made at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida, workmen removed the batteries on Discovery's $1.5 billion payload, the Hubble Space Telescope, and began 130 hours of recharging. The nickel-hydrogen batteries, which run the telescope until its solar panels are extended, can receive a 20 percent higher charge in a cold environment than they could on the launch pad.

DOC.HEAD: Screen Legend Greta Garbo Dead at 84
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 12th graf, `I think..', with 2 grafs to add comment from film director Fellini. Picks up 13th graf, `She never...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY5,6,7,8
DOC.TEXT: Greta Garbo, the husky-voiced, Swedish-born screen legend who turned her back on Hollywood in 1941 to live according to her best-remembered line _ ``I vant to be alone'' _ is dead at 84. The reclusive Garbo died Sunday, said Andrew Banoff, spokesman for New York Hospital. At her family's request, Banoff gave no other information except that donations should be made to a kidney treatment center at the hospital. Ben Buttenweiser, who lived in an apartment below Garbo's, said the actress had undergone dialysis treatment. With her sculpted beauty, Garbo first gained attention in silent films. When talkies came along, Hollywood worried that her accent and throaty voice would end her career, but they only enhanced her appeal, and she became an international sensation with such films as ``Anna Christie,'' ``Mata Hari,'' ``Grand Hotel'' and ``Queen Christina.'' She reigned in Hollywood in the '30s. Public response to her face and her lithe figure in silky halter gowns was so frenzied that the phenomenon had a name: ``Garbomania.'' Some critics considered her the finest screen actress of all time. But Garbo disliked the attention and quit at age 36, her 24 films keeping her name alive for generations. While ``Camille'' and ``Ninotchka'' became film festival standards, the woman known worldwide simply as Garbo remained practically shuttered in her Manhattan apartment, where she moved after becoming a U.S. citizen in 1951, or in various retreats in France and Switzerland. When she traveled, she slipped in and out of airports in dark glasses and a slouch hat. ``Garbo watchers'' would wait hours outside her apartment, hoping to catch a glimpse of her. Photographers who stalked her occasionally stole a quick shot of ``The Face.'' In ``Grand Hotel,'' one of her lines was, ``I vant to be alone.'' Legend has it she used it on reporters who dogged her. But she denied it, telling a friend she actually had said, ``I want to be let alone.'' Nominated four times for an Academy Award, she didn't win until 1955, when the Academy gave her a special Oscar for ``a series of luminous and unforgettable performances.'' Garbo did not appear to collect it. ``As an actress and as a person she had this very special thing about her that I think sort of set her apart,'' actor Jimmy Stewart said. ``It was a combination of the way she looked, her voice and the beautiful way she moved.'' ``She was always a living, unreachable myth ... the founder of a religious order called cinema,'' Italian director Federico Fellini said. ``She gave cinema the sacredness of Mass,'' he told the Italian news agency ANSA. She never married, but rumors of her love affairs with rich and famous men were abundant. Over the years, she was linked with actor John Gilbert, maestro Leopold Stokowski and Russian-born entrepreneur George Schlee. In comments published in Life magazine in 1989, Garbo described herself as a ``sour little creature.'' ``I don't want any kind of attention from anybody, except that I know that someone likes me, and that's nice. Otherwise, it's sickening,'' she said. In the rare interviews she gave, she said ``you cheapen yourself'' in telling others ``your private joys and sorrows.'' She said she preferred to let her work speak for itself. Neighbor Buttenweiser, who said he knew Garbo for 35 years, said he sometimes discussed world developments with her but that she would not talk about her film career. Carl Peterson, a doorman in her building, said he last saw her last week. ``She had gray hair and was very thin. She looked very pathetic,'' he said. Born Greta Lovisa Gustafsson in Stockholm, Garbo was the daughter of an uneducated laborer who was often ill or unemployed. After her father died when she was 14, she left school and earned $25 a month as a department store clerk. While clerking, she was chosen to appear in a filmed hat advertisement. The 17-year-old was stagestruck and enrolled in Stockholm's Royal Dramatic Theater Academy. She won several small parts, the first in a 1923 comedy, ``Peter the Tramp.'' Her big break came when Mauritz Stiller, then Sweden's leading director, made her his protege, changed her name to Garbo and cast her as the star of his 1924 movie ``The Saga of Gosta Berling.'' At first sight of Garbo on film, Stiller said, ``Her face. You only get a face like that in front of a camera once in a century.'' Stiller's film caught the attention of Hollywood tycoon Louis B. Mayer, who offered the director a contract at MGM. Stiller agreed on condition Garbo be signed too. For her first talking picture, the studio cast her in ``Anna Christie,'' which called for an accent. Publicity slogans proclaimed, ``Garbo Talks!'' Later, the comedy ``Ninotchka'' prompted marquees across America to blaze ``Garbo Laughs!'' But her next attempt at a humorous role, in ``Two-Faced Woman,'' flopped and Garbo announced her retirement. Film buffs can recite her first lines on camera: ``Gimme a viskey _ ginger ale on the side _ and don't be stingy, baby.'' A millionaire through wise investing, Garbo _ who reportedly was earning $250,000 to $300,000 a picture by the 1930s _ had no need to work again and never did. A health buff, she was rarely ill. The hospital spokesman said he didn't know who the family members were who requested details of her death be withheld, but neighbors said she had a niece. He said services would be private.

DOC.HEAD: Aquino Confirms British Troops Training Filipinos
DOC.TEXT: President Corazon Aquino confirmed today that British troops are training Filipino security forces, after renegade officers promised to attack what they called British mercenaries in the army. Last week, the Young Officers Union, a shadowy group believed linked to December's failed coup, claimed British mercenaries were training Philippine forces in ``a clear violation of Philippine sovereignty.'' Asked about the claim, Mrs. Aquino said there were no mercenaries training her forces. ``However, there is a team of British military engaged in training the PSG (Presidential Security Group) on military activities, and this was done at the request of the Philippine government,'' she added. The British Embassy was closed today for the Easter holidays. The Presidential Security Force guards Mrs. Aquino and foreign dignitaries. The Union warning was the first directed against the British since the Dec. 1-9 failed coup, in which 113 people were killed and more than 600 wounded. Rebel soldiers have frequently warned the United States to avoid ``meddling'' in Philippine affairs after U.S. jets flew air cover for government forces during the coup attempt. The failed coup was the sixth and bloodiest bid so far to oust Mrs. Aquino. A fugitive ex-army officer suspected of playing a leading role in December's coup attempt said in an interview that mutineers gone into hiding will not surrender ``until this government shapes up.'' Former Lt. Col. Gregorio Honasan did not specify what changes he wanted but criticized alleged corruption and incompetence. ``It (the December coup attempt) may have failed tactically or it may have been a setback tactically. But you have to agree that just like August in 1987, it has really jolted this administration into, for once ... (setting) directions,'' Honasan said. ``That's all we ask,'' Honasan added. ``And then we can probably surrender. And then you can save on the 5 million on my head,'' Honasan said in an interview for the U.S. Cable News Network. Portions of the interview were carried today by the Manila Times newspaper and a private television station Channel 7. He was referring to the 5 million peso ($227,000) reward offered by the government for information leading to his arrest. Honasan initially supported Mrs. Aquino when she came to power during the 1986 ``people power'' revolution. Mrs. Aquino dismissed Honasan's statement, saying he was merely repeating criticism of her government that he has made since breaking away. In another development, the military announced today that 18 more communist rebels were killed in an air assault on 300 New People's Army guerrillas who surrounded a 100-man army patrol Friday on the central island of Negros. The latest casualties bring to 81 the number of rebels killed since the military launched an offensive on March 29, the 21st anniversary of the founding of the New People's Army, said Brig. Gen. Raymundo Jarque, the Negros military commander. No casualties on the government side were reported. The New People's Army, the military wing of the outlawed Communist Party, has been waging an insurgency to establish a Marxist state in the Philippines.

DOC.HEAD: Court to Decide Pension Issue in Texas Case
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to decide whether workers may sue in state courts when they allege their employers fired them to avoid paying pension benefits. With millions of dollars at stake, the court said it will use a Texas case to decide whether such state lawsuits are precluded by a federal law protecting pension benefits. The court is expected to rule sometime in 1991. The justices agreed to hear an appeal by Ingersoll-Rand Co., which was sued by fired sales representative Perry McClendon. McClendon was transferred by the company from San Antonio to Dallas in 1979 to develop a sales market there for the company's construction equipment. He was fired on Nov. 19, 1982, four months before his 10th anniversary with the firm. A worker with 10 years experience is entitled to have his pension vested, meaning the employer must contribute to the employee's retirement benefits. McClendon sued in state court in Texas, accusing Ingersoll-Rand of firing him to avoid paying pension benefits. The company said it dismissed him to reduce its workforce and save money. The federal Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA) protects workers' pension rights. But McClendon did not sue in Texas courts for lost pension benefits. In fact, shortly after he sued, the company agreed to vest his pension. McClendon sought a potentially big-money judgment for lost future wages, mental anguish and punitive damages. The Texas Supreme Court last October overruled lower state courts and revived the lawsuit, ordering a trial. Many states accept the principle that an employer's ability to fire a worker at will is limited by public policy, the state court said. For example, the state court said, workers may claim they were fired illegally because of sex, race or age discrimination or for exercising their collective bargaining rights. ``We hold that public policy favors the protection of integrity in pension plans and requires in this case an exception to the employment-at-will doctrine,'' the state court said. McClendon is entitled to damages if he can prove he was fired because Ingersoll-Rand wanted to avoid paying pension benefits, the state court said. The U.S. Chamber of Commerce and other business groups urged the U.S. Supreme Court to overrule the Texas court and hold that the federal pension law pre-empts such lawsuits. The Chamber of Commerce said lawsuits by fired workers against their former companies already have mushroomed. The organization cited one study showing the national average for damage awards based on wrongful firing rose from $227,280 in 1986 to $311,332 in 1987. Allowing fired employees to sue over the pension issue will prompt thousands of additional suits that could be devastating to American business, the Chamber of Commerce said. It noted that the aging of the so-called baby-boom generation already poses a threat to the financial stability of pension plans. If the Texas court ruling is upheld, the Chamber of Commerce said, ``At the same time that pension plans are being put to their most stringent financial tests, thousands of employees who are about to vest in their pension rights will be able to bring (lawsuits) for wrongful discharge seeking extensive compensatory and punitive damages.'' The case is Ingersoll-Rand vs. McClendon, 89-1298.

DOC.HEAD: Preacher Feeds Homeless Congregation Rabbit
DOC.TEXT: A preacher said he put barbecued rabbit on the menu of his Easter meal for the homeless to dramatize their plight of the poor and to stress that the true meaning of the holiday has nothing to do with bunnies. ``Jesus Christ did not tell us to give each other some cuddly little Easter Bunny,'' said the Rev. Larry Rice as the hungry and homeless lined up Sunday at the New Life Evangelical Center. ``He told us to feed the hungry.'' Christians celebrate Easter to mark the day they believe that Jesus rose from the dead. On the menu Sunday were more than 300 grilled rabbits, served with sauce or without _ plus corn and green beans, carrots, pasta, hard-boiled eggs and chocolate cake. Diners also were given soap, razor blades, shampoo and deodorant _ ``stuff you can't get with food stamps,'' Rice explained. Rice said the Easter supper of rabbit was a deliberate publicity stunt to carry his message that ``there are too many people hungry in America to waste food.'' Yvonne Dozier, seated at dinner with her 8-month-old baby, said those at Rice's tables found the meal ``a blessing.'' ``There ain't no such thing as the Easter Bunny, and I ain't no kid,'' she said. ``This is just food _ good food.''

DOC.HEAD: King Asks Opposition Leader To Be Prime Minister Of Interim Government
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 16 grafs to UPDATE with new opposition leader picked to be prime minister after earlier nominee bows out due to ill health. Other details. Pickup 11th graf `Chand had...'
DOC.TEXT: King Birendra today bowed to a groundswell for further democratic reform and asked a veteran opposition leader to be prime minister of an interim government, the opposition party announced. Earlier today, Birendra announced the resignation of Prime Minister Lokendra Bahadur Chand and the dissolution of the partyless legislature. The developments ended a week of political deadlock that ensued after the king yielded on April 8 to demands that a 29-year-old ban on political parties be banned. That move came two days after a bloody clash between troops and pro-democracy demonstrators that left as many as 200 people dead. Krishna Prasad Bhattarai, the prime minister-designate and acting president of the long-banned Nepali Congress Party, said he will present a Cabinet on Tuesday. Bhattarai also said King Birendra indicated during a meeting today with opposition leaders that he will look favorably upon the idea of becoming a constitutional monarch, foresaking the near-absolute power he has wielded for his 18 years on the throne. There was no immediate comment from the palace. Bhattarai told reporters he was surprised by the offer to become prime minister. ``It's a very, very challenging task for which I was not at all mentally prepared,'' he said. ``I do not know to what extent I shall be able to do something for all those who have given their lives for the cause of democracy.'' An earlier statement issued by the Nepali Congress said King Birendra first offered the prime minister's job to Ganesh Man Singh, supreme leader of the party. Singh, 75, declined, citing poor health. Singh said general elections for a new Rashtriya Panchayat, or National Assembly, would be conducted before April 1991. The balloting would be the first multiparty election in the Himalayan kingdom in three decades. Bhattarai said his government will include members of the United Left Front, a coalition of communist groups that had joined the Nepali Congress in the people power movement. Also today, a youth gang set fire to a movie theater ticket office and stoned another empty cinema, prompting the capital's four other theaters to close. Riot police were deployed, but no one was reported injured. It was not immediately clear why the gang targeted the movie theaters, located 500 yards from the royal palace. Witnesses said the attackers were members of Mandale, a secretive group that had supported the royal family before switching allegiance to National Assembly members who were upset at losing their jobs. In a royal proclamation on government radio today, King Birendra announced Chand's resignation and the dissolution of the Rashtriya Panchayat, or national assembly, conceding the two major pre-conditions of pro-democracy leaders for joining an interim government. ``In view of the events that have taken place in certain parts of the country, the people's aspirations and the ideals of democracy, we have been making political changes,'' Birendra said. Chand had been named prime minister April 6, replacing a hard-liner in one of the king's last moves to try to contain the growing pro-democracy movement. But demonstrators were not satisfied. A few hours later, police unleashed the bloodiest crackdown in Nepal's modern history. Witnesses said as many as 200 protesters were killed as thousands marched on the palace. The government put the death toll at 10. ``This is progress in the right direction,'' Yog Prasad Upadhyaya, secretary-general of the Nepali Congress, said of Birendra's announcement, which came eight hours after talks between Chand and leaders of the 7-week-old pro-democracy movement broke down. The collapse spurred a violent protest by hundreds of demonstrators who had gathered outside the academy where the talks were held. Cars belonging to Chand and Foreign Minister Pashupathi Rana were destroyed, and demonstrators initially refused to allow the politicians to leave. Three times during Sunday's talks, protesters had burst through the gates of the academy, demanding the government give in to the opposition. Birendra's father, King Mahendra, banned political parties in 1961 after two years of Western-style party government headed by the Nepali Congress. Mahendra dismissed the government, accusing it of corruption and inept administration. Since then, the king has shared power with a largely rubber-stamp national assembly. The monarch nominated one-fifth of the assembly's 140 members and, according to poitical observers, approved the nominations of the others standing for election. Observers say the current campaign is succeeding because of a growing belief among the country's 17 million people that genuine democracy may help Nepal to counter widespread poverty. The picturesque kingdom is one of the poorest countries in the world and has a per capita yearly income of $150. Only 25 percent of the population can read and write, and 11 percent of all babies die before the age of one year.

DOC.HEAD: AIDS Panel Studies Special Problems Of Rural Patients
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to update with commission members visiting with patients. Picks up 4th graf pvs, `In the ...'.
DOC.TEXT: Members of the National Commission on AIDS got a first-hand look at the problems of rural AIDS patients today as they visited patients and health care workers in southern Georgia. ``They're trying to learn whatever problems they (AIDS sufferers) face getting treatment in rural areas,'' said commission spokesman Thomas Brant, who was traveling with the 11 members making the trip. AIDS victims in many rural areas have to travel long distances for medical care and are often treated as outcasts by those who think of the disease as a big city problem, health officials and activists say. The panel planned to attend briefings and meet with AIDS patients, doctors and health officials in Waycross, Albany and Macon. In the country, AIDS still is sometimes a dirty word, said Dr. Ted Holloway, director of a 16-county health district in southeastern Georgia. ``There's a big stigma ... about being gay, or being a drug user or being HIV positive,'' he said. ``We've had people lose their jobs and get kicked out of their apartments. ... There's a lot of self-blame. People become totally dependent on their families, living in fear about how people will react to their disease.'' Holloway said some patients are afraid to tell the truth to their insurance companies and instead try to pay for expensive tests and drugs out of their own pockets. A spokesman for Rainbow Partners, a year-old support group in Waycross, said rural residents tend to think of AIDS as a big city problem. ``They see it on TV and say, `We don't have that here.' They have the attitude it's just a bunch of (homosexuals) and drug addicts,'' said the spokesman, who identified himself only as Charles. ``Once they meet someone who had AIDS it becomes personalized and changes their attitudes.'' Of the 3,488 AIDS cases reported in Georgia since January 1987, the eight-county Atlanta area had 2,549. Holloway's district was second with 237 cases. His district, about the size of the state of Massachusetts, has a population of 275,000 and includes the city of Savannah. ``We don't have large gay communities like the big cities,'' Holloway said. ``It's been hard to mobilize community activities because we don't have that leadership from the gay community. People are just beginning to realize the problems we face.'' Health officials are concerned that a syphilis epidemic in Georgia foretells a surge in AIDS cases in years to come. The epidemic is believed to be linked to the practice of trading sex for crack. In southeastern Georgia, syphilis cases jumped from 48 in 1984 to 500 last year. ``We've talked to HIV-positive crack addicts who are having sex with 30 or 40 people a month,'' Holloway said. ``There's just got to be transmission occurring.'' Holloway said rural areas need money for AIDS and drug treatment programs and for drugs such as AZT that can prolong the life of people infected with the HIV, or AIDS, virus. Dr. Paul White, district health director in southwestern Georgia, which has had 97 reported AIDS cases in three years, said poor people from Albany have to make a 350-mile round trip to the AIDS clinic at Atlanta's Grady Hospital once a month for treatment and a supply of drugs. The AIDS commission, made up of scientific and legal experts, was created by Congress in 1988 to coordinate the federal attack on AIDS.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Starts Race at White House Easter Egg Roll
DOC.TEXT: President Bush blew a whistle and eight youngsters charged across a stretch of White House grass this morning, pushing hard-boiled eggs with plastic spoons. But for one contestant, 7-year-old Michael Angel, the annual Easter Egg Roll was an Easter Egg Run. He sprinted across the 10-yard course with his egg in the spoon. ``He's pretty's cool,'' Michael said afterwards of the race starter, who made a brief appearance with his wife, Barbara, as parents and children craned their necks to see them. Thousands of youngsters spilled over the White House lawn in the annual Easter Monday ritual that began in the 19th century. At least 20,000 were expected by day's end. Marshall Bush, the president's granddaughter who turns 4 next month, was in the same race with Michael Angel and his 5-year-old sister, Mia. Both girls used the more conventional approach of pushing the egg forward with the spoon instead of running with it. President Bush started only one of the races, expected to continue through the day. Mia Angel said the president was ``fun,'' but ``he didn't shake my hand.'' A stepbrother, Jason Planakis, did manage to get a presidential handshake. Egg rolling was not the only activity on the White House lawn under blue skies and temperatures near 70 degrees. There were clowns, troubadours, an Abe Lincoln look-alike, balloon-blowers, minstrels and a hunt for wooden eggs, many signed by celebrities. All of the Easter Egg Roll entrants received the same reward: colored wooden eggs bearing the names of George and Barbara Bush. Some of the parents and children were queued up outside the White House gates for an hour or more. ``I want to get my face painted,'' said Chad Hampton, 9, of Herndon, Va., who came with his sister, mother and other friends. ``I got lucky. I got a balloon.'' ``We got up at 6 a.m. We left at 7 and were down here at 8:15,'' said his mother, Margie Hampton, who took the morning off from work as a medical social worker. ``Don't ask me if it's worth it. But what we do for kids!''

DOC.HEAD: At Least 80 Killed In Train Fire
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with 80 dead. Pickup 7th graf `Mathew John...'
DOC.TEXT: A leaking gas cylinder exploded and burned in a passenger train in eastern India today, killing at least 80 people and injuring 65 others, officials said. Local reporters said at least 100 people died in the fire, which raged through two train cars before firefighters extinguished it. The 16-car train was passing through Patna, 500 miles southeast of New Delhi, when the fire broke out at 9:30 a.m. ``The heat was so intense no one dared to enter the train for at least a half hour after the fire,'' said District Magistrate S.K. Sharma, the top civil administrator in the Patna region. ``The outer shell of the bogies (cars) was intact, but the inside was terrible,'' he said. United News of India quoting local officials said at least 80 people died. Mathew John, the director of safety for the Federal Railway Board in New Delhi, said two cylinders of flammable gas caught fire. He said one of the cylinders was leaking and apparently ignited when someone lit a match. Sharma said a cylinder of oxyacetylene gas, used in welding operations, was found in the burned cars. Press Trust of India said many bodies were buried under smoldering wooden berths and heaps of luggage. The news agency said 10,000 people converged on the site in Patna, capital of Bihar state, one of the poorest of India's 25 states. The train, which was traveling from Mokammeh to Arrah, is widely used in the mornings by workers commuting to the state capital. More than 10 million people ride Indian trains every day, and major disasters are reported every year. Trains are jammed, with people often riding on the roofs. One of the worst train accidents in recent years occurred in the southern Indian state of Kerala on July 8, 1988, when 103 people died when a train plunged into a lake near Quilon. Two derailments in 1989 claimed 131 lives: 67 near Jhansi in Uttar Pradesh in north central India on April 18 and 64 near Mughalsarai in eastern Bihar on Nov. 1. India's 38,320 miles of tracks form the world's third-largest rail network after those in the Soviet Union and the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Group Says China Pressuring Governments To Halt Pro-Democracy Ship
DOC.TEXT: A radio ship headed to the Far East to transmit pro-democracy broadcasts into China has been the target of surveillance and harassment by Chinese officials since it left France, its sponsors said Monday. A coalition of sponsoring groups, headed by the French magazine Actuel, said China has tried to pressure various foreign governments in an effort to undermine the ``Boat For China'' operation. It said the 260-foot Goddess of Democracy, which set sail from France on March 17, ``has been the target of administrative harassment, especially in countries where it stopped, and of constant surveillance and intimidation by the Chinese authorities.'' The 1,200-ton ship, a former British oceanographic vessel, is sponsored by 18 press organizations from several countries in concert with the Federation for Democracy in China, a Paris-based organization of Chinese dissidents. The coalition said the ship has recently left Djibouti, on the Horn of Africa, after being held in port for several days for ``various technical and administrative reasons.'' It described the project as ``totally peaceful, with no protection except that of international public opinion.'' Actuel said its editorial offices in Paris were burglarized and ransacked over the weekend. It said documents and computer disks related to the ship were stolen as well as a word processor belonging to a reporter covering the ``Boat for China'' operation. The ship is equipped with two radio studios and a television studio. Its crew hopes to begin broadcasting music and news into China from international waters by the end of April. China has formally protested to France about the boat but was told there was no official French involvement in the project. France rejected China's request to restrict news coverage of the operation. The Chinese also have protested the presence in Paris of Chai Ling, a student leader of the pro-democracy movement that was crushed in Beijing last June. France is considering her application for political asylum, filed after she escaped from China earlier this month.

DOC.HEAD: Guerrillas Claim Victories as Food Aid Begins to Flow To War-Torn Areas
DOC.TEXT: Church groups announced Monday that convoys bearing food for starving Ethiopians had started moving into war-torn areas after months of separate talks involving the government and rebel forces. A convoy of 55 trucks carrying supplies left the city of Dessie in Wollo Province bound for Mekelle, the provincial capital of neighboring Tigre Province, church spokesmen said in Addis Ababa. Seven other trucks will distribute food in outlying areas, the church spokesmen said. A bulldozer was sent ahead of the convoy to clear roads washed away by heavy rains and flooding, the Rev. Francis Stephanos, president of the Ethiopian Evangelical Church Mekane Yesus, told The Associated Press. The Evangelical Church along with the Ethiopian Orthodox Church and the Ethiopian Catholic Secretariat have formed a consortium that recently was granted permission by the government and the rebel Tigre People's Liberation Front to distribute emergency supplies in war-torn Wollo and Tigre provinces. On the battlefront, another rebel army, the Ethiopian People's Revolutionary Democratic Front, claimed to have killed more than 800 government troops in two separate offensives last week in Wollo Province, north of Addis Ababa, according to a clandestine rebel radio broadcast monitored in Nairobi. The guerrilla armies are fighting the Marxist government of President Mengistu Haile Mariam. Both the guerrillas and the government often make claims of battlefield victories that can rarely be verified, as independent observers are barred from the war fronts. The Democratic Front rebels claimed they destroyed a commando brigade and two commando battalions, killing 721 government soldiers, wounding 410 and capturing 351 in fighting around the towns of Ataye and Karakore. The towns are about 110 miles north of Addis Ababa. In a second clash at Degaga, the Democratic Front claimed its forces had destroyed two government battalions, killing 151 soldiers and wounding 223. There was no mention of prisoners. The fighting has made it difficult to get foreign relief supplies to hundreds of thousands of Ethiopians who face starvation in Tigre and Wollo provinces. The Tigre People's Liberation Front claims to control northern Wollo and and most of Tigre and has in the past few months been distributing foreign-donated relief aid itself. The Liberation Front has accused relief officials of delaying the distribution of food in the two provinces by claiming poor road conditions. The rebel group said the highway is in good condition and had been used by tanks.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Hidden in Bus Explodes Near Market
DOC.TEXT: A bomb hidden under a bus exploded near a shopping district Monday morning, but there were no casualties, police said. It was the second blast in three days. The bus, bound for Rawalpindi about 10 miles away, had stopped near a market when the bomb went off, police said. There were only two people on the bus, and they escaped unhurt. No one immediately claimed responsibility, and police refused to speculate who might be behind the bombing. On Friday, a bomb attached beneath a vehicle exploded in a congested marketplace and seriously injured two children.

DOC.HEAD: Militia Leader Killed in West Beirut
DOC.TEXT: Gunmen in a speeding car killed a commander of the Syrian-backed Shiite Moslem Amal militia in west Beirut on Monday, police reported. An Amal official said Ali Abu Hasan, the militia's commander in the Zokak el-Blat district of the city's Moslem sector, was assassinated by the pro-Iranian Hezbollah, or Party of God. The official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Abu Hasan died shortly after he arrived the American University Hospital. Police said Amal militiamen later took to the streets, firing in the air and raiding apartments near the scene of the slaying in an apparent search for the killers. The fundamentalist Hezbollah and the more secular Amal have been fighting off and on for more than two years for control of Lebanon's 1.2 million Shiites, the country's largest sect. More than 1,000 people have been killed and at least 3,000 wounded in the battles.

DOC.HEAD: Albanian Asylum-Seeker Takes Refuge In Greek Embassy
DOC.TEXT: An Albanian national has fled into the Greek Embassy in the Albanian capital and asked for asylum, a diplomat at the mission said Monday. Bernard Kici, a 38-year-old Roman Catholic electrician, entered the embassy in Tirana on Sunday morning and ``asked for our help in providing religious and political asylum,'' Charge d'Affaires Pantelis Karkabassis said in a telephone interview. Public worship and religious institutions were outlawed in the hard-line Communist nation in 1967. ``There has been no contact (between the Greek and Albanian governments) so far, but we expect talks to take place shortly to find a solution,'' Karkabassis said. The Albanian authorities last March allowed Sotiris Antoniou, an ethnic Greek who had sought asylum in the Greek Embassy, to leave the country legally. Greece estimates about 400,000 ethnic Greeks are living in Albania, the last bastion of Stalinism in Europe. Tirana says the Greek minority numbers 60,000 at most. Despite rejecting reforms that have swept Communist monopolies from power in Eastern Europe, Albania has shown some signs of easing its self-imposed isolation. Last month, the government began considering moves to liberalize the penal code and create a justice ministry to oversee the courts. It also opened direct telephone links with the West.

DOC.HEAD: Life Magazine Changes Logo Color for Earth Day
DOC.TEXT: Life magazine's red and white logo is turning green in May to commemorate Earth Day. It's only the second time in the magazine's 53-year history that it has changed the colors. The only other time was when it appeared in black in 1963 after President Kennedy's assassination. ``The last time Life's logo changed color, it marked a moment of national mourning,'' said Jim Gaines, managing editor. ``This time we're hoping to sound an alarm that may prevent worldwide mourning by future generations.'' The May issue includes several articles about the environment, including a cover story on trees. Earth Day is April 22. The magazine's white letters on a red background logo was introduced Nov. 23, 1936.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Knocks Out Cable TV Service to Thousands in L.A.
DOC.TEXT: A multimillion-dollar fire at a cable TV transmission station knocked out service Monday to at least 20,000 customers, officials said. There were no injuries stemming from the blaze at the Continental Cablevision station in the Westchester area of Los Angeles, said fire department spokesman Pat Marek. Forty firefighters took more than an hour to extinguish the fire, Marek said. Authorities were investigating the cause of the fire, which resulted in an estimated $5.5 million to $7.5 million in damage. It was unknown when service would be restored. ``We're asking customers to be patient,'' said Al Kuolas, a Cablevision vice president for engineering. Cablevision serves about 280,000 customers in the metropolitan area, Kuolas said.

DOC.HEAD: 80 Reported Dead of Food Poisoning, Investigation Begun
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with 80 dead, investigation pointing to sulfur compound
DOC.TEXT: At least 80 people died of food poisoning and more than 125 others were hospitalized after a village feast to celebrate a marriage engagement, United News of India reported today. An inquiry was ordered into the cause of the deaths after the Sunday night dinner. United News said preliminary investigations indicated a sulfur compound had contaminated the flour used for making puri, a puffy fried bread. The ``tilak'' ceremony and feast were held in Raipura Jungla village near Lucknow, capital of the nothern state of Uttar Pradesh. During the ceremony, engaged couples exchange rings and feast with their families. A tilak is a decorative dot many Indians, especially Hindus, wear on their foreheads for auspicious occasions. UNI did not say whether the engaged couple was among the victims.

DOC.HEAD: Racial Slaying Trial Opens; Defendant Accused Of Organizing Gang
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Rewrites throughout to update with opening of trial. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Defendant Keith Mondello organized the white gang that surrounded and killed a black teen-ager last summer, a prosecutor said today at the opening of the trial of two men charged in that attack. The death of Yusuf Hawkins raised racial tensions in a city that was then in the middle of a mayoral campaign. ``The evidence in this case is going to show you that an unarmed 16-year-old boy who went with three friends to look at a used car was surrounded and killed by a gang organized by this defendant,'' assistant district attorney James Kohler told the jury. The case against codefendant Joseph Fama, 19, allegedly the triggerman in the murder of 16-year-old Hawkins, was scheduled to start later in the day in the same courtroom. But lawyers said Fama was sick with the flu, and the opening of that case was in doubt. Fama, 19, and Mondello, 20, are the first of eight white men from the largely Italian Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn to go on trial in the fatal shooting Aug. 23 of Hawkins. Two juries sitting side-by-side were chosen for their simultaneous trials to speed justice. A mob of 30 or more men who attacked Hawkins after he ventured into Bensonhurst with three friends to check out a used car for sale. The judge, state Supreme Court Justice Thaddeus E. Owens, ordered two juries to hear evidence in the same courtroom, rather than hold separate trials for Fama and Mondello, to save time. Many in the Bensonhurst mob, which prosecutors recently revealed included a black man, were armed with baseball bats. The group had gathered in a schoolyard to protect their turf from outsiders. Fama and Mondello are charged with murder, riot, assault, menacing and other crimes. They could get 25 years to life in prison on the murder charge.

DOC.HEAD: Alleged Drug Kingpin, Two Others Escape from Private Texas Prison
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `Jonas identified...', with 3 grafs to add details of `Jet Set' allegations, picking up 7th graf pvs, `Compton and...'. SUBS from 15th graf, `Wackenhut officials...', to end to CORRECT that gun believed to be .25-caliber sted 25mm; delete redundant reference to Coral Gables, add detail on prison population.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto Upcoming
DOC.TEXT: An alleged drug kingpin and two other inmates escaped from a privately run prison across from the police station after one of them pulled a gun on a guard, authorities said. Five federal agencies plus Mexican, Texas and local officials were searching today for the men who escaped Sunday evening. They include Mario Alberto Salinas Trevino, who federal authorities allege masterminded one of the largest drug-smuggling and money-laundering rings between Texas and Mexico. Police said the three men may be heading to Mexico and are considered armed and dangerous. At its closest point, the border is about 100 miles away. Salinas, 37, was among 25 people arrested in March 1989 in a drug operation dubbed ``Operation Jet Set.'' U.S. Marshal Bill Jonas said $10 million was seized from Salinas then, and he's suspected of having up to $10 million in drug money stashed in a hideaway either in Texas or Mexico. Prosecutors charge that between 1983 and 1989, a drug ring Salinas helped run was responsible for transporting more than 46,000 pounds of marijuana and 1,900 pounds of cocaine. The ring allegedly distributed the drugs throughout Texas, Pennsylvania, California, Illinois, Florida and Massachusetts. The ring also is accused of laundering of more than $7.6 million, using financial institutions in San Antonio and Roma, Texas and San Ysidro, Calif., to launder narcotics profits. Jonas identified the other inmates as Charlie Edward Compton, 58, and Juan Chapa Garza, 44. Compton was awaiting trial on federal charges of possession of cocaine with intent to distribute. Chapa was charged with possession of marijuana with intent to distribute. The charges were not related to the ``Jet Set'' probe. Compton and Salinas are U.S. citizens, Jonas said. He wasn't sure about Chapa's nationality. The three were cellmates at the Central Texas Parole Violators Facility, a minimum- to medium-security prison in the old Bexar County jail operated by Wackenhut Corp. of Coral Gables, Fla. Compton summoned a guard, claiming he was ill, and pulled a handgun on him shortly before 9 p.m., Jonas said. The three then locked up two guards in the closet and overpowered another guard on the ground floor before seizing the security control panels and opening a door, Jonas said. They fled on foot. According to police reports, San Antonio police weren't notified of the jailbreak until nearly an hour after the three men had escaped. But Wackenhut spokesman Pat Cannan said police were notified 15 to 20 minutes after the jail break by the guard on the ground floor, who was tied up outside. ``It took him about 15 to 20 minutes to get unloose and he ran straight across the street to the police department,'' Cannan said. ``That was the proper thing to do.'' Jonas said he had no indication that Wackenhut had delayed the reporting unneccessarily. Wackenhut officials speculate the pistol was smuggled into the prison during Easter Day visiting hours, Cannan said. He spoke in a telephone interview from Coral Gables. Jonas said the gun was believed to be a .25-caliber. ``We suspect it was brought in by a visitor,'' he said. Cannan said the prison screens visitors, but he declined to give details. The inmates were being held in the private facility for the U.S. Marshal's Service, Cannan said. The 620-capacity prison was housing 583 people Sunday, about 100 of them Marshal's Service prisoners, Cannan said. The prison has 125 guards, 20 to 25 per shift, he said. The Marshal's Service has summoned assistance from the U.S. Drug Enforcement Adminstration, FBI, Customs Service, Immigration and Naturalization Service and Mexican customs, Jonas said. State and local officials also were involved in the search.

DOC.HEAD: Strangeways Prisoners Start Fire, Inmate Suffers Poisoning Symptoms
DOC.TEXT: Rebel inmates started a fire at Strangeways Prison early today and three more prisoners surrendered, suffering from suspected food poisoning, prison governor Brendon O'Friel said. The last seven prisoners still holding out may have eaten food gone bad in the 16-day siege or even rat poison scattered in the aging building, O'Friel said. One inmate became so sick overnight with suspected food poisoning that other inmates asked prison staff to take him to hospital, and two others surrendered, saying they felt unwell, O'Friel said. ``It is possible these three prisoners are suffering from some form of very serious food poisoning, maybe salmonella,'' he told reporters. ``For some time we have been concerned about the state of their food supplies and we have become increasingly worried that they may have been eating contaminated food or water,'' O'Friel told reporters. Prison officers went into the prison about 2:20 a.m. when heavy smoke was seen billowing from the building, but the fire was considered doused at 3:15, according to a Home Office spokesman. ``There was a danger to life _ both to the prison officers who went in to fight the fire and to the inmates,'' said the spokesman, who spoke anonymously in line with British custom. There was no word of any casualties, he said. O'Friel appealed to the last seven rebels to surrender, urging them not to let the siege end in ``some sort of tragedy resulting from food poisoning or other illness.'' The inmates stockpiled large amounts of food before more than 1,500 inmates at the 900-capacity prison rioted on April 1. However, they have no refrigeration in the wing they are occupying. On Sunday, the rebels displayed a large sign saying: ``We was coming down today but because some of the boys departing last week got broken arms and legs we are staying one more week.'' Authorities categorically denied violence had been used against surrendering inmates. One prisoner accused of sexually assaulting three children died from injuries in the rioting and a prison guard died of a heart attack. Several inmates who surrendered earlier claimed they had seen dead bodies inside, but others insisted there had been no deaths. Most prisoners gave themselves up soon after the riot sparked by overcrowding in the Victorian-era facility.

DOC.HEAD: Court Leaves Intact Libel Award Won by Former CIA Official
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 1st graf and 10th graf, bgng, While the ... to CORRECT size of libel award
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today left intact a $931,000 libel award won by a former CIA deputy director who resigned amid allegations of improper business dealings. The court, without comment, rejected an appeal by two brothers successfully sued by former Central Intelligence Agency official Max Hugel. Hugel sued Thomas and Samuel McNell over a July 14, 1981, article published in The Washington Post under the headline, ``CIA Spymaster Accused of Improper Stock Practices.'' The McNells were stockbrokers in the mid-1970s when they had business dealings with Hugel that turned sour. Tom McNell provided the newspaper with tape recordings of telephone conversations with Hugel intended to support allegations that Hugel engaged in illegal securities transactions. Hugel resigned as deputy director of administration at the CIA after the article appeared. He sued the McNells for libel in federal court in New Hampshire, Hugel's home state. Hugel did not sue the newspaper. The McNells, who are from Maine, dropped out of sight and did not emerge until 1987, when they were arrested on federal charges of fraud and shipping stolen goods across state lines. They pleaded guilty and were sentenced to prison. Samuel McNell has been freed from prison and is living in Portland, Ore. His brother remains in prison in California. While the McNells were in hiding, a federal judge in 1984 ruled they had defaulted in the libel suit. Hugel was awarded a default judgment of $931,000. The McNells said they were treated unfairly in the case, saying they were unaware of the lawsuit until they emerged from hiding _ and thus were denied a chance to show in court that the sued-over article was true. The 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the award last year, ruling that the trial judge had the authority to grant the default judgment. ``The McNells knew that release of the allegedly false information would have a devastating impact on Hugel, and it can be fairly inferred that they intended the brunt of the injury to be felt in New Hampshire where Hugel had an established reputation as a businessman and public servant,'' the appeals court said. Even if the McNells' defense to the libel claim had merit, that does not justiify overturning a judgment based on their failure to appear in court to defend themselves, the appeals court said. The case is McNell vs. Hugel, 89-1270.

DOC.HEAD: Teacher Walkout Closes More than 100 Oklahoma School Districts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with higher crowd estimate at Capitol, new data on number of districts shut down. Picks up 8th graf pvs, `The teachers...'. SUBS penultimate graf to delete redundant first reference to Bellmon.
DOC.TEXT: Striking teachers shut nearly a quarter of Oklahoma's school districts today and thronged to the state Capitol to protest the Legislature's failure to pass an education reform bill that would have included pay raises. Thousands of teachers and their supporters, chanting and carrying signs, crowded the plaza on the Capitol's south entrance and picketed around other nearby state buildings. The 30,000-member Oklahoma Education Association, representing 80 percent of the state's teachers, called a five-day statewide walkout last week. Nancy Jewell, OEA vice president, said classes had been dismissed this morning at 143 of the state's 606 school districts. ``We would never accept a 48th ranking in sports,'' read one protest sign, referring to what the teachers say is Oklahoma's ranking among the states in teacher pay. The minimum beginning salary for a teacher with a bachelor's degree is $15,060. Ms. Jewell the crowd around the Capitol at more than 10,000 and said more teachers were expected to arrive in buses later in the day. Other estimates ranged from 5,000 to 15,000. The OEA's delegate assembly is scheduled to meet Friday to discuss the teacher walkout. ``At that point, we'll decide what's next,'' said Karla Feeley, OEA spokeswoman. ``Of course, if the problem is solved before Friday, that'll be another matter. But at this point, we're committed for one week.'' The teachers are incensed by a state Senate vote that killed an emergency clause to the school reform and tax bill. The measure has been the work of an eight-month special session Gov. Henry Bellmon called last August to come up with ways to improve Oklahoma schools. The emergency clause would have made the measure effective immediately. After the Senate voted Wednesday to drop the emergency clause, legislative leaders got the Senate to send the bill back to committee to keep it from going to Bellmon without the emergency clause. The bill would have made number of changes, including proposals to set greater equity in the way state funds are allocated, salary increases for teachers, a school consolidation plan, and a program to close schools that don't meet accreditation requirements, It would have provided an additional $212 million for schools that could be used for teacher salaries and other items. It also proposed $1,500 increases in minimum teachers' salaries for each of the next four years. Much of the opposition stemmed from the supporting tax plan, which called for a half-cent increase in the state's 4-cent sales tax, and increases in corporate and personal income tax. The OEA does not believe the walkout is illegal, Ms. Feeley said. Bellmon asked the state's attorney general, Robert Henry, on Friday to take ``all action necessary to prevent illegal disruption of the education of Oklahoma schoolchildren.'' Henry's office was researching what steps to take. Assistant Attorney General Ned Bastow Jr. said last week that a 1981 statute makes strikes against a local school board illegal, but it's not clear if the prohibition applies to statewide strikes.

DOC.HEAD: Man Who Sued Hospital for Saving His Life Dies
DOC.TEXT: A man who sued a Cincinnati hospital for keeping him alive in 1988 has died. Edward H. Winter, 84, died Saturday at the Hillebrand Nursing Center in suburban Cheviot. He sued St. Francis-St. George Hospital in November 1989 to allege negligence and battery because hospital staff members saved his life after he suffered a series of heart attacks in May 1988. Winter's lawsuit, which is pending in Hamilton County Common Pleas Court, claims the hospital ignored his expressed wish that no extraordinary measures be taken to save his life. The hospital has denied ignoring Winter's wishes, saying he had not given specific instructions. The family has not decided whether to pursue his lawsuit, said his daughter, Lynn Kroger. Winter's lawyer, William Knapp, was out of his office and could not be reached for immediate comment today. Legal experts have said the case could break new ground because hospitals are not normally held liable for saving a life. A funeral service is scheduled Wednesday. Following a heart attack on May 25, 1988, Winter said, he requested that no extraordinary measures be used to keep him alive. He charged in his lawsuit that hospital workers ignored the ``do not resuscitate order'' when he suffered a second heart attack and used electric shock to keep him alive. Two days after he was revived from the second heart attack, he suffered a stroke that left him paralyzed on his right side and unable to care for himself. He suffered mentally and physically following the stroke, Mrs. Kroger said. The lawsuit seeks to recover the costs of Winter's medical care since May 1988, estimated at more than $100,000.

DOC.HEAD: Romanian Monarchists Yell Back At Anti-King Marchers
DOC.TEXT: Supporters of exiled King Michael on Monday yelled back at what they claimed was a government-sponsored rally against the monarch's planned visit to his native land. Several hundred pro-monarchy demonstrators shouted ``Communists go to church!'' and ``Long live the king!'' as they tried to prevent an anti-king rally in front of government headquarters. There was some pushing and kicking between the rival groups but eventually they dispersed quietly, and there were no arrests. Later, about 300 supporters of the monarch signed a petition they planned to send to the Supreme Court asking for a visa for King Michael. ``The government, in withdrawing the visa, has violated the Helsinki Accords on human rights,'' said Noni Andronescu, a supporter of King Michael. The 68-year-old former monarch was forced to abdicate by a Soviet-installed government on Dec. 30, 1947, and now lives in Switzerland. He planned to visit his homeland for 10 days on a private trip. The Bucharest government last week revoked Micheal's visa, forcing him to cancel what would have been his first Romanian visit in more than 42 years. His supporters claim that those opposed to the king's visit are former Communists backed by the National Salvation Front government, the main contender in May 20 elections. ``We don't want a king!'' shouted a woman who was among approximately 100 people marching down the city's boulevards toward the government building to show approval for the visa revocation. ``Communists in disguise, go home or to church! It's a holiday today!'' scores of the exiled monarch's supporters shouted back. Monday is celebrated as the second day of Easter in most of Europe. The demonstrators shouted anti-government slogans and demanded that former Communists be barred from senior administrative jobs for the next 12 years. Police initially stopped the anti-king rally from taking place. Later, they allowed about 500 demonstrators to enter Victory Square after they displayed a letter stating they had the mayor's approval to assemble there. The anti-king march had been previously announced on television, but the other rally was spontaneous, said Victor Alexa, one of the participants. Those opposed to the monarch accused King Michael of not doing enough for the nation while it was ruled by Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. There has been no official explanation for the withdrawal of Michael's visa, but some Romanians believe interim president Ion Iliescu and Premier Petre Roman, both former Communists, were concerned their opponents would earn political mileage from the trip. Michael said after Ceausecu's overthrow in December that he was prepared to return to Romania as head of a constitutional monarchy but indicated that this would have to be subject to a referendum.

DOC.BYLINE: Leaking Gas Container Explodes On Indian Train, Kills At Least 80 ^By DILIP GANGULY
DOC.TEXT: A leaking gas cylinder exploded in a moving commuter train on Monday and set off a fire that left at least 80 people dead and 65 others wounded, news reports and officials said. Reporters at the scene said the explosion and fire killed at least 100 people. Fire swept through two of the train's 16 cars as it traveled near Kumrahar in Bihar state, 500 miles southeast of New Delhi. The fire began at 9:30 a.m. Firefighters eventually extinguished the blaze, but ``The heat was so intense no one dared to enter the train for at least a half-hour after the fire,'' said S.K. Sharma, the top civil administrator in the region. Sharma said a cylinder of oxyacetylene gas, used in welding, was found in one of the gutted cars. ``The outer shell of the bogies (cars) was intact, but the inside was terrible,'' Sharma said in a telephone interview. Mathew John, the director of safety for the Federal Railway Board in New Delhi, said two cylinders of gas caught fire. He said one of the cylinders was leaking and apparently ignited when someone lit a match. Ram Naresh Singh, a survivor, was quoted by Press Trust of India as saying that because ``I would not be able to save anyone and would get killed myself, I jumped off the train.'' The United News of India quoted local officials as saying at least 80 people died and 65 were wounded. The Passengers Welfare Association said the train had no emergency brake. ``It is the most neglected train running in the state. There is no light, no water, and even no alarm chain,'' said association President Rameshwar Pandey. Press Trust of India said many bodies were buried under smoldering wooden berths and heaps of luggage. Bihar is one of the poorest of India's 25 states. The train, which was traveling from Mokammeh to Arrah, is widely used by morning commuters to Patna, the state capital. More than 10 million people ride Indian trains every day, and major disasters are reported every year. Trains are jammed, often with people riding on the roofs. One of the worst train accidents in recent years occurred in the southern Indian state of Kerala on July 8, 1988, when 103 people died after a train plunged into a lake. Two derailments in 1989 claimed 131 lives: 67 near Jhansi in Uttar Pradesh in north central India on April 18, and 64 near Mughalsarai in eastern Bihar on Nov. 1. India's 38,324 miles of tracks form the world's third-largest rail network after those in the Soviet Union and the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Center, Director Plead Innocent To Obscenity Charges
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with innocent pleas entered. Picks up 6th graf, `A trial...'.
DOC.TEXT: Lawyers for the Contemporary Arts Center and its director pleaded innocent today to misdemeanor charges alleging that photographs in an exhibit of the late Robert Mapplethorpe are obscene. Attorney H. Louis Sirkin entered the plea in Hamilton County Municipal Court on behalf of the center and director Dennis Barrie. The court's assignment commissioner referred the case for trial to Municipal Judge David Albanese and scheduled a pre-trial hearing April 30, when a trial date may be set. The date must be set within 90 days. A Hamilton County grand jury indicted the gallery and Barrie on April 7. Five of the 175 photos in the exhibit show homosexual acts and two show children revealing their genitals. Lawyers filed the pleas about two hours before a scheduled arraignment before Municipal Judge Dennis Helmick in the Hamilton County Justice Center, said Martin Pinales, an attorney in the firm handling the case. The exhibit has been drawing large crowds _ more than 23,000 during its first week _ and is scheduled to continue through May 26 before moving on to Boston. Hamilton County Prosecutor Arthur Ney handed over prosecution to the city of Cincinnati last week, saying Ohio law prohibits him from prosecuting misdemeanors. Some city officials accused Ney of getting rid of a case too hot to handle and too flimsy to prosecute. ``We can't dictate to the city solicitor whether or not to proceed with the case, but we can certainly make our views known,'' said Councilman Peter Strauss. ``I personally think they are going to have a hard time making a case that the show in its entirety lacks artistic value.'' Fifty-nine percent of those who responded to a poll conducted for The Cincinnati Post said they believe the photographs should be displayed.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Jets Land in Saudi for Koran Airlift
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet Aeroflot jet landed in this port city Monday to begin an airlift of 100,000 copies of the Koran to the Soviet Union, a gift to Soviet Moslems from Saudi King Fahd. The operation is being organized by the Mecca-based Moslem World League. Saudi Araba is home to Islam's holiest shrines. It has no formal diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union. The League's secretary-general, Abdullah Omar Naseef, said the royal gift was made possible by the changes brought about by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The copies of the Moslem holy book were printed in Arabic at the King Fahd Printing Complex in Medina. Naseef said the consent of Soviet authorities to distribute the Koran among Moslems in the Soviet Union was an indication of the great changes taking place under Gorbachev. A delegation from the League recently visited the Soviet Union to make arrangements for the distribution.

DOC.HEAD: High Court to Consider Whether Business Protected From Some Pension Suits
With AM-Scotus-Dance Ban Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court on Monday agreed to consider shielding businesses from some big-money lawsuits by fired workers. The justices said they will use a Texas case to decide whether workers may sue in state courts when they allege their employers fired them to avoid paying pension benefits. Business leaders, saying millions of dollars are at stake, want the high court to rule that such state lawsuits are precluded by a federal law protecting pension benefits. The federal law is aimed at assuring workers will get their retirement pay. State lawsuits potentially are far more lucrative because workers can win punitive damages that greatly exceed lost pay. The justices are expected to rule sometime in 1991.
