In other action, the court: _Left intact a ban on dances at public schools in Purdy, Mo., where most residents are fundamentalists and some believe social dancing is ``satanic.'' _Let stand a $310,000 award against Los Angeles County stemming from a county jail inmate's 1984 suicide. _Left intact a $931,000 libel award won by former CIA deputy director Max Hugel, who resigned in 1981 amid allegations of improper business dealings. _Refused to make New York compensate the former owners of a Buffalo nursing home forced by the state to remain open even though it was losing money. In the pensions case, the court agreed to hear an appeal by Ingersoll-Rand Co., seeking to kill a suit by a fired worker. The U.S. Chamber of Commerce and other business groups support the appeal. They contend the federal Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA) has exclusive power to protect pension rights and pre-empts state lawsuits. The Chamber of Commerce said lawsuits by fired workers against their former companies already have mushroomed. The organization cited one study showing the national average for damage awards based on wrongful firing rose from $227,280 in 1986 to $311,332 in 1987. Allowing fired employees to sue over the pension issue will prompt thousands of additional suits at a time when many pension plans are being burdened by the aging of the so-called baby-boom generation, the Chamber of Commerce said. Ingersoll-Rand was sued by Perry McClendon, who was transferred by the company from San Antonio to Dallas in 1979 to develop a sales market there for the company's construction equipment. He was fired on Nov. 19, 1982, four months before his 10th anniversary with the firm. A worker with 10 years experience is entitled to have his pension vested, meaning the employer must contribute to the employee's retirement benefits. McClendon sued in state court in Texas, accusing Ingersoll-Rand of firing him to avoid paying pension benefits. The company said it dismissed him to reduce its workforce and save money. McClendon did not sue in Texas courts for lost pension benefits. In fact, shortly after he sued, the company agreed to vest his pension. Instead, McClendon sought a potentially big-money judgment for lost future wages, mental anguish and punitive damages. The Texas Supreme Court last October overruled lower state courts and revived the lawsuit, ordering a trial. The state court said an employer's ability to fire a worker at will is limited by public policy. For example, the state court said, workers have grounds to sue when they claim they were fired because of sex, race or age discrimination or for exercising collective bargaining rights. ``We hold that public policy favors the protection of integrity in pension plans and requires in this case an exception to the employment-at-will doctrine,'' the state court said. McClendon is entitled to damages if he can prove he was fired because Ingersoll-Rand wanted to avoid paying pension benefits, the state court said.

DOC.HEAD: Suburban House May Have Been Drug Factory
DOC.TEXT: For two years, neighbors in a tree-lined section of this New York City suburb saw what they thought was a typical family living in a nice house. Police say the family may have been part of a front for a drug factory that polluted the septic system and well of two homes with chemicals that may have been used to process cocaine. ``They mowed the lawn, did the gardening,'' said Lt. Thomas Johnston, commander of the Westchester Police Narcotics Unit. ``What they did was ruin the neighborhood.'' The family paid the rent and all other bills by cash and used fake names. Neighbors spotted at least two children, but nobody is sure how many there were. The children were not sent to schools, and the family was seen only on weekends. ``During the week, a light was on and no one suspected anything. They blended in and no one was any wiser,'' said Johnston. No one ever saw deliveries being made, said Johnston, but the chemicals probably were brought in in small quantities. One day last summer, they vanished from this Westchester County town about 30 miles north of Manhattan, leaving the toxic mess that authorities say may cost $100,000 to clean up. When the owners returned last autumn from a two-year stay in Japan, they found hazardous chemicals in the well and septic tank: tetrachloroethene, acetone toluene and dichloroethene, which comes from tetrachloroethene. The chemicals are used for processing cocaine but have industrial uses, such as for dry cleaning. But police say they are leaning toward the drug processing theory. Rocco A. Mastronardi, Jr., assistant county public health engineer, said his department was checking wells in the area _ where homes range from $300,000 to $400,000, Samples from the well and septic system taken in March contained 4,000 parts per billion of the tetrachloroethene and 14,000 per billion of dichloroethene, officials said. Quantities above 5 parts per billion are considered hazardous with long-term exposure. Owner Max Marx and one neighbor have been filtering their well water for drinking. The pollution has seeped to the leaching field and affected surface water leading to Wampus Pond, a county recreation area, but Mastronardi said none has been found in the pond itself. The state says Marx is responsible for the clean up. Marx, who is trying to get state or federal Superfund money to help pay, said the people who rented his house ``were very nice.'' He said they replaced carpeting, rerouted electricity and repainted to cover their tracks. Marx, who declined to say what he does for a living, called the evidence of a drug factory ``circumstantial.'' No one has been arrested. ``We got started six months in the hole,'' said Johnston. ``Every name they used was fictitious.'' Drug factories or stash houses for money are not uncommon in the metropolitan area suburbs, and more people are starting to pay attention to suspicious activities by their neighbors, said Mary Cooper, a spokesman for the Drug Enforcement Administration. ``We've seen everything from apartments to farmhouses used,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Youth Pleads Guilty in Abduction of Industrialist's Son
DOC.TEXT: A teen-ager pleaded guilty Monday in the kidnapping of the son of industrialist and former Nixon presidential aide Jon Huntsman and the stabbing of an FBI agent. Nicholas Hans Byrd, 19, pleaded guilty to charges of aggravated kidnapping and aggravated assault in the 1987 abduction. Byrd, who had contested being charged as an adult, entered the pleas before 3rd District Judge Homer Wilkinson. Defense attorney Walter F. Bugden Jr. said he expects his client will serve at least five years under the plea agreement. Byrd was charged with kidnapping then-16-year-old James Huntsman in December 1987 and demanding $1.1 million in ransom from his father. He also was charged with stabbing FBI agent Grant Alan Jacobsen as authorities rescued the Huntsman youth in a phone booth used to arrange a transfer of the ransom money. Byrd, who was 17 at the time, was charged under a law allowing direct filings in adult court against juvenile defendants in certain criminal cases. The aggravated assault charge, a third-degree felony that carries a term of up to five years, was reduced from an original count of second-degree attempted homicide, Bugden said. Byrd remains free on a $20,000 property bond. Sentencing was scheduled for June 7. The elder Huntsman served as a special assistant to President Nixon in 1971-72.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Sweeps Through Government's Conference Center
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout with both government groups in building at time of fire, second fire in business district, blaze still raging after seven hours. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Fire swept through the government's main conference center in New Delhi on Monday, forcing the evacuation of more than 400 police and state government officials who were in meetings. No deaths or injuries were reported. More than 250 firefighters and 45 fire vehicles continued to fight the blaze seven hours after it started at 4 p.m. The United News of India news agency said the fire at the five-story Vigyan Bhawan, or house of knowlege, may have been caused by an electrical short circuit. But senior police officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, did not rule out arson. Meanwhile, a second fire broke out in the Sadar Bazar business section of the Indian capital late Monday, police said. There were no reports of casulties, but police said several shops burned to the ground. More than 100 senior police officials were meeting in Vigyan Bhawan for a scheduled conference when the fire broke out. They had adjourned for a tea break when the blaze began. Additionally, 300 officials of state government's Information and Cinematography Departments also were inside the complex when the fire started.

DOC.HEAD: Jackson Tells Mourners: Boy's Death Must Renew Fight Against Racism
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with funeral, SUBS penultimate graf to add that some of boy's friends disputed report of .22-caliber gun. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: A 16-year-old boy's death by a police officer's bullet marks a call to action for blacks to renew their fight against racial insensitivity, the Rev. Jesse Jackson messaged to mourners today. ``It is Eastertime. We must meditate, but we must march,'' said Jackson in a message read at the funeral of Phillip Pannell, who was fatally shot Tuesday by a white police officer in Teaneck. ``We must not be docile, but decisive,'' Jackson said. Jackson's message was read by the Rev. Herbert Daughtry, pastor of the Pannell family. The civil rights leader dictated it to Daughtry from London, where he is meeting with South African apartheid opponent Nelson Mandela. More than 300 people packed the Community Baptist Church, and hundreds more gathered outside to hear the services through a public address system. ``We're here to support this grieving family,'' said Martha Bolds of Paterson, one of those who listened from outside the church. ``This mother's hurt is every mother's hurt,'' Ms. Bolds said. ``We are concerned about raising black boys in this society.'' The wake for Pannell Sunday night at Community Baptist Church drew several black leaders, including the Rev. Al Sharpton, Black Muslim leader Louis Farrakhan and Moses Stewart, the father of Yusuf Hawkins, who was killed in a racial incident in New York. A candlelight vigil Wednesday in Teaneck to mark Pannell's death turned violent when scores of black youths overturned police cars, smashed windows and looted businesses. Police said the situation was calm Sunday night. Pannell's father, Phillip Sr., was helped out of the church Sunday crying. ``My son, my son, they shot him in the back,'' he said. Sharpton said he planned to lead a march through Teaneck to protest the shooting, but the date of the event was unclear. Pannell was shot Tuesday by Teaneck Officer Gary Spath, who authorities said was responding to an anonymous tip that a teen-ager was brandishing a gun. An autopsy by the Bergen County medical examiner showed Pannell was shot once in the back. Spath has been suspendended with pay while the incident is investigated. Police said that officers believed the teen-ager was reaching for a gun. Police said a .22-caliber gun was found on the body, while some of the dead boy's friends have said he had a BB pistol instead. A grand jury begins hearing evidence in the case Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: At Least 87 Dead From Poison Food At Ceremonial Feast
DOC.TEXT: At least 87 people died of food poisoning after a feast to celebrate a marriage engagement in a northern village, Press Trust of India said Monday. More than 150 others were hospitalized after Sunday's dinner in Raipura Jungla near Lucknow, capital of the Uttar Pradesh state. Other guests streamed to hospitals, complaining of stomach ailments. Additional doctors were rushed to the area. An inquiry was ordered into the cause of the deaths. United News of India said preliminary investigations indicated a sulfur compound had contaminated the flour used for making puri, a fried bread. There was no indication whether the engaged couple was among the victims. In rural areas, such ceremonies are attended by entire villages, drawing hundreds of people.

DOC.HEAD: Three Inmates Surrender At Strangeways Prison, One ``Very Ill''
DOC.TEXT: Three sick prisoners surrendered Monday on the 16th day of a siege at Strangeways Prison, and one of the rebels was described as ``very ill'' with what was believed to be food poisoning. The prison head, Brendon O'Friel, speculated the men were eating contaminated food or water in the Victorian jail, where there have been no fresh supplies since a riot April 1. O'Friel appealed for the remaining seven rebels to give themselves up. Two of the prisoners who surrendered carried a third inmate on a stretcher. He was rushed to hospital. ``One boy is, I am afraid, very ill,'' said Mary Stewart, vice chairman of the prison's Board of Visitors. ``He was semiconscious when they brought him down. He had been hemorrhaging from the mouth.'' Mrs. Stewart, a magistrate and former nurse who has been at the prison most of the time since the riot began, said all three inmates showed the same symptoms. ``It is possible these three prisoners are suffering from some form of very serious food poisoning, maybe salmonella,'' O'Friel said. ``My appeal to the remaining seven is: if any of you are feeling ill, I strongly advise you to come down and let us get you to hospital. I do not want this to end in some sort of tragedy resulting from food poisoning or other illness.'' More than 1,500 prisoners rioted at the overcrowded prison April 1 and caused severe damage to the buildings. Most surrendered in the first days, but some remained on the loose. The number of holdouts dwindled day by day to the seven holding out Sunday. The prisoners stockpiled large amounts of food before the riot, but there was no refrigeration in the wing they were occupying. ``The meat they have been eating is now so rotten they cannot eat it,'' Mrs. Stewart said, adding food cans ``have been left open for 16 days ... It is very doubtful from where they are getting water from.'' O'Friel said ``another possibility with an old prison like Strangeways is that there are areas of the prison where we have been trying to prevent a spread of rats and they may have eaten rat poison.'' Earlier Monday, the rebel inmates started a serious fire, but there was no indication any of the prisoners were injured. The prisoners said Sunday they would carry on their siege another week, alleging that fellow rebels who had surrendered ``got broken arms and legs.'' Authorities denied the accusation.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Asks High Court To Block Environmental Suits
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration and the National Wildlife Federation clashed before the Supreme Court Monday over what it takes to prove an individual has been harmed by opening federal lands to commercial development. The Justice Department asked the high court to reverse a June ruling from the U.S. Appeals Court for the District of Columbia. The ruling gives environmentalists potentially sweeping power to prevent the restricted public lands from being opened to mining and mineral exploration. The appellate ruling said the federation may sue the Interior Department over the government's plans to change the status of 180 million acres of public land in the West and Alaska. The appellate came after the federation presented affidavits from members who said they use some of the land for recreation. Peggy K. Peterson said the Bureau of Land Management's decision to allow mining ``in the vicinity of'' South Pass-Green Mountain, Wyo., has adversely affected her recreational use and aesthetic enjoyment of the federal lands. ``In particular, the South Pass-Green Mountain area of Wyoming has been opened up to the staking of mining claims and oil and gas leasing, an action which threatens aesthetic beauty and wildlife habitat potential of these lands,'' she said in an affidavit. Federation spokesman David Alberswerth said Monday that a high court decision against the environmentalists would prevent them from challenging reclassification of land initiated by the Reagan administration in 1985 following a policy instituted by then-Interior Secretary James G. Watt in 1981. ``It will severely constrain the opportunity for environmental groups such as ours to take the government to court,'' Alberswerth said. The federation said the Reagan administration violated the federal law by opening the land to development without following procedures in the 1976 Federal Land Policy and Management Act, such as conducting environmental impact statements. The issue before the Supreme Court is whether Peterson and the federation's 4.5 million members have standing in the case _ or the right to sue _ based on damage to their recreational use and aesthetic enjoyment of the lands. John G. Roberts Jr. of the Justice Department told the justices that Peterson and others have been too vague in explaining the harm and the specific area where the harm has occurred. He said they should be required to show damages on specific tracts of land where commercial development has been approved.

DOC.HEAD: Bhutto Arrives In Saudi Arabia For Pilgrimage, Talks With Fahd
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto of Pakistan arrived Monday on a three-day visit to Mecca, and diplomatic sources said she would discuss a variety of issues with King Fahd. Bhutto, the only woman head of state in the Moslem world, was accompanied by a 45-member entourage, including her husband, Asif Ali Zardari, senior Cabinet ministers and high-ranking military officials. The Saudi monarch is in Mecca for the last third of Ramadan, the Moslem holy month of fasting. The sources, who spoke on condition they not be named, said Bhutto and Fahd were expected to discuss rising tension in the Indian state of Kashmir. Kashmir is an area on the border with Pakistan where Moslem separtists have been fighting for an independent state. Hindus comprise a majority in India, but Kashmir is the country's only Moslem-dominated area. The Saudi-based 46-member Organization of Islamic Conference has expressed concern about the clashes. Pakistan and India have gone to war twice over Kashmir. Afghanistan also is expected to be discussed. Pakistan and Saudi Arabia are supporters of the Moslem rebels who are fighting the Soviet-backed government. Bhutto's trip comes when her ruling party is trying to smooth differences with the Mojahir Qami Movement, which represents Moslem immigrants from India who entered Pakistan after the 1947 partition of the subcontinent. The movement withdrew its support from Bhutto's government last November, claiming it reneged on promises to the party. The switch allowed the opposition to force a no-confidence vote in Parliament, which Bhutto narrowly survived.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Wins Parliamentary Elections in Yugoslavian Republic
DOC.TEXT: A center-right coalition won a majority in Slovenia's free parliamentary elections and will form the first non-Communist regional government in Yugoslavia in 45 years, according to official results released Monday. The April 8 election in the northern republic was the first free multiparty vote in Yugoslavia since the Communists took power in 1945. The official results showed that the DEMOS coalition, consisting of six center-right parties, received 55 percent of the vote for places in the republic's 140-seat Parliament. The Slovenian Communist Party, which has ruled the republic, will remain the largest single party in Parliament with 17 percent of the vote. The Slovenian Liberal Party, which campaigned apart from the DEMOS coalition, emerged as the second-largest single party in Parliament with 14.49 percent. The Slovenian Christian Democrats were the largest vote-getters among the six parties within DEMOS, with 12.98 percent. The remainder of the vote was split among eight other parties. Slovenia will choose its first freely elected president since the end of World War II in a runoff Sunday between DEMOS leader Joze Pucnik, who advocates the republic's secession from Yugoslavia, and Milan Kucan, a reform Communist. Neither of the two managed to gain more than 50 percent support in the first round of presidential elections April 8. Kucan garnered 44.5 percent of the votes. Pucnik had 26.6 percent. Croatia, the second-largest Yugoslav republic, is also scheduled to stage multiparty parliamentary elections Sunday. The democratic reforms in Slovenia and Croatia have been implemented despite harsh criticism from the largest republic, Serbia. Its leaders support continued Communist Party dominance in Yugoslavia.

DOC.HEAD: Majority in Survey Opposes Killing Animals for Fur
DOC.TEXT: Most Americans say it should be illegal to kill animals for fur coats or to use them for cosmetics research, according to a poll released Monday. Eight in 10 respondents to the survey for Parents magazine said animals have some rights. Majorities disapproved of killing animals for sport or for making leather, but most did not favor outlawing those activities. The survey was conducted by telephone from Sept. 22 to Oct. 10 among a random sample of 1,004 Americans age 21 and older. It had a margin of error of plus or minus 3 percentage points. Eighty-five percent disapproved of killing animals to make fur coats, and 63 percent said it should be illegal. Eighty-one percent disapproved of cosmetics research on animals, and 58 percent said that should be illegal. At the same time, 85 percent said it was acceptable to kill animals for food; about two-thirds accepted capturing animals for exhibit in zoos or training animals to perform for humans; and 58 percent accepted using animals for medical research. While 69 percent disapproved of killing animals for leather, a smaller 46 percent said that should be illegal. And while 60 percent disapproved of hunting, a considerably smaller 33 percent said hunting should be illegal.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Criticized for Environmental Inaction
DOC.TEXT: Delegates from 17 nations gathered for a White House conference on global warming amid criticism Monday from some participants and environmentalists that the Bush administration isn't dealing with the problem. Senior administration officials said the United States will call for increased international research on both the science of global warming and the economic implications of the ``greenhouse'' effect when the two-day conference begins Tuesday. But as delegates arrived, environmentalists chastised President Bush for not calling for specific actions to ease the global warming problem, including commitments to make specific reductions in greenhouse pollutants. The Sierra Club, which announced a TV advertising campaign to highlight concerns about global warming, called the White House conference an attempt by the administration to shift the focus of the issue away from the need for pollution controls to a debate over economic considerations. ``It's really a smoke screen for the administration's inaction on global warming,'' said Daniel Becker of the Sierra Club. ``We know enough now to begin acting on to curb global warming today.'' Some conference participants also expressed concern about the heavy U.S. focus on more research. ``In spite of remaining uncertainties on some aspects of the issue, an effective response policy must be established now, without any further delay,'' said a statement issued on behalf of the 12 nations attending from the European Community. Laurnes Jan Brinkhorst, director-general for the environment of the European Community's Council of Ministers, and Padraig Flynn, environmental minister of Ireland, said there was an ``urgent need for an effective response policy'' while additional research is under way. Senior administration officials have reiterated in recent days that Bush will offer no new policy proposals to curb the manmade pollution that scientists agree is causing the earth to warm. Bush, in remarks that will open the conference, was expected instead to focus on the need for additional research to resolve both scientific uncertainties about global warming and establish clearer estimates on economic costs. The conference, which is being held just days before Sunday's celebration of Earth Day, fulfills a campaign promise Bush made to hold an international conference on global warming early in his presidency. Representatives to the meeting are senior cabinet-level advisers on economics, science and the environment from 17 nations, including the European community, Japan and Brazil. Bush advisers said they hoped the conference would, for the first time, give equal weight to economic and environmental issues related to global warming and ``ensure the economics will be injected ... into all future international forums'' on the subject. ``We hope it will raise the level of debate ... on the science and economics of global change,'' said Michael Boskin, chairman of the president's Council of Economic Advisers and one of the conference co-chairmen. A number of European countries, including the Netherlands and West Germany, have advocated that industrial nations commit to a stabilization of carbon dioxide emissions by 2000 through a variety of programs reducing energy needs. Carbon dioxide, which is produced in the burning of fossil fuels, is responsible for about half the greenhouse pollutants. Environmentalists have argued that a wide range of actions could be taken to conserve energy and reduce greenhouse pollutants by requiring the manufacture of more fuel-efficient cars and promoting energy savings in other ways in homes and businesses. The Sierra Club, which has more than 500,000 members, will take that message to the public with a series of public service ads featuring actors such as William Shatner, John Ritter and Jane Alexander. The Bush administration has maintained that while there is widespread agreement that manmade pollutants are causing the earth to warm, it's not clear how severe the problem will be to warrant pollution controls that could have widespread economic impact. The president's chief science adviser, Allen Bromley, last week criticized those who advocate ``slam-dunk solutions'' to global warming. ``We cannot sail blindly into the future,'' said Bromley, another conference co-chairman. Some computer models have suggested that manmade pollutants will cause a 4-degree to 9-degree Fahrenheit increase in global temperatures in 60 years as the increasing pollution traps heat close to the Earth. However, some scientists said those projections are uncertain and may not adequately take into account clouds or other factors that might have a counteracting effect.

DOC.HEAD: Should Cabbage Glow in the Dark?
DOC.TEXT: The Agriculture Department said Monday it has given the go-ahead for an Auburn University scientist to conduct field tests of cabbage and broccoli that have been genetically engineered to glow. Officials said a permit has been issued to Joseph Shaw, an assistant professor of botany and microbiology, to begin the tests this month in Macon County, Ala. Shaw transferred a set of genes having a code for bioluminescence from a marine organism into bacteria that causes black rot, a major disease of plants in the cabbage and broccoli family. After infecting plants with the luminescent black rot bacteria, the diseased plant parts will glow, allowing scientists to trace the progress of the disease through the plant. One of the benefits of the process will be the observation of the disease's progress without destroying the plants, Shaw said in a report released here. James W. Glosser, administrator of the department's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, which issued the permit, said a review showed the proposed field tests ``will pose no agricultural or human hazard.'' In nature, the microorganism _ Vibrio fischeri _ enjoys a ``symbiotic relationship with fish, for which it produces light,'' the agency said. ``Scientists suspect the fish use the glowing microorganisms to communicate with each other.''

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: Dog may be man's best friend, but sometimes dogs choose other creatures dear _ or deer, as the case may be. Richard Faulkner's yellow Labrador, Jake, has taken up with a chummy young buck that showed up in Faulkner's wooded back yard a couple of weeks ago, looking hungry and lost. Jake, a frisky 3-year-old, made the deer feel at home, sharing his water bucket and trying to entice the woodland animal into games. ``Jake must think the deer is a dog and the deer must think Jake is a deer,'' said Faulkner. The dog tosses a bone into the air, hoping the deer will get the idea and play along. The deer watches closely, but doesn't get it, or just doesn't like that particular game. He does occasionally hunker down on the ground nose-to-nose with Jake, Faulkner said. And when frightened, the deer huddles near Jake's back-yard dog house for protection. ``I can't understand it and I've thought about it quite a bit, too,'' said Faulkner, 59, who retired Friday from his job as a night watchman at a quarry. ``I think both of them are lonely.'' The deer follows Faulkner to his garden and lets him get within 5 feet. ``I think there's a bond between people and animals,'' he said. Faulkner refuses to make a pet of the animal, saying he fears that the deer could hurt children in his neighborhood. He tried scaring the buck off recently but it returned.

A prisoner says he has invented a device that will prevent the crime that put him behind bars. ``It has kept me very busy,'' said Joe Walker, 34. ``I've worked on this 18 hours a day. I probably never would have done it if I hadn't been arrested. I never would have had the time. Right now, all I've got is time.'' Walker is serving a six-year term in federal prison for interstate transportation of stolen property, part of what he calls his ``past minor indiscretions.'' Walker and engineer Tim Jensen say they have a patent pending on The Trailer Guard, which they say will stop the theft of truck trailers. Walker said the Trailer Guard makes it impossible for anyone to connect a truck's ``fifth wheel'' _ the coupling on the rear of the tractor _ to the trailer's kingpin and haul off the parked trailer. In 1987, 177,807 trailers were stolen nationwide at a loss of $8 billion, according to the American Trucking Association. Walker said he had to shop around to find an engineer to help with his invention. ``I had called several engineers, but as soon as I told them where I was calling from they said, `Sorry, can't help you,''' Walker said. Walker, who has 18 months left of his sentence, made his comments by telephone from the Federal Correctional Institute at Seagoville, 15 miles southeast of Dallas. Walker said after he is released, he would like to stay in the Dallas area and set up his business.

DOC.HEAD: Insurance Company Halts Payments for Alzheimer Therapy
DOC.TEXT: An insurance company has rejected more than 40,000 claims totaling $1.1 million from an agency that provides services for Alzheimer's patients. Nationwide Insurance company said it stopped the Medicare payments Oct. 1 because recreational and social activities were part of the therapy provided. A group has formed to fight Nationwide's denial of Medicare payments to Intergenerational Services Inc., a non-profit agency founded five years ago. The Toledo-based agency said it will have to close by the end of the month unless the company changes its position. ``Time is short since we're facing a deadline which is less than three weeks away, but we're determined to gather an impressive number of signatures,'' said Judith Messinger, chairwoman of Advocates for Alzheimer's Victims. The group was formed Friday to call attention to the fact that the agency will have to shut if the claims aren't paid and to gather signatures to show support for their cause. Intergenerational provides psychotherapy to Alzheimer's patients at 66 nursing homes in 15 northwest Ohio counties. William P. Ramsey, vice president of Nationwide's Medicare operation, said in a statement last week, ``As a Medicare carrier under federal government contract, Nationwide is obligated to safeguard the proper use of Medicare money.'' Dr. Alice Faryna, medical director for Nationwide's Medicare operations, said in the statement certain psychotherapeutic services that are medically necessary are payable under Medicare. However, she also said that a review indicates that some of Intergenerational's activities do not fit the description of psychotherapy. ``They just feel that these older people don't have much of a future, and that it's not really worth the money to invest in making their quality of life a little bit better than it was before,'' said the Rev. A. Otto Baumann II, agency president. The program, which began at the suggestion of a Toledo nursing home, is designed to help patients become more social and ease depression, program director Susan Lemle said. It also operates an Alzheimer's day care center in Toledo.

DOC.HEAD: Nepal's King Asks Opposition Party to Form Government
LaserPhoto KAT1
DOC.TEXT: King Birendra on Monday asked the once-banned Nepali Congress Party to form an interim government to rule until the first free elections in nearly three decades are held. A leader of the party, Ganesh Man Singh, met with Birendra and said the king indicated he would give up his wide powers. Singh said after the meeting that parliamentary elections would be held within a year. Birendra approved Krishna Prasad Bhattarai as the new prime minister pending the vote, Singh said. Bhattarai is acting president of the Nepali Congress Party. The events capped a day of political victories for the Nepali Congress Party and its ally, the seven-party United Left Front. They led nationwide pro-democracy demonstrations that began in February. The palace press secretary was not available for comment. Earlier Monday, Birendra dissolved the non-partisan national assembly and announced the resignation of the 10-day-old government of Prime Minister Lokendra Bahadur Chand, clearing the way for the new interim government. The concessions followed the king's decision April 8 to lift the 29-year-old ban on political parties in an effort to appease the pro-democracy movement, which included violent clashes between protesters and police. Bhattarai, 65, told reporters he will present the names of the members of his government to the king Tuesday. A Nepali Congress statement said Birendra first asked Singh to head the government, but the 75-year-old leader refused, citing ill health. Singh then suggested Bhattarai as the new government leader, and the United Left Front agreed, the statement said. ``His Majesty accepted the suggestion and asked Mr. Singh to convey his pleasure to Mr. Bhattarai on his nomination,'' said the statement. It added ``Mr. Singh repeatedly emphasised the great benefits the country shall derive if his majesty very gracefully accepted the role of a constitutional monarch of a parliamentary democracy.'' Singh later said Birendra expressed his inclination toward changing the country to a constitutional monarchy. ``He did not say in explicit terms but favored the idea,'' Singh said. Under the present system all executive, legislative and judicial powers are in the king's hands. Birendra invited Singh to the palace after talks between Chand and opposition groups on forming an interim government broke down Sunday. The Nepali Congress and the United Left Front, who launched their movement Feb. 18, demanded multiparty elections, an interim government headed by an opposition leader, the dissolution of the national assembly and a new constitution. Bhattarai said a commission would draft a new constitution. He added, ``I hope in course of our work with the king there will be no use for his special powers.'' Those powers will remain in force until a new consitution is framed. He said it was unlikely members of the former national assembly would participate in the new government. Bhattarai called his new job ``a very, very challenging task for which I was not at all mentally prepared. Still I am glad that my friends and comrades have reposed so much ... confidence in me for which I am thankful to them all. ``I still do not know to what extent I shall be able to do something for all those who have given their lives for the cause of democracy,'' he said. Bhattarai was the speaker of the Nepalese parliament during the nation's only previous experience with Western-style democracy from 1959-60. Birendra's father, King Mahendra, dissolved the government led by the Nepali Congress in December 1960, accusing it of corruption and incompetence. Political parties were banned shortly afterward. Thousands of demonstrators stoned Chand's car Sunday afternoon and wrecked it during the night outside the Royal Nepal Academy of arts and literature. Bhattarai said the new government's first priorities would be improving the economy and relations with India. Landlocked, mountainous Nepal is one of the world's poorest countries. Bhattarai also said his government planned to compensate the families of those killed by security forces during the seven-week democracy campaign and reorganize the police force to limit its powers. In a radio broadcast announcing the dissolution of the national assembly, Birendra said ``in view of the events that have taken place in certain parts of the country, the people's aspirations and the ideals of democracy, we have been making political changes. ``There should be a congenial atmosphere where every citizen can enjoy democracy and nobody should be forced to do anything which can run counter to the expression of freedom.'' Yog Prasad Upadhyaya, secretary-general of the Nepali Congress, described Birendra's statement as showing ``progress in the right direction.''

DOC.HEAD: UNITA Claims Military Successes
DOC.TEXT: Angolan rebels Monday claimed their forces killed 78 soldiers, destroyed 92 military vehicles and shot down two helicopters belonging to the Marxist government in two days of fighting. The heaviest clashes occurred Saturday in the province of Uige, 150 miles northeast of the Angolan capital Luanda, the rebels said in a statement distributed in Lisbon. They said guerrillas ambushed a convoy of military vehicles there. The U.S.-backed UNITA rebels claimed to have destroyed 70 vehicles and killed 43 government troops in the raid. Two of four helicopters taking part in the fighting were destroyed by rebel anti-aircraft fire, said the UNITA statement. The Angolan Defense Ministry said a Soviet-built Mi-17 helicopter was downed by the rebels, killing three crew members, but said another Mi-17 escaped with minor damage. UNITA has vowed to step up its activities in northern Angola in response to the government's advance into its southeastern territories in December. Monday's rebel statement said 35 government soldiers died in three clashes with UNITA forces on the southern front over Friday and Saturday. Western and Angolan diplomats in Lisbon said Monday no date or venue had been set for peace talks between UNITA and the government to end the guerilla conflict, now in its 15th year. Unconfirmed reports last week said direct negotiations between the two sides could start soon in Lisbon. UNITA proposed the Portuguese capital as a venue for talks, but the government said it would prefer the West African nation of Cape Verde. Both sides have expressed a desire for talks aimed at a cease-fire and a political solution to the conflict. A cease-fire agreed to last summer and tentative peace talks broke down within weeks. UNITA _ the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola _ has been fighting since the country gained independence from Portugal in 1975 to force the Cuban and Soviet-backed government to share power.

DOC.HEAD: Milk Production Up Slightly
DOC.TEXT: Milk production in the first three months of 1990 was up about 1 percent from the first quarter of last year, the Agriculture Department said Monday. The U.S. total was reported at about 36.9 billion pounds in the first quarter, compared with less than 36.5 billion pounds a year earlier. In the 21 major dairy states, which account for about 85 percent of the U.S. total, output was reported at 31.3 billion pounds. The number of cows on farms was shown at 8.51 million head, down 27,000 from a year earlier. The average milk output per cow in the 21 states was 1,291 pounds in March, up 23 pounds from March 1989. Department analysts forecast U.S. milk production this year may rise 1 percent to 3 percent from last year's 144.3 billion pounds. ``The high milk prices of late 1989 and early 1990 have provided a financial boost to dairy farmers and a stimulus to production,'' the department's Economic Research Service said.

DOC.HEAD: Work Continues to Empty Religious Group's Leaking Fuel Tanks
DOC.TEXT: The estimated size of a fuel leak near Yellowstone National Park reached 31,000 gallons Monday, and the state considered legal action against the sect that owns the leaking tanks. Workers continued to pump out 35 tanks with a capacity of 634,500 gallons of diesel fuel and gasoline that were buried during the winter by the Church Universal and Triumphant as part of a 750-person fallout shelter complex. The sect buried the fuel for use after an unspecified global catastrophe it believes may occur this spring. The complex is five miles north of Yellowstone National Park and within several hundred yards of Mol Heron Creek, an important cutthroat trout spawning stream that runs into the Yellowstone River. The estimated size of the spill was increased from 19,000 to 31,000 gallons as a result of more accurate measurements, but officials hadn't ruled out the possibility that more fuel was leaking, said Steve Pilcher, chief of the state Water Quality Bureau. Small amounts of fuel that reached the creek Sunday were gone Monday, and no major damage had occurred, officials said. U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service officials took water samples downstream from the spill for tests. The sect owns about 30,000 acres in southern Montana's Park County. It has sponsored several housing developments in the rural, remote area and urged its members to build fallout shelters in anticipation of a nuclear war or nuclear accident. But the church says its concern over nuclear holocaust took second place to pollution when it discovered last week that three tanks were leaking. ``This is our home; the last thing we want is to have to deal with an environmental problem,'' said church spokesman Murray Steinman. Church spiritual leader Elizabeth Clare Prophet ``has said protecting our ecosystem is more important the our bomb shelters.'' State health officials met in Helena to decide whether to seek a court order to make sure the church carries out its plans to dig up the 35 tanks and inspect them for leaks, Pilcher said. The state may seek an injunction either to guarantee the tanks are emptied, tested and removed, or to halt construction at the site, he said. State officials also were attempting to determine if the spill violated the state's water quality and underground storage tank laws, Pilcher said. ``We don't have any idea where that 31,000 gallons of fuel is,'' Pilcher said. ``If we did, we'd know how dangerous our enemy is. ... It could show up anywhere. They're going to have to begin digging and follow the contaminated soil until they find it, and either recover it or get rid of it.'' Pilcher said the tanks may have ruptured because they were installed in frozen soil that shifted when it began to thaw. By being installed during the winter, the tanks are exempt from new underground tank regulations that took effect April 1. Church officials decided over the weekend to pump out the tanks. ``After the second and third leaks, we said, `That's it, we're going to get all this out of here,''' Steinman said. He said tanker trucks hauled out 110,000 gallons of gasoline Sunday, leaving 430,000 gallons of gasoline and diesel fuel to be moved. State officials earlier this year reopened an environmental review of church developments near Corwin Springs, saying the church concealed construction of the shelter complex during the original review, completed in March 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Says ``Time is Wasting'' on Nicaragua Aid
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration suggested Monday that delaying action on its Central American aid package beyond Nicaragua's April 25 inauguration would be an affront to incoming President Violeta Chamorro. ``I have pledged to Mrs. Chamorro that the United States government would respond in Nicaragua's hour of need,'' said President Bush, renewing criticism of congressional inaction on his $800 million aid request for Nicaragua and Panama. ``I'm disappointed that Congress failed to take the final steps to make the funds available before the Easter recess,'' he told a conference at the White House on Latin-American affairs. At the same time, a senior administration said ``it would be a very unfortunate message for the Congress to send to Mrs. Chamorro not to have this on the president's desk by her inauguration.'' ``Time is wasting. To cut this package and reduce it supposedly to help some other part of the world would be a historic mistake,'' said the official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity at a briefing on Tuesday's visit of Honduras President Rafael L. Callejas. The package bogged down in Congress calls for $500 million for Panama and $300 million for Nicaragua. However, the House increased the package to $2.4 billion, adding money for U.S. projects including food stamps, disaster relief, fighting forest fires and veterans programs. The Senate has yet to act on the legislation. Congress returns from its recess later this week and the Senate is expected to quickly take up the Central American aid package. Many members have called for expanding the package to include more aid for emerging Eastern European democracies. The administration last week said it would shift some $3.6 million in already appropriated funds as a stopgap measure to help a joint United Nations-Organization of Americans States team begin the process of demobilizing Contra rebels. Many of the rebels are in camps in Honduras. But the senior administration official said, ``There are some 45,000 family members of the resistance who will remain in Honduras as refugees. They want to go home.'' Bush's $300 million request for Nicaragua includes $47 million for refugees and resistanze members and families. ``If that money is not available, the ability of the Central Americans and Mrs. Chamorro to help this process move along is going to be crippled. It would burden Honduras with a burden it should not have at this time. They've been very patient for many years,'' the official said. Bush told his audience that Mrs. Chamorro's inauguration ``will close a painful chapter in (Nicargua's) history and begin a new story _ a new life in democracy.'' ``I believe the United States of America has a great deal at stake in the success of Violeta Chamorro, but more so in democracy itself in Nicaragua,'' Bush said.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Pondering Sweeping Changes in Banking System
DOC.TEXT: Bush administration is examining ideas for broad changes in the banking system, but is months away from deciding on specific proposals, officials said Monday. The Treasury Department has expanded an ongoing study of federal deposit insurance to include a look at restructuring the regulatory bureaucracy and at mixing commercial banking with the insurance and securities industries, officials said. Savings and loan legislation enacted last August requires Treasury to complete the deposit insurance study by February. It is focused on ways to limit taxpayers' liability for the insurance and on removing incentives from the system that encourage unwarranted risk-taking by insured institutions. Administration officials also have long discussed modernizing the financial system by relaxing the restrictions that have separated commercial banking from the securities business since enactment of the 1933 Glass-Steagall Act. The effort, which is being combined with the deposit insurance study, has been intensified by the prospect of increased competition from foreign institutions after the economic unification of Europe in 1992. The administration also is reviewing a recent congressional report that predicted the savings and loan bailout will fall short, requiring billions of dollars more from taxpayers. ``The Treasury Department is ... broadening (the study) to consider other problems in the financial industry. The savings and loan situation certainly demands attention,'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Monday. ``I think it's fair to say that Treasury is looking at the broad regulatory aspects of banking.'' Officials denied, however, that the administration was settling on a number of controversial proposals reported in Monday's editions of The Washington Post. Among them were: _Cutting the $100,000-per-account deposit insurance in half and limiting depositors to one insured account. _Merging the banking and S&L industries and eliminating the Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision. _Combining the insurance funds for banks and thrift institutions, thereby forcing banks to help pay for the S&L bailout. ``We don't have any conclusions at the moment. (The study) is certainly a long way from being completed,'' Fitzwater said. Treasury spokeswoman Desiree Tucker-Sorini said the deposit insurance review is in its early stages and the administration has no preconceived ideas about how the system should be changed. She said the administration last year rejected merging the bank and S&L insurance funds and ``we have no proposal'' to do that now. ``At this time, we don't see any reason'' to abolish the thrift office, she added. But she also said that the department hasn't rejected any ideas either, only that the administration believes this year is too soon after passage of the S&L law to act on major banking legislation. ``For next year, who knows? At this point, it's way too early to determine,'' she said. Deputy Treasury Secretary John E. Robson, in a private speech earlier this month to the Independent Bankers Association of America, revealed that the department had widened the scope of its approach. ``The Treasury study is not going to focus on deposit insurance in a vacuum,'' Robson said. ``We are taking a comprehensive approach, including consideration of ... the financial activities in which institutions engage and the regulatory structure.'' Lobbing groups objected strongly to some of the ideas floated in the Post's story. ``Floating a proposal to cut back existing levels of deposit insurance is unfortunate,'' said Kenneth Guenther, executive vice president of the Independent Bankers Association of America. ``It further weakens confidence in the financial industry and, if implemented, would further weaken the thrift industry and consequently increase the cost of the S&L bailout.'' Robert Dugger, chief economist of the American Bankers Association, said merging the bank and S&L insurance funds would raise public concerns about bank safety. ``It's a formula for ... financial disaster,'' he said. ``You can't burden the bank insurance fund with the thrift crisis. It's not designed for that and would collapse under the weight.''

DOC.HEAD: Militant Moslem Groups Banned in Kashmir
DOC.TEXT: The government on Monday banned eight militant Moslem organizations in Kashmir and closed two local newspapers in its latest effort to contain unrest in the disputed territory. The Press Trust of India news agency said one of the organizations outlawed was the Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front, which is leading the bloody independence campaign in the northern area bordering Pakistan. The two newspapers closed are in Srinagar, Kashmir's main city and the center of the separatist campaign. A government statement said the Urdu language newspapers, Aftab and Alsafa, had published materials to incite the public. Earlier Monday, witnesses accused Indian soldiers of brutalizing suspected militants during house-to-house searches. At least 33 people were arrested. The searches came on the 10th day of a 24-hour curfew that has restricted civilians to their homes. In one district, troops were seen forcing a group of men to perform squats _ a knee-bend exercise _ with heavy stones on their backs. ``None of them are militants,'' said one witness. ``But this will make them militants. We thought the Indian army was disciplined, but we were wrong.'' He and other witnesses, all of whom spoke on condition of anonymity, said they were too far away to know what provoked the action. The government imposed a round-the-clock curfew April 6 after three people were kidnapped by Moslem militants, whose seek secession of the Kashmir valley from Hindu-dominated India. All three hostages were shot to death when the government failed to respond to the kidnappers' demands of freedom for three jailed comrades. Since then, residential areas of Srinagar, at the far northern tip of India, have been under constant curfew as troops fan out to search for suspects. On Monday, the government announced a two-hour relaxation of curfew in the Civil Lines shopping district. Witnesses said most shops in Civil Lines did not open because the shop owners live in downtown Srinagar, where curfew was not lifted. The insurgency in the Kashmir valley has claimed at least 270 lives since the government cracked down on the Moslem movement on Jan. 20. Most of the victims have died in confrontations between security forces and the militants. The independence movement has also escalated tensions between India and Pakistan, which have fought two wars over the valley since both counties gained independence from Britain in 1947. The Hindu ruler of the Moslem-dominated Kashmir province opted to join India, although other Moslem-majority provinces went to Islamic Pakistan. A Moslem secession movement has grown in recent years because of complaints the region was being ignored by New Delhi. India accuses Pakistan of fomenting the insurgency, an accusation Pakistan denies.

DOC.HEAD: Alleged Drug Kingpin, Two Others Escape from Private Prison
DOC.TEXT: Local, federal and Mexican officials on Monday searched for a suspected leader of a multimillion-dollar drug ring and two other inmates who pulled a gun on a guard and escaped from a privately operated jail. The three cellmates at the Central Texas Parole Violators Facility fled late Sunday on foot. One of the three lured a guard to the cell by pretending to be sick, then pulled a .25-caliber handgun, said U.S. Marshal Bill Jonas. The three inmates then locked up two guards in a closet and overpowered another before seizing the security control panels and opening a door, Jonas said. Officials of Wackenhut Corp., which operates the supplementary jail under contract with Bexar County to alleviate jail crowding, speculate the pistol was smuggled inside during visiting hours Sunday, said Pat Cannan, spokesman for the Coral Gables, Fla., company. Visitors are screened at the prison, across the street from police headquarters, but Cannan would not give details of the process. The escapees were identified as Mario Alberto Salinas Trevino, Charlie Edward Compton and Juan Chapa Garza. Salinas, 37, led one of the largest drug-smuggling and money-laundering rings between Texas and Mexico, authorities said. He was among 25 people arrested last year in ``Operation Jet Set,'' a series of raids by federal authorities in California and Texas. Authorities seized $10 million from Salinas when he was arrested. He's also suspected of having up to $10 million in drug money stashed in Texas or Mexico, Jonas said. Law enforcement authorities suspect Salinas would go to Mexico, about 150 miles away. ``That's a logical escape route,'' said Jonas. ``If that's the case, I think he's acting ill-advisedly. I have every reason to believe the Mexican government will cooperate with us.'' Salinas allegedly led a drug ring with Ramiro Mirales Felix of Guadalajara, Mexico, federal prosecutors said when Salinas was arrested. Officials allege the ring transported more than 46,000 pounds of marijuana, 1,900 pounds of cocaine and made financial transactions or purchases in excess of $7.6 million. The ring allegedly distributed the drugs in Texas, Pennsylvania, California, Illinois, Florida and Massachusetts. Indictments alleged the ring used banks in San Antonio and Roma, Texas, and San Ysidro, Calif., to launder the narcotics profits. Compton was awaiting trial on possession of cocaine with intent to distribute charges. Chapa was charged with possession of marijuana with intent to distribute. The fugitives' cases were not connected, Jonas said, but added: ``I would think that the three of them would stay together for awhile.''

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Won't Block Return Of Youth Facing Possible Death Sentence
DOC.TEXT: A juvenile facing a possible death sentence in Alabama lost his final court battle to avoid extradition Monday when the Supreme Court refused to hear his appeal. The 17-year-old boy, identified in court proceedings only by the initials O.M., is charged with arson and murder in the May 1988 death of 14-month-old Tamal Jackson, who was killed when a firebomb exploded inside an apartment at a Gadsden, Ala., housing project. O.M. has been fighting extradition since his arrest by District of Columbia authorities in December 1988. His battle has attracted widespread attention because of its focus on capital punishment for juveniles and Southern justice for blacks. James A. Hedgspeth, district attorney for Etowah County, Ala., said the Supreme Court's refusal to hear the case removes the last legal obstacle to the youth's return to Alabama to face the juvenile petition charging him with arson and murder. The Etowah County District Court will determine whether O.M. will be certified to stand trial as an adult, a move that could subject him to the death penalty if convicted. O.M.'s lawyers argued unsuccessfully in Washington courts that his extradition would violate the district government's ban on capital punishment. They also contended that O.M., who is black, could not get a fair trial from the predominantly white judicial system in Etowah County, where both his father and another relative died in police custody. Two of O.M.'s uncles, 32-year-old Yul Devoe Guice and an 18-year-old identified only by the initials S.T., also were charged with arson and murder in the death of the Jackson infant. S.T. was arrested by District of Columbia authorities last summer and has also been fighting extradition to Alabama.

DOC.HEAD: President Gets Things Rolling at White House
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 9th graf pvs `Some eggs ...' to UPDATE with crowd count. SUBS 21st graf pvs `Some people ...' to UPDATE with thousands of seedlings given away
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos WX8, WX11
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of children frolicked on the White House lawn Monday, hunting wooden eggs and rolling real ones in a rite of spring that converted the presidential estate into a playground. President Bush joined briefly in the fun, blowing a shiny whistle to start an Easter Egg Roll in which his 3-year-old granddaughter, Marshall Bush, was entered. Seven-year-old Michael Angel of Fairfax, Va., was unabashed at the competition. While the others nudged, poked or putted their eggs along with plastic spoons, Michael ran away from the field with his egg firmly esconced in spoon. ``He's pretty cool,'' Michael said about Bush. Mia Angel, Michael's 5-year-old sister, said the president was fun, but ``he didn't shake my hand.'' Actually, there were no winners or losers in the 10-yard races. All comers got wooden eggs bearing the names of George and Barbara Bush. The same prizes were to be found without too much scrutiny under hay strewn about in pens elsewhere on the lawn. Some eggs bore real signatures from the likes of Michael Jackson and other famous White House visitors. At day's end, Debra Romash, director of the White House Visitors Office, reported that 23,250 people came through the gates, up from about 22,000 last year. The wait for some families to get in was hours; others, like the four children that Frankie Mason brought from a shelter in nearby Alexandria, Va., had special passes that let them right in. ``C'mon,'' said Ms. Mason, lining up her charges for pictures in front of a billboard-sized Easter egg. ``We need to know that we were here.'' Vin and Paula Paolino came from Boston with sons David, 6, and James, 3. They arrived on the Ellipse at 10:15 a.m.; at 12:38 p.m., they were still in line, 50 yards _ and another 20 minutes _ from the White House gate. They had no complaints. ``I've been telling all my patients about this for three months. Everybody's been cheering us on,'' said Vin Paolino, a dentist. Eric Valdes, a spindly 7-year-old from Wheaton, Md., displayed unusual strength at the Easter Egg Roll. He gave one powerful swipe that lofted his egg across the finish line _ and onto the head of Margaret Hedger, intent on taking a picture of her own child in the same race. The young mother from Stafford, Va., was not hurt, but said she would ``probably not'' be back next year. The lawn teemed with clowns, minstrels, an Abe Lincoln look-alike, balloon-blowers, dancers, bands, a yo-yo master, and other entertainers, including puppeteer Shari Lewis. ``I want to get my face painted,'' said 9-year-old Chad Hampton of Herndon, Va., who came with his sister, mother and other friends. ``I got lucky. I got a balloon.'' ``We got up at 6 a.m. We left at 7 and were down here at 8:15,'' said his mother, Margie Hampton, who took the morning off from work as a medical social worker. ``Don't ask me if it's worth it. But what we do for kids!'' Thousands got Virginia pine seedlings, including Beverly Johnson, who brought 11 youngsters from a local day-care center she runs. ``We'll plant it right in the (center's) front yard,'' said Damares Blondonville, her assistant. All the children got canvas sacks crammed with books, suggestions for celebrating Earth Day and other souvenirs.

DOC.HEAD: Republican Chairman's Wife Gives Birth
DOC.TEXT: Sally Atwater, wife of Republican Party chairman Lee Atwater, gave birth Monday to the couple's third daughter, Sally Theodosia. Lee Atwater has been undergoing treatment for a brain tumor and is resting at home after receiving radiation and chemotherapy treatment at a New York hospital. ``This just goes to show you that regardless of how tough things get there's always a brighter tomorrow and room for new hope and sunshine,'' Atwater said in a statement issued through the Republican National Committee.

DOC.HEAD: Singapore Leader Says Bush to Retain Asian Presence
DOC.TEXT: President George Bush assured Singapore's probable next government chief Monday that the United States intends to maintain a strong military presence in the Western Pacific, said the visitor, First Deputy Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong. ``We support that,'' Goh told reporters after a half-hour White House meeting with Bush, Secretary of State James A. Baker III, National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft and other U.S. leaders. ``Don't give up your influence in the area'' under fiscal pressure, added Goh, named by longtime Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew three years ago as Lee's eventual successor as head of the Singapore government and ruling Peoples Action Party. The United States has invested many years building influence in the Western Pacific and it would be wrong to abandon it just as countries in the area such as Singapore, Hong Kong, Taiwan and South Korea are taking off economically, he said. Goh also urged U.S. steadfastness in backing the policy of Singapore and other members of ASEAN, the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, toward seeking a comprehensive solution for Cambodia, devastated by years of civil war. ``The question is, do we now become suddenly exhausted and hand the game to the Vietnamese-backed Hun Seng government, or to the Khmer Rouge, or do we try ... to ensure that the non-communist resistance has a chance to win in a fair elections which may be held under United Nations supervision?'' he said. U.S. officials have been reported reassessing U.S. Cambodian policy to break a deadlock among the Cambodian factions that critics say threatens a return to power of the Khmer Rouge, blamed for more than a million Cambodian deaths in the 1970s. Singapore has said U.S. forces could use some of its facilities if the United States and the Philippines fail to agree on future terms for American bases in the Philippines.

DOC.HEAD: Striking Bus Driver Arrested in Bus Shooting
DOC.TEXT: A striking bus driver was arrested Monday on federal charges in the shooting of a Greyhound bus last month, a prosecutor said. In Falksville, Ala. a Greyhound bus was fired on as it travelled from Nashville, Tenn., to Birmingham, Ala., said company spokeswoman Ann Wheat. The shot missed, and there were no injuries. In Kansas City, maintenence workers found a bullet embedded in the radiator of a bus that arrived from St. Louis, Ms. Wheat said. Dennis L. Daniels, a Greyhound driver for 10 years, was arrested at his Columbus home and was being held without bond pending a bail hearing, said U.S. Attorney D. Michael Crites. A federal grand jury Friday charged Daniels, 42, with damaging the bus in reckless disregard for the safety of passengers and using a firearm in damaging the bus. The bus, en route from Columbus to Cincinnati, was hit by three shots fired from a car early March 9 on Interstate 71 about 25 miles southwest of Columbus. There were no injuries to either the 29 passengers or the bus' replacement driver. ``We are very happy an arrest has been made,'' said Greyhound spokesman George Gravley. ``We are obviously pleased that federal agencies have become involved in the shootings. ``Our overall interest is getting the violence stopped,'' Gravley said. ``If more arrests are made, it may be effective in preventing further violence.'' Daniels was the fourth person arrested since Greyhound's 6,300 drivers and 3,000 maintenence and office workers walked out March 2 in a dispute over wages and job security. One person was arrested in Connecticut and two in St. Louis. Gravley said there have been 31 shooting attacks involving Greyound and seven injuries since the strike began. He said the company won't negotiate with striking drivers and other employees until a week goes by without incident. The striking employees' union said the seven-day standard means any criminal can hold up negotiating talks. ``Ninety-three hundred employees are being held hostage by common criminals,'' said Jeff Nelson, spokesman for the Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions in Washington. Nelson said company officials ``have a legal obligation to negotiate and they're hiding from that legal obligation by using violence as a smokescreen.'' ``First of all, until proven guilty, the gentleman is innocent,'' he said. ``But we continue to stand by our previous statment, that anyone involved in violence should be brought to justice, no matter who he is.''

DOC.HEAD: Medal of Honor Winner Dies
DOC.TEXT: Retired Vice Adm. Lawson P. Ramage, who was awarded the Medal of Honor during World War II, died of cancer Monday at his home. He was 81. Ramage was the first living submariner to receive the Medal of Honor, which was awarded after his vessel attacked a Japanese convoy off Formosa on July 31, 1944. A 1931 graduate of the Naval Academy, Ramage took over his first command _ the USS Trout _ in 1942. The Trout engaged in successful patrols near Midway and the Truk Islands and in the South China Sea. Later in 1942, he was promoted to commander and the next year took over command of the USS Parche. After retiring from the Navy, Ramage was active in consulting and community service work. Survivors include his wife, four children, two brothers, eight grandchildren and a great-grandson.

DOC.HEAD: British Journalist Begins 5th Year in Captivity
DOC.TEXT: Friends and relatives of hostage John McCarthy sent messages to Beirut newspapers and television stations asking for his freedom as the British journalist marked his fourth year in captivity Monday. There is no word on McCarthy's welfare and no group has claimed responsibility for his kidnapping. ``We think constantly of the long years you have spent in Beirut and hope that 1990 will see you safely back home,'' McCarthy's father, Patrick, wrote in a message. McCarthy's girlfriend, Jill Morrell, wrote: ```No one has forgotten you for a second. I long to know how you are and what you are thinking, but the longer this goes on the more determined I am to see you back home. Hang on and do not lose hope.'' Several newspapers, radio and television stations in Beirut are planning to broadcast or print the messages that friends and relatives hope McCarthy will be permitted to hear or read. McCarthy, 33, was kidnapped April 17, 1986, while driving to Beirut airport to catch a flight to London. He was working for the London-based Worldwide Television News. In London, a noon church service and a silent vigil outside the Iranian Embassy were planned to mark his abduction. Despite repeated appeals from his family, published in Beirut newspapers, little is known about McCarthy's kidnappers. McCarthy's mother, Sheila, died of cancer at age 66 on July 9, 1989. A month before her death she appealed to her son's abductors to let her see him before she passed away. She received no response and it is unclear if McCarthy is aware of his mother's death. Appeals from the British government, the International Federation of Journalists and the United Nations Education, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) have also failed to draw any response from the kidnappers. Sheik Mohammed Mehdi Shamseddin, spiritual head of Lebanon's Shiite Moslem community, said recently that all Western hostages kidnapped in Beirut were alive and well. He did not expand on the statement. Shiite extremists loyal to Iran are believed to hold most of the 18 Western hostages in Lebanon. Most have been captives for more than three years. Longest-held is American journalist Terry A. Anderson, 42, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He was abducted March 16, 1985. The 18 hostages include eight Americans, four Britons, two Swiss, two West Germans, an Irishman and an Italian.

DOC.HEAD: NRC Approves Texas' 2nd Nuclear Power Plant
DOC.TEXT: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission granted an operating license Monday to the Comanche Peak, Texas, nuclear power plant. The five-member commission approved the license for the plant, the second in the state, after a last-minute claim from opponents that evacuation plans do not account for the area's higher summer population. Opponents organized as Citizens for Fair Utility Regulation complained that TU Electric Co., the plant's owner, has failed to adequately warn residents living near the plant, 80 miles southwest of Dallas, about evacuation plans. The activists complained particularly about the added summer population of children attending church camps. Another activist group, Citizens Association for Sound Energy, had sought a licensing condition to assure a more ``disciplined, accountable approach'' to resolving operational incidents. But the NRC staff recommended said such a condition was not called for. Utility spokeswoman Kathi Miller said the company, which is seeking a 10.2 percent rate increase in part to recover the costs of building the $9.1 billion plant, could reach full power by this summer. The plant is a decade behind schedule and billions of dollars over budget. The utility's 2.1 million customers, who live across the northern third of the state, could begin receiving electricity from Comanche Peak 15 years after construction began in 1975 at Glen Rose. Comanche Peak would be the second, and likely the last, plant this year to receive a full-power operating license from the NRC, NRC spokesman Frank Ingram said. The commission last month awarded the controversial Seabrook nuclear power plant in New Hampshire a full-power license. Texas' other nuclear power plant is the South Texas Project near Bay City.

DOC.HEAD: State Department Says Steel Products Being Imported from South Africa
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 10th graf pvs `There is ...' to UPDATE with Treasury Department comment. Picks up 11th graf pvs `The law ...'
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is allowing South African iron and steel into the United States despite a 1986 economic sanction designed to force an end to apartheid, the State Department said Monday. Most of the controversial imports are ferroalloys, strategic commodities never intended by Congress to be banned under the law, said department spokeswoman Margaret D. Tutwiler. The administration's definition of steel was upheld in a federal court in 1987 and certain prefabricated products that contain steel are not included in the definition of steel, she said. ``This administration will continue to enforce fully all provisions of the Comprehensive Anti-Apartheid Act,'' Ms. Tutwiler said. ``This is an old issue that has been thoroughly reviewed by the Treasury Department.'' Another U.S. official, requesting anonymity, said some prefabricated items, such as toasters and some ferroalloys had been imported. The official said the volume of imports was not readily available. The New York Times, quoting Commerce Department officials, reported Saturday that more than 900,000 tons of South African iron and steel products worth at least $350 million had entered the United States despite the sanctions. ``Nothwithstanding any other provision of law, no iron or steel produced in South Africa may be imported into the United States,'' the law says. The Times said Treasury Department lawyers had defined ``steel'' to exclude fabricated steel products such as girders, beams and plates used in the construction of bridges. However, Rep. John Bryant, D-Texas, took issue with the interpretation. ``There is no excuse for the administration to allow even one ounce, much less billions of pounds, of such products to enter the United States,'' Bryant told the Times. A Treasury Department official told The Associated Press on Monday that ferroalloys were always outside the scope of the law and that the department intended to screen out prefabricated products containing steel. But, the official said, the appeals court for the court of international trade, ruled against the department. The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said such imports were ``very minor,'' about 1 percent of the volume of ferroalloys. ``Our enforcement is very strict,'' the official said. ``There is no reason for alarm.'' The law, passed by Congress over President Reagan's veto, also prohibits new lending and investment, bans flights to and from South Africa and prohibits American imports of South African coal, textiles, uranium, farm products and gold coins. The Reagan administration called repeatedly for an end to racial segregation in South Africa. However, it opposed sanctions, saying blacks would suffer if the country's economy were hurt.

DOC.HEAD: Three Killed, 11 Wounded in Minibus Blast
DOC.TEXT: A bomb exploded in a minibus Monday in this southeastern township, killing three people and wounding 11, the semi-official Anatolia news agency reported. The dispatch said four of the wounded were in critical condition. It is unknown who planted the bomb on the vehicle. Derik is in a region where guerrillas from the Kurdish Labor Party have been fighting for an independent Marxist state since 1984. At least 2,500 people have been killed since the beginning of the insurgency in clashes between guerrillas and government troops and in rebel hit-and-run attacks on civilian targets.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutors: Bensonhurst Ringleader Bragged He Was Ready to Kill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note language in 3rd graf.
DOC.TEXT: The man accused of being the ringleader in a racial slaying carried a pistol and bragged that he was going to shoot blacks, the prosecution said Monday at the start of his murder trial. ``Keith Mondello was going to murder a black man,'' Assistant District Attorney James Kohler said. ``It didn't matter what black man. Yusuf Hawkins innocently appeared on the scene, and his fate was sealed.'' Mondello ``boasted that he would blow the heads off the nigger bastards,'' the prosecutor said. A state Supreme Court jury began hearing the case against Mondello nearly eight months after 16-year-old Hawkins and three of his pals crossed paths with a mob of bat-wielding whites in the mostly white Bensonhurst section of the borough of Brooklyn. Prosecutors say Mondello _ charged with two counts of second-degree murder and other crimes _ did not shoot Hawkins, but created the circumstances that caused his death by assembling the white gang. A second jury in the same courtroom was to hear opening statements in the trial of the accused gunman, Joseph Fama. However, those proceedings were postponed until Tuesday because defense lawyer David DePetris had the flu. Mondello and Fama, both 19 years old and charged with two counts of second-degree murder, would face 25 years to life in prison if convicted. Kohler charged the slaying was a racial murder motivated by Mondello's hatred of blacks and Hispanics. ``To call it anything else but a race riot would demean and trivialize the death of Yusuf Hawkins,'' Kohler said. He added: ``The person who will put many of the pieces to the puzzle together is the defendant himself.'' In statements Mondello made to the police following his arrest, he admitted assembling the gang, admitted having a gun in his car and said he was carrying a bat at the time of the attack, the prosecutor said. Mondello's lawyer, Stephen Murphy, disputed prosecutors' accounts of the killing and asserted his client was being falsely accused by Gina Feliciano, a key prosecution witness he described as a habitual liar and an unreformed drug addict. Murphy said he would play for the jury a recorded conversation between Miss Feliciano and her sister that ``makes it real clear that the truth has nothing to do with anything.'' Murphy charges that the girl brought on the entire episode by inviting some black and Hispanic friends to an Aug. 23 birthday party in the mostly Italian-American neighborhood. Murphy asserted that Mondello was ``horrified'' by the shooting. Six other young whites also were indicted in the killing and will be tried later.

DOC.HEAD: Military Families Stung by Decision to Sell Housing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `The housing ...,' to CORRECT to 104 families in New Jersey, sted 140; 124 in Massachusetts, sted 136; and 32 in Virginia, sted 23; SUBS 10th graf, `She and ...,' to CLARIFY that wages can amount to $15,000 or less.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto HF2; LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Military families are used to being moved around, but the latest marching orders for 1,200 families arrived in the form of an eviction notice. In a cost-cutting move, the families of mostly low-paid military recruiters and support staff have been told they must leave their cozy Army-owned ranch houses near obsolete Nike missile bases by Aug. 15. A few have until 1993 to find new homes. ``We don't know where we're going to go,'' said Cynthia Aitken, whose New Britain home is in a cluster of 16 Army houses that are being sold off.
