The houses once were occupied by the families of Nike anti-aircraft missile crews who had to live nearby so they could rush to their battle stations in the event of war. The missiles were phased out two decades ago, and the housing passed on to younger generations of military families, many of them in the Army but with some from the other branches of the armed forces. Two years ago, Congress ordered the Army to close or reorganize 86 installations. As part of that order, the Army must sell 53 housing complexes near former Nike bases. The housing is concentrated in the Northeast, with 239 families in Connecticut, 163 in New York, 104 in New Jersey, 124 in Massachusetts, 133 in Pennsylvania and 78 families in Rhode Island. There also are 12 houses in Maryland, 94 in St. Louis, 32 in Virginia, 110 in Wisconsin, 24 in Illinois and 60 in Washington state. The closings will save the Army about $2 million in maintenance and utility costs in Connecticut, Massachusetts and Rhode Island this year alone, said Helen Mulligan, a spokesman for Fort Devens in Ayer, Mass. Until the closings were announced, Mrs. Aitken did not have to worry about housing costs because her family was allowed to live rent-free. Her husband, Bruce, a first-class petty officer and 13-year Navy veteran works at the Plainville Reserve Center. She and others like her are worried about how they will rent or buy homes on annual salaries that in some cases can amount to less than $15,000. When they leave their free, Army-owned housing, the families can expect housing allowances in the range of $600 a month, depending on rank and where they live. The issue is particularly sensitive for military families in New England, where housing costs are among the nation's highest. ``That $600 isn't going to buy anything except in neighborhoods dogs shouldn't be forced to live in,'' said Patricia Berkley, one of more than 100 military spouses who gathered at the Army Reserve Training Center in West Hartford last month to express their frustration to military officials. ``How do you expect my husband to be all he can be while he's worried about his wife and children getting mugged?'' Roberto Ramos, a Coast Guard officer who lives in Middletown, says the Army should have given families who live in the houses the first chance to rent or buy them. ``A lot of these guys are young with young kids,'' said Ramos. ``If you put them out in this economy, they're going to be poor people.'' Under the law, the Army had to offer the housing to other service branches and federal agencies first. Houses the federal government doesn't want will be offered to state agencies, and any remaining will be offered for sale to the public. Ramos said he is among the more fortunate because the Navy is considering moving him to another rent-free home. In Connecticut, 60 units owned by the Coast Guard and Navy will be preserved for military families. The Army is holding meetings around the country for families who are losing their homes, and is considering giving some of them loans or advances, said Joseph Carter, a spokesman for U.S. Forces Command at Fort McPherson, Ga. Beyond that, the Army says there's much else it can do. ``It's not a case of us saying we want to get rid of our real estate and we don't care about housing our people,'' Carter said. ``Congress made the decision.''

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Report Chides Some Allies, Praises Others
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, in an annual report on the defense spending of NATO nations and Japan, faulted Luxembourg, Denmark and Canada on Monday for ``below par'' contributions to the common defense. ``These nations have, by and large, relatively prosperous economies and relatively high standards of living, yet devote relatively small proportions of their resources to defense,'' said the report, released at the Pentagon. ``The performance of this group of nations ... looks substantially below par,'' it said. However, the report noted Canada has had a ``relatively good performance'' in increasing defense spending in recent years, Luxembourg is an important host to Allied forces, and Denmark has a ``better than average'' showing in other areas, such as in its active and reserve troop numbers in relation to the nation's population. The annual Report on Allied Contributions to the Common Defense is required by Congress, which has become sensitive in recent years to the high defense contributions the United States makes to economically robust nations in Western Europe and the Far East. The report said that with revolutionary changes sweeping Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, ``the need for defense, arms control, and burdensharing objectives to remain in harmony is crucial.'' ``Within NATO a stronger European pillar is evolving. Adjustments in the roles and responsibilities for the common defense will contribute to this evolution,'' the report said. Overall, the report said, the NATO nations and Japan spent about $489 billion on defense in 1988, the last year for which common figures were available. ``The United States accounted for $293 billion, or 60 percent of that amount,'' the report said. The other major spenders included: France, $36.1 billion, 7.4 percent; West Germany $35.1 billion, 7.2 percent; Britain, $34.7 billion, 7.1 percent; Japan, $28.9 billion, 5.9 percent; Canada, $10 billion, 2 percent; Italy $20.4 billion, 4.2 percent; and others, $30.7 billion, 6.3 percent, the report said. Besides assessing the amount spent on defense by each nation, the report also attempts to look at such things as weaponry and the number of each nation's active duty and reserve forces in relation to its population. But the report said some things are much harder to measure, such as the loss of real estate given over in order to Allied troops on a nation's soil. Nations such as Japan and West Germany are sensitive to such matters, and the report said the market value of such property in West Germany alone ``has been estimated at $24 billion.'' The report lauded the so-called ``burdensharing'' efforts of Turkey, Greece, Britain and France, saying they all allocated relatively high proportions of their national income to defense. Turkey and Greece _ nations often at odds with each other _ have made such contributions even though they enjoy a rather low economic prosperity, the report noted. The nations that have made ``mixed efforts'' included Norway, West Germany, the Netherlands, Portugal, Italy, Belgium and Spain, the report said. Germany, Norway and the Netherlands ``comprise an upper echelon of nations who are making good to excellent force improvement efforts and strong contributions in a number of areas,'' but are lagging somewhat in the defense spending arena, said the report. ``Portugal's relatively modest efforts appear genuinely equitable when its poor economic situation is taken into account,'' and Italy is ``making major efforts to improve'' despite a low financial contribution, the report said. The report said if Japan's defense spending were measured only against its high standard of living and economic output, it would also be judged ``substantially below par.'' But the report noted Japan's contribution of 1 percent of its so-called gross domestic output to defense puts it among the top five nations in total defense spending. ``Of greater relevance, Japan is making rapid progress towards the military capability to fulfill its agreed-upon mission ... the defense of its territory'' and its sea-lanes to a distance of 1,000 miles, the report said. Japan and Okinawa host nearly 50,000 U.S. troops and Japan contributed nearly $2.2 billion in support for U.S. forces in 1989, including $685 million for military construction and $410 million in labor cost sharing, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Thomas Picked for Budapest Ambassadorship
DOC.TEXT: President Bush announced his selection Monday of Charles H. Thomas, a career foreign service officer, to be U.S. ambassador to Hungary. Thomas, 55, most recently served as principal deputy assistant secretary of state for European and Canadian affairs. For almost a year he has been studying Hungarian in preparation for his new assignment. If confirmed by the Senate, he would replaced Mark Palmer, who recently retired from the foreign service for a job in international banking. U.S. relations with Hungary have improved steadily since that nation held democratic elections last year. Earlier this month, the United States entered into a pact with Hungary that extends to the Warsaw Pact most-favored-nation trade status. Thomas is a former deputy chief of mission at the U.S. embassy in Brussels and director of the Peace Corps in Uruguay and Honduras. The White House also announced these appointments: _Florida Lt. Gov. Bobby Lynn Brantley of Tallahassee to be a member of the National Commission on Agriculture and Rural Development Policy, succeeding Arthur R. Brown. _Philip Larson of Reston, Va., a career diplomat, to be U.S. representative to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development. He succeed Denis Lamb. _Gerald William Ebker of Potomac, Md., an IBM Corp. vice president, as a member of the president's National Security Telecommunications Advisory Committee.

DOC.HEAD: Passengers Abandoned on Burning Ship, Senior Officer Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 15 `The Scandinavian' to ADD dropped words `had not.' Picks up 16th pvs, `The panel...'
DOC.TEXT: Chief officer Oddvar Finstad of the Scandinavian Star conceded at a marine inquiry on Monday that he and other officers abandoned the blazing ferry while passengers awaited rescue. Police in Oslo, Norway, estimated 161 people died in the April 7 fire, but said the figure was not final because it was still uncertain how many passengers boarded the ferry. The Danish-owned vessel was on an overnight run from Oslo to Frederikshavn, Denmark. Finstad, the third-in-command, said he; Capt. Hugo Larsen, the Norwegian master of the Scandinavian Star; and other officers left the burning vessel in a lifeboat, knowing passengers remained on the deck. The fate of the abandoned passengers, some of whom were rescued later, was not discussed as they rowed away in the last usable lifeboat, Finstad said. ``I can't see what more I could have done on board after the captain left the ship,'' he said. Larsen and other officers returned three hours later to help Swedish and Norwegian firefighters. Larsen testified as the first witness in the inquiry and said he abandoned ship while some passengers remained alive on board. Finstad's testimony on the sixth day of the inquiry supported accounts by rescued passengers that the crew appeared confused and ill-trained to deal with an emergency. Under questioning, Finstad acknowledged he knew practically nothing about the ship's emergency plan or evacuation procedures; that he was unaware of his assignment in the posted emergency plan as head of the ship's 14-member fire squad, and was unable to identify the other squad members. The inquiry established that the required fire and evacuation drills were not held. Finstad was asked why safety procedures were not checked before the 20-year-old ferry was allowed to sail with passengers. ``We had been on board such a short time that we hadn't gotten around to it,'' he replied. Most of the predominantly Portuguese and Filipino crew signed on the Scandinavian Star five days before the fire, which police believe was deliberately set. The ship's safety officer, First Officer Sverre Aashildrods, testified he knew nothing about international safety regulations that require fire drills when more than 25 percent of the crew is new. The Scandinavian Star's alarm systems had not been checked, and passengers coming on board did not receive the required safety cards telling them what to do in an emergency, the inquiry was told. The panel is headed by five judges and includes Norwegian and Danish police, three Scandinavian maritime authorities and lawyers for the shipowner and the insurance companies concerned. The judge leading the inquiry is Frank Poulsen, president of the Marine and Trade Court. He said the inquiry came at the request of the shipowner, VR Da-No Lines. Criminal charges cannot arise from the inquiry, but witnesses testify under oath and are warned their testimony could be used in any subsequent criminal case. A joint commission of Danish, Norwegian and Swedish maritime officials is to hold hearings on the case follow the Copenhagen inquiry.

DOC.HEAD: Snow and Cold in North-Central States, Rain In Drought-Stricken California
DOC.TEXT: A surge of colder air brought snow and rain to the northern and central Plains and the upper Midwest on Monday, and parts of dry California received welcome rain. Light rain and wet snow extended across northern and central Wyoming, and about an inch of snow fell across North Dakota from late Sunday into early Monday. A mixture of rain and snow fell across the northern third of South Dakota and northern Minnesota during the early morning. Overnight snowfall in Minnesota included 3 inches north of Duluth and 2 inches at Morris. By noon, the cold front marking the boundary of the cold temperatures reached across central Upper Michigan, north-central Missouri, southwestern Kansas, southeastern Colorado and north-central Montana. The temperature in Sioux City, Iowa, dropped 7 degrees in seven minutes as the cold front passed, and temperatures dropped as much as 10 degrees across Colorado. At midday, snow showers continued over eastern Colorado, western Nebraska, eastern Minnesota, northern Wisconsin and Upper Michigan. Temperatures in Nebraska were slightly higher than freezing, so snow didn't accumulate. But wind along the cold front gusted to about 45 mph at Broken Bow, Ord and North Platte. Rain extended from Iowa to southeastern Nebraska and northwestern Missouri, and showers and thunderstorms were scattered over northeastern Kansas and northwestern Missouri. During the early monring, spring rain moved into southern California, where some communities have restricted water use because of a lengthy drought. The rain was expected to continue through Tuesday, with snow at higher elevations. Up to a half-inch of rain fell in the mountains northwest of Santa Barbara, and slightly more than an inch of rain fell just west of Gaviota. Rain also fell over northwestern through west-central California. The low temperature for the Lower 48 states was 23 degrees at Gunnison, Colo., and Houghton Lake and Sault Ste. Marie, Mich. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 31 degrees at International Falls and Warroad, Minn., to 92 at Carlsbad, N.M.

DOC.HEAD: King Fahd Releases 7,700 Inmates in Goodwill Ramadan Gesture
DOC.TEXT: The government said Monday it had freed nearly 7,700 inmates, including all political prisoners, as a goodwill gesture marking the holy month of Ramadan. There is ``not a single political prisoner'' in the kingdom, according to an Interior Ministry announcement broadcast by state-run Riyadh radio, because King Fahd had declared amnesty for 7,681 prisoners. The gesture was made possible by benefactors who donated about $87 million to help pay the public and private debts of some prisoners, the ministry said. In a report on Saudi Arabia issued in January, the London-based human rights group Amnesty International said more than 700 people were detained without trial from 1983 to 1989, mainly Shiite Moslems, including Iranian-backed fundamentalists. The report said at least 100 people were seized last year and named 66 held in three prisons. Saudi Arabia denied the report. Monday's announcement did not specifically refer to the Shiites. Those still jailed were being held for capital crimes or were convicted and awaiting sentencing. Capital crimes under Islamic law include murder, punishable by beheading; adultery, punishable by stoning; and thievery, punishable by cutting of hands from the wrist. In recent years, beheading was also decreed by Moslem theologians for drug smuggling. The amnesty included Saudis and foreigners, but no breakdown was released. It referred to an unspecified number of foreigners detained for various misdemeanors, financial crimes and public law violations. It said their embassies were asked to prepare for their deportation, as is customary. It is a tradition for rulers in Islamic countries to issue amnesties during Ramadan and other Moslem occasions. Islamic law also allows for benefactors, sometimes anonymous, to settle prisoners' debts as an act of charity. Neighboring Gulf countries have already announced their amnesties for Ramadan, but they have not exceeded 200 prisoners. The Saudi statement did not identify the benefactors. In neighboring United Arab Emirates, President Sheik Zayed bin Sultan Al Nahyan personally underwrote the debt of the 150 prisoners released in the capital Abu Dhabi.

DOC.HEAD: Turkey on Thanksgiving, Rabbit on Easter, Says Preacher
DOC.TEXT: A preacher who says the Easter Bunny is nothing more than a pagan icon served barbecued rabbit to the needy, hoping to shift the focus to the true meaning of the Christian holiday. ``Just like turkey is served on Thanksgiving, I would like to see rabbit served in homes across America every Easter,'' said the Rev. Larry Rice, director of the New Life Evangelistic Center in St. Louis. Rice came up with the idea to attract more attention to the original meaning of Easter, a Christian holy day that celebrates the resurrection of Jesus Christ and the promise of everlasting life. ``The Easter Bunny is tremendous competition to that message,'' Rice said Monday. ``We like to think of ourselves as a Christian nation, but our focus on a mystical rabbit is really paganistic.'' The New Life Center, a privately operated shelter for the poor in downtown St. Louis, bought 604 rabbits to serve on Easter Sunday, Rice said, primarily because they were cheaper than beef or pork. People who came to the Easter dinners didn't have to eat rabbit if they didn't want to, Rice said. About 500 people could choose from grilled rabbit, sauteed rabbit, rabbit cacciatore, turkey or ham. ``The majority of people ate rabbit, but that's partly because we only cooked 10 turkeys,'' said Ruth Powell, a volunteer at New Life who planned the dinner. ``I was surprised by the number of people that wanted the rabbit.'' Yvonne Dozier, seated at dinner with her 8-month-old baby, James, didn't have a problem eating rabbit. ``It's great,'' she said, tearing into her dinner. ``There ain't no such thing as the Easter Bunny, and I ain't no kid. This is just food _ good food,'' she said. In Kansas City, about 200 people were given a piece of chicken and a piece of rabbit. Rice said he's received some calls from people who canceled their plans to make donations to his shelter. One woman called to complain about the psychological counseling children were going to need because of his idea. But he said overall, response was positive. ``I'm toying with another idea for later this year. There's a lot of hunting for deer around Christmas and we might take advantage of that and serve white-tail deer, mule deer, even reindeer,'' Rice said.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Will Not Ban Offset Military Deals
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration said Monday it would not forbid American companies from offering special purchasing incentives to win contracts for military sales aboard, though it will not encourage thoce incentives either. A White House statement said that incentives, known in military circles as offsets, have become a common feature in the international arms trade. An offset is a requirement that the selling company buy a certain amount of goods and services in the buying country. ``The decision whether to engage in offsets, and the responsibility for negotiating and implementing offset arrangements, resides with the companies involved,'' the White House said in a policy statement issued under President Bush's name. The administration said no agency of the U.S. government will encourage offsets or commit U.S. firms to offset deals. Moreover, it said that no U.S. government funds will be used to finance offsets in security assistance deals ``except in accordance with currently established policies and procedures.'' White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said the government views offsets for military exports ``as economically inefficient and market distorting.'' One case of offsets cited by the Pentagon involved the recent purchase of 11 airborne radar warning and control planes from Boeing by Britain and France in an $1.8 billion deal. The two countries demanded an offset from Boeing of 130 percent, meaning that the manufacturer would have to buy more than $2.3 billion in goods and services from Britain and France. Such an arrangement puts the U.S. company in the role of a middleman for selling the foreign countries' goods if they have nothing to sell that the U.S. company needs immediately.

DOC.HEAD: Two Planes Damaged after Brush Fire Sets Off Blasts at Air Base
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Soviet-made plane destoyed during brush fire, second plane damaged, details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: A brush fire started by farmers to clear their land set off explosions Monday at a nearby air base ammunition dump, wrecking a Soviet-made cargo carrier and damaging a second airplane, police chief Rene Vivas said. Vivas said a gust of wind spread the fire to the air force base adjoining Managua international airport, and the blasts destroyed the AN-26 cargo plane. He said a second air force plane, also parked on a runway, was damaged but gave no further details. Officials said the airport was immediately shut to traffic until further notice as a precaution. The midday explosions were heard throughout the capital, but Vivas told reporters that although many residents were alarmed, ``There are no victims and there was no major damage.'' Vivas said farmers were burning brush and weeds to clear their field for planting when a strong wind spread the flames to open ground at the air base where explosive material and fuel was stored. Fire brigades at the airport quickly brought the blaze under control, Vivas said, who added he doubted ``very much'' that the explosions could have been caused by sabotage. U.S.-supported Contra rebels have been fighting Nicaragua's leftist Sandinista government for nine years, and President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro's civilian administration takes office for a six-year term April 25. Most of the rebels have refused to surrender their weapons and demobilize until Mrs. Chamorro takes office and exercises control over the Sandinista-dominated military.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands of Teachers Demonstrate at Oklahoma Capitol
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of teachers went on strike Monday to show their anger over a failed $230 million education improvement package, and many picketed at the state Capitol. Teachers say their pay ranks 48th in the nation. The minimum beginning salary for a teacher with a bachelor's degree is $15,060. The crowd outside the Capitol was estimated at more than 10,000 by Nancy Jewell, vice president of the Oklahoma Education Association. Other estimates ranged up from 5,000. Hundreds of teachers clogged legislative halls inside the Capitol, lobbying for additional school funding. ``If you can read this, thank a teacher. If you can't, thank a legislator,'' read a sign carried by one picket. Schools were closed in more than 145 of the state's 606 school districts, where more than half the education association's members are teachers, said association President Kyle Dahlem. The association represents 80 percent of Oklahoma's teachers. The Tulsa school district, the largest in the state, was among those closed. Schools were open in Oklahoma City, but not in many of the capital city's suburbs. Teachers in Oklahoma City and some other districts said they feared reprisals if they took part in the strike. School administrators supported the walkout in some areas and opposed it in others. At the Capitol, the knob to the main door of Gov. Henry Bellmon's office was loosened because so many teachers wanted to register their presence, said Andrew Tevington, Bellmon's chief of staff. Bellmon asked state Attorney General Robert Henry to go to court, if necessary, to block the walkout. Henry issued a statement late Monday saying it did not appear immediate legal action was warranted. Henry said state law forbidding strikes against local school boards did not appear to apply in the case of a walkout to express dissatisfaction with legislative action. The education association called for a five-day teacher walkout after the Oklahoma Senate failed last week to pass the school reform bill as an emergency measure, which would have put it into effect immediately. The measure has been the work of an eight-month special session Bellmon called in August to improve Oklahoma schools. The Republican governor supported the bill, but only one of the Senate's 15 Republicans voted for it Wednesday, along with seven of the Senate's 33 Democrats. After the Senate voted Wednesday to drop the emergency clause, legislative leaders got the Senate to send the bill back to committee to keep it from going to Bellmon without the provision. The bill mandates greater equity in the way state funds are allocated, salary increases for teachers, a school consolidation plan, and a program to close schools that don't meet accreditation requirements, It calls for an additional $212 million for schools that could be used for teacher salaries and other items, and proposes $1,500 increases in minimum teachers' salaries for each of the next four years. Much of the opposition was stirred by the plan for taxes to support the reforms, including a half-cent increase in the state's 4-cent sales tax and increases in corporate and personal income taxes. Senate President Pro Tempore Bob Cullison said there were negotiations over the weekend to revive the school bill, which he had said last week was apparently dead. He said he could not comment on whether there had been any progress toward a compromise. Ms. Dahlem said critics of the walkout should ``come walk in our shoes and then tell me that what we are doing isn't necessary _ that this isn't the last resort on a list of options that have all failed over long months of pushing, pulling, frustration and compromise'' only for education supporters to come up empty-handed. The walkout was supported by the National Education Association, which has 2 million members. NEA President Keith Geiger and other officials of the national group issued a statement saying there was ``an educational emergency in Oklahoma right now.''

DOC.HEAD: Pediatric Group Urges Increased Caution on TV Viewing
DOC.TEXT: Long-term television viewing is one cause of violent or aggressive behavior in children and contributes substantially to childhood obesity, the American Academy of Pediatrics said Monday. In its first policy statement on children and television since 1984, the 39,000-member academy called for more involvement by parents and pediatricians in regulating children's viewing, and urged that viewing time be cut in half. By the time a child today reaches age 70, he or she will have spent approximately seven years watching television, the pediatricians said. ``For some children, the world shown on television becomes the real world,'' the statement said. The academy also recommended: _Intensifying efforts to teach parents and pediatricians about television's influence, and promoting critical viewing among children. _Parents' limiting children's viewing to one to two hours daily and developing activities such as reading, athletics and hobbies. _Supporting legislation making broadcast of high-quality children's programming a condition of license renewal and mandating at least one hour per day of educational children's programming. _Supporting efforts to ban programs that have toys as main characters. _Portraying sexuality responsibly. _Working to eliminate alcohol ads on television and encouraging extensive counter advertising. A.C. Nielsen Co. data indicate children ages 2 to 5 watch TV about 25 hours weekly; 6- to 11-year-olds, more than 22 hours weekly; and 12-to 17-year-olds, 23 hours per week, said the policy statement. ``We're asking that parents cut their kids' television viewing in half or more,'' said Dr. Victor Strasburger of the University of New Mexico School of Medicine. He added that the academy did not recommend a time limit five years ago. Experts have established a link between heavy television viewing and obesity, he said. The policy statement credits a 1985 study by Drs. W.H. Dietz and S.L. Gortmaker that appeared in the journal Pediatrics. Dietz, a member of the academy committee that prepared the policy statement, has done followup research, Strasburger said. ``It could be that television watching is such a sedentary activity,'' he said in a telephone interview Monday. ``It could be because the nutritional messages on television are so terrible. Or it could be that kids usually ... eat while they're watching television. ... It probably is all three.'' He said TV still offers ``a steady diet of violence,'' causing some children to believe ``that if you're the good guy, violence can be acceptable'' to solve some problems. The policy statement also calls for contraceptive advertising and for responsible portrayals of sex. Strasburger said ``no national networks have been brave enough ... or public-spirited enough'' to advertise contraceptives. ``They're so wrapped up in business decisions they really don't see that this is an urgent public health matter, not just because of AIDS'' but also because of teen-age pregnancy. He said soap operas offer the worst examples of sex on television and are shown when small children often watch TV. What TV airs ``at 10 o'clock at night is not what we're worried about,' he noted. ``It's what they put on at 2 o'clock in the afternoon.'' Despite TV's negative aspects, he said, the academy believes ``it's OK to use the television set occasionally as an electronic baby-sitter.'' But parents should videotape programs they approve of ``rather than let the kids play `channel roulette.''' In calling for an end to programs featuring toys as the main characters, the academy reasoned that such shows are really marketing vehicles. ``Saturday morning television is still the vast wasteland that it was 10 or 15 years ago,'' Strasburger said. ``It could be far more educational than it is. The fact that it hasn't changed is really a reflection'' on the Federal Communications Commission.'' William Johnson, deputy chief of the FCC's Mass Media Bureau, said the problem the agency faces in regulating children's programming borders on censorship. Another issue, Johnson said, is whether the federal government should arbitrarily decide between good and bad programming. ``How do we define it, and how would you enforce that?'' he said in a telephone interview from Washington. He said cable TV outlets have provided more opportunities for good children's programming, and said there was much less violence on children's programs than before. Spokesmen for ABC, NBC and CBS could not be reached for comment by telephone late Monday because they were either gone for the day or unavailable.

DOC.HEAD: Opponents of Ban on Dancing Disappointed by Court Ruling
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING a0642 to fix slugline.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Supreme Court on Monday let stand a ban on school dances in this Bible Belt town, prompting an opponent to lament a victory ``for liars, cheats and hypocrites.'' Opponents said they now hoped the school board would voluntarily lift the rule, but officials said they wouldn't discuss the issue until May. The high court without comment rejected arguments that the no-dance rule was religiously motivated and violated the constitutionally required separation of church and state. A federal appeals court in September upheld the ban. ``I'm disappointed by the ruling but I'm not surprised,'' said attorney William Fleischaker, who represented 21 Purdy High School students and their parents who filed a lawsuit in 1986 seeking to overturn the ban in this Ozarks town. ``We knew the odds against us were pretty strong. We had hoped we could get the ear of someone at the Supreme Court and get them to review the situation. Obviously, that didn't happen,'' he said. No further legal appeals are planned, Fleischaker said. School Superintendent Sheldon Buxton declined to speculate whether the school board would again prohibit all school-sponsored dances or modify or abandon the rule. The board was scheduled to hold its regular meeting Monday night but didn't plan to discuss the ruling, Buxton said. ``This is not the time or place for the board to gloat,'' said board President Glenn Garrett. ``It is time for the board, administration, faculty, students and the Purdy citizens to set about healing the divisions caused by this litigation.'' The student body president and several other students refused to comment as they were leaving school Monday afternoon. ``I think the students are just glad to see it all end,'' said Becky Woods, a high-school physical education teacher and Purdy native. ``There was excitement about the first dance, but then the whole thing dragged on so long, the press got into it, and now I think students just don't care where they dance, at the school or elsewhere.'' School board member Alan Keeling praised the ruling, saying it's best for the board to decide whether dances should be held. He said board members had been confident they would win the case. Buxton said three dances have been held at the school since U.S. District Judge Russell Clark in Springfield ruled in 1988 that the no-dance rule was unconstitutional. Clark's ruling was overturned by the appeals court. He said the dances went smoothly with no problems and no complaints from five fundamentalist ministers in the southwestern Missouri community of 900 who regard dancing as ``satanic'' and ``sinful'' and led support for the ban. ``I'm relieved that this situation has come to a closing point,'' Buxton said. ``I think the support and interest in the school that has been shown from people on both sides will help the healing process, allow us to get back to business as usual and put this issue behind us.'' The ban on dancing at the high school, which has an enrollment of about 230, drew national attention for its similarity to the movie ``Footloose.'' The 1984 film centered on a fight in a fictional Texas small town between young people and city fathers, who thought dancing sinful and immoral. Joan Fox, a parent and plaintiff along with her son and husband, said the Supreme Court's refusal to hear the case ``is a real loss for students in this community and around the country.'' ``It's an extreme victory for liars, cheats and hypocrites,'' she said. ``I think the judicial system in this country has gone to pot.'' Mrs. Fox called on the school board to voluntarily abandon the 100-year-old dance ban. ``The kids have had several successful, wonderful dances and I hope the school board realizes that it's for the kids' benefit to have dances on campus,'' she said. ``I hope they don't tell them to get lost, which is what they've always said previously.'' Fleischaker said he hoped school board members would note how well the first three dances had gone and permit future dances. This year's junior-senior prom will be held in the nearby community of Monett at students' request, school officials said. ``There certainly has been strong and vocal opposition to school-sponsored dancing,'' Fleischaker said. ``I would hope the opposition has mellowed a bit.''

DOC.HEAD: 10-Year-Old Saves Brother from Choking
DOC.TEXT: A 10-year-old girl whose mother taught her the Heimlich manuever used it to save her brother, who was choking on a jawbreaker. Adrienne Sharpe and two younger brothers were at their grandparents' home Saturday when the youngest, Schuyler, 4, got the jawbreaker lodged in his throat. Two uncles rushed to Schuyler after the boy began waving his arms for help, but they couldn't dislodge the candy. Adrienne first ran to the house to tell her grandfather, then returned, grabbed her brother and began the manuever, a thrusting motion from behind the victim that forces the rescuer's fist into the rib cage. ``When I did the Heimlich the second time, the jawbreaker just flew out,'' the girl said. Schuyler didn't need to be hospitalized. The children's mother, Glenda, a licensed practical nurse who works at an adult care center, taught her children the manuever last summer when she had to be recertified in lifesaving techniques. Adrienne said she found the training fun at the time. ``I didn't think it was funny when my brother was choking though,'' she said. ``I was glad mom had taught us.''

DOC.HEAD: Driver's Dummy Nabbed By Police
DOC.TEXT: Police fined a truck driver Monday for trying to pass off a dummy of a woman _ complete with lipstick and a wig _ as a passenger in a car-pooling lane. State Trooper Richard Edmonds was patrolling the northbound restricted lane of Interstate 279 Monday morning, looking for speeders and violators of the occupancy requirement: three people per vehicle. He spotted a pickup truck with what looked like three occupants in the front seat _ a male driver, a woman in the middle and another man, who had his arm around the woman's shoulders. Not quite convinced, Edmonds followed the truck to get a better look. ``When he got close enough for a better look, the trooper waved the driver over,'' said Sgt. Jim Garofalo. ``The female passenger wasn't too bad looking, but she was a dummy.'' The driver, identified as Earl W. Heintzinger, 36, of Pittsburgh, was given a ticket with a $82.50 fine for violating the lane limit. Garofalo said the dummy, taken to police barracks in Findlay Township, was made of a plastic head tied to a costumed torso, with a nylon stocking over the head. It had on lipstick, eye makeup and a wig.

DOC.HEAD: Kilauea Volcano Poses Another Threat to Hawaii Island Homes
DOC.TEXT: A slow but persistent lava flow from Kilauea Volcano oozed to within 800 feet of a housing subdivision Monday after destroying an isolated home the day before, authorities said. The flow had the potential to reach homes at the western edge of the Kalapana Gardens subdivision by Monday evening, said Harry Kim, administrator of the Hawaii County Civil Defense Agency. There are 80 homes in Kalapana Gardens and 43 others in the surrounding coastal community. Lava was following the path of a flow that entered Kalapana Gardens two weeks ago and destroyed two homes. On Sunday, lava encircled the home of Carl Mildrum about a half mile east of Kalapana Gardens. The home was destroyed when a finger of lava passed close enough to ignite the wooden structure. It was the 80th dwelling destroyed since Kilauea's current eruption began more than seven years ago.

DOC.HEAD: Center and Director Plead Innocent
LaserPhotos CS1
DOC.TEXT: An attorney for an art gallery and its director pleaded innocent Monday to charges they displayed obscene photographs by the late Robert Mapplethorpe. H. Louis Sirkin, attorney for the Contemporary Arts Center and director Dennis Barrie, filed the written pleas in Hamilton County Municipal Court about two hours before a scheduled arraignment. The action effectively waived a court appearance for the parties. Barrie and the gallery face misdemeanor charges of pandering obscenity and use of a minor in nudity-oriented material. If convicted on both charges, Barrie could face up to a year in jail and a $2,000 fine, and the center could be fined up to $10,000. Judge David Albanese set a pretrial hearing for April 30, when a trial date could be set. Sirkin said it is possibl the case may not go to trial until after the Mapplethorpe exhibit ends its Cincinnati run May 26. The indictment singles out seven of the photos, which show naked children and homosexual acts. Grand jury members viewed the exhibit before returning the indictment. About 25 demonstrators supporting the Contemporary Arts Center chanted and waved signs outside the Hamilton County Courthouse. One sign read: ``Myopic Politicians Are Suffocating the People with Backward Social Structures.'' In another development, Hamilton County Prosecutor Arthur M. Ney Jr., whose office obtained the indictment April 7, announced Monday his office will not prosecute the case and will instead hand it over to City Solicitor Richard Castellini. Ney said Ohio law requires the transfer because the case has been moved into municipal court as a misdemeanor offense, and because the alleged offense occurred within the city. Critics have suggested Ney got rid of the case as a political hot potato and that his office has routinely prosecuted misdemeanor cases before. Ney declined to comment further. The arts center began displaying the 175-photo exhibit April 7. By Monday, more than 25,000 people had viewed the show. Since late 1988, the exhibit has appeared in Philadelphia, Chicago, Hartford, Conn.; and Washington, drawing large crowds. It goes to Boston in August to complete its national tour. The Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington canceled the exhibit, but a smaller gallery there displayed the show. The Washington exhibit prompted Congress to limit funds for the arts after Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., declared the photographs obscene. Mapplethorpe, 42, died in March 1989 in New York City of AIDS.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Urges Unrelenting Anti-Apartheid War at London Rock Concert
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Mandela quotes, color, details. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos LON5,11, LaserColor LON6
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela stepped triumphantly onto the world stage at a concert full of rock stars Monday night and urged foes of apartheid to wage unrelenting war against the system that jailed him for 27 years in South Africa. The 71-year-old black nationalist leader, standing before a sellout crowd of 72,000 at Wembley Stadium, beamed with pleasure and obvious affection as seven minutes of applause and cheers washed over him. With his wife, Winnie, standing nearby, Mandela then spoke forcefully for a half-hour, interrupted about 30 times by applause. The fatigue that showed in his face earlier vanished as he thanked supporters and spoke of the need to carry on the fight. The address was telecast to millions in 40 countries. International stars filled the stadium with music and the crowd danced, sang and chanted ``Mandela is free!'' before the deputy president of the African National Congress spoke. It was his largest audience since his release from prison Feb. 11, where he was serving a life term for sabotage and plotting to overthrow the government. The concert sold out in two days. Among those who paid $33 to attend were American politician Jesse Jackson and Neil Kinnock, leader of Britain's opposition Labor Party. Top British reggae group Aswad kicked off the celebration, which featured Simple Minds, Grammy Award-winner Bonnie Raitt, Neil Young, Soul II Soul, The Neville Brothers, Peter Gabriel, Anita Baker, Tracy Chapman and Oscar-winning actor Denzel Washington, who played murdered black activist Steve Biko in the film ``Cry Freedom.'' Miriam Makeba canceled her scheduled appearance for reasons of health. Said Mandela, ``We are meeting here to celebrate the victory represented by the release of some of us. We must, however, remember that only a few have been released. ``A greater number remains in prison, we should therefore treat this day of celebration as one of rededication to ... the struggle for the emancipation of all the remaining political prisoners ... and (against) the system which keeps the outstanding sons and daughters of our people in jail.'' He begged the world not to stop fighting the racial separation system in white-dominated South Africa that denies the black majority the vote. ``The apartheid crime against humanity remains in place. It continues to kill and maim ... to oppress and exploit. Its blood-stained offspring continue to rain death and destruction on the peoples of Mozambique and Angola. Every day it produces orphans throughout southern Africa,'' Mandela said. Mandela said sanctions should be maintained and that Pretoria must not be rewarded for releasing political prisoners or lifting the ban on the ANC. His audience filled the playing field and most of the stands. A huge banner across the stage said: ``The Struggle Is My Life,'' the title of a book of Mandela's writings and speeches. Mandela, wearing a navy blue blazer and a tie striped in the black, green and gold colors of the ANC, told reporters before his speech, ``Twenty-seven years ago when I went to jail I had no vote. I have come out and I still have no vote. '' He said concerts such as this one were important for raising world awareness. ``I think artists can play a very decisive role in the fight for human rights. Artists can reach quarters not nececssarily interested in politics through music, which interests everybody, so that the message can go further than we politicians can push it.'' Mandela told the crowd: ``Dear friends, it will not be long now before we see the end of the apartheid system. The dreams of millions of people to see our country free and at peace will be realized sooner rather than later. We are determined to ensure that our country is transformed from being the skunk of the world into an exemplary oasis of unrivaled race relations, democracy for all, a just peace and freedom from poverty and human degradation.'' He thanked those around the world who had clamored for his release, including the thousands who attended a ``free-Mandela'' concert at Wembley two years ago. ``Even through the thickness of the prison walls ... we heard your voices demanding our freedom. During all the days we spent buried in the apartheid dungeons, we never lost our confidence in the certainty of our release and our victory over the apartheid system.'' Mandela spoke warmly of ANC President Oliver Tambo, who is in Sweden recovering from a stroke. Tambo's wife, Adelaide, sat with them in the stadium's executive box. ``There is no man in this country or anywhere else in the world who could have performed as magnificently in the past 10 years,'' Mandela said. As Mandela left the stage and Tracy Chapman started to sing ``Talking About a Revolution,'' the huge crowd danced in joy. Jesse Jackson praised Mandela at a news conference, saying: ``He is in good health. His vision is clear, his objectives are clear and he's gaining world support.'' The Mandelas arrived about an hour after the concert started, smiling and waving their fists in the air as the crowd cheered. They flew to London on Sunday to attend and left immediately after the concert to fly to Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. Concert organizers said part of the proceeds will go to charities, including Oxfam and Save The Children Fund. They gave no estimate because the sale of television rights was still under way.

DOC.HEAD: Funeral For Slain Teen Marked By Call For Black Unity
DOC.TEXT: Black leaders appealed for unity and increased activism Monday at the funeral of a black teen-ager whose shooting by a white policeman sparked a suburban rampage. About 300 people packed Community Baptist Church in this New York suburb for the funeral of Phillip Pannell, 16, and about 200 more gathered outside to listen to the service over a speaker. Most were black. Elected officials, religious leaders and community officials took turns at the pulpit to call for solidarity in the wake of Pannell's death. Pannell was killed in Teaneck last Tuesday by an officer responding to reports that the youth was brandishing a gun. A vigil there the following night turned violent, with angry black youths smashing police car windows and looting stores. ``No longer will we put up with public officials putting guns in the hands of people untrained to our needs,'' said Theo Bolden, a junior at Teaneck High School. ``Today we say goodbye to Phillip Pannell, but with our minds and hearts and souls we must say hello to the black community of tomorrow.'' George Powell, president of the Bergen County chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, touched on a theme heard throughout the two-hour service, saying parents in the minority community must listen to children who complain of racial harassment. ``We apologize to our children for letting them down and not lending an attentive ear in a critical time of need,'' Powell said. The Rev. Herbert Daughtry, the Pannell family's pastor, read the names of about 10 blacks killed recently in altercations with police in the New York metropolitan area. Despite the riot in Teaneck the day after Pannell's death, the black community has been complacent in responding to violence from police, he said. ``I just wonder what would happen if a black officer killed a 15-year-old Irish, Italian or Jewish kid,'' said Daughtry. ``I submit to you we would not have a few broken windows down in Teaneck.'' Pannell was shot by Teaneck police Officer Gary Spath, who has since been suspended with pay. Wayne Blanco, the officer who responded with Spath, has been temporarily relieved of his duties. An autopsy by the Bergen County medical examiner showed Pannell was shot once in the back. An investigation showed that Spath's .38-caliber service revolver was fired twice, while Blanco's revolver was not fired. A grand jury is to consider the case Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Swedish Foreign Minister, Key Figure in U.S.-PLO Talks, in Egypt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Arafat in Amman saying he has no plans to meet with Andersson. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Swedish Foreign Minister Sten Andersson, a key figure in arranging U.S.-PLO talks, arrived in Egypt's capital Monday for a meeting with PLO leader Yasser Arafat. But Arafat instead arrived in Amman, Jordan, late Monday and told reporters he did not plan to meet with Andersson in Cairo because he already had talks with him Sunday in Tunisia. Andersson had been scheduled to meet Tuesday with the Palestine Liberation Organization chairman and Egypt's foreign minister, Esmet Abdel Meguid, before leaving for Tunisia. Sweden has in the past worked as a go-between in secret talks between the United States and the PLO. Those talks led to Arafat's renunciation of terrorism and, in response, the United States lifted its 13-year-old embargo on official contacts with the PLO in December 1988. Arafat's official spokesman, Bassam Abu-Sharif, said Arafat met Andersson Sunday on the Tunisian island of Garba. In an interview prior to Arafat's arrival in the Jordanian capital, Abu-Sharif said the PLO was not ruling out another meeting between Arafat and Andersson. Speaking to reporters shortly after his arrival, Andersson said Sweden is trying to ``facilitate'' the establishment of direct Palestinian-Israeli talks. ``There are developments in Israel that could help bring about a dialogue,'' he said. In recent weeks, Shimon Peres, the leader of Israel's left-leaning Labor Party has been trying to put together a new coalition government that would back direct talks with Palestinians.

DOC.HEAD: Three Lost Fishermen Sought; One Rescued From Wooden Box in Ocean
DOC.TEXT: The Coast Guard searched the Atlantic Ocean off Georgia and South Carolina for three missing fishermen Monday after a fourth man was plucked from a wooden box in which he may have been floating for days. Nathan Nesmith was found drifting in an open box about 9 a.m. Monday by a passing boat about 20 miles east of Hilton Head Island, S.C., said Petty Officer Brett Farrell of the Coast Guard's rescue station on Tybee Island, Ga. Nesmith, 32, was in serious condition at Memorial Medical Center in Savannah, suffering from hypothermia and dehydration, said hospital spokeswoman Ronnie Boaen. The man told his rescuers he was one of four crew members on a 34-foot commercial fishing boat that sank after it left Darien, Ga., last Wednesday, Farrell said. The 34-foot boat was en route to a fishing area off Edisto Beach, S.C., he said. Coast Guard officials didn't know when the boat sank or how long the man had floated in the box, which may have been used as an engine cover, Farrell said. ``As far as I know he was conscious; he was answering questions, fairly coherent,'' he said. ``He was mainly just worn out from floating for however many days he's been out there.'' Farrell said the Coast Guard sent two boats and two helicopters to search for the fishing boat's three other crew members, but no sign of them had been found by Monday afternoon. Boaters and commercial fishermen were helping with the search, which was centered about 30 miles east of Hilton Head, Farrell said. He said the boat had not been reported missing. Commercial fishing vessels frequently make weeklong trips off the Georgia and South Carolina coasts and ``don't keep communication scheduled with anybody unless they just happen to pass another boat,'' Farrell said. Farrell identified the missing men as Billy Joe Nesmith, 23, Keith Wilkes, 18, and Franklin Brantly 23.

DOC.HEAD: Ortega Reports Continued Fighting in Northern Nicaragua
DOC.TEXT: President Daniel Ortega said Monday that the U.S.-backed Contra rebels have been carrying out raids in northern Nicaragua despite his promises to turn power over to a newly elected government. ``Blood continues to flow and the Contras have not disappeared,'' Ortega said to a group of visiting Protestant evangelists. ``We have to pray to God for peace.'' Also Monday, about 260 Nicaraguan Indians who fought alongside the Contras turned their weapons over to international peacekeepers in Honduras. Another 1,000 fighters are scheduled to give up their weapons on Wednesday. Ortega urged the evangelists, led by the Rev. Jorge Raschke of Puerto Rico, to pray that ``the Contras are disarmed and there be peace in the country'' after President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro succeeds him on April 25. Mrs. Chamorro's United National Opposition, a 14-party coalition, won the Feb. 25 national elections, ending a decade of Sandinista rule. The Contras and Ortega's Sandinista government have been exchanging charges and countercharges for weeks, each claiming that the other side plans to retain their weapons after Ortega steps down. The Sandanistas have vowed to leave office peacefully, but have argued that they should retain control of the military to combat the Contras. The U.S.-backed Contra rebels have waged a nine-year civil war to topple the Sandinistas. The Sandinistas say sporadic clashes have been occurring in the northern areas of the country and a Sandinista military spokeswoman accused the rebels of planning a massive offensive to pry concessions from the government. ``They are trying to make the president (Mrs. Chamorro) negotiate,'' said Lt. Col. Rosa Pasos. The Sandinistas have demanded the Contras demobilize before Mrs. Chamorro's inauguaration. Some Contra leaders have agreed, but others say they will not put down their weapons until they are sure the Sandinistas will turn over full control of the government to Mrs. Chamorro's administration. The demobilization continued Monday as a group of Nicaraguan Indians surrendered their weapons to Gen. Agustin Quesada Gomez, the Spanish commander of a United Nations peacekeeping force, in the Honduran town of Sirsitara, about 40 miles from the Nicaraguan border. The fighters were members of Yatama, an organization of Miskito, Suma and Rama Indians from Nicaragua's Caribbean coast. They have been fighting the Sandinistas since 1981. Forty Venezuelan soldiers in the U.N. force set about destroying the rebel weapons, mainly Soviet-designed AK-47 assault rifles. ``It is a sad day for us, but the decision has been taken,'' Yamata chief, Serafino Bencie, told reporters as his men surrendered their arms. Quesada Gomez said each rifle will be cut into three pieces and then blown up with explosives.

DOC.HEAD: All-White Jury Chosen in Racially Charged Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with all-white jury chosen; reax; picks up 5th graf pvs, `The case was...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto DN2
DOC.TEXT: An all-white jury was chosen to hear the murder trial of a former Houston police officer accused of killing a black woman, prompting outrage from community activists monitoring the trial. ``They could have gotten that jury makeup in Houston. I don't even know why they came to Dallas to do this,'' said activist Ada Edwards, referring to a change of venue. The killing of Ida Lee Delaney, along with another killing of a black motorist by a white officer, has been the focus of protests by blacks and calls for reform of Houston's police force. The former officer, Alex Gonzales, 25, is accused of killing Mrs. Delaney, 50, last fall during an exchange of gunfire following a highway chase while he was off-duty. Prosecutors say the case has nothing to do with race, so the racial makeup of the jury isn't important. ``The State of Texas is very happy with the jury,'' said Don Smyth, assistant Harris County district attorney. ``We think they'll do a fine job. As we've been telling eveyrbody else, this is not a racial case. Some folks are trying to make it a racial case.'' ``It's not a surprise,'' said Ms. Edwards, one of more than 40 people who drove from Houston to Dallas to monitor the trial. ``I just hope the process will carry itself out and that those people are people who will be willing to hear the entire story.'' ``I feel like this trial, this marching, none of this should be going on,'' said Ora Shaw, a sister of the dead woman who has taken part in protests. ``She was murdered ... for nothing.'' The case was moved to Dallas because of pretrial publicity in Houston. Ms. Edwards said activists were more concerned with the process than the outcome of Gonzales' murder trial. But, she said, ``He is guilty of killing Ida Delaney. Now if they want to get technical about what level of guilt, I can't speak to that.'' Some of the spectators in the Dallas County courtroom were ushered out to make space for 60 potential jurors. Mrs. Delaney's was killed within two weeks of the death of Byron Gillum, who was shot eight times after a traffic stop by an officer who said he saw Gillum reach for a gun. The officer hasn't been charged. A gun was recovered from Gillum's car. Ms. Edwards, who is co-chair of the Ida Lee Delaney-Byron Gillum Justice Committee, said the group and volunteer attorneys would watch the trial ``to make sure the community is aware of what happened.'' Testimony is expected to begin Tuesday, said Don Smyth, who heads the Harris County District Attorney's office's civil rights division and is prosecuting Gonzales. Mrs. Delaney, driving to work on a Houston freeway, apparently cut off Gonzales and two other off-duty officers in an unmarked car about 5 a.m. on Oct. 31. She pulled over after a 12-mile chase, and Mrs. Delaney and Gonzales exchanged gunfire. Gonzales' attorney, Mike Hinton, said Mrs. Delaney fired first. The off-duty officers had been attending a birthday party at a nightclub for several hours before the shooting. Hospital records showed Gonzales was legally intoxicated when he sought treatment for gunshot wounds to the abdomen. All three officers were fired, but only Gonzales was indicted on a murder charge by a grand jury. All are appealing their firings to independent arbitrators. Activist groups in Dallas and Houston planned to monitor the proceeding. Eva McMillan, of the Dallas Anti-Apartheid Coalition, said Dallas juries tend to ``disregard the people.'' ``I think nothing should be handed down but a guilty verdict,'' Ms. McMillan said. ``But knowing Texas justice, especially Dallas, and the type of juries Dallas selects ... juries which will vote in favor of the Establishment.'' One Houston activist, Alkebu Motapa, said he would fast throughout the trial, which attorneys say could last two weeks. ``Throughout the trial, I'll be in constant prayer and meditation for justice,'' Motapa said. Ms. Edwards said activists want Houston to establish a civilian review board of police. The committee organized a march that attracted 200 people in Houston Saturday. On Sunday, members planted a black cross near where Gillum was killed. Earlier this month, Harris County grand jurors declined to indict former Officer Scott Tschirhart, 27, in Gillum's death. Gillum was the third black civilian killed by Tschirhart during the officer's seven years on the Houston force.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Supreme Court Rejects Appeal of Courthouse Killer
With AM-Scotus Rdp
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Supreme Court on Monday refused to hear an appeal from a man condemned to die for killing an attorney during a 1985 courthouse shootout. The justices denied Ronnie Lee Gardner's bid for a Supreme Court hearing without comment, except for customary dissenting statements by Justices William J. Brennan and Thurgood Marshall, who oppose capital punishment under all circumstances. Gardner, 27, was sentenced to die for gunning down Michael J. Burdell during a botched escape attempt April 2, 1985, at Salt Lake City's Metropolitan Hall of Justice. Police said a girlfriend of Gardner's slipped him a handgun while he was being transported to a hearing on a separate second-degree murder charge stemming from the 1984 slaying of a bartender. Though shackled hand and foot, Gardner turned the weapon on two Utah State Prison guards accompanying him. One of the guards shot Gardner in the shoulder before he fled, confronted Burdell and shot the attorney once in the head. Gardner also wounded a bailiff before surrendering. In February 1989, the Utah Supreme Court denied Gardner's appeal following a three-year review. Defense attorneys had argued that Gardner should have been granted a change of venue due to pretrial publicity. His lawyers also contended that the state district judge who tried the case should have removed himself, since he was in the courthouse at the time of Gardner's escape attempt. Gardner's attorneys were not immediately available for comment on the latest decision.

DOC.HEAD: Galileo Fires Thrusters as Part of Earth, Jupiter Missions
DOC.TEXT: The Galileo spacecraft successfully fired its thrusters almost 1,600 times during a four-day maneuver designed to help it reach Jupiter in 1995, NASA said Monday. The sequence of thruster pulses, completed late last Thursday, slowed the spacecraft by about 55 mph, said Jim Wilson, a spokesman for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. The next set of maneuvers is scheduled for this summer, said Bob MacMillin another spokesman. The 2.8-ton Galileo was launched on its $1.35 billion mission by the space shuttle Atlantis on Oct. 18. It flew past Venus on Feb. 9 so that planet could act as a ``gravity slingshot'' to help propel the spacecraft on its looping 2.4-billion-mile, six-year journey to Jupiter, the solar system's largest planet. The spacecraft will fly past Earth on Dec. 8 of this year and again on Dec. 8, 1990, in two more ``gravity slingshot'' maneuvers. Galileo will examine Earth, Earth's moon and one or two asteroids before the spacecraft separates into an orbiter and a small probe in July 1995. In December 1995, they arrive at Jupiter. There, the probe will parachute into the atmosphere and make measurements until the planet's intense heat and pressure vaporize it. The orbiter will photograph and study Jupiter and its major moons until late 1997, circling the planet instead of flying past it like the Pioneer and Voyager spacecraft.

DOC.HEAD: Flutist James Galway Hospitalized on Eve of Opera Debut
LaserPhoto PX4
DOC.TEXT: Flutist James Galway was hospitalized Monday with inflammation of the intestinal tract, forcing him to cancel his first performance in an opera, it was announced. Despite feeling ill, Galway had planned up until Monday morning to go ahead with his performance as the title character in the Opera Company of Philadelphia production of Rossini's ``The Thieving Magpie,'' said Jane Grey Nemeth, the company's acting general director. He was admitted to Thomas Jefferson University Hospital as a precaution, Ms. Nemeth said. Galway was treated with intravenous antibiotics for an inflammation of the intestinal tract, said hospital spokeswoman Betsy Samuels. He was in stable condition Monday night. Galway's doctors don't anticipate operating on the flutist, who should recover in seven to 10 days, Ms. Sameuls said. He should be able to immediately return to performing, she said. Sitting in for Galway in what would have been his operatic debut was his wife, Jeanne. In Gioacchino Rossini's original production, the part of the Magpie is generally played by a walk-on actor, but in the Philadelphia production, a flute player takes the part. In the opera, the Magpie steals a silver spoon, and a servant girl is blamed and sentenced to death. But the true culprit is discovered at the end.

DOC.HEAD: British Tubes Maker Says Iraq Deal Also Involved Space Research
DOC.TEXT: The manufacturer of the steel tubes suspected to be parts of a huge Iraqi weapon said Monday its contract with Iraq involved Space Research Corp., which designed a satellite launch system and was run by slain American ballistics expert Gerald Bull. Customs seized the eight sections April 12 as they were to be shipped to Iraq, and insist they could be used as part of a large gun. Sheffield Forgemasters has insisted they were for use in a petrochemical installation and not subject to the licensing controls that bar sales of armaments to Iraq. Forgemasters' lawyer Stuart Benson said in a statement Monday, ``All documents I have seen support Forgemasters' understanding that the pipes were for a petrochemical application. ``It has always been accepted by Forgemasters that Space Research Corp. had involvement in this contract. Forgemasters has never sought to conceal such involvement.'' He said a Dr. Cowley, not Bull, was the Space Research representative in the contract with the Iraqi Ministry of Trade. Space Research has its headquarters in Brussels. Customs said there was no question the tubes could be used as a barrel of a large artillery piece to fire a projectile. It holds the tubes pending investigation. Benson said it was not for Forgemasters to prove or disprove the ultimate use and purpose of the tubes. ``My only concern is to rebut any suggestion that it has acted in any way improperly or unlawfully,'' he said. Bull, 62, a Canadian-born U.S. citizen, was slain in Brussels March 22. Belgian police said he was shot twice in the head with a silenced gun and robbery was not the motive because $20,000 was found in Bull's pockets. Bull's company was described as a multinational dealing in space and military research and employed in international arms sales. Sheffield Forgemasters says it agreed to supply 52 sections of the steel tubing and had delivered 44 to the Ministry of Industry and Minerals in Baghdad. It denied the eight tubes seized last week could be joined together to form a huge gun to attack Iraq's Middle East enemies or launch satellites. Iraq says the tubes are petrochemical pipes. On Saturday, Press Association, the British domestic news agency, quoted unidentified ``reliable government sources'' as saying they had correspondence linking British industry with Bull's firm. The correspondence refers to orders for the manufacture of smoothbore pipes that experts believe match the specification detailed in Bull's design for a space satellite launch system, the sources were quoted as saying. The Times of London on Friday quoted an unidentified Customs official as saying the seized materials matched a design by Bull. Jane's Defense Weekly has identified Bull as a designer of South Africa's G5 155mm howitzer, which has been sold to Iraq. On March 28, British Customs officers arrested five people at Heathrow Airport and seized 40 U.S.-made components for nuclear bomb triggers that were being shipped to Iraq. One of those arrested was deported, one was released and three await trial.

DOC.HEAD: Cult Leader, 2 Followers Plead Innocent
DOC.TEXT: The leader of a cult pleaded innocent Monday to murder and kidnapping charges in the execution-style shooting deaths of a couple and their three children. Two cult followers also pleaded innocent in the slayings of Dennis Avery, his wife Cheryl and their three daughters, whose bodies were found in a common grave under a barn in nearby Kirtland. Altogether, 13 cult members are charged in the slayings, believed to have taken place in April 1989. Jeffrey Lundgren, 39, pleaded innocent to five counts of aggravated murder and five counts of kidnapping, and the judge ordered him held without bond. Lundgren also pleaded innocent to one count of complicity in attempted aggravated murder lodged in a separate indictment. Lundgren was defrocked about two years ago as a lay minister of the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints in Kirtland after he espoused radical beliefs. He and the 12 others, including his wife and son, lived commune-style on the farm he rented near Kirtland, about 30 miles east of Cleveland. The Averys belonged to the cult but didn't live with the Lundgrens. Authorities have said the Averys were considered less devout than the other cult members and speculated they may have been killed as a sacrificial ``cleansing'' of the spirit. Authorities also have said the Averys may have been slain out of fear they would tell others of an alleged cult plan to storm a Kirtland temple and kill people near it. No such raid occurred. Lake County Public Defender Paul LaPlante declined to discuss potential defense strategy. Another cult member, Daniel Kraft, 25, pleaded innocent to five counts of aggravated murder and five counts of kidnapping. He was ordered held without bond. Kathryn Johnson, 36, entered innocent pleas to five counts of complicity in aggravated murder and one count of complicity in attempted aggravated murder. Bail was set at $300,000. None of the three spoke at the hearings. The three had fought extradition from San Diego since their arrests there in January. They were returned to Painesville on Friday. Also Monday, two cult members were freed from the Lake County Jail after their charges were reduced. Dennis and Tonya Patrick each had been charged with five counts of conspiracy to commit aggravated murder. Each posted 10 percent of a $25,000 bond on one count of complicity in attempted aggravated murder.

DOC.SECOND: Roseanne Unseats Cosby as Ratings Champ
DOC.TEXT: ABC's ``Roseanne'' edged NBC's ``The Cosby Show'' as prime-time ratings champ in the just-concluded 1989-1980 season, NBC announced Monday. ABC's Tuesday comedy starring Roseanne Barr averaged a 23.3 rating, two-tenths of a ratings point more than the Bill Cosby family comedy which has been first in the Nielson ratings for the last four seasons. ``The Cosby Show,'' wound up in second place for the season. Cosby's series has been on the air for six seasons, and Barr's series for two. Each ratings point represents 921,000 homes. Final figures for the 30-week season, which ended Sunday, won't be available until Tuesday. But network research analysts say that NBC will easily win its fifth consecutive season, with ABC coming in second, and once-dominant CBS in third place for the third straight season. Still awaiting final figures for the last three days of the season, Preston Beckman, NBC vice-president for research, said that NBC thus far had a 14.6 ratings average, ABC a 12.9 and CBS a 12.2 during the season. NBC's ratings are down by nine percent, ABC's are flat, and those of CBS are down by three percent, he said. He cited competition from cable, the fledgling Fox network, and independent stations as factors in the overall ratings drop. However, he attributed 25 percent of NBC's decline to the absence of three sports events it had in prime time during the previous season _ the Summer Olypmics, the World Series and pro football's Superbowl.
