DOC.HEAD: Argentina to Lay Off 80,000 Public Employees
DOC.TEXT: Argentina's public works minister, Roberto Dromi, said Monday that about 80,000 public employees will be retired or laid off by the end of the month as an austerity measure. Government workers past retirement age or within two years of retirement are affected. Employees who hold two jobs in the state sector must give up one. ``Employees who are in position to be retired are going to receive their pensions and be retired,'' Dromi said in an interview broadcast by Radio Rivadavia. Such action has been rare in Argentina since the late President Juan Peron came to power in 1946. Peron entrenched himself by creating or expanding state companies in part to spur employment and improve working conditions. Peronist provincial governments still expand public rolls during bad economic times. Argentina returned to democracy in December 1983, after nearly eight years of harsh military rule, but the economy has been in constant trouble for decades. Dromi said the public sector amounts to about 3 million of the 12{ million total workforce. Argentina's total population is about 31 million. ``The public administration is absolutely too big,'' Alberto Kohan, a key aide to President Carlos Menem, told reporters. The government announced on March 4 that it was planning job cutbacks and tax increases to slash the budget deficit by $2 billion. It put no figure on forced retirements and layoffs until Dromi's comments. Retirement clauses in collective bargaining contracts vary from ages 55 to 65. A recession has idled up to 15 percent of the workforce and shrunk wages for many workers to $100 or less a month. Many rely on overtime or a second job to make ends meet. Initial comments from labor leaders were cautious. Victor de Gennaro, secretary-general of the 145,000-member Association of State Workers, said the measure ``won't serve to lower public spending'' because more employees would be suspended with pay than retired. ``The retirements won't improve the functioning of the state. On the contrary, capable people will be lost,'' he told the private news agency Noticias Argentinas. Union leaders supported Menem, a Peronist, during his election campaign last year. However, many have protested since he took office last July that his policies of budget austerity and economic reform have hurt union members. Menem drastically increased public service rates, freed wages and prices, opened the oil industry to foreign investment and put state companies up for sale in an attempt to reduce the fiscal deficit. The deficit, for years covered by the Central Bank's printing currency, is a prime cause of inflation that soared by 95 percent in March and 20,266 percent the past 12 months. The forced retirements are almost certain to provoke a labor reaction. Unions representing oilfield and train workers, bank clerks and others have staged strikes or job actions this year to protest layoffs. Shrinking the public payroll is seen as a major test of whether Menem is willing to take on organized labor, long the backbone of the Peronist party. Analysts and critics say such a confrontation is essential and unavoidable. The Labor Ministry this year has asked labor courts to withdraw the legal status of unions that strike for political, rather than economic reasons. Last week, about 70 members of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers were fired for participating in a strike the ministry ruled illegal.

DOC.HEAD: No Defense Witnesses To Be Called For Ford Trial
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Rep. Harold Ford told a federal court Monday that he has decided not to call any defense witnesses in his trial on charges he took political payoffs from bankers. ``We're going to send it to the jury and let the jury decide,'' Ford said as he left the courtroom where he has been on trial since Feb. 12. The 44-year-old Memphis Democrat is being tried on charges of conspiracy, bank fraud and mail fraud. He is accused of taking payoffs from former Tennessee bankers Jake and brother C.H. Butcher Jr. Prosecutors surprised defense lawyers and courtroom spectators last week by resting their case without calling C.H. Butcher, who had been expected to be a star witness against Ford. Butcher, charged with Ford in 1987, has pleaded guilty to conspiring with him to commit bank and mail fraud. Assistant U.S. Attorney Dan Clancy declined to comment on his decision not to summon Butcher. Ford is being tried with three former Butcher aides: accountant David Crabtree and laywers Douglas Beaty and Karl Schledwitz. The congressman's co-defendants also announced they were ready to turn the case over the jury following final arguments. Before resting their case, defense lawyers asked U.S. District Judge Odell Horton for a direct verdict of acquittal, saying the prosecution had fallen well short of proving its case. Horton denied the motion. Defense and prosecution lawyers are scheduled to discuss procedural matters Tuesday afternoon with Horton. Final arguments are expected to begin Wednesday. Government lawyers called 29 witnesses who outlined a complicated series of loans to Ford from lending institutions once run by the Butchers. Most of those loans were without collateral or adequate financial statements, and Ford made few if any payments on them until the Butchers' banking empire collapsed in 1983, witnesses said. The Butchers set off the largest banking collapse in Tennessee history and are serving 20-year bank fraud sentences in federal prison. Government witnesses said Ford's loans were moved from bank to bank, apparently to hide them from federal examiners. Many of the loans eventually ended up at C.H. Butcher's Southern Industrial Banking Corp., a state-chartered finance company. A federal bank examiner described SIBC as a ``dumping ground'' for bad loans issued by the Butchers. The government says Ford got some $1 million in Butcher loans between 1976 and 1982, but he puts the loan total at $650,000. Ford said the loans have been settled since 1983. He paid a bankruptcy trustee $25,000 in 1983 to settle his obligations stemming from a $350,000 loan from SIBC to a company called Tenn-Ford Inc.

DOC.HEAD: Animal-Rights Activist Pleads No Contest in Bomb Case
DOC.TEXT: A woman whose 1988 arrest on charges she tried to kill the head of a medical company galvanized the animal rights movement pleaded no contest Monday in exchange for a reduced one-year prison sentence. Although she strongly contested the case against her, Fran Trutt, 33, pleaded no contest to attempted murder, possession of explosives and bomb manufacturing, said her attorney, John Williams. Trutt was arrested in November 1988 after a remote-controlled pipe bomb was found near the parking space of Leon Hirsch, chairman of U.S. Surgical Corp. in Norwalk. Animal-rights activists had criticized U.S. Surgical for using anesthetized dogs to train physicians how to use surgical staples in place of stitches. The dogs are then killed. Under the plea bargain reached late Monday afternoon, Trutt will serve one year in prison followed by three years of probation as part of a 10-year suspended sentence. Trutt, who lived in New York City when she was arrested, has been held on $500,000 bond at the Connecticut Correctional Center in Niantic. In pleading no contest, she resisted any suggestion that she was guilty. Instead, she accused Hirsch of murdering dogs. ``I disagree completely with guilt. The evidence we needed to prove has not come up yet,'' Trutt told Stamford Superior Court Judge Joette Katz. As Katz reviewed the charges, Trutt said, ``The one who was guilty of that is Hirsch.'' Animal-rights activists and Trutt claimed she was set up by the company to discredit their movement. U.S. Surgical said Trutt's conviction vindicated the company. ``Her convictions should send a clear message to animal-rights activists that they can protest, that they can disagree and they can picket peacefully, but the American system of justice will pursue vigorously those who attempt to force their views on others through violence,'' said company spokeswoman Marianne Scipione. The pleas discredit the entrapment argument, Ms. Scipione said. The plea bargain was similar to one that fell through April 5. In the earlier agreement, Trutt would have pleaded no contest to at least one of the charges against her in exchange for a one-year sentence and the right to visit her four dogs. But when prison officials denied Trutt the dog-visitation rights, she opted for a trial, Williams said. Williams said Trutt decided on the plea bargain because the prosecution was prepared to introduce tape recordings of her discussing details of her sex life and the murder attempt. ``The sex tapes _ I think that's what did it. It was just disgusting,'' Williams said after Monday's hearing in state Superior Court in Stamford. ``I have been fearing this from the first day: How long will Fran be able to stand up to this?'' The tapes were of telephone conversations between Trutt and Mary Lou Sapone, who was hired by U.S. Surgical to befriend Trutt and spy on her, Williams said. The case was in the pretrial stage when Monday's agreement was reached. Trutt could have been sentenced to up to 20 years in prison on the attempted murder charge alone.

DOC.HEAD: Vargas Llosa Says He Will Continue Presidential Campaign
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with Vargas Llosa saying major factor in staying in race was constitutional requirement, doubts cast on his enthusiam for race, names of well-known books. Pickup 12th pvs, `Some of...'
DOC.TEXT: Mario Vargas Llosa said Monday he will continue his presidential campaign and participate in an election runoff against Alberto Fujimori, a political neophyte now favored to win Peru's presidency. ``I will go to the second round fighting for the reforms that our country needs,'' the celebrated novelist said in a brief statement following a two-hour meeting with campaign strategists and leaders of his center-right Democratic Front coalition. Vargas Llosa said he had been ready to end his candidacy to save Peru the turmoil of two more months of election campaigning but was persuaded to continue for the good of this Andean nation, wracked by economic problems and a violent guerrilla uprising. He had been seriously considering dropping out of the runoff election after a disappointing showing in the April 8 opening round, according to key figures in his campaign. Fujimori, the descendent of Japanese immigrants and a political unknown when he started the campaign, ran a close second to Vargas Llosa and has emerged as a favorite in the runoff because he is expected to pick up the support of voters who favored leftist candidates. Vargas Llosa said a major factor in his decision was the constitutional requirement for a runoff if no candidate receives a majority of votes, effectively barring by law from withdrawing his name from the second round. That appeared to confirm reports he was participating in the runoff, expected to be held in late May or early June, to fulfill a legal requirement and was not enthusiastic about continuing his presidential campaign. Key supporters said the novelist had been considering dropping out because he was reportedly discouraged by the prospect that he would lose the runoff or, if he won, face the prospect of governing the country without control of Congress. Vargas Llosa, author of such celebrated books as ``The Green House,'' ``Aunt Julia and the Scriptwriter'' and ``Converations in The Cathedral,'' went into seclusion with his family last Wednesday to mull over the decision on whether to continue the race. He said Monday night hoped the second round of campaigning would produce a ``clean debate'' on the best ways to solve Peru's problems. News commentators and political figures close to the writer had said earlier Monday they were convinced he would stay in the race. Some of Vargas Llosa's closest supporters have stressed the need for a runoff to ensure that Peru's next president can claim a popular mandate to deal with the country's problems. Due to the growing violence by the Shining Path guerrillas and the country's severe economic problems, Peru needs a president elected with majority support, Manuel d'Ornellas, editor of the Expreso newspaper and a close friend of the writer, said last week. ``The mandate that Fujimori would receive after Vargas Llosa's resignation could be questioned in the future, opening the doors to a possible military coup,'' d'Ornellas wrote in a column in his paper. Fujimori had been given little chance of making the second round a month ago. But a late surge propelled him into second place in the field of nine candidates. Vargas Llosa had hoped for a majority to avoid a second round but received only 32 percent of the votes. Fujimori, an agricultural engineer and former university rector running as an independent, received nearly 30 percent. Fujimori is favored in the runoff because Vargas Llosa is unlikely to receive support from the left-of-center ruling Aprista Party and Peru's leftist parties. Vargas Llosa harshly criticized the leftists' policies, while Fujimori conducted a conciliatory campaign. Fujimori avoided specifics in his campaign, stressing instead general goals like improved health care and revitalized industry. Analysts say Fujimori also benefited from voter concerns about the harsh economic austerity measures advocated by Varsa Llosa and suspicions about the old-line politicians in the Democratic Front. The Democratic Front also fell far short of gaining a majority in the congressional elections. Without support in Congress, Vargas Llosa would have great problems as president imposing his economic austerity program aimed at reviving Peru's moribund economy.

DOC.HEAD: State Mental Institute Employee Slain, Patient Held
DOC.TEXT: A property clerk at a state hospital for the criminally insane was fatally attacked Monday while working with a patient, who was arrested in the slaying, officials said. The 59-year-old victim, whose name was withheld until his relatives could be notified, was pronounced dead of head injuries at Twin Cities Hospital in Templeton shortly before noon, said a statement from Atascadero State Hospital. Terry Caylor, 43, was arrested for investigation of murder, said San Luis Obispo County Sheriff's Lt. Pat Hedges. Details of the attack were sketchy, and Atascadero spokesman David Hamilton said the hospital would not elaborate pending an investigation by the district attorney's office and sheriff's department. According to the central California hospital's statement, the patient had been working with the property clerk when the clerk was unexpectedly attacked. Atascadero's acting executive director, Dr. Gordon Gritter, ``expressed deep sympathy for the family, and reflected the shock of all the hospital employees,'' the release said. ``He also stated the great dismay of all who have been working to improve safety at the hospital.'' The last violent incident at the 891-patient hospital involved an attack on a female technician in March 1989, Hamilton said. A patient is being prosecuted in that attack, he said. The hospital is one of two facilities in California that handle patients deemed by the courts to be mentally disordered and unfit for criminal prosecution.

DOC.HEAD: Escobar Leadership of Medellin Cartel Thrown Into Question
DOC.TEXT: The Medellin drug cartel rejects its longtime leader, Pablo Escobar, because of his indiscriminate terrorism, according to a statement claiming to be from cartel members. The newspaper El Tiempo on Monday doubted the the statement's authenticity. It said the format and lettering were different from previous documents sent by the traffickers to local media. Defense Minister Oscar Botero said Monday he did not know if the statement was authentic, but that a split in the cartel does exist over tactics in a battle against the government. ``There are many drug traffickers,'' Botero said in a TV interview broadcast by the Cinevision news program, adding that some members of the Medellin Cartel were opposed to terrorist violence. The statement was issued Sunday night and declared: ``We the Extraditables do not agree with the terrorist acts that Pablo Escobar is ordering in an indiscriminate and personal way. Previously we asked Pablo Escobar to stop detonating bombs and executing innocent people because such acts did not help our cause. ``From now on, we declare ourselves in total disagreement with the terrorist acts ordered personally by Pablo Escobar. We reject the violent way (Escobar) is forcing us to carry on his personal war by kidnapping, torturing and threatening our families.'' Authorities have blamed the Medellin Cartel for a campaign of bombings and other terrorist violence that killed 238 people in the last eight months. The attacks were in retaliation for a government crackdown in which 15 drug suspects were extradited and hundreds of traffickers' properties seized. Last month the cartel ended a unilateral truce declared in January. It said the renewed violence was in reply to continued government pressure on them. In two weeks, terrorists killed 28 police officers in Medellin. On April 5, police defused a 1,650-pound dynamite truck bomb on a main avenue in Bogota during morning rush hour. Authorities say the bomb could have killed thousands. Authorities blamed the Medellin cartel for all the attacks. The statement makes it appear that Escobar may have acted alone. Police dispatched 300 anti-terrorist agents to Medellin to search for Escobar, who they say has undergone plastic surgery to evade authorities. Police sources say Escobar's capture, dead or alive, is imminent since he is losing organization support. Authorities say Escobar has killed and tortured cartel members suspected of betraying him.

DOC.HEAD: Chinatown Merchants' Strike Doesn't Change Vote on Freeway Demolition
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with board of supervisors voting to recommend tearing down freeway despite protest; picks up 9th graf pvs, `But Pak...'
DOC.TEXT: Despite a merchants' strike that shut down the city's famed Chinatown, the Board of Supervisors voted Monday to tear down a quake-damaged freeway the merchants consider a vital link to their community. Almost 1,200 shops, restaurants and professional offices _ all but five small businesses _ signed up to take part in the three-hour shutdown, said protest organizer Rose Pak of the Chinese Chamber of Commerce. Many of the business people attended the meeting at which the supervisors considered a proposal by Mayor Art Agnos to consider replacing the elevated Embarcadero Freeway with either a surface or underground road. The board voted 6-5 to accept Agnos' proposal. The state Department of Transportation previously agreed to abide by the supervisors' vote on the state-owned freeway. Supervisor Angela Alioto said the vote means the freeway that runs along the waterfront will have to be torn down, but Pak vowed to continue the fight and hold state officials to a plan to repair the road. The strike began at 1:30 p.m. and Chinatown came to a grinding halt. Most stores closed, with shopkeepers taking their goods off the sidewalks. The usual shoulder-to-shoulder pedestrian traffic in the heart of Chinatown went away. The noise of car horns was replaced by the sound of chimes blowing in the breeze. ``We just got in to Chinatown and already got kicked out of two shops,'' said Michael Kiriazis, a businessman from Portland, Ore., just as the strike began. Hundreds of Chinatown business people and residents climbed aboard buses that shuttled them to City Hall. It has stood empty since a 7.1-magnitude earthquake shook northern California six months ago, killing 68 people, cracking concrete columns supporting the waterfront roadway. Agnos recently proposed tearing down the elevated freeway, long considered an eyesore as well as an easy entrance for drivers into Chinatown and the restaurants of North Beach and tourist attractions at Fisherman's Wharf. In its place, the mayor suggested building an underground road that he believes would be safer from earthquakes and more aesthetically pleasing. But Pak and others such as Supervisor Tom Hsieh contend repairing the existing freeway would be better because it would get business traffic back into the economically depressed Chinatown area sooner and cheaper. The Agnos plan calls for expenditures of about $120 million, mostly in federal funds, over four years. Repairing the old freeway, however, would cost the state transportation department about $32 million to wrap the structure's support columns in 2-inch-thick steel jackets, making it able to withstanding an 8.3-magnitude quake. Under that plan, the freeway would reopen by October. Time is essential to Chinatown merchants. While Deputy Mayor James Ho estimated business in that area is down by 8 percent, Pak placed the loss closer to 30 percent for tourist-dependent businesses and 20 percent for those relying on local residents. She said the community is united behind the repair plan. ``This is the first time in 205 years the Chinese community has shut down their businesses to protest,'' Pak said. While Chinatown initiated its protest action, the San Francisco Chronicle ran a column by 1990 Pulitzer Prize-winning architecture critic Allan Temko, headlined: ``Freeway Must Go for the City to Thrive.'' Temko argued for a buried freeway, and said San Francisco could once again be the ``beau ideal of a civilized American metropolis, as it was before the freeway transformed one of the loveliest waterfronts in the world into one of the most obscene.''

DOC.HEAD: Deaths Raises Fears on Streets Where Even Normal Days Are No Picnic
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 4th graf pvs, `Most of...,' to UPDATE with drivers' protest after false report of another killing; picks up 5th graf pvs, `The latest killing...'
DOC.TEXT: The killings of five cab drivers in the Bronx, including three who may have been victims of the same robber, have terrorized hundreds of drivers who are sacrificing profits for daytime driving. At the Seaman Car Service, employer of the latest victim, black flags flew Monday from the antennas of cabs, and drivers held a memorial procession. At the Flash Car Service Co. in the Bronx, only 15 of the 80 drivers who normally work Sunday nights showed up for work, said dispatcher Pablo Feliciano. ``Most of them are switching to the days,'' Feliciano said. ``They're really disturbed about what's going on. Everybody's shaken up really badly.'' Drivers again vented their outrage later Monday when 400 to 500 cabs descended on a section of the Bronx and tied up traffic after hearing a false report on their radios that another driver had been shot, said Officer Fred Weiner. With lights on, the cabs parked in the street and blocked traffic from 3 p.m. to 5 p.m., said Weiner, a police spokesman. ``A canvass of the car service companies did not turn up any drivers missing,'' Weiner said. ``They caused a major traffic jam over there.'' The latest killing Saturday and another three days earlier were dismissed by police as unrelated to the first three, but the slayings heightened fears in an area where cab drivers haven't felt safe for decades. Officer James Terretta, part of a task force of about 30 officers investigating the slayings, said police do not have a suspect in any of the killings but are receiving many tips. Mayor David Dinkins has offered a $10,000 reward for information leading to the killer or killers. The terror spree began March 7 with the death of Acton Jones, 37. On March 14, 43-year-old Eliot Whitaker was killed, and on April 9, Paul Burghard, 25, was fatally shot. In each shooting, a man phoned a car service requesting a cab, then killed the drivers with a shot to the head from a .22-caliber gun and robbed them. Last Wednesday, Dennis Forbes, 41, the driver of an unlicensed cab, was shot in the head and killed before he had a chance to use a .25-caliber pistol police said he kept on the seat next to him. Late Saturday, Rafael Montes De Oca, 38, of the Seaman Car Service was shot in the head and killed after he went to pick up a regular customer. ``The first three are connected and the last two are not,'' said Officer Ralph St. Just, a police spokesman. He said investigators refused to explain why. In New York City, there are four basic types of taxicabs. Yellow cabs, also known as medallion cabs, roam the streets of the borough of Manhattan and airports, picking up passengers at random. Car services, or so-called livery cars, generally operate outside Manhattan and are dispatched in response to customer calls. ``Black cars'' are used almost exclusively by corporate clients who arrange their pickups. Then there are thousands of unlicensed cabs which ply the streets. The number of car services grew in the 1960s and 1970s when yellow cab drivers began avoiding the outer boroughs where they felt less safe and where there generally was no customer to return with to Manhattan. Cars are dispatched from 120 bases in the Bronx but some companies have lost up to 80 percent of their drivers at night because of fear caused by the deaths, said Tony Carter, a spokesman for the Taxi and Limousine Commission, which licenses cabs in the city. Customers calling cabs in the Bronx now wait an hour or more for a car that used to be at their doorstep in 10 to 20 minutes, he said. Last year, 32 cab drivers were killed, about half of them in the Bronx, said Officer Kim Royster, a police spokeswoman. Citywide, 3,032 cabbies were robbed last year. There are 11,787 yellow cabs, 35,000 livery cabs and up to 20,000 unlicensed cabs in the city. Of the 1989 deaths, 28 were livery drivers and four were medallion drivers, the spokeswoman said.

DOC.HEAD: Postal Worker Injured in Tax-Night Blast at Suburban Detroit Post Office
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to UPDATE with victim released from hospital.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Tax Rdp
DOC.TEXT: A bomb inside an envelope addressed to ``tax thieves'' exploded outside a post office Monday night, injuring a worker taking last-minute federal tax returns, authorities said. The worker, whose name wasn't released, was taken to William Beaumont Hospital suffering from burns on his hands and face, said city Fire Chief Bill Crouch. The 29-year-old victim was treated and released, said hospital spokeswoman Valerie Mabaczek, who declined to discuss the man's injuries. ``He asked that no information be given out.'' The blast occurred around 8:30 p.m. outside the post office in this Detroit suburb as workers collected tax returns. Workers spotted the envelope, which had been placed in a bin, smoking. The victim had picked it up to put it in a puddle when it went off, Crouch said. The envelope was addressed to ``tax thieves'' and contained at least one tea bag, the fire chief said. The blast did little or no structural damage to the post office, said police Lt. Ray Taylor. The FBI, the federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms agents and the state police bomb squad responded to the bombing, Taylor said. The bomb squad was called out to make sure there were no other bombs. No suspects were in custody, Taylor said.

DOC.HEAD: Publishers
Editors
Managing Editors
DOC.TEXT: A summary of developments in the news industry for the week of April 9-16:
DOC.HEAD: Three Pulitzers Honor Reporting on Health Threats
DOC.TEXT:
Newspapers that warned readers of health threats in drinking water, blood supplies and a dietary supplement won Pulitzer Prizes on April 12. Two papers won for their coverage of the California earthquake. Public service Pulitzers were awarded to the Washington (N.C.) Daily News for an expose of carcinogens in the city water supply, and to The Philadelphia Inquirer for a probe of the blood industry. Reporting on a third health threat, the link between the dietary supplement L-tryptophan and a rare blood disorder, won the Pulitzer for specialized reporting for Tamar Stieber of the Albuquerque (N.M.) Journal. The staff of the San Jose (Calif.) Mercury News, which published with the aid of emergency generators after the Oct. 17 quake, won the general news award for its coverage of the disaster. The spot news photography award went to the photo staff of The Tribune of Oakland, Calif., for pictures of the earthquake's devastation. The award for international reporting went to Nicholas D. Kristof and Sheryl WuDunn of The New York Times, a husband-and-wife team who covered the mass movement for democracy in China and its suppression. David C. Turnley of the Detroit Free Press won the feature photography prize for his coverage of the political tumult in China and Eastern Europe. Announcement of the awards set off celebrations around the country. ``I always thought Pulitzers were for overturning a government or exposing a scandal in the stock market,'' said Los Angeles Times sports columnist Jim Murray, who won the prize for commentary. ``I thought Walter Lippmann got Pulitzers, not us guys.'' ``I will say we haven't had this much excitement in this town since the Union cavalry and the Confederate cavalry chased each other up Main Street in 1862, and there's been nothing like that since,'' said Bill Coughlin, the Washington Daily News' executive editor. The Daily News revealed that carcinogens had been in the water supply for eight years, and that the local government had neither disclosed the problem nor corrected it. They broke out the champagne at the Inquirer, which won for reporter Gilbert M. Gaul's series. It was the Philadelphia newspaper's 17th Pulitzer and the 11th in the past six years. ``I feel great. It is a terrific honor,'' said Gaul. ``The paper showed an incredible amount of courage to allow me to spend a year and a half on the story and to report on a subject that is of great importance to everyone that we don't often think about _ blood.'' Gaul, 38, had previously won the Pulitzer Prize for investigative reporting in 1979. The blood series, which found that the industry is little regulated, was inspired by his questions about what happened to the blood he donated four times a year. It was the first time in 23 years that two newspapers were cited in the public service category. The investigative reporting award went to Lou Kilzer and Chris Ison of the Star Tribune of Minneapolis-St. Paul, for their revelation of a network of local citizens who were linked to members of the St. Paul fire department and who profited from fires. The explanatory journalism award went to David A. Vise and Steve Coll of The Washington Post for stories examining the workings of the Securities and Exchange Commission and its former chairman, John Shad. Four reporters for The Seattle Times _ Ross Anderson, Bill Dietrich, Mary Ann Gwinn and Eric Nalder _ received the national reporting award for their coverage of the Exxon Valdez oil spill and its aftermath. For his feature writing award, Dave Curtin of the Colorado Springs (Colo.) Gazette Telegraph profiled a family that was struggling to recover from an explosion that devastated their home and left them severely burned. Other awards included: _For criticism, Allan Temko of the San Francisco Chronicle. ``Did I win?'' said the architecture critic. ``Is it true? How extraordinary. I've always been a bridesmaid.'' _For editorial writing, Thomas J. Hylton of The Mercury of Pottstown, Pa., who wrote editorials about a local bond issue for the preservation of farmland and other open space in rural Pennsylvania. _For editorial cartooning, Tom Toles of The Buffalo (N.Y.) News.
Following is a list of non-winning finalists for the 1990 Pulitzer Prizes in journalism. Pulitzer juries make up to three recommendations in each category without listing them in order of preference. The Pulitzer board, which awards the prizes, is not limited to these recommendations in choosing a winner. Public service _ Atlanta Journal and Constitution, for stories by Jane O. Hansen about abuses in Georgia child welfare system; The Tennessean, Nashville, for investigation by Phil Williams and Jim O'Hara of corruption in charity bingo. General news reporting _ The State, Columbia, S.C., staff, Hurricane Hugo; Roanoke (Va.) Times & World-News staff, mine workers strike. Investigative reporting _ Lexington (Ky.) Herald-Leader staff, effect of political abuses on public schools; Olive Talley, Dallas Morning News, health care in federal prisons. Explanatory journalism _ Dallas Morning News staff, ``hidden'' wars around the world; Times-Advocate of Escondido, Calif., staff, shooting spree by a mail carrier; Eric Nalder, The Seattle Times, oil-tanker safety. Specialized reporting _ Jim Dwyer, New York Newsday, New York subway system; Claire Spiegel, Los Angeles Times, investigation of a Los Angeles medical center. National reporting _ Charles R. Babcock, The Washington Post, congressional abuses of power; Gilbert M. Gaul, The Philadelphia Inquirer, operation of blood industry (winner in public service). International reporting _ David Remnick, The Washington Post, changes in Soviet Union and Communist bloc; Serge Schmemann, The New York Times, upheavals in Germany and Eastern Europe. Feature writing _ Jay Reed, The Milwaukee Journal, return to Vietnam; Mark Kriegel, New York Daily News, basketball in city playgrounds. Commentary _ Richard Cohen, The Washington Post, national columns; Walter Goodman, The New York Times, television. Criticism _ Jory Farr, The Press-Enterprise of Riverside, Calif., pop music; Wayne Lee Gay, Fort Worth Star-Telegram, piano competition coverage. Editorial writing _ David C. Anderson, The New York Times, drugs and the homeless; Leonard Morris, The News-Sentinel of Fort Wayne, Ind., abortion. Editorial cartooning _ Chan Lowe, Fort Lauderdale (Fla.) News-Sun-Sentinel; Jim Morin, The Miami Herald; Garry Trudeau, Universal Press Syndicate. Spot news photography _ The Associated Press, mob at Khomeini's bier; Jeff Widener, The Associated Press, man blocking tanks in Beijing; David C. Turnley, Detroit Free Press, uprisings in China and Eastern Europe (winner of feature photography). Feature photography _ Stormi Greener, Star Tribune, Minneapolis-St. Paul, mother struggles to resist child abuse; Robert Hallinen, Erik Hill and Paul Souders, Anchorage Daily News, Exxon Valdez oil spill; John Tlumacki, The Boston Globe, celebration at collapsed Berlin Wall.

DOC.HEAD: 11th World Media Conference Held in Moscow
DOC.TEXT: Participants in an international media conference said April 10 that new communications technology and Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev's reforms have combined to open up the East bloc to the rest of the world. But at least one Western journalist taking part in the 11th World Media Conference expressed concern over the closing of Lithuania and other restive Soviet republics to foreign reporters. The conference, meeting for the first time in Moscow, held a three-day symposium to discuss the impact of political changes in the Soviet Union on international communications. About 500 delegates from 60 countries, including many former heads of state, attended the meeting of the association, which was founded by the Rev. Sun Myung Moon to encourage East-West communications. Allen H. Neuharth, retired chairman of Gannett Co. Inc., told an afternoon panel discussion that advanced satellite communications and publishing technology have opened a new window on the world. He said people around the world were able to watch the events unfolding in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe on television and read about them almost immediately in newspapers. Andrei Grachev, deputy director of the Communist Party Central Committee's International Affairs Department, agreed. ``The 20th century began as an age of electronics, and is ending as the age of communications,'' Grachev said. ``We are living in an age where secrets cannot be kept,'' he said, citing the example of foreign scientists who detected the 1986 Chernobyl nuclear disaster, and satellite intelligence on the location of nuclear missile sites. Most panelists agreed that Gorbachev's policies of perestroika and glasnost helped create the conditions for radical change in the East bloc and the speedy reporting of events in East bloc nations. However, Jim Laurie, Moscow bureau chief for ABC News, noted that in cases of unrest, several republics had been closed to foreign reporters. Recently, Western journalists were ordered out of Lithuania after the republic declared its independence. The absence of foreign journalists could lead to partisan manipulation of the media by means of circulating stories that could not be independently checked, Laurie said. Among the delegates attending the conference were Arthur A. Hartman, former U.S. ambassador to Moscow; Joseph Luns, former NATO secretary-general; Raul Alfonsin, former president of Argentina; Alfonso Michelsen, former president of Colombia; and Jihan Sadat, widow of Egyptian President Anwar Sadat. Representatives from the Soviet Union included Andrei Grachev, deputy director of International Affairs; Vadim Zagladin, adviser to Gorbachev; economist Abel Aganbegyan; Nikolai Vorontsov, chairman of the State Committee for Protection of the Environment; and Ivan Ivanov, deputy chairman of the International Economic Commission. Media representatives included Allen H. Neuharth, founder of USA Today; Bo Hi Pak, publisher of The Washington Times and president of the World Media Association; and Arnaud de Borchgrave, editor-in-chief of The Washington Times.
DOC.HEAD: Bush's Broccoli Ban Well Known to Public, Survey Finds
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's distaste for broccoli has received nearly six times as much public attention as Earth Day, according to a surve of people's attentiveness to the news. The Times Mirror Center for The People and The Press said April 11 that its interviewers asked 1,212 people age 18 and older what vegetable it is that Bush recently said he wouldn't eat. Seventy-six percent said broccoli, the right answer. Four percent named some other vegetable. The rest refused to answer or said they didn't know. By contrast, 13 percent knew that April 22 is being observed as Earth Day to honor the environment. Fifteen percent gave a wrong answer and 72 percent said they didn't know when asked what was special about the date. The survey also found, for the fifth month in a row, that Americans paid more attention to foreign news than domestic news. The organization listed 18 news stories and asked people which was the most important. Forty percent cited an international story, with 21 percent naming Lithuanian independence. Also mentioned were other political developments in the Soviet Union, Germany and elsewhere in Eastern and Central Europe. Two percent named the release of black leader Nelson Mandela from a South African prison. Four percent mentioned domestic stories, including oil spills, the NCAA basketball playoffs, the death of 87 people in a fire at a social club in New York and the attempt in Idaho to pass a bill that would severely restrict abortions. Ten percent named stories not on the list, 43 percent said they didn't know and 2 percent refused to answer. This adds up to only 99 percent because the percentages were rounded to the nearest full number. The survey results are based on telephone interviews conducted under the direction of Princeton Survey Research Associates from April 5-8, with the 1,212 respondents interviewed by The Gallup Organization. The results are subject to a sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points. The Times Mirror Center for The People and The Press is an arm of Times Mirror Corp., which owns the Los Angeles Times and other publishing and broadcasting enterprises.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Hearst President Warns Against Recyling Laws
DOC.TEXT: Laws mandating the use of recycled newsprint will slow progress toward recycling rather than speed it up, the president and chief executive of The Hearst Corp. said April 11. Frank Bennack Jr., who is chairman of an American Newspaper Publishers Association task force on recycling, said such laws could cause the severe disruption of the newspaper and newsprint production industries. ``Society cannot legislate solutions to what are basically economic problems,'' he said. ``Only a free market can produce solutions to economic problems that are effective and efficient.'' Bennack received the Rochester Institute of Technology's Isaiah Thomas Award for outstanding contributions to the newspaper publishing industry. About 35 percent of all used newsprint is recycled, Bennack said. ``There is obviously much room for improvement in those statistics,'' he said. ``And there is agreement that it can and will be done.'' But Bennack said the conversion must be voluntary. There is a shortage of recycled newsprint because most paper mills are not equipped to handle recycling, Bennack said. Laws mandating recycling, such as those in California and Connecticut, could cause imbalances and shortages in other parts of the country, he said. Bennack said he also opposes such regulations in principle because ``regulated newsprint is typical of a non-democratic society.'' Instead, Bennack said there should be more voluntary agreements by publishers to increase their use of recycled newsprint. He called for efforts by the states to make used newsprint available and encourage the construction of recycling plants.
DOC.HEAD: Journalist Charged With Computer Hacking
DOC.TEXT: A freelance journalist pleaded innocent April 6 to charges that he used a computer in an effort to steal information from a TV tabloid show. Stuart Goldman, 44, was charged with seven felony counts of violating a California Penal Code section prohibiting unauthorized access to computers. Goldman allegedly used another person's access code to enter a computer used by the Fox Television show ``A Current Affair'' at the network's Hollywood television station, KTTV, said Sandi Gibbons, spokeswoman for the district attorney's office. Information was allegedly taken out of the computer through a telephone connection and stored in Goldman's home computer. Last month, federal prosecutors filed an affidavit in U.S. District Court in New York stating that the reporter had tried to gain access to computer files concerning news stories that Fox reporters were working on. Prosecutors dropped the New York case without comment. Goldman briefly worked for ``A Current Affair'' as well as ``Hard Copy,'' a competitor's show. He has written articles for National Review magazine, the Los Angeles Times and other publications. If convicted of all the state charges, Goldman could be sentenced to a maximum of six years in prison.
DOC.HEAD: Paper Says Its Meeting May Have Violated State Sunshine Law
DOC.TEXT: The Bradenton Herald reported that a meeting between representatives of the paper and four city council members April 9 to discuss newspaper rack regulations may have violated the state's open government law. The council members met with Herald Publisher Dorothy Ridings and four other employees at the newspaper's offices at the Herald's invitation. The meeting was called to discuss how area newspapers could address the council's concerns about newspaper rack placement and appearance, said General Manager Robert Turner, one of those present. In December, Herald representatives requested that the council delay voting on an ordinance regulating newspaper racks. City officials gave the newspaper three months to come up with possible alternatives to the proposed ordinance. Florida's Sunshine Law prohibits public officials from conducting business in private meetings. The state's courts have held that the law applies to any gathering of two or more members of the same board, and that it is applicable when board members are discussing any matter on which action might be taken. Ridings said she did not realize at the time that the meeting might have violated the law. ``If anyone should have realized it, I should have,'' she said. ``All I can do is apologize to the public and our colleagues for putting us and them in an embarrassing situation.'' Council members said they thought the media had been invited to the session, and that there was no intent to break the law.
DOC.HEAD: McDonald's Warns Papers Against Critical Ad
DOC.TEXT: Attorneys for McDonald's Corp. have written letters to newspapers advising them not to publish advertisements from an anti-cholesterol crusader who launched a national campaign earlier this month. Phil Sokolof placed ads in newspapers April 4 asking McDonald's to lower the amount of saturated fat on its menu. The ads, headlined ``The Poisoning of America!'' included a plea to McDonald's to cut the fat in their hamburgers by 10 percent. McDonald's attorney Joseph Califano said April 13 the ad was inaccurate and that newspapers did not check the facts. ``Now they know the facts, now they are all on notice. ... To publish anything like that ad would be a malicious act,'' said Califano, secretary of the department of Health, Education and Welfare in the Carter administration. Sokolof said McDonald's was putting up a ``smokescreen'' and that the ad was a public service. ``McDonald's has chosen to try and intimidate the nation's leading newspapers,'' said Sokolof, who blames a bad diet for a heart attack he suffered years ago. He would not rule out placing more ads in the future. McDonald's spokesman Chuck Ebeling said the ad overstated the saturated fat content of McDonald's products, including an assertion that McDonald's precooked hamburger meat is 21.5 percent fat. ``In reality, the fat content before cooking is 17 to 20 percent fat and is typically 19.5 percent fat,'' Ebeling said. An official of a Washington, D.C.-based consumer advocacy group, the Center for Science in the Public Interest, said either way the saturated fat levels in fast food are too high. ``To me, the important part is that the general thrust of the ad was correct,'' said nutrition director Bonnie Liebman. ``Many of the foods served at McDonald's are loaded with saturated fat and cholesterol and eating less would reduce heart disease _ the nation's largest killer.''
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Reporter Called as Defense Witness in Murder Trial
DOC.TEXT: A newspaper reporter testified April 9 as a defense witness in the murder trial of a prison inmate who claims he was insane when his former wife was beaten to death in 1989. Marti Goodlad Heline, the courts reporter covering the trial for the South Bend Tribune, had been subpoenaed as a prosecution witness. The prosecution rested its case without calling her. Alan L. Matheney is charged with murder and burglary in the March 4, 1989, slaying of Lisa Marie Bianco. Defense attorney Scott L. King called Heline to testify about two interviews she conducted with Matheney and three stories based on the interviews, published in March and June 1989. Under King's questioning, Heline said Matheney told her he went to Ms. Bianco's home to retrieve audio tapes recorded by Ms. Bianco. ``He believedt a ring of physicians performed unnecessary surgery on elderly patients for profit. In the series, reporter Ed Gonzalez said Srivastava lost his privileges to practice at Santa Rosa Hospital and the Baptist Memorial Hospital System amid claims of unnecessary surgery. The doctor contended the series ruined his San Antonio practice. His malpractice insurance skyrocketed and he was forced to move to Midland, where he now practices at a loss, said his lawyer, James Branton. KENS-TV President and General Manager Michael J. Conly said the station was surprised at the verdict. ``At the same time, we know media companies frequently lose verdicts at the jury level, for whatever reasons, but then win on appeal because the law recognizes the crucial role the media plays in educating the public and protecting our democratic institutions,'' Conly said. The news series included interviews with family members of some of Srivastava's patients and documentation of the suspensions. KENS-TV stood behind the broadcast as good journalism on a subject of great public concern. The station's attorney, Mark Cannan, argued that the medical community already knew of Srivastava's hospital suspensions and, therefore, the doctor's reputation was damaged before the first KENS-TV story aired. He noted the suspensions also were reported in the San Antonio Express-News the morning before the first broadcast. Cannan said the series ran over a period of several days and Srivastava had an open invitation to appear. The jury found that the reports as a whole were false and ruined the doctor's reputation. The panel also said the television station knew the stories were false and acted with ``reckless disregard for the truth.''
DOC.HEAD: 5 Felony Charges, 3 Misdemeanors Filed Against Hunter S. Thompson
DOC.TEXT: Hunter S. Thompson, the dean of ``gonzo journalism,'' was charged April 9 with possessing blasting caps and various drugs police found after a former porn actress accused the writer of molesting her in his home. Thompson, 52, pleaded innocent to three misdemeanors: third-degree sexual assault, third-degree simple assault and possession of marijuana. Those charges were based on allegations by Gail Palmer-Slater, star of ``The Erotic Adventures of Candy,'' that Thompson threw a drink at her, twisted her breast and shoved her during a visit at his home Feb. 21. Her allegations led to a police search of Thompson's home Feb. 26 and 27. Police said they seized blasting caps and substances they allege to be LSD, cocaine, the tranquilizer Diazepam and marijuana. An April 23 hearing was set on five felony charges: three counts of possession of a controlled substance, one charge of using cocaine and one charge of unlawful possession of incendiary devices. Palmer-Slater, who lives in Port Huron, Mich., said she went to Thompson's home in Woody Creek to discuss a business enterprise, and claimed he became angry when she refused to conduct the discussion in his hot tub. Thompson says he never assaulted the woman. He told reporters Palmer-Slater was drunk and was pressuring him to have sex with her when he pushed her away. Thompson remains free on $2,000 bond. Deputy District Attorney Charles McCrory said Thompson could receive a maximum of 16 years in prison if convicted of all eight charges against him. Thompson is the author of several books written in a style that has come to be known as gonzo journalism, intermingling a description of real events with exaggerated accounts of his own involvement, which often include drug and alcohol abuse. Thompson ran a full-page advertisement April 9 in the Aspen Times Daily that read: ``BEWARE. Today: the Doctor. Tomorrow: You.'' The ad was paid for by the ``Hunter S. Thompson Legal Defense Fund.'' Thompson's books include ``Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas,'' ``Fear and Loathing on the Campaign Trail,'' ``The Great Shark Hunt'' and ``Generation of Swine,'' a compilation of some of his newspaper and magazine columns.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: British Journalist Freed by Liberian Guerrillas
DOC.TEXT: Liberian rebels freed a kidnapped British journalist April 11 and returned him to this neighboring West African nation. Mark Huband, a correspondent for United Press International and the London Financial Times, was taken hostage April 6 by the guerrillas, who seek to overthrow Liberian President Samuel Doe. He was seized during an ambush of a freight train that he was riding on in Liberia's eastern Nimba County, where the insurgents invaded in December. Speaking from his home in Abidjan, Huband said the insurgents contacted British Embassy officials and arranged for them to meet him at the Ivorian-Liberian border on Wednesday. Huband said he had not been mistreated during the four days with the guerrillas in Nimba County.
DOC.HEAD: Poland Formally Votes to End Censorship
DOC.TEXT: Poland's lawmakers on April 11 formally ended censorship, one of the final relics of four decades of Communist rule. The decision, by a 266-0 vote with eight abstentions, was largely symbolic. Censorship has been almost non-existent since the Solidarity-led government of Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki was voted in to power last fall. Solidarity deputy Juliusz Braun said censorship had actually ``allowed slandering with impunity'' without permitting a person to defend himself. The censorship law allowed the former Communist authorities to control all kinds of publications and stage and film performances, preventing criticism of the political system. Many Poles turned to underground printing, which flourished through the 1980s. Solidarity, the East bloc's first independent trade union, fought for elimination of censorship since its foundation in 1980.
DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders News Organizations to Turn Over Film of Tax Riot
DOC.TEXT: A judge on April 6 ordered 25 newspapers and television stations to give police all film and photographs of a March 31 anti-tax riot in London. A dozen organizations immediately opposed the order, two said they were willing to hand over what they published and the remaining 11 neither opposed nor consented. Judge Neil Denison issued the order after a day of legal argument, ruling the film would help police and that it was in ``the overriding public interest.'' However, he said in other cases the public interest may be better served by allowing the news media to report events freely and each case should be decided on its merits. ``It is right, as has been argued, that the court should not automatically or routinely grant such orders,'' Denison said. ``It should not be seen to be rubber-stamping such applications.'' The news organizations reacted angrily. ``If we are seen to be a potential arm of the state, journalists are going to be targets of the rioters,'' said TV-am news director Jeff Berliner. Geoffrey Shaw, lawyer for the BBC and TV-am, argued there had been 2,750 police officers at the poll tax demonstration. ``They should not require the media to be their eyes and ears. If they want film, it is reasonable to expect them to take it themselves,'' Shaw said. The riot broke out after 40,000 had gathered for a peaceful demonstration to protest the new poll tax by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's government.
DOC.HEAD: Two New England Journalists To Take Part in Soviet Exchange
DOC.TEXT: Two New England journalists will spend two months this summer working in the Soviet Union, taking part in an exchange between the two nations. Susan Milton, a reporter for the Cape Cod Times, and Mary Murphy, a photographer for The Providence Journal, were selected by a panel of New England editors to work on Soviet publications for two months. Milton, who earned an undergraduate degree in Russian language and English literature from Washington University in St. Louis, will work for Moscow Pravda newspaper. Murphy, who traveled to the Soviet Union five years ago under the sponsorship of the Citizens Exchange Council, will be assigned to The Soviet Union, a monthly magazine published in several languages. The agreement between the New England Society of Newspaper Editors and the Union of Soviet Journalists is in its third year. It calls for two Soviet journalists to work on New England newspapers later in the year.
DOC.HEAD: Religious Institute to Defend Fired Journalists
DOC.TEXT: A religious defense group said April 13 it would help file a discrimination complaint on behalf of two newspaper editors fired for refusing to quit as leaders of an anti-abortion group. The Rutherford Institute said its staff attorneys would help John Kennedy and Terri Lambertsen pursue the religious discrimination complaint with the federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. The announcement of assistance came as dozens of protesters, some carrying pictures of aborted fetuses, picketed the offices of The Fairfield Ledger, where Kennedy was news editor and Ms. Lambertson was People Page editor. The journalists were fired April 9 because they refused to give up their posts with the newly formed Southeast Iowa Pro-Lifers. Ms. Lambertsen is president and Kennedy is secretary. The paper said they were violating a policy against being active in groups that receive news coverage. Kennedy and Ms. Lambertsen have complained that their constitutional rights to free speech and religious freedom were violated.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Tribune To End `USA Tonight' Under Deal With Turner Broadcasting
DOC.TEXT: Tribune Broadcasting Co. will discontinue its ``USA Tonight'' national newscast and use Cable News Network to expand local newscasts in six markets under an agreement announced April 9 with Turner Broadcasting System Inc. The 10-year deal, announced by TBS Chairman Ted Turner and Tribune President James C. Dowdle, also includes joint production of news, documentary specials and entertainment programs. As part of the agreement, Tribune will end ``USA Tonight'' and its IDNX news service. Six Tribune stations will become affiliates of Cable News Network, subscribing to CNN coverage on a non-exclusive basis. Those stations are WPIX in New York, KTLA in Los Angeles, WGN in Chicago, WGNX in Atlanta, KWGN in Denver and WGNO in New Orleans. The stations will use the CNN coverage to expand their evening newscasts to one hour this summer, Tribune officials said in a statement. ``USA Tonight'' and IDNX will be discontinued in June, Dowdle said.
DOC.HEAD: Ban Against Siskel and Ebert Lifted
DOC.TEXT: Twentieth Century Fox lifted its ban April 9 against critics Roger Ebert and Gene Siskel, who gave harsh reviews of a recent Fox film. The studio said three weeks earlier that they would be barred indefinitely from preview screenings after both critics said on a television talk show that the comedy ``Nuns on the Run'' wasn't funny. Siskel called Fox April 9 shortly before the screening of another Fox film _ the first in Chicago since ``Nuns on the Run'' _ and asked if he was still unwelcome. The ban was over, a company spokesman said, and Siskel went to the show. Ebert didn't know about the lifting of the ban and was out of town. ``I'm happy the ban is lifted,'' Ebert said. ``I feel vindicated. In the future I will continue to review Fox films in the same evenhanded way I have in the past.'' The two appear on ``At the Movies,'' a syndicated half-hour television show.
DOC.HEAD: Man Who Threatened TV Anchor Gets Three-Year Prison Term
DOC.TEXT: A man convicted of threatening to kill television anchorwoman Kelly Lange was sentenced April 9 to the maximum of three years in prison. Warren Sevy Hudson, a 57-year-old unemployed laborer described as an obsessive fan of Ms. Lange's, was convicted Dec. 5 on one count of making a terrorist threat. Hudson, who had sent the KNBC-TV anchorwoman flowers, jewelry and a fur coat since 1985, threatened in a postcard to Ms. Lange to shoot her, prosecutors said. Ms. Lange testified in Hudson's trial the postcard read ``something to the effect that, `I'm going to blow your head off in the parking lot some night and you're never going to know what hit you.''' When Hudson was arrested at the Linda Motel in August 1989, police recovered a .38-caliber handgun and ammunition. Superior Court Judge J.D. Smith gave Hudson the maximum sentence under the law, but Hudson will serve less than two years because he has already been in jail for the equivalent of one year since his arrest.
DOC.HEAD: Citing Motherhood and Travel, Maria Shriver Quits ``Sunday Today.''
DOC.TEXT: NBC's Maria Shriver, citing her new baby and a weekly commute from Los Angeles, announced April 8 she no longer will anchor Saturday's ``NBC Nightly News'' and co-anchor ``Sunday Today.'' Shriver, who gave birth to a daughter in December, said she will stay with NBC News. Under her arrangement with the network, she lived with her husband, actor Arnold Schwarzenegger, in Los Angeles and commuted each week for Saturday's evening news in New York, ``Sunday Today'' in Washington with Garrick Utley, and occasional specials.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.TEXT: Humorist-folklorist John Henry Faulk, who faced blacklisting head-on with a lawsuit in the 1950s and became a champion of civil rights, died April 9 after a long bout with cancer. He was 76. Faulk was a popular CBS radio and television personality when, in 1957, he mounted a six-year legal battle in a New York court against AWARE Inc., a group that accused him of having subversive associations. Faulk sued AWARE, saying the group had libeled him and destroyed his career. He won the lawsuit and was awarded $3.5 million, but the judgment was later reduced to $725,000 on appeal. He recounted the struggle in a best-selling book, ``Fear on Trial.'' The book was made into a made-for-TV movie that was broadcast on CBS in 1975. Faulk is survived by a wife and son.

Cove Hoover, former publisher of newspapers in New York, Illinois and Pennsylvania, died April 13. He was 67. Hoover's newspaper career started in the Boston area at the Patriot-Ledger. He joined the former Elmira Advertiser in October 1950 and became managing editor of its sister paper, the Elmira Star-Gazette, seven years later. He was named general manager in 1965 and was promoted to publisher two years later. Gannett Co. Inc., which owns the Star-Gazette, transferred Hoover in 1972 to Rockford, Ill., where he became publisher of the Rockford Morning Star, the Register-Republic and the Sunday Register-Star. Hoover left Gannett in 1975 and became editor and publisher of the Delaware County Daily Times in Chester, Pa. He retired a year later and had been in poor health. Survivors include his wife, Barbara; two sons and a stepson, two daughters and 10 grandchildren.

Patrick D. Horan Jr., picture editor of The Milwaukee Journal since 1976, died April 9 at Waukesha Memorial Hospital, a day after suffering heart failure at his home. He was 52. Horan joined the newspaper's picture desk staff in 1967. After graduation from college, he worked as an assistant news editor for WISN radio and television in Milwaukee and as an educational television photographer for the Milwaukee Public Schools. From 1961-67, he taught reporting, editing, photography, broadcast programming and English at Marquette. Survivors include his wife, Barbara, two sons, a daughter and a sister.

Lloyd G. Larson, former sports editor of the Milwaukee Sentinel, died April 14 at his home after a long illness. He was 87. Larson served as Sentinel sports editor for 27 years before he retired in 1974. A Milwaukee native, he started his newspaper career at the age of 12 when he worked as a high school correspondent for the former Wisconsin Evening News. He was named Wisconsin sports writer of the year five times in a 57-career that included 33 years with the Sentinel. Survivors include his wife, Alice, and a daughter.

Ernest F. Lyons, a former editor of The Stuart News who retired after 44 years with the newspaper, died at his home April 6 after suffering from cancer. He was 85. Lyons, a champion of conservation causes, wrote two books about early days on the St. Lucie River, ``My Florida'' and ``The Last Cracker Barrel.'' ``He was a country editor,'' said Thomas E. Weber Jr., who was hired as an intern by Lyons in 1966 and who succeeded him as editor in 1975. ``He was straight out of central casting. He liked suspenders, he always wore white shirts. He had an earthy type of approach.'' Lyons is survived by a sister, a son and daughter, six grandchildren and three great-grandchildren.

Al Nakkula, a 46-year Rocky Mountain News police reporter known for his aggressive style, died April 11 at age 68. Nakkula started as a copy boy at the News in August 1944. He was credited with breaking a Denver police burglary scandal in 1960, which led to the arrest of 51 police officers and the reorganization of the department. Nakkula also covered the kidnapping and murder of Adolph Coors III in 1960, and the case of John Gilbert Graham of Denver, who was convicted of blowing up a United Airlines plane in November 1955. Nakkula is survived by his wife, Charlotte.

Alma Sioux Scarberry, a reporter and writer whose career spanned more than seven decades and included interviews with Charles Lindbergh, Babe Ruth and Jack Dempsey, died April 10 of a stroke at a San Antonio nursing home. She was 90. She got her start in reporting in 1919 at the Elmira (N.Y.) Advertiser. She also worked for the New York Mirror, Pittsburgh Sun-Telegraph, Washington Times Herald and King Features. Ms. Scarberry wrote 21 novels, including ``Thou Shalt Not Love,'' ``The Flat Tire'' and ``Dimpled Racketeer.'' She is survived by a son and four grandchildren.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Florida Newspaper Wins Kennedy Journalism Grand Prize
DOC.TEXT: The Fort Myers (Fla.) News-Press won the Robert F. Kennedy Journalism Awards' $2,000 grand prize April 9 for ``Far From the Dream,'' a 12-part series on the problems of blacks in southwestern Florida. The News-Press, which also received a $1,000 first prize for print journalism, was honored for its articles last year on housing, education, economics, politics and other problems affecting poor blacks. The awards committee said that as a result of the series, the Lee County, Fla., school board took steps to hire more minority teachers, the county director of public housing was suspended, and the Justice Department and the NAACP Legal Defense Fund requested a study of the county's desegregation policy of busing only black children. The News-Press will receive its awards at a May 14 reception at the suburban Virginia home of Ethel Kennedy, widow of the former New York senator who was assassinated during his 1968 presidential campaign. The awards, sponsored by the Robert F. Kennedy Memorial, are given for outstanding coverage of the problems of disadvantaged Americans. The first-prize winner in television was a team from WGBH, the Boston public TV station, for ``The AIDS Quarterly With Peter Jennings: Winter 1989.'' National Public Radio won a first prize for ``Young Black Men: Lost Generation?'' and Stormi Greener of the Minneapolis Star Tribune was awarded first prize in photojournalism. Paul Conrad of the Los Angeles Times won first prize for cartoons. T. Jeff Rutherford of the University of Illinois won the student first prize for a series on Medicare. International awards went to CBS' ``60 Minutes,'' Sandy Tolan and Jerry Kammer of The Arizona Republic in Phoenix, and Bruce Chambers of the Press-Telegram in Long Beach, Calif.
DOC.HEAD: Denver Journalist Receives Miller Award
DOC.TEXT: Jean Otto, associate editor of the Rocky Mountain News in Denver, has become the third recipient of the Paul Miller Medallion at Oklahoma State University. The award was presented April 12 in conjunction with the Paul Miller lecture series recognizing prominent journalists. The lecture series was established three years ago by Miller and his wife, Louise. Miller, an Oklahoma State graduate, was chairman of the board of The Associated Press and served 16 years as president and chief executive officer of Gannett Co. Inc. He retired in 1978. Ms. Otto was to give the keynote address for the Oklahoma Collegiate Press Association, which was meeting on the Oklahoma State campus. ``Jean Otto has long had a grave concern for freedom of the press and the free flow of information,'' said Marlan Nelson, director of the School of Journalism and Broadcasting. ``She was the founder of the First Amendment Congress, which according to its statement of purpose is committed to making all Americans aware of the importance of their First Amendment freedoms in our democratic society.''
DOC.HEAD: Pa. Newspaper Awards Announced
DOC.TEXT: Pittsburgh Press staff writer Douglas Heuck has won the fifth annual Pennsylvania Distinguished Writing Award in the Keystone Press Awards contest, the Pennsylvania Society of Newspaper Editors announced April 12. Heuck, who won the award for the second year in a row, was honored for his series on AIDS patients, ``A Rose Wilting Is Still A Rose.'' The annual Keystone Press Awards recognize outstanding newspaper writing, photographery and design.

ABC News correspondent Carole Simpson, who is black, says she still suffers the nightmares that began after she was assaulted by a South African police officer while covering a disturbance in Johannesburg. ``I still dream about police and violence,'' she says. ``I don't necessarily relive what happened to me, but they're scary nightmares and I wake up in a panic'' ... Spending for newspaper advertising totaled $32.37 billion last year, up 3.8 percent from 1988, according to preliminary estimates from the Newspaper Advertising Bureau published in The New York Times. The increase was smaller than in 1988, when spending rose 6 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Pulitzer Board Members Named
DOC.TEXT: Robert Christopher, former editor at Time and Newsweek magazines and professor of journalism at Columbia University, was re-elected secretary of the 1990-91 Pulitzer Prize Board, Columbia University announced. The board's chairman remains Eugene L. Roberts Jr., executive editor and president of The Philadelphia Inquirer. The 1990-91 board will decide next year's winners. The other members are: Columbia University President Michael Sovern; Joan Konner, dean of the Graduate School of Journalism at Columbia; Russell Baker, columnist, The New York Times; Sissela Bok, professor, Brandeis University; Michael Gartner, president, NBC News, and editor of The Daily Tribune, Ames, Iowa; Meg Greenfield, editorial page editor, The Washington Post; James F. Hoge Jr., publisher, New York Daily News; Peter R. Kann, publisher of The Wall Street Journal; David A. Laventhol, president, Times Mirror Co., and publisher and chief executive officer, Los Angeles Times. Also, Robert C. Maynard, editor and publisher, The Tribune, Oakland, Calif.; Burl Osborne, president and editor, The Dallas Morning News; Geneva Overholser, editor, The Des Moines (Iowa) Register; James V. Risser, director, John S. Knight Fellowships, Stanford University; Walter Rugaber, president and publisher of the Roanoke (Va.) Times & World-News; Charlotte Saikowski, former chief of The Christian Science Monitor's Washington bureau; Claude F. Sitton, editor and vice president, The News & Observer, Raleigh, N.C.
DOC.HEAD: Rowley, Heintz, in New Scripps League Posts
DOC.TEXT: Don Rowley is the new publisher of The Arizona Daily Sun, succeeding Richard Heintz, who was named publisher of The Napa Register in California, Scripps League Newspapers announced April 11. Rowley previously was advertising manager of The Daily Herald in Provo, Utah.
DOC.HEAD: Moreno Named Santa Fe Correspondent
DOC.TEXT: Edward H. Moreno, a newsman in the Santa Fe bureau of The Associated Press, was named correspondent in charge of the bureau on April 9. The appointment was announced by Albuquerque Chief of Bureau Mark Mittelstadt. Moreno succeeds J.W. (Bill) Feather, who is retiring after 32 years with the AP. Moreno, 36, joined the AP in Santa Fe in 1983 after working for newspapers in three states. He is a native of Mexico City and a graduate of the University of Northern Colorado. Moreno began his journalism career on a Colorado weekly and later worked for the Scottsbluff, Neb., Star Herald and The New Mexican of Santa Fe.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.TEXT: Internal Revenue Service Form 4868 is one of the most-sought pieces of paper in the nation today as an estimated 6 million Americans abandon hopes of meeting the midnight deadline for filing a federal tax return. Filing a Form 4868, along with a check for estimated taxes owed, automatically extends the return deadline to Aug. 15. IRS offices and Postal Service branches in many parts of the country planned extra hours today to accommodate those who put off the inevitable. The IRS did not estimate how many couples and individuals were waiting until the last minute to file. But the agency predicted that about 34 million returns _ more than 30 percent of the 111 million expected this year _ would be filed April 7 or later.

The Kremlin's deadline for cutting off crucial supplies passed with Lithuania's leaders ignoring Mikhail S. Gorbachev's plea to repeal laws implementing their independence decree. The Baltic republic's deputy prime minister, Romualdas Ozolas, went on Lithuanian television Sunday night as the 48-hour deadline expired. He said the republic's president, Vytautas Landsbergis, and prime minister, Kazimiera Prunskiene, would discuss Moscow's ultimatum today. The council of ministers and parliamentary leadership also were expected to convene. Landsbergis has repeatedly said Lithuania would not abandon its drive to restore the independence lost when, with fellow Baltic states Latvia and Estonia, it was forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940.

Greta Garbo, the husky-voiced, Swedish-born screen legend who turned her back on Hollywood in 1941 to live according to her best-remembered line _ ``I vant to be alone'' _ is dead at 84. The reclusive Garbo died Sunday, said Andrew Banoff, spokesman for New York Hospital. At her family's request, Banoff gave no other information except that donations should be made to a kidney treatment center at the hospital. Ben Buttenweiser, who lived in an apartment below Garbo's, said the actress had undergone dialysis treatment. With her sculpted beauty, Garbo first gained attention in silent films. When talkies came along, Hollywood worried that her accent and throaty voice would end her career, but they only enhanced her appeal, and she became an international sensation with such films as ``Anna Christie,'' ``Mata Hari,'' ``Grand Hotel'' and ``Queen Christina.''

President Bush will ask a 17-nation conference this week to examine the economic impact of global warming, but the administration plans to argue it's too early to propose specific measures to deal with the problem, officials say. The White House's cautious approach in developing responses to global warming is expected to unleash renewed criticism from some European countries that the United States is failing to provide leadership in dealing with the so-called ``greenhouse'' effect. The Bush administration has maintained that while there is widespread agreement that man-made pollutants are causing the earth to become warmer, there remain too many unanswered questions to warrant pollution controls that could have widespread economic implications. The president is hosting a White House conference on the greenhouse effect on Tuesday, just days before next Sunday's Earth Day observance. During his 1988 campaign, Bush said such a conference was a top priority and would be held in his first year as president.

``Nigger Creek'' and ``Dead Negro Draw'' should be wiped off the Texas map, says an NAACP official working to replace those and other racially offensive place names with expressions of black pride. Gary Bledsoe, NAACP Austin chapter president, said he resolved to eliminate slurs from the map during an outing two years ago, when he ran across ``Nigger Creek'' and ``Niggerhead Hill'' within an hour's drive of the Capitol. ``I couldn't believe what I saw and how totally offensive that was,'' he said recently. Many Texas locations were tagged with such names because blacks lived there at some point. Bledsoe is looking to rename 33 places.
