DOC.TEXT: As long as two football fields end-to-end, it's the world's largest sailing ship now in service. The recently launched Club Med I will sail the Caribbean in the winter and the Mediterranean in the summer with a cargo of mostly young adults looking for fun and games. And don't worry if there is no wind. The sails are just boosters for its diesel engines.

When a sudden blow came up on the Spanish Main the other day, no bearded bosun bellowed, ``All hands aloft to bend canvas, reef and furl sail.'' The captain just pushed a button and the computer located behind the wheelhouse rolled up the seven enormous sails like window shades and in seconds set about controlling the list of the world's largest sailing ship now in service. ``I am in love with this ship; she maneuvers just like a fish,'' enthused Alain Lambert, captain of the recently launched Club Med I, presiding over a console of dials, scopes and screens. ``Even in the roughest seas, she just stays on the waves. On the passage from the Canaries to Cape Verde, during our maiden voyage in January, we had 40-knot winds and the computer reduced sail perfectly.'' As we headed toward the U.S. Virgin Islands, on one leg of a seven-day cruise out of Guadeloupe with 220 passengers on board, a weathered old schooner with dingy brown sails crossed our bow. The captain ``spoke'' her with a friendly blast on the foghorn. ``For me this is something glorious, a whole new life,'' he said, studying a yellow screen that in dancing graphics showed the sails receding on the five aluminum masts and the booms changing position. ``It's like going back a century to find a passenger ship that looks like a ship and not like a floating soapbox. Notice, wherever we go, they admire us.'' Sure enough, as we entered the harbor at Charlotte Amalie, a whole flotilla of yachts, fishing smacks, sightseeing craft, even a straying ferry, ventured near to ogle us, the way the South Sea Islanders circled Captain James Cook's HMS Endeavour in their outrigger canoes. At anchor, a huge stern ramp was lowered like a World War II landing craft to disgorge an armada of water-ski boats, windsurf boards, sailing sloops, several boatloads of scuba divers shouldering air tanks and a school of web-footed snorkelers. Dr. Jean-Yves Siriez, the ship's surgeon, led the diving party. The German second mate, Uwe Heidenreich, took leave of the bridge to join the water-skiers. Meanwhile, a long file of passengers, some in T-shirts proclaiming ``When The Going Gets Tough, The Tough Go Shopping,'' went down the long gangplank into the bobbing tenders for an assault on the duty free shops and posh restaurants of the U.S. Virgin Island capital. Is this a cruise ship, like dozens of others in Caribbean waters, offering the seagoing ambiance of shuffleboard, glitzy floor shows, bouillon at 11 on the sun deck and black-tie captain's dinners? Or is it a floating Club Med village, dedicated like the 110 others around the globe to macho sports, sumptuous buffet meals with wine, casual dress and lifestyles in an atmosphere of ebullient camaraderie? Some of both. Village veterans on their first cruise wondered whether Chef de Village Janyck Daudet outranked the captain in the reception line at the welcoming cocktail party. When the ship's program decreed ``elegant dress'' for dinner, some put their best foot forward in jogging sneakers. Cruise ship veterans, spoiled by big-name Las Vegas acts on other ships, were only moderately tolerant of the nightly amateur musicals staged by the exuberant staff in the superbly equipped theater. For Club Med addicts, the beachcomber fantasy was blurred a bit by using credit cards instead of beads to barter for drinks in the five bars. There was a bridge instructor on duty in the card room, but in deference to a younger, more active cruising clientele there were no shuffleboard, bingo or steeplechase races.

DOC.TEXT: During the winter season, the Club Med sails the Caribbean out of Guadeloupe. In the summer it will cruise the Mediterranean out of Ville Franche on the French Riviera. Designed by architect Francois Xavier Poylo and built in Le Havre, France, the $100 million ship is owned by three French banks and leased to Club Med and Service et Transport, a shipping firm, for seven years with an option to buy. At 617-feet, it is not the largest ship with sails in history. The Great Eastern, nearly a century and a half ago, was 60 feet longer, had propellers the size of windmills and stationed a bugler at the top of the companionway to summon her 4,000 passengers to dinner. A failure in the passenger trade, she found glory as a giant sea spider, spinning out the Atlantic cable. Second mate Heidenreich, a sailing buff, cites the cargo ship Thomas Lawson, plying the Maine coast at the turn of the century. ``She had seven masts, each named for a day of the week.'' This ship's top speed of 14 knots, with an assist from her four diesel-powered electric turbines, is sluggish compared with the great clipper ships like Cutty Sark and Flying Cloud, which fully rigged with 28 sails rushed Forty Niners around the Horn to the California gold rush at 20 knots. But her creature comforts are a far cry from what Club Med offered poor French students and vacationing secretaries at its first tent village on Majorca 40 years ago. Telephones, TV, hair dryers, mini-bars, king-sized beds and Matisse prints grace the 204 cabins decorated by Alberto Pinto, who did the Gucci offices in Milan and a royal yacht for Prince Kaled of Saudi Arabia. There are two dining salons, two outdoor pools, a casino, a beauty parlor, sauna and a duty-free boutique. Alas, the tradition of a ship's library has shrunk to a bookcase of paperbacks. With a draft of only 15 feet, this hi-tech windjammer can visit smaller islands and lonelier beaches. A boulder-strewn cove called ``The Baths'' on Virgin Gorda in the British Virgin Islands was scorned as ``too commercial'' because its pristine sands were interrupted by a beer tent and a stall selling T-shirts. On St. Thomas the beach was already occupied by a few thousand sailors from the U.S. aircraft carrier Enterprise enjoying their first shore leave in six months. The exotic combination of a new five-masted cruise ship anchored in the same harbor with a nuclear powered carrier begged the question of why this return to sail in the Atomic Age? The Japanese had experimented with sail-driven tankers during a world oil crisis in the '70s, and now, said Capt. Lambert, ``They want to buy our software.'' When Mikhail Gorbachev addressed the United Nations a year and a half ago, a Soviet trade fair in New York exhibited models of a new generation of freighters with auxiliary sails. Two other computerized sailing ships, about a third smaller, are already in the cruise trade and more are on the drawing board. ``This is not a romantic gimmick,'' insists Lambert. ``Under sail the ship is quieter, more comfortable for passengers. She rolls less. There is no vibration. With normal power we use 20 tons of marine diesel in 24 hours. Under full sail, with our four generators also going, we use 7 tons. If the wind is from the starboard, our computer directs the exhaust fumes off to port side. ``Even when there is very little wind, the sails give us an extra 2 knots speed, and every owner knows the last 2 knots are the most expensive.'' The great clipper ships required a crew of 130 to wrestle with acres of canvas. Stretching 2,990 square yards of Dacron, this latter-day descendant needs only 35 officers and seamen. ``Not counting our most versatile hand, the computer,'' adds the captain.

DOC.TEXT: The new head of the U.S. Border Patrol believes illegal aliens looking for work should be treated with compassion, even as they are turned back. But when it comes to drug runners and other criminals, Mike Williams is in favor of using the military to help seal the border. Some alien advocates disagree.

For almost a quarter century, Mike Williams has wrestled with the paradoxes of the nation's southwest boundary, an escape route for the destitute, the front line of the nation's war on drugs, yet a doorway for commerce. Williams, a Border Patrol agent who learned Spanish from the illegal aliens he turned away, is the agency's new chief. Williams was appointed in January to oversee the policing of some 5,960 miles along the U.S. borders with Canada and Mexico. It's a $263 million-a-year operation involving 3,800 Border Patrol agents in 22 districts. Williams says a good Border Patrol boss should know how to balance compassion for the illegal aliens looking for work in the United States with intolerance for the drug runners, auto thieves, alien smugglers and other sinister characters who defy the law. ``I think that we don't need to apologize because we want to control our borders,'' Williams said in a recent interview as he completed his move to Washington from El Paso. ``I think we need to recognize the sensitivity of the reasons why people come _ and we do _ but I don't think we need to say that we should not enforce laws.'' Williams also makes no apologies for controversial proposals to have the military help the Border Patrol fight illegal drug traffic. ``I feel it is morally right to try to prevent this plague that's attacking America,'' he says. Williams, a native of Gainesville, Fla., began his Border Patrol career in 1967 after a four-year stint with the Coast Guard. At his first posting in Comstock, Texas, he learned the Indian tracking techniques the patrol uses to pursue undocumented aliens. Often he would track them up to 70 miles inland though rugged country. He says conversations with the illegal immigrants he arrested taught him Spanish and developed his understanding of their hardships. ``They come here to get jobs, to feed their families, to possibly increase their standard of living,'' he says. ``The worst thing that can happen to them is they'll get sent back to Mexico, so they're going to come here to try to improve their standard of living.'' Williams demanded similar empathy from his officers when he headed the El Paso Border Patrol sector, says Gus de la Vina, now its acting chief. ``He taught the difference between dealing with a criminal vs. dealing with a person that is coming in that is not a criminal, but is violating an administrative law,'' de la Vina says. Jose Guadalupe Moreno, director of the El Paso Catholic Dioceses Migrant and Refugee Services, says he applauds the appointment of a Border Patrol chief who professes to understand the plight of immigrants. But he's not sure that a law enforcement officer can be compassionate. ``Their job is to look for individuals who are here without documents,'' Moreno says. ``No matter how professional they should be, no matter what the policy, it still takes the individual to follow through, to act in a way that will not step all over people's basic and human rights.'' Before coming to El Paso, the 45-year-old Williams headed the patrol's office in Havre, Mont., and was deputy chief in San Diego, the largest Border Patrol sector. Williams says he has no hobbies, spending most of his free time with the patrol when he's not home with his wife, Pat, and their three children. Even before leaving El Paso, he was talking eagerly about the fight ahead to get more funding from Congress. ``It's a challenge to me, and I've always rode to the sound of the guns,'' he said. ``I feel I can make a difference, that I can help these men and women that are out here on America's front line doing their job.'' Williams has taken on Capitol Hill before. In 1986, he criticized Congress for its sluggish pace rewriting immigration laws. ``We are losing control of the border,'' he said then. The Immigration and Naturalization Service believes the number of people crossing U.S. borders illegally grows each year, though there are no statistics other than the numbers caught. And that number has dropped by half since the Immigration Reform and Control Act _ the law Williams pushed for _ was passed in 1986. It granted amnesty to about 3 million aliens who had lived in the country since 1982 and imposed sanctions on employers of undocumented workers. In 1986, 1.6 million aliens were arrested. That fell to 855,315 in 1989. Border Patrol officials figure that fewer arrests mean fewer people are trying to cross the border. Recently the number of arrests began to rise again. Patrol agents say they believe they've controlled the exodus of Central Americans over the border, but not Mexicans. Critics such as Brownsville immigration attorney Linda Yanez say that's a sure sign immigration reform is not working. ``The purpose of much of the legislation was to curb and control immigration, and it has not done that,'' Ms. Yanez says. ``It just created more laws to punish and they don't work. Obviously we're not addressing issues at their core.'' The Border Patrol is moving into yet another arena of controversy as it takes on more duties in the war on drugs. In fiscal 1989, the Border Patrol made 5,441 drug seizures valued at $1.2 billion, up from 3,257 valued at $700 million the year before. Ms. Yanez says she is most concerned about proposals to use the military on the border. ``I don't think it solves any problem and sends the wrong message,'' she says. But Williams welcomes the additional manpower. ``Because of the magnitude of this influx of drugs we're experiencing, we welcome any assistance we can get,'' he says. ``They can be our eyes and ears out there, when we don't have the manpower to be out there.''

DOC.TEXT: Stephanie Zimbalist has gone from solving mysteries on television to creating one in ``Caroline.'' She plays a young woman who was presumed dead for 16 years before turning up to claim a family fortune. ``Caroline,'' the season's final Hall of Fame presentation on CBS on Sunday, is in reality a touching family drama masquerading as a mystery. The story, set in the 1950s, appears sinister at first, with Caroline suspected of being an impostor out for the inheritance. It then turns into something quite different. ``It's about how families work and don't work,'' says Zimbalist, who starred for four seasons in the private eye series ``Remington Steele.'' ``It's a study of how families operate in a group. It's like a little boat. If one person is dysfunctional it tips the boat. ``You have a father who is a workaholic. You have a mother who's a control freak. You have a young girl who's handicapped. You have a boy who has the one chance to become normal. But he's attached to his sister by the hip. ``Caroline is the therapist. The hook of the story is whether she's real? Is she Anastasia? But she comes in and helps the family.'' Pamela Reed also stars as Grace, the stepmother, who sees Caroline not only as a fortune-hunting impostor but as an interloper trying to drive a wedge between her and her own handicapped daughter. George Grizzard is the father, Patricia Neal is Caroline's former school mistress and Dorothy McGuire is the grandmother who leaves the money to Caroline. Shawn Phelan plays as the young son and Jenny Jacobs, the 1982 Cerebral Palsy Poster Child, is Heidi. Joseph Sargent directed the production from a screenplay by Michael de Guzman, based on the novel ``Father's Arcane Daughter'' by E. L. Konigsburg. At the heart of the drama is the conflict between Caroline and the mother over special schooling for Heidi. Caroline sees her as a bright child who is only mildly dysfunctional, while the mother treats her as totally helpless and incapable of learning. ``Caroline says Heidi is who she is,'' Zimbalist says. ``You can't keep hiding her. You face it, you erase it, you move on. ``Joe Sargent directed a lot of scenes with the children watching from behind doors. That's because the children were not allowed into the life of the family. It's so expressive of how life was in the 1950s.'' Zimbalist says her greatest pleasure in doing ``Caroline'' was working with Pamela Reed, who is currently starring in NBC's ``Grand.'' ``When you work with Pamela her burner is always on high,'' she says. Given her druthers, Stephanie Zimbalist would rather be on stage in front of an audience than in front of a camera. She has spent much of her time in the theater since the end of ``Remington Steele.'' Zimbalist grew up in a show business family. Her father, Efrem Zimbalist Jr. is an actor who starred in ``77 Sunset Strip' and ``The F.B.I.'' Her grandfather was concert violinist Efrem Zimbalist and her grandmother was opera singer Alma Gluck. Even as a teen-ager she preferred the stage, but opted for television when she was unable to find work. One of the first things she did was a comedy pilot with her father. One of her earliest roles, and one she still regards as one of her best, was as Elly Zahm in the massive miniseries ``Centennial'' in 1978-79. Author James Michener liked her portrayal of the ill-fated pioneer woman so much that he wrote her a letter. She also won the heart of James Stewart when they worked together in ``The Magic of Lassie,'' one of her few theatrical films. He said she was his favorite young actress. She's currently co-starring in ``The Baby Dance,'' a two-act play at the Pasadena Playhouse that she helped develop. The play is about a yuppie couple from California who are adopting a baby from a backwoods family in Louisiana. ``Musicals are the thing I love to do most,'' Zimbalist says. ``There's hardly a musical that I don't know all the songs. It's why I became an actress.'' After the end of ``Remington Steele'' she toured for six months with Tommy Tune in ``My One and Only.''

Video View: Home Video News and Reviews
DOC.TEXT:
``Black Rain'' (Paramount Home Video. VHS-Beta. Rated R)
Take one maverick cop, a young, vicious Japanese gangster, motorcycles, two gritty cities and more blood and gore than most people would rather see. Add more than a few cliches. Stir fry for two hours and five minutes. And you get ``Black Rain.'' ``Red Rain'' would have been more like it. This crime thriller directed by Ridley Scott of ``Aliens'' and ``Blade Runner'' fame features a murder by stabbing, another by throat-cutting, a shooting death, at least one machine gunning and the slashing of the hero _ and that's just in the first half-hour. We're also treated to a graphic beheading, a finger amputation and gunfire aplenty. Michael Douglas plays Nick Conklin, a New York detective whose hobbies include daredevil motorcycling and raising obnoxiousness to an art form. He's also suspected of stealing money from drug dealers, but his brash manner makes him just a little likable. Sometimes. Nick collars a gangster, Sato (Yusako Matsuba), after Sato rubs out two rival Japanese mobsters in a New York bar. (Remember that first half-hour?) Nick takes Sato back to Japan, but the killer escapes after the plane touches down. And the hunt is on. The plot has so many twists and turns, you're dizzy by the end. And there are other things that make little sense. For instance, most of the time, the Japanese speak Japanese, without dubbing or subtitles. But towards the end, they get subtitles. The Japanese actors do speak English at some points, but in some cases it's still impossible to understand what they're saying. The maverick cop has become a cliche, but Douglas takes it to extremes. He's so mouthy and rude, you're surprised his Japanese counterparts don't put him on the first 747 back to New York _ with the luggage. There are some other formula characters to help him. There's likable Charlie, good cop to Nick's bad cop, played well by Andy Garcia. (Anyone who's been to the movies knows what happens to the likable character. It does.) Then there's Kate Capshaw, who plays a tough-cookie hostess at an Osaka bar. She's a walking scorecard on Japanese gang warfare who fills Nick in despite the danger to herself, but it's never made clear exactly how she knows all this stuff or why she's helping Nick. Matsuba does a chilling job of playing Sato and Ken Takukara is also good as Nick's Japanese partner in crimebusting, Masahiro. The Osaka street scenes are interesting and Ridley Scott's dark, flashy sets are up to his usually high standards. But this formula film is way too violent and muddled. ``Black Rain'' isn't a tasty sukiyaki. It's mulligan stew.

PG-13 _ Special parental guidance strongly suggested for children under 13. Some material may be inappropriate for young children. R _ Restricted. Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian. X _ No one under 17 admitted. Some states may have higher age restrictions.

DOC.TEXT: The works of Leonore Tawney, whose magical incorporation of materials into her art made her one of the century's leading fiber artists, will be on show at the American Craft Museum in New York as part of the museum's ``Master Artist'' series. ``Leonore Tawney: A Retrospective,'' opening April 18, will feature more than 100 works created over a 45-year period. The exhibit will chronicle her use of feathers, eggs, stone, shells and weavings, as well as abstract and figurative works in clay. ``Tawney was always an independent spirit who continuously expanded the expressive potential of fiber and broke the traditional rules of weaving when she found them restrictive,'' said Kathleen Nugent Mangan, guest curator. After its runs at the American Craft Museum through June 17, the show moves to the Art Institute of Chicago from July 26-Oct. 28, and the Renwick Gallery in Washington from April 12-July 21, 1991. Music Makers: Tradition and Individuality
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Pianist Marcus Roberts is traveling the jazz road laid down by the masters toward his own individuality. ``I figure, if you're going to learn how to play piano, why wouldn't you listen to the music of (Thelonious) Monk. Or listen to Duke Ellington,'' he says. ``I'm interested in following a road that has been forged and set by the great masters of the art form. That will lead me to the natural power of identity that I possess. ``It is my feeling that if you have a concept of the tradition from which you come, that can only strengthen your personal statement. It is not going to limit your creativity to have studied 30 great Duke Ellington compositions.'' Roberts, who is blind, has been receiving increasing attention and praise as pianist in trumpeter Wynton Marsalis' group for the last five years. He now has his second album on Novus Records, ``Deep in the Shed,'' referring to a place for intense practice and jazz experimentation. It presents six tunes he composed and arranged, each a different exploration of the blues. ``I believe very strongly in playing blues. Any of the truly great jazz musicians play blues. Some nights Duke Ellington would play nine or 10.'' ``The Truth Is Spoken Here,'' Roberts' first album, also on Novus, an RCA Records label, had performances by drummer Elvin Jones and tenor saxophonist Charlie Rouse. ``Rouse played with Monk. Elvin Jones played with the great (John) Coltrane. I always had a great love for Coltrane's music. It was an honor for me to be in the studio with him.'' This record uses some of Marsalis' musicians and some unknowns who played dates with Roberts last summer. ``There are a lot of brilliant young musicians who deserve an opportunity to play. Whatever I can do to perpetuate that, I'm going to do,'' Roberts said. Marsalis' group is touring now. Roberts will start touring as a leader in May but he isn't really looking forward to doing that full time. ``I like nothing better than to walk on Wynton Marsalis' bandstand every night. Each day I have more love for him and his music. It's hard to picture myself not playing with him, even though I know eventually that will probably happen.'' He didn't always dream about leading his own combo, Roberts says. ``First and foremost, I just wanted to be part of a group of musicians that were all very serious and dedicated and who could all play. ``I realized to get to a certain level of artistry it is necessary that you, if possible, try to establish your own vision and direction. I guess over the years I've started to think more of having my own music and musicians. ``The first time it came up was years ago. Wynton brought it up. I hadn't been in his band very long. He said, `Whenever it's time for you to go and do what you have to do, know that I'll understand.' I didn't know what he was talking about.'' Roberts is 26. Nine years ago, jazz pianist Marian McPartland was the first established performer to take an interest in him. She was a judge in the first music competition he entered, which he won. ``I was in high school. She gave me a lot of real good advice early on. She represents what jazz music is all about. She goes all over the place and does what she can to encourage young musicians to come out and play. I have a great love for her.'' He has been a guest on her ``Piano Jazz'' radio program. ``She told me, `Do as many records as you can. Document your music because that's the only way people ever remember who you are. Whatever you have to do, no matter what the money is, if you have music ready to be recorded, get it recorded.' That's definitely some of the best advice I've ever been given by anybody,'' said Roberts, who plans his third record as a solo piano of tunes by Jelly Roll Morton, Ellington and Monk. When he cuts his own records, Robert said, ``You have to determine everything, concept, music, musicians. The puzzle has to be in my mind and how the pieces should all fit together. When I do records with Wynton, he is such an organized person, all I've got to do is come in and play the piano.'' Marsalis first heard Roberts in 1982 in Chicago, where he played as a student winner at a jazz educators convention. ``He only heard me three more times before I joined his band,'' he said. ``We would stay in touch over the telephone. We'd talk. He was never that impressed with my playing. I was very, very surprised when he asked me to join his band. I always hoped it would happen. There was not a band in the world I would have preferred to play with. ``Wynton's true greatness was not developed in the '80s. In the '90s people will really see the level of genius Wynton has.'' Roberts, who was born in Jacksonville, Fla., had cataracts as a youngster. ``They operated when I was four or five. That was that. I did have some vision before.'' He was named Marthaniel. ``When I was in elementary school I couldn't stand my name being butchered. I thought of Marcus. I like Marthaniel better but I don't like people mispronouncing it.'' He's a graduate of Florida State University. Earlier, he attended a school for the blind in St. Augustine, Fla., which had renowned piano teachers. He already knew Braille. He composed a bit there, ``a few little love songs for my girlfriends.'' His spirit has not been sapped by his blindness. ``My mother lost her sight when she was 15. She was able to keep me in the right track. I couldn't say, `Nobody understands.'''

Nashville Sound: The Ultimate Thank You Song
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The composers who wrote the Grammy-winning song ``Wind Beneath My Wings'' are aiming their ambition at another challenge: an Academy Award. The touching tune about worshiping loved ones was voted song of the year in February, earning a Grammy award for co-writers Larry Henley and Jeff Silbar. The song also was chosen record of the year, earning another Grammy for Bette Midler. The song, performed by Midler in the movie ``Beaches,'' was not eligible for an Academy Award because it was not written for a motion picture. ``I watched the Academy Awards and thought, `Boy, I'd like to have one of those,''' Henley said in an interview. ``You get this award syndrome. It's so much fun to go up on that stage and get an award. ``I'm hopeully going to get more songs in movies. My next goal is to win the Academy Award.'' Henley lives in Nashville. Silbar, who lives in Studio City, Calif., is directing his songwriting toward an Oscar as well. ``I'm trying, since the Grammy award, to write with the best writers I can and write for special projects,'' he said by telephone. Henley and Silbar wrote ``Wind Beneath My Wings'' in 1981 on Nashville's Music Row. Henley put the finishing touches on the lyrics the next day as he sat alone on a yacht in the Gulf of Mexico off Corpus Christi, Texas. An estimated 200 singers have recorded the song, with Midler's version hitting No. 1 on the pop music charts last summer. The well-crafted tune, in dramatic and sweeping fashion, is about one person telling another person that he or she is his or her hero. The person being addressed is saluted for strength and willingness to let others reap the glory of life: ``I can fly higher than an eagle. Because you are the wind beneath my wings.'' Warner Chappell, which published the song, says it has become the most performed piece of music at weddings. It also is played often at funerals. ``It gets people coming and going,'' Henley said. Silbar refers to it as ``the ultimate thank you song.'' ``People have been looking for the words to say this and the song just kind of crystallizes their thoughts,'' he said. ``The stories I hear about it are wonderful: The song is dedicated to fathers, brothers, husbands. It goes the whole boundaries of relationships and how people feel to each other.'' Henley says, ``It's become a catch phrase in America. I'm very proud of that. I think that's one of the things hardly anyone ever writes.'' Both writers said the song fit well in ``Beaches,'' a movie about friendship, even though the tune was written years before the movie was conceived and was first a hit record by Gary Morris in the country music field. ``The spot in the movie was the ultimate for a ballad,'' Silbar said. ``It worked wonderfully in the movie,'' Henley said. ``It was sort of a `Terms of Endearment' kind of movie. It was funny, then it makes you want to cry. It leaves you with a very special feeling.'' Henley primarily wrote the lyrics, which is ironic because such moving sentiments came from someone married and divorced four times. ``I've been single now for about 10 years,'' he said. ``I think I've learned my lesson.'' One of his ex-wives, who inspired the song, called him with congratulations the night the Grammy Awards were announced. ``She's thrilled I'm sure,'' Henley said. ``She was one of the heroes in my life. I've always been grateful for some of the things she taught me.'' Henley owns a place in music trivia. He'll probably always be known for co-writing ``Wind Beneath My Wings,'' but in the 1960s he was lead singer for the Newbeats rock 'n' roll group. It was his falsetto on such hits as ``Bread and Butter'' in 1964, and ``Run, Baby, Run'' in 1965. ``I think my story has been sort of interesting, from `Bread and Butter' to `Wind Beneath My Wings' by way of country music,'' he mused. ``From rock 'n' roll to country to pop. It's sort of a strange route.'' His fondest memory from the Newbeats is doing a concert tour with the Rolling Stones and Roy Orbison in Australia and New Zealand. ``It was the most fun I ever had,'' Henley recalled. ``We had the world in our hands and didn't even know it.''

Star Watch: Impresario of Bad Taste Goes Mainstream
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: What's this? John Waters, the impresario of bad taste, hooked up with the people who gave you ``Parenthood''? What's more, his new film, ``Cry Baby,'' is being released by a mainstream company, Universal Pictures. Has the onetime king of underground sleaze succumbed to the Establishment? ``I've always tried to make commercial movies,'' he explains unapologetically. ``Think about it. `Pink Flamingos' (1972) cost $10,000. All the hideousness I put in that movie was commercial. Nobody heard of us before. All the people who left that movie said, `Oh my God, you wouldn't believe what I just saw!' ``I always try to be commercial _ on my terms. It worked, too. That movie's still playing. Two generations have been offended by that movie. I'm proud of that. It's hard to do.'' Talk about inflation. ``Cry Baby'' cost $8 million, minor by Hollywood standards but not Waters'. The film is backed by Universal and Imagine Films Entertainment, operated by Ron Howard and Brian Grazer, makers of ``Splash'' and ``Parenthood.'' ``They have been a wonderful support,'' said Waters. ``They never said to me, `You can't do that.' They gave me the money to do everything I wanted to do, hire `all the stars in heaven.''' Well, not quite. ``Cry Baby'' stars Johnny Depp, the teen rage of TV's ``21 Jump Street,'' and Amy Locane as star-crossed lovers in the 1950s. The cast ranges from Polly Bergen and Susan Tyrell to Traci Lords and Iggy Pop with cameos by Willem Dafoe, Patty Hearst, David (``Ozzie and Harriet'') Nelson and Troy Donahue. It's all set to the beat of early rock 'n' roll. ``I wanted it to look like a '50s musical, like `The Girl Can't Help It' or early Elvis,'' Waters said. ``Or like the spinoff, lower versions of `The Wild One' or `Rebel Without a Cause.' I liked those movies, but better, I liked the cheap imitations.'' A movie nut all his life, Waters confessed his lifelong ambition: ``I always wanted to be a villain in a Disney movie.'' With his thin, pallid face, razor-thin mustache and black suit, he could easily have done so. Growing up in Baltimore, he gave puppet shows from the age of 8 to 14, when he feared his playmates would consider it ``uncool.'' His first movie was shot in 8mm in 1964 when he was 19. The title: ``Hag in a Black Leather Jacket.'' ``It's in my closet, where it will stay,'' he said. ``It was filmed on the roof of my parents' house. It was about a black man marrying a white woman with a Ku Klux Klan member performing the ceremony. The man took her away on the honeymoon in a garbage can. It was very influenced by the 1960s Theater of the Absurd. It played once in a beatnik coffee house, and that was it.'' Waters continued making films with his Baltimore buddies until the breakthrough with ``Mondo Trasho.'' ``It was the story of a hit-run driver on one hideous day in her life,'' he recounted. ``It starred Divine, and in the end Divine died in a pig pen and the Virgin Mary appeared to her. ``In `Multiple Maniacs,' Divine was raped by a 15-foot broiled lobster. `Pink Flamingos' was about a battle between the filthiest people alive. `Female Trouble' was about a criminal who wanted to be famous so badly that she got the electric chair; that was like the Oscar in her chosen profession. `Desperate Living' was about the worst town you could live in when you're so embarrassed about your life you have to move there. ```Polyester' was a comedy about the hell of suburban life where everything smells bad; it was released in `Odorama.' `Hairspray' was a musical comedy about a teen dance show. `Cry Baby' is a juvenile delinquent comedy. ``So you can see that my sense of humor has been the same from the very beginning.'' Despite the outrageousness of his themes, Waters claims, ``the critics have been good to me since the very beginning. You get bad press when you start believing the nice things that you all sign. ``Bad reviews? Rex Reed gave us the best: `Where do these people come from? Where do they go when the sun goes down? Isn't there a law or something?' That quote was our whole campaign in selling the picture.'' Although Waters' films are treasured at Saturday midnight screenings, he insists that he enjoys a wide audience: ``After `Hairspray' had been out, we found that 8- and 9-year-olds really loved the films. That's an audience I had never tested, never even thought of. They liked it on one level; they didn't see the parody of it. ``When we tested `Cry Baby,' there were a lot of kids who said they thought it was a really romantic movie. They can like it on a another level. That's OK. It is romantic, it is sexy. All juvenile delinquents were sexy, that's why they had 'em. The word itself is sexy. We don't have juvenile delinquents anymore. We have 13-year-old mass murderers.''

The Artists: Mellencamp Lets Paintings Talk _ $15,000 a Pop
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Singer John Mellencamp's art is populated with characters from America's heartland. But these days, those characters are more likely to be found in oil paintings than on the radio. For Mellencamp, painting has provided a respite from the pressures of rock 'n roll and the recent collapse of his second marriage. His second exhibit of oil paintings opened April 12 at the Churchman-Fehsenfeld Gallery of the Indianapolis Art League. Mellencamp first displayed his work last year at an exhibit with jazz artist Miles Davis in Los Angeles. The 29 portraits depict the singer-songwriter's family and friends. The facial expressions created by his muted brush strokes are always sad, and they convey the same disillusionment found in his musical anthems about the nation's heartland and the farm crisis. ``I think you can say much more in a painting than you can in a stupid song,'' he said in an interview with Rolling Stone magazine last year. ``Some days I start at seven o'clock in the morning, and I paint until five, eat dinner and come back and paint till midnight. I don't have to see anybody. I don't have to talk to anybody. It's better than sex for me.'' However, Mellencamp's wealth hardly fits the stereotype of a struggling artist. His albums have sold millions, he records in his own studio and he could afford to spend much of the last year in an art studio he had built next to his home near Bloomington. He and his wife, Vicky, are in the middle of a divorce. They are the parents of Teddi Joe, 8, and Justice, 4, who currently are living with their mother. Mellencamp's manager, Harry Sandler, said the singer did not want to be interviewed about his venture into the art world. ``John wants to let the paintings stand on their own,'' Sandler said. ``He just chooses not to speak at this time.'' Mellencamp has not hinted that his music career is over, but it has certainly taken an extended vacation. His growing discontent with pop stardom surfaced in his last album, ``Big Daddy.'' ``Never wanted to be no pop singer, never wanted to write no pop songs,'' goes the bitter refrain of the hit single, ``Pop Singer,'' which offers Mellencamp's cynical view of today's music scene. He refused to tour in support of ``Big Daddy,'' and his only stage appearance in recent months came at the Farm Aid IV concert in Indianapolis March 7. The rousing ovation he received and his energetic three-song performance were far removed from the solitude of a blank canvas. Mellencamp organized the first Farm Aid back in 1984 with Willie Nelson as a benefit for struggling farmers. ``I think people my age need to start taking their position in the community seriously, and start dealing with local problems within the system,'' he said in an interview with the Associated Press. ``I don't mean standing in the back rows and throwing stuff, any coward can do that. We tried that in the '60s and it didn't work out too good. I mean to take affirmative action, and to make positive steps to change in a country that needs to go through that right now.'' But those who have worked with Mellencamp say he is serious about painting, and that it is not merely a hobby. Jan Royce traveled to Mellencamp's studio several times last summer to help him learn oil techniques. ``He's very bright, very eager to learn, very driven,'' said Royce, a portrait painter from Indianapolis. ``He paints from the heart, just as his music is from the heart.'' Royce said the immediacy of creating a painting appeals to Mellencamp's impatient nature. ``He works very fast and tries to capture what he's feeling immediately,'' said Julia L. Muney, exhibits curator at the art league. By displaying his paintings to the public and critics, Muney said Mellencamp wanted ``some validation for himself. He wants the public to confirm, `Am I going in the right direction?''' At least some buyers think so. Three of his self-portraits, ranging in price from $2,000 to $6,000, were sold before the show opened, Muney said. Reaction to the show was enthusiastic among 450 guests invited to a pre-opening party attended by Mellencamp, Muney said. ``They liked the work a lot. They might have been skeptical, but they are no longer,'' Muney said. ``I was expecting things to look a little more folksy. I was surprised at the expertness of the paint-handling.'' In yet another paradox, Mellencamp chose to personally oversee all aspects of the Indianapolis showing. Muney said he helped set up the exhibit, fussed over the titles of each painting and wired the frames himself in preparation for hanging. ``He'll deprecate his paintings. It's very strange because he's serious about painting but after a while he won't be satisfied with the results. ``We were looking at some of these paintings and he told me, `This is crummy, but you can hang it anyway,''' Muney said, gesturing toward the exhibit. Mellencamp insisted on removing two paintings from the exhibit because he wasn't satisfied with them, Muney said. He may not want to discuss his paintings, but the prices on his works speak volumes. His two least expensive works are a self-portrait of himself and another titled ``Big J,'' showing his daughter, Justice, in a pink dress. Both sell for $2,000. Three paintings are priced at $15,000. They are among the largest works in the exhibit, measuring roughly 72 inches long by 48 inches wide. His first wife, Priscilla, is the subject of ``Cil,'' which shows her wearing '50s-style glasses and large earrings. In ``The Beach or the Bar,'' said to be Mellencamp's favorite, he portrays seven people gathered around an outdoor bar. At his showing last fall in Los Angeles, the painting carried a $25,500 price tag. In Indianapolis, it's practically a steal at $12,000. ``Paintings cost more in L.A. He adjusted his prices down for the Midwestern market,'' Muney said. Muney said Mellencamp asked her if his prices were too high. ``Given his name and what he's putting into them, frankly, I said no,'' she said. But Muney admits few artists who have been painting for less than two years can tag such elaborate prices on their works. ``Yes, they're paying for the name,'' she said of potential Mellencamp collectors.

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Music Makers: Writing the Best Record of the Year
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: John Trudell can still remember the date (Jan. 14, 1979), the place (Vancouver, British Columbia) and what he was doing (riding in a car) when he wrote his first lyrics. ``Suddenly, these lines came into my head, `Gently the rains of purification wash my mind,''' recalled the 44-year-old Trudell, a longtime Indian activist who has recorded several albums of his poetry. ``Something told me to write them down and I've been writing since then. ``I wrote a set of 20 lines. It was not something I expected. Then I started writing and I started writing a lot. And I saw, well, there's some reason I'm doing this and I'll see where the writing takes me.'' His writing found its way on tape with friend and guitarist Jesse Ed Davis composing backing tracks for two albums. Unable to sign with any record label, Trudell formed Peace Music and released the songs on mail-order cassettes. In 1986, ``a.k.a. Grafitti Man'' wound up in the hands of Bob Dylan, who called it the best record of the year. ``I think he was doing the Grateful Dead tour that year and he played our tape at his concerts,'' Trudell recalled. ``The effect wasn't monetary at that time. What it was was more recognition from other artists.'' So rock stars Jackson Browne, George Harrison and Bono became fans, too, and Midnight Oil made Trudell the opening act for their 1988 tour. Trudell is a rock 'n' roll fan himself, paying tribute to Elvis Presley in ``Baby Boom Che.'' But while many of his co-stars are musicians who developed politically, Trudell is an activist now giving live recitals. ``I knew how to handle the stage for myself, but I had never worked it this way, with four or five other people. That's something that I'm not trained for,'' Trudell said. ``I'm not familiar with the poets. I never really listened to any poets. Their lines may have had great symbolic meanings, but they were not real to my world. What was real to my world was country music and rock 'n' roll music and blues.'' Why he began writing is almost too painful to talk about, a time he refers to as ``when things changed in my life.'' In 1979, after leading a march in Washington and speaking out against FBI policy towards Indians, a mysterious fire at his Nevada home killed his wife, his three children and his mother-in-law. ``I realized I needed to survive, but surviving isn't enough,'' said Trudell, who soon developed a ``compulsion'' to write. ``There's got to be something else that goes with it. Otherwise, a lot of things lose their meaning and purpose. I was trying to figure out how I was going to deal with that.'' He was born in Omaha, Neb., in 1946, and lived on and off the Santee Reservation until joining the Navy in 1963. ``I knew the realities in my reservation and life of the reservations and I knew the reality of racism and a whole lot things. But when I was in the military it showed me that there were a lot of Indians around the world as far as America was concerned,'' said Trudell, who served in Vietnam. ``I had the experiences of the military, and then I went to college for a little while. Basically, college taught me the same thing the navy taught me. There are many realities here, and what the controlling class taught me was you've got to submit to be successful.'' He became a leader of the Indian rights movement in the late 1960s, serving as chair of ``Indians of All Tribes'' during the occupation of Alcatraz Island in 1969, and heading the American Indian Movement in the '70s when protests took place at Mount Rushmore, Washington and Wounded Knee. ``Graffiti Man'' includes political songs such as ``Rich Man's War,'' and love songs such as ``Stardreamer Woman.'' Trudell speaks of his writing as the next new wave in music, sounding like a true punk rocker who's tired of the state of the art. ``Because the music industry, with all its high tech, has basically gone as far as it could go, it's stagnant. It needs a new infusion of human energy. I think spoken word can be that infusion of human energy. ``People are used to langauge being spoken, used to being talked to,'' he said. ``In our generation, all our poets got sucked up as musicians and are identified as musicians and that put it out of reach of your average person. Poets are within every person's reach.''

DOC.HEAD: VA Plans First Review of Health Care in 25 Years
DOC.TEXT: America's military veterans are growing older as a group, forcing the Veterans Affairs Department to re-evaluate its health care system for the first time in a quarter-century. By May, VA Secretary Edward J. Derwinski plans to have in place a commission to review the ``mission'' of the department's 172 hospitals, nearly 400 outpatient clinics, nursing homes and other facilities. Medicine has changed greatly since 1965, but the politics of closing a hospital have not. In 1965, the VA barely managed to close seven of the 15 hospitals and old soldiers' homes it had recommended should be shut down. The emphasis has shifted from in-hospital care to outpatient and extended care, and prevention. Government medicine, like private care, costs more today. And VA hospitals must compete for federal budget dollars to pay adequate salaries for doctors and nurses while maintaining up-to-date equipment. Congress has complained that for the last 10 years the system has been underfunded, and it says the VA needs $250 million more this year to keep a bare-bones operation through September. Derwinski's proposal for the next fiscal year calls for a record $31 billion for health care. The cost of medical care grows with the age of the patient. And the main point that Derwinski has driven home in one congressional hearing after another is the rapid change in the veteran population. Of the nation's 27.1 million veterans, more than one-third served during World War II. The average age of those World War II veterans is 68. The number of veterans age 65 or older is supposed to peak at 9 million in 1999, according to the VA. Veterans 75 and older will grow from 1.4 million today to 2.6 million in 1995, and to 4.4 million in the year 2010, the VA says. ``By the year 2010, veterans 65 and older will comprise 40 percent of the eligible veteran population, as compared to 26 percent in 1989,'' Derwinski said in recent testimony before the Senate Veterans Affairs Committee. By 2010, Derwinski said, 35 percent of VA hospital patients will be at least 75 years old, and 60 percent will be over 65. ``Major adjustments'' to the VA system may be needed to meet these veterans' needs, Derwinski said. Like the rest of the population, some veteran retirees are moving from their homes in the Northeast and Midwest, where many of the older VA facilities are, to Arizona, Florida and other sunnier states. The VA has not kept up with this population shift. With those trends in mind, the VA Commission on the Future Structure of Veterans Health Care will begin meeting next month to come up with a set of recommendations by October 1991. Derwinski has already promised that no facilities will be closed, even though a city like his own, Chicago, may have three hospitals with overlapping services. VA facilities, like dams and highways, are prime cuts of pork. Congress gave Derwinski a cool reception last summer when he proposed legislation that would give lawmakers a role in choosing the commission members. Lawmakers were reluctant to be connected with a group that could recommend closing a facility in their districts. Congress was still up in arms over another panel's recommendation to close domestic military bases, so Derwinski decided to appoint his own commission. What the VA can do is convert a hospital to another use, such as nursing care, and allow only one hospital in a population center to offer expensive, specialized equipment or surgery. Still, members of Congress and other groups are wary of the VA in light of past budget-cutting, when the agency was dominated by the Office of Management and Budget. Also, there are questions of how independent the commission will be, especially since its support staff will be drawn from within the VA. ``All too often in the past, when there was talk of re-examining the VA's mission, reducing services was the hidden agenda, '' James N. Magill of the Veterans of Foreign Wars recently testified. There's a major reason for leaving some slack in the system, a reason few like to think about: war or large-scale armed conflict. ``If the work of the commission will be undertaken with the assumption there will not be a new generation of wartime veterans by the year 2000, then the final report of the commission may not be totally germane by the beginning of the next century,'' John F. Sommer of the American Legion said in recent testimony.

DOC.HEAD: State to Deal with Fastest-Growing Segment of Driving Population _ Seniors
DOC.TEXT: Lonnie ``Layne'' Hall lives alone in his house on the outskirts of this village, so his driver's license is also his ticket to independence. The license says he's 110. He insists he's five years younger. Either way, he is New York's oldest driver, according to the state Department of Motor Vehicles. ``How many times a week do I go out driving?'' said Hall. ``Oh, whenever I have to _ maybe once or twice. I take my laundry out. I buy my groceries.'' Hall has a clean record, but the DMV is reviewing regulations dealing with the fastest-growing segment of the driving population: senior citizens. New York has 1.9 million drivers over 60, said John Boffa of the governor's Traffic Safety Committee, which is conducting the review along with the state Office for the Aging. ``The basic directive was to identify ways to make driving safer for elderly people without imposing additional burdens on them,'' said Boffa. Studies show the eyes provide 95 percent of the information drivers use to make decisions, said Boffa. So, the width of stripes on the New York State Thruway _ 559 miles from New York City to Niagara Falls _ has been increased from four to six inches. The rest of the state's interstates also will get wider stripes, Boffa said. And over the next few years, the Thruway's 15,000 signs will be replaced with ones that have greater reflectivity and larger letters. Those changes are relatively easy. ``The more complicated issue is how to deal with the drivers,'' Boffa said. According to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, drivers in most age groups can expect to be involved in an average of five crashes per million vehicle miles traveled. The exceptions: the youngest and oldest drivers. For teen-agers, the figure is about 30; for those 80 and over it is close to 40. Three states _ Indiana, Illinois and New Hampshire _ and the District of Columbia require drivers to retake road tests after a certain age, generally 75. But Boffa said New York officials are not convinced of the merits of that because it would overwhelm the Department of Motor Vehicles. It also would be discriminatory, said Steve Stiles at the American Association for Retired Persons. ``The difficulty we have is when a state selects older drivers and says, at age 65, you go through some special testing different from everybody else,'' he said. ``Let's do better testing,'' Stiles said, ``but let's do it on a performance basis, not age.'' Boffa said New York is moving deliberately as it considers older drivers. ``The automobile provides mobility and individuality for people in many cases,'' he said. ``Self-esteem is pretty deeply interwoven with the ability to drive. When you take that away from people, it can be pretty devastating.'' In rural areas, driving is essential. ``Automobiles are the only means of transportation for people to get to the doctor's office and the pharmacy,'' Boffa said. ``We're trying to balance safety considerations with concern and sensitivity to the elderly population,'' he added. ``It's not an easy dilemma to resolve, to be frank.''

DOC.HEAD: Survey Finds Elderly Want to `Age in Place'
DOC.TEXT: Growing numbers of older Americans want to stay in their homes and never move, but more than half have done little or no planning for their housing needs in later years, a national survey shows. The survey of 1,500 people aged 55 and older, commissioned by the American Association of Retired Persons, found that 86 percent wanted to ``age in place,'' up from 78 percent in 1986. Fifty-three percent had done little or no planning for their housing. Those most likely to have done no planning were those over 75, with less than $12,000 annual income, widowed, divorced or never married, and with health problems. ``In general, the people who have the strongest desire to stay put are also the most vulnerable _ the old-old, the poor and the widowed,'' the report said. ``They are more likely to be forced out of their homes because of some crisis.'' Forty-three percent of older Americans have lived in their homes for more than 20 years, while only 17 percent have moved within the past five years. Of those who move, 63 percent stay in the same city or county. The survey found that 22 percent of older people expect to move, but only 13 percent want to. ``Midlife and older people need to evaluate housing options before a crisis occurs,'' the AARP said. ``A lack of planning may force many older people out of their home against their wishes.'' Those who are willing to move, especially the oldest respondents and those in poor health, were more receptive to age-segregated housing than they were in AARP's previous survey in 1986. Forty percent prefer a senior citizens' building to one for all age groups, up from 32 percent in 1986. The latest survey, conducted in 1989, also found a growing expectation among the elderly that they will need help around their homes. Sixty-five percent anticipate needing help with outside maintenance such as mowing lawns, up from 40 percent in 1986. Fifty-five percent expect to need help with heavy housework, up from 33 percent. ``Individuals' decision to move or stay may be influenced by how affordable, reliable and accessible home and outdoor maintenance services become,'' the AARP said. The survey found that 23 percent of older people live alone, with women, those 75 and older and those with incomes below $12,000 most likely to do so. Five percent live in a retirement community or building planned for older adults. Twenty-seven percent live in a neighborhood or building where a majority of the residents are 60 or older. The telephone survey was conducted by Market Facts Inc. in June 1989 and had a margin of error of plus or minus 3 percentage points. Results of the survey were released by the AARP this month.

DOC.HEAD: Older People Express Love in Many Ways
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: T. Franklin Williams, a geriatrics physician, is director of the National Institute on Aging, one of the 13 institutes that comprise the National Institutes of Health of the Department of Health and Human Services.

The capacity and need for sexual expression continues into old age. Love and sex can be expressed in many ways. The joy of companionship between two people can be shown by touching and holding hands, caressing, or by conversation and doing things together. While some physical responses slow with age, individuals of all ages can benefit both physically and psychologically by expressing their sexuality. Most older people want _ and can lead _ an active, satisfying sex life. Indeed, many 80- and 90-year-old men and women have satisfying sexual relations. With age, women do not ordinarily lose their physical capacity for orgasm, nor men their capacity for erecton and ejaculation. There is often, however, a slowing of response. For women, changes that occur in the shape, flexibility and lubrication of the vagina can usually be traced to lowered levels of the hormone estrogen during and after menopause. Many women say that after menopause, when the fear of pregnancy and distractions of mid-life have passed, they become especially responsive sexually. Most healthy older men maintain their production of sex hormones at levels found in younger men; however, it usually takes an older man longer to achieve full erection. Although a pattern of regular sexual activity helps to preserve sexual ability, research shows a gradual decline of sexual activity with age. Studies at the National Institute on Aging's Gerontology Research Center found that levels of sexual activity expressed in early adulthood usually predicted activity later in life. Overall health is of primary importance in maintaining sexual relationships. In a study of 241 married men, 60 and older, 75 percent of those without mobility problems reported they were sexually active, while only 16 percent of those with mobility problems were. Even a serious disease rarely warrants stopping sexual relations. One distressing myth is that sex is bad for your heart. Although cardiac patients should check with a doctor before resuming sexual activities, generally the risk of a heart attack during sexual intercourse is about equal to the risk from climbing a flight of stairs. Several diseases, such as arthritis, can limit sexual activity. Depression, a treatable disorder, is one of the most common causes of altered sexual motivation. Diabetes is one of the few diseases that can cause impotence. However, once diabetes is diagnosed and controlled, potency may be restored. Excessive use of alcohol, which may reduce potency in men and delay orgasm in women, is probably the most widespread drug-related cause of sexual problems. Tranquilizers, antidepressants and certain high blood pressure drugs may also cause impotence; other drugs may reduce sexual desire. Almost everyone experiences a sexual problem at some time or another. Because sexual functioning is emotional and psychological as well as physical, what's happening in the family or at work can have an important influence. When problems occur, they should not be viewed as a sign of aging but rather as the possible result of disease, disability, drug reactions, or emotinal upset. Many sexual problems have emotional or organic causes that can be treated. One barrier to a healthy sex life in old age stems from the disturbing myth that older people lose their sex appeal. Negative stereotypes are still too common. Any expression of sexual interest by an older woman who has no partner is typically viewed as unacceptable in our society. The ``dirty old man'' who seeks sexual expression is the object of many jokes. With the increasing lifespan and improvement of the overall health of older people, sexual activity becomes an important aspect in overall quality of life.

For a free copy of ``The Age Page, Sexuality in Later Life, contact the National Institute on Aging Information Center, P.O. Box 8057, Gaithersburg, Md., 20898-8057. Additional information is available from the Sex Education Information Council of the United States, 80 Fifth Ave., Suite 801, New York, N.Y., 10011, 212-673-3850.

DOC.HEAD: Forget Killer Bees; the Ash Whitefly Is Here
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: James Walters worked for the AP as a reporter and editor from 1947 until he retired in 1984.

To most gardeners in this country, whiteflies are minor nuisances that look like flakes of dandruff when disturbed. But forget foreign invaders like killer bees, fire ants and Japanese beetles. The ash whitefly now is in the United States. So far it's been spotted mainly around Los Angeles, but Dave Langston, entomologist for the University of Arizona-State Extension Service, says there are some suspicious areas in Arizona and he's pretty sure confirmed outbreaks will be found this summer in this state and possibly others. That would be consistent with California's experience. ``California Agriculture,'' published by the University of California, says in the January-February edition that since the first North American report of ash whitefly in the summer of 1988, ``populations have reached extraordinary levels in Los Angeles County and may affect fruit and nursery crops throughout the state.'' The scientific name of this super whitefly is Siphoninus phillyreae. First recorded in 1835, it's now known in most of Europe, northern Africa, the Middle East, southern Russia, Pakistan and India. Natural enemies limit severe outbreaks in the Old World. Unfortunately, there don't seem to be any on this continent. California is experimenting this spring with imported biological controls, including a tiny wasp. Meantime, gardeners should be prepared. Insecticides never have been effective against even our native whiteflies. But for the most part, damage has been isolated. The ash whitefly is like comparing a tiger to a cat. Climate, hot or cold, doesn't seem a problem. It reproduces in about 25 days and passes through four stages, all of which feed by sucking sap from leaves. There frequently are reports of clusters on every leaf of a mature tree. Adults often are inhaled or caught in people's eyes. Known hosts, besides ash trees, include citrus, olive, pomegranate, jujube, apple, peach, pear, loquat, apricot, plum and many ornamental shrubs and trees. The common name, ash whitefly, was applied in this country after the first ones were found on ash trees. In Europe it's usually known as the pear whitefly or peach whitefly, because of damage to those crops. Some textbooks call it the pomegranate whitefly. Whiteflies were more numerous than usual last year in Arizona. Is it possible some were ash whitefly? ``Not a chance,'' says Langston. ``Once you get this one you'll know it. Trees turn yellow. Some die. It's not like now, when you get just honeydew and whiteflies flying around. These aren't necessarily any bigger in size, but they feed a lot more and suck large quantities of fluid. So there's major symptoms on foliage.'' ``California Agriculture'' says, ``Populations grow to enormous densities ... often covering 100 percent of available foliage and producing substantial amounts of honeydew and sooty molds.'' To entomologists, appearance of the species is unique because of 40 to 50 tiny, dorsal, siphon tubes in the pupal stage. But whiteflies are too small for gardeners to spot this. So damage will be the clue. ``I think this summer we'll see a couple isolated cases in Arizona where we'll have to treat for it,'' says Langston. ``What we'll use I have no idea, since I understand nothing works. Biological control probably is the ultimate answer.'' Pesticide treatment, in the California experience, may be successful in small areas, such as nurseries. Sprays or water or insecticidal soap seem to reduce the population on smaller plants. However, re-infestation is likely from nearby vegetation. Many nursery-trade groups and government agencies, including the California Department of Food and Agriculture, are participating with the University of California in the biological control program. Encarsia wasps supplied by Israel and Italy have been promising in field tests. The wasps reproduce by laying eggs inside ash whitefly nymphs, which are eaten by the wasp larvae. The ash whitefly probably entered this country on plants sent to Los Angeles either by air or sea, according to ``California Agriculture.'' Infestation in Los Angeles County was widespread when first reported. Just-detectable levels were found then in an adjoining county. However, between the following spring and autumn, that infestation grew to nearly equal that in Los Angeles.

DOC.HEAD: Group Urges Appointments to Social Security Board
DOC.TEXT: A senior citizens group is urging President Bush to fill two vacancies on the Social Security Board of Trustees, saying the public is being denied a voice in oversight of the giant retirement program. The National Council of Senior Citizens said the administration has failed to fill two positions reserved for the public, one Democrat and one Republican, leaving the board controlled by the three government officials on it. The board is charged with oversight of Social Security's giant trust funds and of operations at the Social Security Administration. The two public trustee positions have been vacant since November, according to the council. ``The president has elected to ignore the virtues of a system of checks and balances because that very system might further expose unsound management principles and inadequate resources within the Social Security Administration,'' said Lawrence Smedley, executive director of the council. The council, and several Democratic members of Congress, are urging Bush to appoint Alicia Munnell, senior vice president and director of research at the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, as the Democratic public trustee.
DOC.HEAD: Legislation Proposed to Allow Senior `Olympics' to Continue
DOC.TEXT: Legislation has been introduced in the Senate to allow the a national seniors competition to use the word ``Olympics.'' The first National Senior Olympics, in St. Louis in 1987, attracted more than 2,500 participants, including athletes from Canada and Taiwan. The competition was open to people over 55. However, after the 1987 games, the U.S. Olympic Committee said the games could no longer use the word ``Olympics,'' arguing it would ``compete programmatically or financially with the United States Olympic effort.'' Sen. John Danforth, R-Mo., was among 18 senators who wrote to the U.S. Olympic Committee in 1988 asking that the U.S. National Senior Olympics be allowed to continue under that name, but the committee refused the request. Danforth this month introduced legislation that would authorize the U.S. National Senior Olympics to use the term and to register the name as its trademark. The next games, now called the U.S. Senior Sports Classic, are to be held June 28-July 3, 1991, in Syracuse, N.Y.
DOC.HEAD: Aging Groups Urge Cut in Defense Spending
DOC.TEXT: A coalition of national groups representing older Americans is urging members of Congress to cut defense spending to help reduce the federal budget deficit. Members of the Leadership Council of Aging Organizations sent a letter to members of the House and Senate Budget Committees stating that the reduced threat of communism around the world means massive defense spending no longer is justified. Without a significant reduction in military spending, across-the-board federal spending cuts may be necessary, which would have a disproportionate effect on domestic programs, the groups added. The groups said at least $20 billion should be cut from the defense budget in fiscal 1991, perhaps through eliminating new weapons systems, reducing troops, sharing defense responsiblities with U.S. allies, and stricter regulation of defense procurement.
DOC.HEAD: Survey Finds Americans Expect Drop in Medicare Benefits
DOC.TEXT: Nearly two-thirds of working-age Americans do not think Medicare will provide them with the same level of benefits that it does today when they become eligible for coverage, according to a nationwide survey. The January survey of 1,001 Americans age 18 and older was conducted for the Employee Benefit Research Institute by The Gallup Organization. Sixty-four percent of those not yet eligible for Medicare said they did not expect to get the same benefits as today's Medicare beneficiaries. Respondents approaching retirement age were most confident in the system's ability to pay benefits. Thirty-six percent of those aged 55 and older said they expect the program to be able to pay them today's level of benefits, while 19 percent of those aged 35-54 and 26 percent of those aged 18-34 had that view. Those surveyed were divided about whether they would be willing to pay more now to guarantee Medicare benefits later. Forty-eight percent said they would be willing to pay an increased Social Security contribution during working years to insure that they receive the current level of Medicare in the future, 47 pecent said they would not be willing to do so, and 5 percent were unsure. Eighty-six percent of respondents thought they would need additional health insurance beyond what is provided by Medicare. The survey showed a lack of understanding about the Medicare program. More than half of those surveyed thought Medicare covered individuals when they retire, rather than when they reach the eligibility age of 65. Thirty-seven percent thought Medicare covers home health care, and 26 percent thought it covered extended stays in nursing homes, neither of which is covered.
DOC.NOTE: End advance for April 19

DOC.TEXT: Wholesale prices, helped by a record drop in vegetable costs and lower gasoline prices, fell in March for the first time in seven months, the government said. The Labor Department's Producer Price Index declined 0.2 percent last month after no change in February and a huge 1.8 percent gain in January, the largest in 15 years. Vegetables prices were down by 25.5 percent, the department reported Friday.

Business inventories fell in February for the second time in three months while sales surged in another sign that the economy has avoided a recession, the government said. Inventories on shelves and backlots shrank 0.4 percent, the steepest drop since December 1986, to a seasonally adjusted $794.6 billion in February, the Commerce Department reported Friday. Sales, meanwhile, rose 1.3 percent to a seasonally adjusted $535.4 billion. It was the largest increase in seven months.

Boeing Co. said it would begin producing a new commercial jet under an agreement with three Japanese companies that will produce parts and provide up to 20 percent of the capital for the venture. The so-called 767-X is intended to fill the size gap between Boeing's 767, another jetliner that uses some Japanese-produced components, and its 747 jumbo jet, company officials said Friday. Under the agreement, Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Kawasaki Heavy Industries and Fuji Heavy Industries would get a share of any profits but would have no equity in the project and get no proprietary information.

Big Mac is on the attack, warning newspapers around the country not to reprint a full-page ad placed by an Omaha industrialist who claims that McDonald Corp.'s food is too fatty. ``We think the papers just didn't check the facts,'' said McDonald's attorney Joseph Califano. He said the fast food company had advised the newspapers that the ad was misleading and asked them not to publish it again. The fat flap began April 4, when industrialist and anti-cholesterol crusader Phil Sokolof placed ads headlined ``The Poisoning of America!'' in The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal and several other papers. The ad asked McDonald's to reduce the fat in its hamburgers by 10 percent as a ``contribution toward lowering cholesterol levels for Americans.''

Chrysler Corp. Chairman Lee Iacocca was the only Big Three automaker chief executive who got a raise in 1989, pulling in $4 million, or 8.1 percent more than he collected in 1988, the company's proxy statement said. Earnings last year for the nation's No. 3 automaker were down 65.8 percent from the year before. Iacocca's compensation in 1989 salary, stock and bonuses earned from the year before, disclosed in the proxy statement Friday, topped the $2.5 million received by General Motors Corp. Chairman Roger B. Smith but was less than the $6.6 million awarded to Ford Motor Co. Chairman Donald E. Petersen, who retired March 1.

Trade negotiators ended talks without reaching an agreement on U.S. demands that Japan remove restrictions on imports of wood products but another round of discussions is planned. Lumber products trade is the only unresolved issue among three areas in which Washington has been seeking to remove trade barriers under a section of U.S. trade law known as ``Super 301.'' ``There are still significant differences in our positions,'' a U.S. official in Tokyo told reporters Friday.

The advertising agency Wells Rich Greene Inc. said it will sell a 40 percent stake to a French firm, BDDP, and join an international ad agency network in an effort to give its clients more worldwide services. In a separate development, Wells Rich founder Mary Wells Lawrence said she was stepping aside as chairman and chief executive and that the agency's board had elected Kenneth Olshan to succeed her. The privately-held Wells Rich Greene handles billings of about $850 million a year and its clients include International Business Machines Corp., Ford Motor Co., Procter & Gamble, Hertz and MCI Communications Corp.

Competition for students and drops in government support were the main reasons for huge tuition jumps at private and public colleges during the 1980s, says a new study. And while experts predict some relief in the 1990s, they say the price of higher education will still rise faster than inflation _ at least until the baby boom's babies start to hit college age.

A federal bankrupcty judge extended the deadline for General Development Corp.'s financing plan and ordered the troubled real estate giant to honor back paychecks. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge A. Jay Cristol on Friday gave General Development until Monday to present a short-term financial plan. He also scheduled a series of status hearings through May on the company, which pleaded guilty last month in connection with a scheme to sell overpriced homes.

The dollar was little changed in virtually motionless trading Friday as most world financial centers closed early for the Easter weekend. The nation's stock, bond, precious metals and commodity markets also were closed Friday.

DOC.TEXT: Here is how Tax Freedom Day has changed over the years. Tax Freedom Day is the Tax Foundation's way of dramatizing how Americans are affected by federal, state and local taxes. For 1990, the date is estimated to be May 5, meaning that if every dollar earned during the first part of the year were earmarked for taxes, the average worker would be paid up on May 5. The figures assume individuals pay all taxes, including those collected from corporations.

DOC.TEXT: International Business Machines Corp. said today its first quarter profit rose a better-than-expected 9 percent over a year ago as new products and healthy demand worldwide helped boost revenue. The computer giant netted $1.03 billion, or $1.81 per share, in the three months ended March 31. That compared with earnings of $950 million, or $1.61 a share, in 1989. Revenue was up 11 percent to $14.18 billion from $12.73 billion. The quarterly results exceeded expectations of most analysts, who had predicted earnings per share of between $1.35 and $1.70. IBM attributed the growth in earnings and revenue to continued healthy demand across the company's product line. ``Our strategy of listening to our customers and improving the competitivness of our products and services is working,'' Chairman John F. Akers said in a statement. ``We are encouraged by our first quarter results.'' Wall Street also appeared optimistic. In the first half hour of trading IBM soared $4 to $111.12{ a share in active trading on the New York Stock Exchange. ``The application of new technology to customers' business problems is really the key to IBM's future success,'' said Sam Albert, who runs the computer consulting firm Sam Albert Associates Inc. of Scarsdale, N.Y. ``Those applications are starting to pay off.'' In the first quarter, IBM introduced several additions to its product line, including its RISC System-6000, a series of workstations that offer power and solutions to scientists, engineers and other professions. IBM also fabricated the world's first 16 million bit memory chip at its Essex Junction, Vermont, facility during the quarter, and it agreed, among other things, to work with Siemens AG to jointly develop 64 million bit memory chips.
