DOC.HEAD: Rejects Arguments That Utility Customers OverGrand
DOC.TEXT: Gulf I nuclear plant near Port Gibson, Miss., a project that cost about six times more than original estimates. Middle South Utilities built the plant and ordered its subsidiaries to share in the financing. The costs then were passed on to consumers in the form of higher rates. Mississippi officials said consumers from their state are being forced to pay unfairly to help operate other nuclear plants in the Middle South Utilities system. That argument was rejected by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission when it adopted a rate formula for the four utilities. The formula was pegged to each utility's demand for electricity generated by the entire system. Mississippi officials said consumers there are helping pay for nuclear plants that supply no power to Mississippians. The U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals here last year upheld the commission's rate formula. The appeals court said the commission properly allocated costs by basing them on overall demand by each utility and by taking into account that consumers in one state benefit indirectly from the system's nuclear units that only serve customers in the other states. For example, the appeals court said, a nuclear plant in Arkansas produces extra power available to be used by utilities from the other states. The case is Mississippi vs. Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, 89-1041.

DOC.HEAD: Facing the Inevitable: It's Income Tax Day
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS new grafs 8-9, `This year ...' with state Tax Freedom Day; picks up 8th graf pvs, `The Foundation...' This also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Internal Revenue Service Form 4868 is one of the most-sought pieces of paper in the nation today as an estimated 6 million Americans abandon hopes of meeting the midnight deadline for filing a federal tax return. Filing a Form 4868, along with a check for estimated taxes owed, automatically extends the return deadline to Aug. 15. IRS offices and Postal Service branches in many parts of the country planned extra hours today to accommodate those who put off the inevitable. The IRS did not estimate how many couples and individuals were waiting until the last minute to file. But the agency predicted that about 34 million returns _ more than 30 percent of the 111 million expected this year _ would be filed April 7 or later. Residents of New England and New Yorkers who mail their returns to the IRS Service Center in Andover, Mass., have until midnight Tuesday because Monday is Patriots' Day, a state holiday in Massachusetts. As the 1989 return-filing season drew to a close, the Tax Foundation offered some sobering news: The average person will have to work 125 days this year _ through May 5 _ just to pay his or her share of federal, state and local taxes. That is the latest ever for the organization's ``Tax Freedom Day.'' Last year, the nonpartisan research organization put the date at May 3. It reached May 4 in 1981, before the across-the-board tax cuts voted that year took effect. This year the foundation calculated Tax Freedom Day in each state and found New Hampshire and South Dakota the earliest, April 19. Residents of the District of Columbia and New York will have to work through May 23 to settle their taxes. The state figures are influenced not only by state and local taxes but by personal incomes; those with higher incomes tend to have a later Tax Freedom Day. The foundation attributed the growing tax burden to new laws reducing itemized deductions, a Social Security tax increase that will cost workers more than $10 billion this year, boosts in state and local taxes, and a gradually slowing economy. ``The nation's nominal income is estimated to grow only 5.7 percent (in 1990) while the total tax take is projected to increase 7.2 percent,'' the organization said. Viewed from another perspective, the average worker will toil three minutes longer each day this year _ a total of 2 hours, 45 minutes of each eight-hour day _ to pay taxes. That is one minute longer for federal taxes and two minutes more for state and local. The foundation says more bad news may be on the way. ``The combined pressures of a persistent federal budget deficit, demands to expand funding for new and existing programs, budget crises in numerous states and the slowdown in income growth could easily make Tax Freedom Day even later on our calendars,'' the foundation said. The Tax Foundation calculations assume that individuals pay all taxes, including those collected from corporations. About eight of 10 tax returns filed so far this year have qualified for refunds, averaging more than $850 each. The IRS cautioned that taxpayers who owe but don't have the money to pay should not let that deter them from filing by the deadline, since that could result in separate penalties for failing to file on time and not paying on time. If you cannot pay, the IRS advises, file your return on time and attach a letter of explanation. You still may face a late payment penalty. Other tips for eleventh-hour filers: _About 14 percent of taxpayers are making mistakes on their returns. One of the most common is copying the wrong figure from the tax tables. Double-check your arithmetic. If a parent or someone else can claim you as a dependent, check the proper box. _If you do not itemize deductions, remember to write in your standard deduction. _Attach your W-2 forms and any schedules and supplemental forms in the proper sequence. You'll find the sequence number in the upper right corner, just under ``1989.'' _Your return will not be accepted if not signed; if it is a joint return, both spouses must sign. _Don't forget the correct postage. Use of the bar-coded IRS envelope expedites the mail and use of the gummed label on the front of your return could mean a quicker refund.

DOC.HEAD: Good Weather for Farmers Restrains Grain and Soybean Futures
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices dipped slightly in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade. Analysts said weather favoring farmers helped keep prices down, along with some follow-through selling after last week's relatively soft close. ``There was a lot of rain all over the Midwest during the long holiday weekend, and there's more expected later this week,'' said Victor Lespinasse, a grains trader for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in Chicago. The market was otherwise featureless, he said. ``The South American and European markets are still closed today for the Easter holiday, so we won't get any direction from them until tomorrow,'' Lespinasse said. In early trading, wheat was } cent lower to { cent higher, with the contract for delivery in May at $3.66\ a bushel; corn was \ cent to 1} cents lower, with May at $2.67} a bushel; oats were \ cent to 1\ cents lower, with May at $1.48} a bushel; and soybeans were 1 cent to 2} cents lower, with May at $5.84{ a bushel. DOC.HEAD: Upjohn Reports First-Quarter Increase
DOC.TEXT: Upjohn Co. on Monday said its first-quarter earnings increased by 10 percent over a year earlier as sales grew 3.7 percent. The Kalamazoo-based pharmaceutical manufacturer reported net earnings of $114.3 million, or 59 cents per share, for the three months ended March 31, up from $103.0 million, or 55 cents per share, in the first quarter of 1989. Worldwide sales totaled $772.9 million in the first quarter, up from $745.09 million in first three months of 1989. Pharmaceutical sales growth was led by Ansaid, a non-steroidal, anti-inflammatory agent. Rogaine, the treatment for male pattern baldness and Motrin IB, a non-prescription internal analgesic introduced in June 1989, contributed to U.S. growth, according to the company. Foreign pharmaceutical sales were down, the company said. ``Improvements in operating income and net earnings significantly exceeded the rate of sales growth as a result of cost-control measures instituted throughout 1989 and in the first quarter of 1990,'' Theodore Cooper, Upjohn chairman, president and chief executive officer, said in a news release.

DOC.HEAD: Torchmark Begins Calling for Proxies for American General Directors' Slate
DOC.TEXT: Torchmark Corp. began calling for proxies Monday for a slate of five independent nominees to American General Corp.'s board who face selection at the insurance and financial firm's annual meeting May 2. The action follows Thursday's ruling by the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals that stayed a preliminary injunction prohibiting Torchmark from soliciting proxies for directors. American General, based in Houston, has argued that nominees for the board had to be presented by March 3, or 20 days after it notified shareholders of its annual meeting. But the three-judge panel questioned the validity of the March 3 date since American General's Feb. 15 report did not mention vital information _ including the fact American General had expanded its board from 13 to 15 members and that shareholders were being asked to vote for six directors instead of four. Torchmark said Monday it had mailed the supplemental proxy materials to American General shareholders over the weekend. Proxy materials initially had been sent soliciting support for a non-binding resolution calling for the board to seek a sale or merger of American General. A spokesman for Torchmark said if the independent nominees are elected and the shareholder resolution is adopted, Torchmark intends to submit another bid for American General. The nominees on the proposed slate are Robert H. Allen, 62, of Houston, chairman of the board and chief executive officer of Realm Resources Inc.; David A. Finley, 67, of Bedford Hills, N.Y., former president of IBM Credit Corp.; C. Roderick O'Neil, 69, of Hartford, Conn., former chief investment officer of Travelers Insurance Co.; Clive Runnels, 64, of Houston, private investor; and John H. Young, 46, of Houston, president of John H. Young Inc., and president of Jefferson Pipeline Co.

DOC.HEAD: Higher Log, Chip Prices, Weak Paper Demand Send Profit Lower
DOC.TEXT: Weak demand for paper products coupled with higher prices for logs and wood chips sent Boise Cascade Corp.'s first-quarter profit plunging 57 percent, the company said Monday. The wood-products company said first-quarter earnings totaled $33.6 million, or 73 cents per share, down from $78.2 million, or $1.78 a share, in the January-March quarter a year ago. Sales were off fractionally to remain over $1 billion in the first quarter. ``The decline in first-quarter income was the result of continuing adverse market conditions for the company's paper business,'' Board Chairman John Fery said in a statement. He also said ``delivered-log costs for the company's building products segment were higher than those of the same period in 1989, particularly in the Pacific Northwest.'' Operating income from the company's paper segment, which has accounted for up to two-thirds of Boise Cascade's income, dropped to under $51 million in the first quarter of this year from nearly $127 million in the same period a year earlier. Fery said sluggish demand for most paper grades manufactured by the company along with higher prices for wood chips in the Pacific Northwest hurt results. Operating income from the building products segment slumped to $19.1 million from $22.1 million the previous year as log prices were up and lumber prices down, Fery said. The company said its office products segment reported record sales and operating income in the first quarter. Sales jumped 12 percent and income was up 16 percent on what Fery said was seasonally robust demand combined with increased corporate emphasis on operating efficiency. In the current quarter, Fery expects the office products business should be seasonally down while the building products business ``should show some improvement.'' ``Pricing in the company's pulp and paper business should show little change overall while we expect additional downtime associated with several paper mill capital projects and continued sluggish demand for some products,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Weekly Magazine 7 Days Stops Publication
DOC.TEXT: 7 Days, a weekly magazine that tried for two years to find a readership among affluent Manhattanites, has stopped publication, the magazine's owner announced Monday. The magazine had a circulation of 75,000 with 45,000 of those copies distributed free in wealthy areas. Local retail stores and real estate agents bought ads, but other local and national advertisers did not, dooming the large-format weekly. Negotiations to sell 7 Days were revealed last month, but no qualified buyer came forward, according to the principals. ``The 7 Days staff very quickly created a stylish, provocative and useful publication,'' said owner Leonard Stern. ``But magazine start-ups are always a risky business, and I'm deeply saddened that we couldn't generate the kind of advertising support that their professional efforts deserved.'' David Schneiderman, president of Stern Publications, said the current weakness of the Manhattan advertising market, ``coupled with the difficulty of obtaining national advertising with a limited circulation base, have made it impossible to continue publishing.'' Stern is the owner of Hartz Mountain, a diversified company that sells pet food and develops real estate. He also owns the Village Voice and Harmon Publications, which publishes 225 local real estate guides across the country.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also running on business wire; no other versions planned.
DOC.TEXT: The National, the sports daily that has been publishing editions in New York, Chicago and Los Angeles for 2{ months, plans to begin editions this summer in San Diego and San Francisco. Publisher Peter Price said Monday that he expects the San Diego edition to start by July 1. The San Francisco edition will be launched in July. Price said the newspaper plans to add at least one city a month during the last five months of the year, but he didn't name the cities. The National is currently distributing an average of about 350,000 newspapers a day, and selling more than 200,000 copies a day, Price said. He said the paper hopes to have editions in 10 to 12 cities by the end of the year with average circulation ``approaching 400,000.''

Grain and soybean futures prices advanced Monday at the Chicago Board of Trade, reversing an early retreat as rumors circulated about a possible Soviet wheat deal. Earlier in the day, prices dipped as wet weekend weather and a forecast for more rain in the Midwest sparked selling in the grain and bean pits, analysts said. But ``talk about the Russians possibly being in the market for wheat, 300,000 to 600,000 tons,'' encouraged a wave of buying, said Victor Lespinasse, a grains trader for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in Chicago. Concerns about the weather in the Midwest were tempered by bullish rains in Brazil that could curb the South American soybean harvest, he said. At the close, wheat was 2{ cents to 3 cents higher, with the contract for delivery in May at $3.69{ a bushel; corn was \ cent to 1} cents higher, with May at $2.69} a bushel; oats were 1 cent to 3\ cents higher, with May at $1.53 a bushel; and soybeans were 2{ cents to 4 cents higher, with May at $5.90 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: TJX Restates 1989 Earnings Because of Ames Troubles
DOC.TEXT: The TJX Cos. Inc. said Monday it would restate its 1989 financial results as a loss due to possible fallout from a 1988 deal with Ames Department Stores Inc. TJX sold the Zayre retail chain to Ames in 1988 in deal that included $200 million in stock. Ames, however, announced last week it lost an estimated $228 million in its most recent fiscal year. As a result, TJX said it would take a complete write-off on the stock, assigning no value to it. TJX also said it was setting aside reserves because the leases sold to Ames represent potential TJX said the action would result in a $172.1 liabilities. million charge, creating a net loss of $78.3 million or $1.10 per share for the fiscal year that ended Jan. 27. TJX, which operates T.J. Maxx and Hit or Miss stores around the country, originally reported 1989 earnings of $93.8 million, or $1.43 per share. Bernard Cammarata, president and chief executive officer of TJX, stressed in a statement that the company's ``operations are strong and are solid generators of capital.''

DOC.HEAD: Posts 19.7 Percent Profit Increase in 1st Qtr
DOC.TEXT: Eli Lilly & Co. reported Monday a 19.7 percent increase in its first-quarter earnings and an 18 percent increase in sales. The pharmaceutical company credited worldwide sales of its products, including the antidepressant Prozac, for the increase. The company said it earned $340.8 million, or $1.16 per share, in the first three months of 1990 compared with $284.7 million, or 99 cents a share, a year earlier. First-quarter sales rose to $1.24 billion from $1.05 billion a year ago.

DOC.HEAD: Citicorp Gets Jump On Interstate Banking
DOC.TEXT: Citicorp on Monday gave its 132 California branches the flagship Citibank name. The nation's largest banking concern, which is based in New York, had been forced to keep its California operations separate since it began operating in the state in 1982 after acquiring San Francisco-based Fidelity Savings. But the barriers came down in last year's thrift bailout law, known as the Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery and Enforcement Act, or FIRREA. California is not allowing the big commercial banks from New York inside its borders until 1991. But Citicorp does not fall under that restriction because its state operations are chartered as a savings and loan, formerly known as Citicorp Savings. The Citibank branches in California are now able to sell retail banking services to state residents who already conduct business with the company through its New York headquarters. One example of the new freedom is the right for California branches to contact the 1.5 million residents who have a Citibank credit card and attempt to sign them up for a checking or savings account. The old regulations meant that the savings branches in California could not cross-market to any customers with the New York branches. The rigorous regulations forced Citicorp to hire an independent electronic network to allow its California customers the use of automatic teller machines in New York. ``There were a lot of people in California who didn't know that Citicorp Savings was part of the largest bank in the United States,'' said David A. Brooks, in charge of Citicorp's consumer banking in the West. ``It's the end of a disadvantage for Citicorp,'' said Donald K. Crowley, an analyst with Keefe, Bruyette and Woods in San Francisco. ``They are now in position to bring more of their consumer products and muscle to California.''

DOC.HEAD: Chase, Manufacturers Hanover Profits Down; J.P. Morgan Up
DOC.TEXT: Chase Manhattan Corp. and Manufacturers Hanover Corp. said Monday that their first quarter earnings declined over a year ago, while another large banking company, J.P. Morgan & Co., reported higher profit. All three banks, however, continued to feel the pinch of the Third World debt problem. Chase Manhattan said it netted $44 million, or 20 cents per share, for the first three months of 1990, down 66 percent from $132 million, or $1.27 a share, earned in 1989. Manufacturers Hanover said net income declined 6.8 percent to $96 million, or $1.21 per share, from $103 million, or $1.84 per share, in 1989. The 1990 quarter reflects issuance of more than 18 million shares of new stock last year. J.P. Morgan's quarterly earnings more than doubled to $399 million, or $2.09 per share, from $180 million, or 96 cents, in the same period last year. Chase said its earnings were hurt by a $75 million increase in provisions for losses from bad loans, mostly because of deterioration in some U.S commercial real estate markets. The company added $225 million to reserves against possible loan losses in the first quarter, up from $150 million a year ago and $130 million in the 1989 fourth quarter. ``If economic conditions in domestic commercial real estate markets deteriorate further, it is likely that the provision for possible credit losses will continue at relatively high levels,'' Chase said in a statement. Total loan loss reserves at Chase on March 31 were $3.19 billion, including $2.35 billion to developing countries, compared with $2.73 billion a year ago. The bank said it wrote off $325 million in bad loans in the quarter, including $114 million to Third World countries, up from a total of $159 million in the year-ago period. Manufacturers Hanover said it wrote off $246 million in loans to developing countries in the quarter, compared with $10 million a year ago, and $73 million for other loans, down from $89 million. The bad foreign loans included debt exchanges on loans to Mexico and Argentina. Manufactures Hanover said it added $73 million to its loan loss reserves in the quarter, down from $87 million a year earlier. Its total reserve against bad loans was $2.43 billion as of March 31, including $1.97 billion for loans to developing countries. Those figures were up from $2.21 billion and $1.68 billion, respectively, in the 1989 quarter. J.P. Morgan attributed its gain largely to increases in revenue from trading, investment management and other services. But it said net interest revenue was down 11 percent mainly because it received no interest on loans to Brazil in the quarter. The company said it increased its reserve against loan loasses to $2.35 billion from $1.49 billion a year earlier. The bank said it had $3.1 billion in outstanding loans to developing counties, down from $4.6 billion a year earlier. The bank added $10 million to its loan loss reserves in the quarter, same as in the year-ago period. J.P. Morgan also reported $265 million in losses from the sale or exchange of Third World loans in the first quarter.
Stock prices turned mixed today as Wall Street retraced its steps following a broad advance. Five minutes before the close, the Dow Jones industrial average was up 5.41 to 2,757.21.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Give Up Broad Advance, Close Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Prices closed mixed on Wall Street today as the stock market was unable to sustain a broad advance prompted by a better-than-expected earnings report from International Business Machines Corp. IBM reported first-quarter earnings of $1.03 billion, or $1.81 per share, up 9 percent from $950 million, or $1.61 a share, a year earlier. Revenue was up 11 percent to $14.18 billion from $12.73 billion. The results surpassed most analysts' predictions of earnings per share of between $1.35 and $1.70. Investors, who are generally buoyed by good earnings reports, moved into the market enthusisastically at the opening after hearing the news. Big Blue's announcement dispelled some concerns that corporate profits for the first quarter would be disappointing. The stock market has been held in check in recent months because of companies' poor results in 1989. But Wall Street couldn't hold its gains. Secondary stocks began to lose ground while blue chips remained higher for much of the day, but program selling finally eroded the Dow Jones industrial average's advance during the last hour.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Steelworkers Protest Sluggish Wheeling-Pittsburgh Contract Talks
DOC.TEXT: About 50 steelworkers waved signs and black flags outside Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corp. headquarters Monday to protest sluggish contract negotiations on the fifth anniversary of the company's bankruptcy. ``It's April 16th, a day of mourning,'' said Galvie Gardner, one of the demonstrators and president of United Steelworkers Union Local 1187 at Wheeling-Pitt's Allenport, Pa., plant. ``Five years of working for substandard wages,'' Gardner said. Most of the steelworkers wore black armbands and some carried signs aimed at Wheeling-Pittsburgh executives that read ``Restore Our Standard of Living,'' and ``We Helped You _ Now You Help Us.'' The steelworkers union buttressed the protest with $4,638 in full-page newspaper advertisements in four newspapers. ``The ad and the protest are both for the same purpose,'' said Dick Fontana, a spokesman at the union's headquarters in Pittsburgh. ``We want to protest the lack of progress in the negotiations.'' ``Our wages and benefits have been frozen at low levels for five long years,'' said the ad, signed by USW International President Lynn Williams, district directors representing USW locals in Ohio, Pennsylvania and West Virginia, and the presidents of 11 union locals. ``And Wheeling-Pitt and its creditors demand that we agree to be frozen into second-class status for three more years,'' the advertisement said. ``That's not right.'' Wheeling-Pittsburgh filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code on April 16, 1985. Contract talks between the steelworkers and the company stalled in February when the union accused Wheeling-Pittsburgh of refusing to file an amended reorganization plan. On Monday, lawyers representing the groups discussed amendments to the reorganization plan proposed by unsecured creditors and supported by the company. The steelworkers have been working under terms of a concessionary contract they accepted after a 98-day strike that ended about six months after the company filed for bankruptcy. That contract is to remain in effect until 10 days after a reorganization plan is confirmed by U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Warren Bentz in Pittsburgh. The steelmaker filed its plan on April 3 along with a plan drafted by Goldman Sachs & Co., a New York investment firm. Lawyers representing the company, the unsecured creditors, and Goldman Sachs told the bankruptcy court last week they had reached a compromise more favorable to shareholders.

DOC.HEAD: Accounting Firm Plans Layoffs, Profit Pay-Out Cuts
DOC.TEXT: The accounting firm of Laventhol & Horvath, hit by costly litigation payments, is cutting profit pay-outs and personnel, but its executive partner-elect said Monday that business was generally strong. Robert N. Levine said layoffs were following the usual accounting industry pattern of spring cuts and fall hiring. ``That's the cycle. Our cycle is no different this year than it's been in past years,'' he said. He declined to say how many people would be laid off, but said it would be no more than usual _ ``certainly below 10 percent.'' ``We look at productivity and performance when we make these cuts,'' he said. ``We don't look at a number.'' The firm, seventh largest accounting concern in the country, has been hit hard by lawsuits in recent years alleging poor work, leading to large payments. Levine said a quarterly profit pay-out to partners in April _ to pay taxes _ was cut in half because litigation payments reduced taxable income and tax liabilities. ``We reduced that payment accordingly,'' Levine said, but added that the firm plans to increase 12 monthly profit pay-outs this year. Laventhol has 425 partners, 3,500 professional staffers and 1,200 administrative workers in 51 offices nationwide. Levine officially becomes executive partner June 1 but is running the firm's operations now. Revenue for the fiscal year ending Jan. 31 was $345 million, up 5.2 percent from the previous year, he said. Operating profit, not counting litigation costs, was down 9 percent from a year ago. He said the firm took on two major clients this month that would be the top two clients in terms of fees and number of staff serving them. He would not name the clients. ``I'm looking forward to the best year we ever had,'' Levine said. He said reports of hard times for the firm came from ``jealous competitors.'' Laventhol settled a class-action lawsuit in December with investors in several fraudulent limited partnerships for which it prepared audited financial statements. Insurance covered only $4.4 million of the $13.5 million settlement. A settlement in October with nine creditor banks stemming from a holding-company bankruptcy proceeding cost the firm $30 million, of which $20 million was covered. In 1988, it paid $15 million to settle an anti-racketeering suit. That was covered by insurance, he said. Besides the profit pay-out cut and layoffs, the company is offering early retirement to some partners. ``We're seeking greater productivity and are streamlining our firm,'' he said. According to Bowman's Accounting Report, revenue growth for major firms slowed to 12.8 percent in 1989 from 17.25 percent a year earlier. ``I think that the industry as a whole, just as American business as a whole, has been tightening up and everyone is scrambling to be prodcutive,'' Levine said.

DOC.HEAD: Futures Close Higher
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures finished higher Monday as fresh buying emerged after last week's sharp selloff. Oil prices also got a boost from news that ministers from three OPEC countries would meet informally Tuesday to discuss the weakness in world markets due to an abundance of crude. The heaviest buying occurred in the unleaded gasoline pits on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The contract for May delivery of unleaded gasoline jumped 1.66 cents to 60.21 cents a gallon, more than making up for a loss of 1.03 cents on Thursday, the last previous day of trading. Markets were closed for the Good Friday holiday. Contracts for delivery further in the future also ended with substantial gains. Among other refined petroleum products traded on the Merc, home heating oil for May delivery rose 0.89 to 54.72 cents a gallon, adding to Thursday's increase of 0.20 cent. Later contracts posted slightly smaller advances. The May contract of West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, edged up 7 cents to $17.85 a 42-gallon barrel after retreating 28 cents on Thursday. The June, July and August crude contracts had stronger increases. Meanwhile, natural gas for June delivery settled at $1.598 per million British thermal units, the same as Thursday's close. The July and August contracts also ended unchanged. Much of the renewed buying Monday appeared to be technical in nature and didn't reflect a shift in sentiment toward the energy market, analysts said. In particular, the gasoline buying was attributed to short covering as market participants bought to compensate for previous selling. A report that oil ministers from Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates would meet in Jiddah, Saudi Arabia, on Tuesday offered some encouragment to oil traders worried about the impact plentiful oil supplies are having on prices. The Saudi Press Agency quoted the Saudi Oil Minister Hisham Nazer as saying the meeting would take place. He also expressed concern about some OPEC members violating the cartel's oil production quotas. It was Saudi Arabia's first official response to last week's wild price swings. But the positive reaction to the news was blunted by the belief that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is not about to enact a sweeping cut in production to shore up prices. ``Nothing's really happened fundamentally to change the market around,'' said energy analyst James Steel at Refco Inc. ``There's no real reason to reverse the downtrend just because these three oil ministers are meeting.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up, Gold Down
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose against major foreign currencies Monday in quiet post-holiday trading. Gold and silver prices declined. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery closed at $375.20 a troy ounce, down 70 cents from late Thursday. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $374.60 an ounce, off 65 cents. Silver fell on the Comex to $5.059 a troy ounce from $5.091 Thursday. Precious metals and currency markets were closed in Europe on Friday and Monday for the Easter holiday. The New York metals market was closed on Friday but trading resumed Monday, while currency markets in New York were open both days. Dealers said the dollar started out strong as the market speculated the February trade data, due out Wednesday, would show improvement in the U.S. trade deficit. A strong trade report will likely strengthen the dollar on currency markets. However, dealers said the dollar fell off its highs for the day largely on profit-taking. In Tokyo, where global trading begins, the dollar closed at 159.42 Japanese yen, up from Friday's 158.42 yen. Later, in New York, the dollar stood at 159.30 yen, up from 158.705 yen late Friday. In New York, one British pound cost $1.63035, down from $1.63675 Friday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's quotes, included: 1.6778 West German marks, up from 1.6722; 1.4900 Swiss francs, up from 1.4835; 5.6365 French francs, up from 5.6195; 1,232.50 Italian lire, up from 1,230.25; and 1.16885 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1645.

DOC.HEAD: 1st-Qtr Profit Up 62 Percent at Primerica, 15 Percent at Smith Barney Unit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS graf after 5th graf pvs, `Primerica reported... to UPDATE with closing stock price; PICKS UP 6th graf pvs, `The rise...
DOC.TEXT: Primerica Corp. said Monday its first-quarter earnings rose 62 percent, including a 14.9 percent gain at its Wall Street subsidiary, Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. Analysts said the rise at Smith Barney was strong during a slowdown in the securities industry, and that worse results were expected at other firms. Smith Barney was the first brokerage to report first-quarter earnings. Smith Barney reported it had a profit of $13.1 million on revenue of $384 million in the quarter ended March 31, up from a profit of $11.4 million on revenue of $291 million in the same 1989 quarter. Overall, Primerica, a diversified financial company, reported earnings of $83.2 million, or 73 a share, on revenue of $1.44 billion. That compared with net income of $51.4 million, or 53 cents a share, on revenue of $1.24 billion in the same period a year ago. Primerica reported earnings increases of 21 percent in its consumer finance division and 37 percent in its insurance services business, which includes A.L. Williams and Gulf Insurance. In New York Stock Exchange trading Monday, Primerica rose 75 cents to close at $30.25. The rise at Smith Barney comes during a prolonged slump in Wall Street business, including retail brokerage activity and investment banking services such as stock and bond underwriting. ``If they had a good quarter I think that's notable,'' said Lawrence Eckenfelder, who follows the industry for Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. in San Francisco. ``I don't think you're going to see too many of the other firms show that kind of a gain.'' Because Smith Barney is a subsidiary of a larger corporation, analysts have difficulty tracking its business in detail. Primerica said in a statement that Smith Barney's results ``reflected good performance in most businesses, particularly in retail brokerage, asset management and investment banking.'' In a sign of better retail brokerage activity, Primerica said Smith Barney benefitted from the acquisition of 16 retail offices of collapsed Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. last May. Analysts said individual investment activity for the first quarter was better than in the same 1989 period.

DOC.HEAD: Alcoa Reports 46 Percent Earnings Drop
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lede to show Brazilian affiliate's results declined by $36 million from a year ago, not that it lost $36 million. Picks up 2nd graf, Alcoa, the ...
DOC.TEXT: The Aluminum Company of America said Monday its earnings plunged 46 percent in the first quarter and blamed the decrease in part on a $36 million decline in results from its Brazilian affiliate. Alcoa, the world's largest aluminum producer, said earnings also suffered because of reduced shipments of fabricated products and a drop in prices for those items and for ingots. The company said increased sales of ingot also contributed to the slump. For the first quarter, Alcoa reported earnings of $148.6 million, or $1.69 a share, on sales of $2.6 billion. That compared with earnings in the first quarter of 1989 of $276 million, or $3.12 per share, on sales of $2.6 billion. Alcoa Chairman Paul H. O'Neill said the company's share of earnings from Brazilian affiliate Alcoa Aluminio was ``at break-even'' the first quarter of this year. During the same period of 1989, Brazilian earnings for Alcoa amounted to $36 million, he said. ``Alcoa's order rates in March were better than in recent months,'' O'Neill said in a statement. ``Given the softness in the economy, we are pleased by the level of first quarter earnings.'' O'Neill said Alcoa expects its earnings from the Brazilian venture to be hurt throughout the year. But he said the company expects to benefit in the long run from measures being taken to curb rampant inflation in the country.

DOC.HEAD: IBM Posts Higher-Than-Expected Income
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf pvs, IBM was ..., with two grafs to UPDATE with market closing. Picks up 7th graf pvs, Don Young ... SUBS 12 graf pvs, Still, market ..., to reflect close
DOC.TEXT: International Business Machines Corp. helped give the stock market a boost Monday after reporting a better-than-expected 9 percent jump in first quarter earnings over a year ago. The world's biggest computer company, considered a bellwether stock on Wall Street, said continued worldwide demand for its product line resulted in stronger revenue and higher profits. Some analysts said the improvement was partly a rebound from a depressed first quarter 1989, when IBM experienced shipment problems in its mainframe computer line. For the three months ended March 31, IBM earned $1.03 billion, or $1.81 per share, compared with a profit of $950 million, or $1.61 a share, in 1989. Revenue rose 11 percent to $14.18 billion from $12.73 billion. IBM's results exceeded expectations of most analysts, who were predicting earnings per share of between $1.35 and $1.70. IBM had been forecasting $1.55 to $1.65 a share profit, some analysts said. IBM closed up $3.75 to $110.87{ a share Monday in active composite trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The rise in IBM, considered one of the most heavily weighted stocks in the Dow Jones industrial average of 30 blue-chip companies, helped boost the Dow by 11.26 to 2,763.06. Without it, the Dow, which rose as much as 41 points before giving back some of its gains, would have been little changed, analysts said. Don Young, a computer analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Co., called IBM's quarterly revenue gain its best in several years. He also noted that operating income was up 33 percent to $2.13 billion from $1.60 billion. Expenses, led by higher income taxes, rose to $12.04 billion from $11.12 billion. But Young stopped short of predicting a major turnaround for IBM, which has seen its earnings and stock performance weaken in recent years. The world's largest computer maker was hurt by the dollar's volatility and the company's difficulty in making transitions to new products. It also has faced slow growth in demand for its big mainframe computers, which were being overtaken by speedy personal computers and workstations. William J. Milton Jr., a computer analyst with Brown Brothers Harriman, agreed it was too early to say IBM had turned the corner for good: ``IBM has said nothing about a resurgence. We do know from dealer surveys in recent months that IBM has been gaining market share in its personal computer share. As far as demand for other products ... we don't know.'' He said in the year-ago quarter IBM's earnings were depressed because a chip problem caused a delay in shipment of mainframe computers, the biggest and most profitable part of IBM's product line. Still, market observers said Monday's results helped push blue-chip stocks higher by dispelling worries that first quarter corporate profits would be widely disappointing. IBM's results are among the first of a deluge of first-quarter earnings reports expected over the next several days. Analyst say the reports could have a major impact on the stock market in the near term. IBM Chairman John F. Akers said he was encouraged by the latest results. ``Our strategy of listening to our customers and improving the competitiveness of our products and services is working,'' he said in a statement. ``We are focusing our investments to take advantage of the opportunities in our industry, and we are streamlining our operations while we improve our product line.'' In the first quarter, IBM introduced several products. Among them were its RISC System-6000, workstations aimed at capturing a share of the small but fast-growing market for such machines. The new machines have garnered favorable comments from industry analysts, who called them impressive for their performance, pricing and features. ``The application of new technology to customers' business problems is really the key to IBM's future success,'' said Sam Albert, who runs the computer consulting firm Sam Albert Associates Inc. of Scarsdale, N.Y. ``Those applications are starting to pay off.''

DOC.HEAD: Control Data Board Chairman Price Says Won't Seek Re-Election
DOC.TEXT: Control Data Corp. Chairman Robert M. Price said Monday he will not stand for re-election to the company's board of directors at the company's May 2 annual meeting. Price said his decision not to stand for re-election ``is best for the company,'' but did not elaborate. He continues as a consultant under a three-year contract that pays him $450,000 annually. Price was replaced as chief executive in January by Lawrence Perlman after the company posted a net loss of $680.4 million in 1989. He retired as a Control Data employee on March 15, and came under fire for entering retirement with a $4.24 million severance package after his four-year reign yielded $923.9 million in net losses and thousands of layoffs. The 1989 financial report released by Control Data in March said the company laid off 7,750 employees last year. ``Control Data has been through a tumultuous period,'' Price said in a statement announcing that he will not seek re-election. ``For the past decade, the computer industry has undergone fundamental and irreversible change. For many enterprises, that has been fatal. ``For Control Data, the task of reshaping the company so that it has the potential for future profitability and growth has been long, difficult and painful,'' he said. ``It is clear that, under current circumstances, my decision to withdraw from active management at this time is best for the company.'' Price, 60, joined Control Data in 1961 as a computer programmer. He became close to founder William Norris and replaced him in 1986 as chairman and chief executive. Price will not be replaced on the company's board, and the size of the board will be reduced at the annual meeting to 10 directors, the company said. Proxies will not be voted for Price since he will no longer be a board nominee, Control Data said, adding that no new chairman will be named at this time. Shareholders of record were being notified of the change, the company said. ``Bob Price has served Control Data with commitment and loyalty for almost 30 years,'' Perlman said. ``He has many contributions yet to make to the community in the areas of quality and of educational and technology policy.'' Control Data is a provider of data solutions that integrate hardware, software and services to meet customers' complex data collection, processing and communications needs.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Close Mixed After Giving Up Early Gains
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Prices closed mixed on Wall Street Monday after the stock market was unable to hold on to a broad advance prompted by a better-than-expected earnings report from International Business Machines Corp. The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 11.26 at 2,763.06 after having been up more than 41 points early in the session. Declining issues ran slightly ahead of advancers in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 714 up, 778 down and 510 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 142.81 million shares, slightly higher than 142.47 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 173.64 million shares. The market surged higher at the opening after IBM reported first-quarter earnings of $1.03 billion, or $1.81 per share, up 9 percent from $950 million, or $1.61 a share, a year earlier. Revenue was up 11 percent to $14.18 billion from $12.73 billion. The results surpassed most analysts' predictions of earnings per share of between $1.35 and $1.70. Investors moved into the market enthusiastically after hearing the news _ Big Blue's announcement dispelled some concerns that corporate profits for the first quarter would be disappointing. The stock market has been held in check in recent months because of companies' poor results in 1989. The Dow Jones average was up by around 25 points for much of the day, although the broader market began to retreat. Then, in the last hour, program selling brought prices even lower. Dennis Jarrett, an analyst with Kidder Peabody & Co., said Monday's performance reflected the continuing trend of a ``two-tier'' market, in which traders have more confidence in blue chip stocks than in the secondary issues. Jarrett said a strong performance by IBM accounted for as much as 9 points of the Dow Jones average's advance _ meaning the average would have been little changed without the computer giant's gain. IBM led the NYSE most-active list, rising 3} to 110~. Earnings reports also affected the performance of other stocks. Eli Lilly tumbled 1\ to 67\ after releasing first-quarter profit figures that fell short of analysts' forecasts. Banking stocks fell after reporting their first-quarter earnings declined. Chase Manhattan fell 1| to 27} and J.P. Morgan slipped } to 34}. Among blue chip issues, AT&T was unchanged at 41~, Philip Morris rose ] to 42], and General Electric gained } to 66}. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market rose $2.917 billion, or 0.09 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 0.14 to 188.94. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 0.46 to 400.42, and S&P's 500-stock composite index picked up 0.40 to close at 344.74. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market rose 0.39 to 436.70. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 356.98, off 0.90.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Futures Rise Before OPEC Meeting
DOC.TEXT: Crude oil futures prices rallied Monday on the eve of an OPEC meeting called to address the market's recent steep declines. Home heating oil and unleaded gasoline prices also rose in trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange. On other markets, grain and soybean futures prices advanced; cattle and precious metals futures declined; and pork prices were mixed. OPEC's monitoring committee meeting Tuesday in Saudi Arabia was not expected to produce major action. But traders anticipated the 13-nation cartel's ministers may take some move toward ``taming market declines,'' said Peter Beutel, head of the energy group at Elders Futures Inc. in New York. The meeting, to be followed by a full OPEC session next month, stems from a 33 percent drop in oil futures prices between January and last Thursday, Beutel said. ``It's possible they may make commitments to cut some sort of production,'' but major cuts are not anticipated, Beutel said. West Texas intermediate crude oil settled 7 cents to 25 cents higher, with the contract for delivery in May at $17.85 a barrel. The May contract for the key grade of U.S. crude declined 28 cents Thursday. Heating oil settled .20 cent to .89 cent higher, with May at 54.72 cents a gallon, while unleaded gasoline settled .60 cent to 1.66 cents higher, with May at 60.21 cents a gallon. A possible Soviet purchase of 300,000 to 600,000 tons of U.S wheat sent prices higher at the Chicago Board of Trade and helped ease early weather-related pressure, analysts said. Traders' initial concerns about a bearish forecast for more rain in the Midwest were tempered by wet weather in Brazil that could curb the South American soybean harvest, said Victor Lespinasse, a grains trader for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in Chicago. Wheat settled 3{ cents to 4} cents higher, with the contract for delivery in May at $3.70{ a bushel; corn was 2\ cents to 4 cents higher, with May at $2.72\ a bushel; oats were 3\ cents to 3} cents higher; and soybeans settled 4\ cents to 5{ cents higher, with May at $5.91 cents a bushel. Cattle prices declined and pork futures prices were mixed in trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. The cattle market was hit by liquidations and profit-motivated selling by traders wary of the record-high price of the April live cattle contract, 80.55 cents a pound, said Chuck Levitt of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. in Chicago. ``Whenever the market moves into that historical high ground, people get nervous about pushing it that much further,'' he said. The price reflects a tight supply of market-ready cattle that is expected to continue at least through the end of the month, Levitt said. High prices in the pork complex also caused some jitters, he said. Live cattle settled .13 cent to .35 cent lower, with the contract for delivery in April at 80.07 cents a pound; feeder cattle settled .25 cent lower to .10 cent higher, with April at 84.10 cents a pound; live hogs settled .45 cent lower to .10 cent higher, with April at 56.15 cents a pound; and frozen pork bellies settled .15 cent lower to .22 cent higher, with May at 59.17 cents a pound. Gold and silver prices at New York's Commodity Exchange fell in lackluster trading reflecting the early strength of the U.S. dollar, analysts said. Gold futures prices settled 70 cents to 90 cents lower, with the April contract at $375.20 a troy ounce. Silver prices settled 3.2 cents to 3.7 cents lower, with the April contract at $5.059 a troy ounce.

DOC.HEAD: Zenith Says French Company to Pay Additional $15 Million
DOC.TEXT: Zenith Electronics Corp. said Monday that the French company Groupe Bull had agreed to pay an additional $15 million plus interest for Zenith's computer products business. That brought the final sale price to about $511 million. When Zenith sold the business to Paris-based Groupe Bull on Dec. 28, it received an advance payment of $496.4 million in cash, effectively closing the sale of Zenith Data Systems. Zenith said in a statement that 30 days of negotiations led to the agreement for Groupe Bull to pay the additional money. Groupe Bull had contended earlier that post-closing adjustments should result in a refund from Zenith of about $49 million, while Zenith contended Groupe Bull still owed it an additional payment. The dispute would have been submitted to arbitration if the companies had not reached an agreement. Zenith said its first-quarter results for fiscal 1990 would reflect a charge to discontinued operations of about $11 million, because the negotiated final payment was less than the net receivable that Zenith had recorded on its books at year end. On Oct. 2, Zenith had announced an agreement to sell the computer unit to Bull for $91.9 million plus the adjusted net book value of the assets sold, for a total that Zenith initially estimated at $635 million and later lowered to an estimated $610 million. No one answered the telephone at Groupe Bull's U.S. offices in Billerica, Mass., on Monday.

DOC.HEAD: 1st-Qtr Profit Down at E.W. Scripps; Up at Scripps Howard Broadcasting
DOC.TEXT: The E.W. Scripps Co. said Monday its first-quarter earnings fell 36 percent, while its 80.4 percent-owned subsidiary, Scripps Howard Broadcasting Co., said its profit rose 78 percent. E.W. Scripps, which owns 19 newspapers, earned $9.7 million, or 13 cents per share, for the quarter ending March 31 compared with $15.1 million, or 19 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue edged up to $297.5 million from $294.9 million a year earlier. In the publishing division, Scripps reported that advertising revenues declined 2.3 percent to $120 million. ``The weakness in newspaper advertising, which had been with us throughout 1989, accelerated in the first quarter,'' president and chief executive Lawrence A. Leser said. ``Advertising revenues and volume softened seriously in March.'' Revenue from the licensing of comic characters declined $1.1 million, to $15.9 million, which the company attributed to growing strength of the U.S. dollar against foreign currencies. Scripps is the worldwide syndicator and licenser of comics including ``Peanuts'' and ``Garfield.'' Operating income from publishing fell to $20.3 million from $29.3 million. Scripps reported its operating income from broadcasting rose 6.8 percent to $10.2 million, while operating income from cable television was unchanged at $4.5 million. Scripps Howard Broadcasting, meanwhile, reported it earned $3.3 million, or 32 cents per share, in the first quarter compared with $1.9 million, or 18 cents, for the same period of 1989. Revenue rose to $71.6 million from $68 million a year earlier. Scripps Howard attributed the improvement to higher operating income from cable and broadcast television operations and a $1.2 million decrease in interest expenses. Scripps Howard owns nine television stations, five radio stations and operates cable systems with 231,000 basic subscribers.

DOC.HEAD: Investors Ask Continuances in Insurance Hearings on Takeover Bid
DOC.TEXT: The investor group attempting a hostile takeover of BAT Industries PLC asked for continuances Monday in deliberations under way in six states on its bid for California-based Farmers Insurance Group. The sale of Farmers to France's Axa-Midi Assurances is a key element of Hoylake Investments Ltd.'s strategy in its proposed $21 billion takeover of BAT, Britain's largest conglomerate. California state insurance regulators rejected the proposed acquisition April 9, balking at Axa-Midi's proposal to finance its $4.5 billion offer for Farmers entirely with borrowed funds. ``This brief hold will allow us to adjust our transaction to answer the concerns expressed by U.S. regulators,'' said Claude Bebear, chairman and chief executive officer of Axa-Midi. Motions for continuance were filed Monday in Illinois and Idaho. Illinois has conducted the most extensive review of the planned acquisition, holding about 40 days of hearings and compiling more than 10,000 pages of testimony and depositions. Similar applications will be filed in Oregon, California and Washington, where hearings have been held, and in Texas where a hearing is under way, an Axa-Midi spokesman said. Insurance departments in Arizona, Kansas and Ohio also planned hearings on the proposal. The Hoylake takeover bid was announced in July by an investor group led by Sir James Goldsmith, British investment banker Jacob Rothschild and Australian entrpreneur Kerry Packer. The acquisition would be the biggest British takeover and rival the record $25 billion buyout of RJR Nabisco Inc. by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Co. in 1989 as the biggest anywhere. Hoylake has said it intends to break up the London-based BAT, which has interests in tobacco, financial services, retailing and paper.

DOC.HEAD: Ford: Brazilian Uncertainty Could Hurt Earnings
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co. said Monday that continued uncertainty over Brazil's economic situation could hurt the automaker's earnings. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Ford said it has halted production temporarily at Autolatina, its joint venture with Volkswagen in Argentina and Brazil. Ford cited a ``liquidity shortage'' stemming from a recent reform package proposed by Brazil's new president that includes price and wage freezes as well as tax increases for the stoppage. Ford said that although Brazil's Congress must approve the package this month, details ``remain uncertain and change daily.'' ``Uncertainty about further government action and a liquidity shortage resulting from the economic reform package have caused Autolatina to halt production temporarilly and to defer all non-essential expenditures,'' Ford said. ``Continuation of the present economic situation in Brazil could have a substantial adverse effect on Ford's earnings,'' the document said. Ford owns 49 percent of Autolatina. The disclosure came in a filing by Ford's Dutch subsidiary, Ford Capital B.V., seeking SEC permission to offer $500 million in debt securities from time to time. Ford owns 99 percent of Ford Capital B.V., which is to serve as a financing vehicle for Ford. Proceeds from the debt securities may be used to help refinance short-term debt Ford incurred acquiring Jaguar PLC, the British luxury carmaker, for $2.5 billion last year. Ford's 1989 earnings, $3.2 billion on sales of $82.9 billion, were down $1.4 billion from the previous year. While automotive earnings outside the United States were down 3 percent, to $2.1 billion, from 1988, earnings were higher in the Asia-Pacific and Latin American markets, according to the SEC filing. No specific figures were given for either region. Ford has said it anticipates it will increase borowings in 1990.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Approves Interim Finance Plan For GDC
DOC.TEXT: A federal bankruptcy judge on Monday approved a plan that allows troubled General Development Corp. to receive $10.5 million in temporary financing for six weeks until it can arrange permanent financing. General Development already owes $175 million to the eight banks who guaranteed the interim financing, according to a schedule submitted Monday to U.S. Bankruptcy Judge A.J. Cristol. Each bank will put up a proportionate amount of the $10.5 million, based on the total owed to them, under the plan submitted by attorneys for GDC and the banks and approved by Cristol. General Development filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy April 6, claiming a severe cash shortage after failing to secure $60 million in short-term credit. Cristol heard objections from lawyers representing property owners from all over the United States, who objected to a clause in the agreement under which GDC had to give the subscribing banks liens on the properties. But lawyers for the property owners appeared satisfied when they were assured by attorneys for GDC and the banks that those who had paid in full for their property _ believed to number about 12,000 _ would not be encumbered with a bank lien when their deeds are delivered. But they were reminded that, as previously agreed, the property owners might not get the same lot they paid for, but might get one of equal or greater value in a portion of the development already built. The company is not involved in property improvements for the time being. Attorneys for other property owners appeared skeptical. ``If everybody works together, this thing will work,'' the judge told them. ``The alternative is to see everything swept away.'' The financing arrangement will expire June 1 and under the proposal: ``It will be secured by a lien on all of GDC's assets including the collateral and all other real and personal property ...'' The collateral is identified as accounts receivable, payments from property owners, real estate and fixtures, mortgages, contracts and stock and various subsidiaries of General Development. Cristol directed that the banks participating in the new $10.5 million temporary loan should not be permitted to ``enhance their position'' in relation to other creditors. Cristol's order says, in part: ``Among other things, entry of this order will minimize the disruption of GDC's businesses and operations as going concerns and will increase the possibility of a successful reorganization. ``The entry of this order appears to be in the best interest of the debtors, their creditors and the estates.''

DOC.HEAD: Rockwell Net Down 36 Pct Due to Division Sale in 1989
DOC.TEXT: Rockwell International Corp. said earnings fell 36 percent in its fiscal second quarter because of a big gain on the sale of its meter and valve business in the year-earlier period. Earnings would have been up 4 percent in the three months ended March 31 without the one-time gain a year earlier, the company said Monday, as increased operating earnings from electronics and graphics business more than offset declines in aerospace and automotive business. ``Our results for the first six months were better than we anticipated when the fiscal year began,'' Chairman Donald R. Beall said. The company expects a modest increase in earnings-per-share for the full year, not counting the effects of last year's divisional sale. In the latest quarter, Rockwell earned $173.4 million, or 70 cents a share, compared with $270.7 million, or $1.04 a share, in the same period a year earlier. The year-earlier net included a gain of $104 million, or 40 cents a share, from the sale of the meter and valve division. Revenue dipped slightly to $3.15 billion from $3.16 billion. For the first half of the company's fiscal 1990, earnings fell 28 percent to $319.2 million, or $1.28 a share, from $430.7 million, or $1.65 a share. Revenues totalled $6.04 billion vs $6.03 billion. Excluding the one-time gain a year earlier, earnings in the first half were down 2 percent. The company said its backlog of orders on March 31 was $15.6 billion, up 24 percent from the fiscal year-end backlog of $12.6 billion. The backlog includes $3.7 billion of commercial orders, $4.4 billion of funded government orders and $7.5 billion of unfunded government orders. Rockwell, based in the Los Angeles suburb of El Segundo, makes the space shuttle and the B-1 bomber. It also manufactures everything from printing presses to truck drivetrains to products for cellular telephone networks.

DOC.HEAD: Nintendo Sues Over Alleged Counterfeit Games; Threatens More Suits
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Sylvie and Kenn in 10th graf are correct
DOC.TEXT: Nintendo of America said Monday it has filed lawsuits in several U.S. and Canadian courts to stop the sale of counterfeit copies of its popular video games, and the company promised more suits. ``What's happening here is an outrageous theft of Nintendo's valuable intellectual property rights,'' said Howard Lincoln, company senior vice president. He said counterfeit cartridges were being manufactured in Taiwan. Nintendo said lawsuits for copyright infringement have been filed in federal courts in Los Angeles, Minneapolis and Tampa, Fla., and in Canadian federal court in Ottawa against defendants in Quebec, Ontario and British Columbia. The company said it would file additional suits within two weeks. It said it was acting because counterfeit activity has grown markedly the past month. A sting operation in Wilmington, N.C., led to the arrest Thursday of four people and the seizure of 700 counterfeit cartridges after the company joined forces with undercover U.S. Customs agents, who allegedly were offered the cartridges for $60,000, Nintendo said. The company said it was aiming its legal actions against counterfeiters, video rental outlets and other retailers, distributors and importers who rent or sell the cartridges. A typical counterfeit cartridge contains many games, is about half the size of Nintendo's cartridges and come with an adapter to use on Nintendo's system, the company said. Lincoln said Nintendo does not sell ``multiple game cartridges.'' The lawsuits ask that defendants be stopped from distributing, advertising, promoting and selling counterfeit cartridges. Nintendo also seeks monetary damages. The four people arrested in North Carolina included a Taiwanese couple, Sylvie and Paul Sun, said Nintendo. Also arrested were Kenn Ketchum and Brad Ison of Tampa, Fla. Each was charged with trafficking in counterfeit goods. Ketchum and Ison were named, along with Gary Brinson, in the suit filed in Tampa, said Lynne Gray, of the public relations firm of Hill and Knowlton Inc. in Los Angeles. Named in the suit filed in Los Angeles was Herschel Naghi, doing business as Space Video, said Gray. Defendants in the Minneapolis suit included Bigelow Distributing and various Bigelow Video stores in several locations, Robert Bigelow, Laurence Bigelow, Niles Bigelow, Sunshine Video, Century Video & Tanning, Rodney William Reif and Patricia Ann Reif, Valley Video, Chanhassen Video, Mr. Movies, The Video Library, United States Video, Video Update and Video Shuttle Network, as well as individuals. Nintendo said it has had to battle counterfeiters before. In the early 1980s, the company initiated more than 30 lawsuits across the country to stop production of counterfeit copies of the game Donkey Kong.

DOC.HEAD: Resorts Plans To Sell Paradise Island Holdings To Pay Off Debt
DOC.TEXT: Resorts International Inc. said Monday it lost $303 million in 1989 and planned to sell its lucrative properties in the Bahamas to help pay off its debts and emerge from bankruptcy. Resorts also filed an amended bankruptcy reorganization plan that called for bondholders to exchange their securities for new debt and 78 percent of the company's stock. The plan made minor changes to a proposal the company filed late last year. Spokesman Harris Diamond said the property sale would erase hundreds of millions of dollars of debt Resorts has been carrying since entertainer Merv Griffin purchased the company from Donald Trump in late 1988. ``If you look at the company debt structure ... it just made the most sense,'' Diamond said. ``Assuming everything goes OK, we're hoping to be out of bankruptcy by summer.'' The Chapter 11 reorganization plan, which will reduce Griffin's stake to 22 percent of Resorts stock, has to be approved by the U.S. Bankruptcy Court, owners of two-thirds of the bonds and the state Casino Control Commission. The government of the Commonwealth of the Bahamas also must approve any deals involving Resorts' holdings, which include a casino, four hotels, a golf course and undeveloped land on Paradise Island and Grand Bahama Island. Resorts said it posted a net loss of $302.8 million for 1989, compared with $381.4 million a year earlier. Last year's loss reflected a writeoff of $181.3 million in goodwill, or the amount by which Griffin's purchase price exceeded Resorts' assets, and interest payments of $121.5 million. Operating losses were $7.8 million in 1989, compared with profits of $28.4 million in 1988. Industry observers say the sale of Paradise Island, with estimated profits of $25 million to $30 million a year, makes sense for Resorts and will help it to refurbish its sagging Atlantic City casino. ``Paradise Island is a very successful place and it ought to be very marketable,'' said Dan Lee, a gaming analyst with First Boston Corp., who added that the resort is the leading casino in the Caribbean. ``Something had to be done. The bondholders were insisting on cash and there was a building that needed refurbishing,'' he said. ``If they can sell and recoup substantial values, then it would make sense to go forward,'' said Ron Grobeck, a research analyst with R.D. Smith, a New York brokerage that specializes in distressed securities. Grobeck said Resorts has 200 undeveloped acres in Paradise Island and 1,500 undeveloped acres on Grand Bahama. ``They are not generating any value,'' he said. ``To the extent that they could put it on the block, maybe it makes sense to cash in.'' The amended reorganization plan calls for holders of certain Resorts debt to receive an additional $20 million in new bonds. It also calls for Griffin to invest a total of $26 million into the company. Resorts' outstanding debts include about $600 million in bonds that were issued before Griffin's takeover and another $325 million of junk bonds Griffin issued to finance the acquisition. The reorganization blueprint keeps intact plans for a ``fraudulent conveyance'' lawsuit against Trump, for which a $5 million litigation fund is to be established. The suit would claim that something of value was transferred to Trump in the buyout without him giving a fair return to the company. One such asset is the Taj Mahal, which Trump bought for $273 million as part of his deal with Griffin after Resorts spent about $500 million on it.

DOC.HEAD: Industry Reports Weekly Production
DOC.TEXT: Domestic steel production totaled 2,019,000 net tons during the week ending April 14, up 1.1 percent from the previous week, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. The latest week's production represented 89.8 percent of the industry's capacity, the steel industry group said Monday. American steelmakers produced 2,050,000 net tons in the same week last year, AISI said. Domestic steel production so far this year is 28,559,000 net tons, 3.8 percent below last year's pace, AISI said. Production by district for last week, (previous week in parentheses): North East Coast 234,000 tons (220,000 tons); Pittsburgh-Youngstown 323,000 tons (322,000 tons); Lake Erie 159,000 tons (159,000 tons); Detroit 164,000 tons (162,000 tons); Indiana-Chicago 531,000 tons (517,000 tons); Southern 302,000 tons (302,000 tons); Western 113,000 tons (111,000 tons).

DOC.HEAD: ADM Releases Third-Quarter Earnings Report
DOC.TEXT: Archer-Daniels-Midland Co., a major agriculture processing company, reported flat earnings of for its fiscal third quarter. Earnings totalled $116.4 million compared with $116.2 million in the same period a year earlier, the company said Monday. Earnings per share were unchanged at 41 cents. Net earnings for the first three quarters of the fiscal year were $365.7 million, or $1.29 a share, compared with $307.9 million, or $1.10 a share. Spokesman R.E. Burket said the company would provide sales information at a later date.

DOC.HEAD: Mack Trucks Announces Extension From Creditors
DOC.TEXT: Mack Trucks Inc. said it has gotten a 15-day extension from its creditor banks to help prepare a restructuring of its more than $148 million in debt. Joe McDevitt, Mack assistant treasurer, said seven of the 10 banks require the company to maintain a certain ratio of assets to liabilites, which it has been unable to do. The banks previously had waived that requirement until April 15, he said, and they agreed to extend the waiver Monday until April 30. ``This will give us more time to prepare the paperwork for the deal that's closing ... and resolve the loan restructuring at certain subsidiaries,'' McDevitt said. Mack, which now has separate agreements with each of the 10 creditor banks, is restructuring its debt and forming a secured syndicated credit agreement with all the banks, McDevitt said. The company reported a $185.4 million net loss for 1989, reflecting a big drop in demand for commercial trucks generally last year.
